column2: An investigation is being made by the police as to the cause of the death of Otto Pieck of 177 East One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, who was found lying unconscious in the hallway of his house, Sunday night, Oct. 6. He died day before yesterday in the Manhattan Hospital. He recovered consciousness twenty-four hours after being found. He remembered opening the door, but after that everything was blank, he said.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 14. -- Chancellor McGill to-day granted a writ of error in the case of Anello Spina and Joseph Aragio, sentenced to be hanged at New-Brunswick next Friday for the murder of Antonio Pristo.

The Journal des Debats recounts with profound sorrow one of those cruel disappointments which France from time to time experiences in her efforts to found a colonial empire. At Hanoi, in the far East, our dear neighbors have established a botanical garden, the pride of which was a melon of European origin.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 14. -- As a result of the investigation by the Councils into the charges that City Attorney Moreland has received interest on city funds, Moreland to-day resigned, and Clarence Burleigh was chosen as his successor. The Finance Committee of the Councils was in session all day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The Supreme Court convened at noon to-day for the October Term, 1805. All the surviving Justices were present. The death of Justice Jackson caused a slight rearrangement of the sittings on the bench. Mr. Justice White taking the deceased Justice's place at the extreme right of the Chief Justice. This brought together Justices Gray, Brown, and White.
The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst was announced as the principal speaker at a meeting last evening at the Lexington Avenue Church, at One Hundred and Eleventh Street and Lexington Avenue.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 15. -- Waterbury to-day entertained more guests than ever before in its history, 5,000 or more in its triple celebration -- the dedication of a new one-hundred-thousand-dollar Odd Fellows building, the observance of the fiftieth anniversary of the order in the city, and the initial recognition of the new Connecticut holiday, Lincoln's Day, a creation of the last General Assembly.
LONDON, Oct. 15. -- The Chronicle to-morrow will print the following dispatch from Constantinople, under date of Oct. 14:

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Oct. 15. -- Franklin L. Pope, the electrician, whose accidental death was announced yesterday, probably died from an electric shock. Dr. Small, the medical examiner, is still in doubt about there being an autopsy.

In forming our judgments of the rightfulness of the Cuban rebellion, and in estimating its chances of success, it ought not to be forgotten that the troubles of the island are economical as well as political. Economically, Cuba suffers in common with all the other regions where cane sugar has been grown -- the smaller West India islands and Demerara.

Mr. George R. Read has resold for Mandelbaum Lewine, to John R. Downey, at an advance, the property at 24 Beekman Street, Mr. Downey giving in part payment the two five-story brick tenements 511 and 515 East Eighty-first Street, each 25 by 85 by 100, at the valuation of $40,000.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 15. -- Three hundred persons filled with the spirit of George Washington crossed the Delaware River from Pennsylvania to New-Jersey to-day, and fought the battle of Trenton over again. They crossed over at about the same place, but they went over on a bridge, and paid 2 cents each for the privilege.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 15. -- Charles J. Peshall, a well-known lawyer, was arrested late last night on a charge of forgery and locked up in the county jail. The complaint was made by Leon D. Montreville, agent for Leggett Meyers of St. Louis, Mo.

The case of Otto Odendahl of 658 East One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, who died about ten days ago from the effects of strychnine which he took unwittingly in a dose of epsom salts, is still under investigation at the Coroners' office.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Oct. 15. -- A number of farmers in this vicinity are bemoaning the loss of about $2,000 worth of hogs and calves. The swindle was neatly worked, and the man who profited got away easily.

-- The Mecca of a large number of people of social prominence to-day will be Summit, down in Jersey, where will take place at noon the marriage of Miss Pierson to Mr. H.W. Garrett. The bride-elect is a daughter of Col. Henry F. Pierson, and is related to Gen. J. Frederick Pierson, whose daughter, Miss Daisy Pierson, is one of the well-known belles in town.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The President arrived in Washington at 4 o'clock this afternoon. He was accompanied by Private Secretary Thurber and E.C. Benedict, who has been, for the past four days, his host aboard the steam yacht Oneida.

A dispatch from Chicago says that Edward T. Jeffery, President and General Manager of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad, has agreed to accept the Presidency of the reorganized Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe system. Mr. Jeffery is a wide-awake and progressive railroad man, and if he does take hold of Atchison, he will doubtless endeavor to administer that property on strictly business lines.

After all the trouble and turmoil over the Tammany Senatorial nomination in the Twentieth Senate District, Senator Jacob A. Cantor is to be the candidate. That was agreed on at Tammany Hall yesterday afternoon. John Norton, who was nominated by the convention of many ballots at the last moment to save the place on the regular ticket, has withdrawn, as THE NEW-YORK TIMES has predicted.

Dr. Greene's lectures are always inspiring. They proclaim a new gospel of hope to suffering humanity. And in this particular his lecture last night at Chickering Hall surpasses them all. It is a watchword of faith and promise, and is of incalculable value and benefit to thousands struggling in our land of fast living, tremendous activities and ruinous nervous tension.

The comment on the very significant speech of Mr. Secretary CARLISLE in Boston on Saturday last is favorable even from his political opponents. It is generally recognized as a clear and very strong statement of sound doctrine, and a renewal, with increased emphasis, of the pledges of the Administration to maintain all forms of Government currency at par in gold.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The Judge Advocate General of the Army has submitted to the Secretary of War his annual report for 1895. The statistics relating to trials by courts-martial, as compared with those of last year, indicate an improvement in the morals of the army.
The twelfth annual meeting of the New-York State Medical Association was opened yesterday morning at the Mott Memorial Hall, 64 Madison Avenue. Sessions will also be held to-day and to-morrow.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- The Grand Jury this noon presented an indictment against the Rev. John M. Fitzgerald, pastor of the Holy Cross Church, at Charlotte, charging him with arson in the second degree, in setting fire to an occupied building in Charlotte on the night of May 23, 1893, thereby endangering the lives of Theodore Barlow, George Barlow, and Mary Barlow.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- The residents of Larchmont Manor have determined to take active measures against further invasion by hotels and boarding houses on territory that they claim cannot be rightfully used for such purposes. The women of Larchmont Manor have just raised $1,500 with which to institute a test case, by which it may be determined once for all whether hotels and boarding houses have any right there.
The meeting of the members of the German-American Reform Union who were opposed to supporting Tammany Hall took place last night in Maennerchor Hall.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- At Catford yesterday, J.W. Stox, a bicyclist, attacked the fifty-mile record. He made a world's record for from ten to forty-four miles, inclusive, when he was compelled to retire, owing to saddle soreness. He covered ten miles in 20:10 1-5, and forty-four miles in 1:134:11 4-5. He also made a new record for an hour's riding, covering in that time twenty-nine miles and forty-five yards.

" A Special Report on the Teaching of Music in the Elementary Schools," by Dr. Edward Brooks, Superintendent of Public Schools in the City of Philadelphia, which was presented to the Board of Education in that city a few months ago, has been subjected to some severe criticism from several quarters.

Morris Schoenholz, the firebug, was convicted yesterday of arson in the first degree, second offense. Under this finding the man must be sentenced to imprisonment for life. The Court is given no discretion. So far as known it is the first case of the kind on record.

In an interview ex-Congressman Belmont yesterday described Secretary Carlisle's recent speech in Boston as the most cogent Mr. Carlisle had made in condemnation of the old and new greenbacks. He said the speech was especially gratifying to him because his own at Syracuse, as temporary Chairman of the Democratic State Convention, "ran on all fours" with it.

The "silent campaign" plan does not meet with acceptation in Saratoga County. "Saratoga should soon have a Republican rally," says The Saratogian, for "there is an enthusiasm that means results in a demonstration of party ardor." The anxiety for inspiring talk is keen. "Rally around the eagle," it says, "and explain to the voter that good Republican times are coming again, when the Nation is reclaimed in 1897."

The Society for Political Study is to devote itself to the laudable object of studying the State Constitution this Winter, and Mrs. Lillie Devereux Blake began the first talk on that topic yesterday afternoon at the regular place of meeting of the society, 144 Madison Avenue.
HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 15. -- A mild sort of scandal has been precipitated in the Church of the Holy Innocents by the resignation of the rector, the Rev. Edward N. Webber, to take effect Nov. 1.

The American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, which is the organization in charge of the foreign work of the Congregational Church, began its eighty-sixth annual meeting in the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday afternoon. This organization, which is usually known either as the "American Board," or as the "A.B.C.F.M.'" is the oldest foreign missionary society in this country, having begun its work in 1810.

A committee from the Manhattan Single Tax Club, composed of Alfred Bishop Mason, Chairman; Charles F. Adams, E. Lawson Purdy, Daniel Cavanagh, J. Whidden Graham, Alfred B. Cruikshank, and G.W. Everett, called on Mayor Strong yesterday afternoon and presented to him a voluminous petition calling his attention to alleged discrimination in real estate assessments in this city.

BOSTON, Oct. 15. -- The battleship Indiana came to anchor at 7:30 o'clock this evening off Boston Light, after a remarkably successful run from the Delaware capes. The Indiana left Cramps' shipyard on Saturday morning at 7 o'clock, and after waiting for two tides, arrived at the Delaware Breakwater on Sunday morning.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 15. -- The opening of the big Saugus meeting was spoiled to-day by the rain after one race had been completed and four heats paced in another. The air was raw and the track heavy. In the 2:15 trot Yankee Luck and Fred B. sold at $50 each, and the field at $30. Seylex was overlooked, but the California bred gelding won two heats handily.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. -- Motherly looking women with gray hair and earnest faces were largely in evidence at the second day's session of the National Purity Congress. Among those who have devoted years to aiding and comforting their more unfortunate sisters who have given way to human weaknesses and have become social outcasts were scattered a number of laymen and clergymen who, too, have identified themselves with the work.
LONDON, Oct. 15. -- Truth to-morrow will say: "Lord Sackville's pamphlet has raised an altogether unnecessary storm in the United States. Its secret history may be told in a few words.
When George Ringler, the brewer, died, he left a will tying up his estate so that his two children could not get the bulk of it until they reached the age of thirty-five years.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- The Daily News tomorrow will print a dispatch from Constantinople saying that the agitation there is being renewed, owing to the neglect of Turkish officials to fulfill their promise of security given to the Armenian refugees when they left their churches. Another attack was made on Kassim Pasha and other Armenians Oct. 12, when four were killed and a number wounded. It is alleged that the police refused to interfere.
It is not to be wondered at that the two recent challenges for the America's Cup do not find unmitigated favor in British eyes.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 15. -- A river larger than any other stream in the Province of Quebec, an unlimited area of timber lands, and unknown country suitable for agricultural purposes is what Dr. Robert Bell, Assistant Director of the Geological Survey, who has just returned from a trip to James Bay, reports having discovered.
HONGKONG, Oct. 15. -- Advices from Ku-Cheng state that the deadlock which has existed in connection with the Commission of Inquiry into the outrages upon the foreign missions is ended.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. -- The Republicans opened their campaign in this city to-night with a mass meeting at Music Hall. The principal speeches were made by ex-Congressman John V.L. Findlay, who represented the Fourth Maryland District as a Democrat, and Theodore Roosevelt, the New-York Police Commissioner.

A comparatively brief conference was held at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday afternoon between Messrs. J. Harsen Rhoades and Charles Stewart Smith, representing the Committee of Fifty, and Edward Lauterbach, Chairman of the Republican County Committee, respecting the nomination to be made on the fusion ticket for City Court Judge, to fill the vacancy caused by the withdrawal of James W. Hawes. No decision was reached, and the conference was adjourned until to-day.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Oct. 15. -- The steamship Stillwater to-day brought additional particulars of the loss of the steamer Freddie M. The steamer Freddie M. left Corozal Thursday morning last at 2 o'clock on her trip to Belize. She had twenty-one cabin passengers and twenty-six on deck, and the crew numbered eleven.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day devoted the first hour of its session to hearing motions by attorneys, chiefly to advance cases on the docket for an early hearing. Solicitor General Conrad, on behalf of the United States, made this motion in nine cases, the most important being that of the United States ex rel.

The United States Military Wheelmen were formally organized yesterday at the Broadway Central Hotel. All day and all the evening the believers in the great value of bicycles in military use listened to papers and arguments supporting their views.

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- Although a cold and penetrating rain was falling all the afternoon on the harbor hills, it did not prevent the cross-country run of the Meadowbrook Hunt Club along the shore of Long Island Sound. The turf was exceedingly slippery, and made the jumps over hedges and fences very dangerous.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 15. -- The American Bankers' Association, holding its twenty-first annual session, met this morning. President John P. Odell formally opened the convention. Prayer was offered by the Rev. E.H. Barnett of the First Presbyterian Church of this city. Mayor King, welcoming the association, spoke of Atlanta's warm appreciation of the honor conferred upon her by the selection of this city as the place for the convention.

Gen. John McNulta, receiver of the Distilling and Cattle Feeding Company, says to a representative of this bureau: "All of the seventeen distillery properties sold by me at judicial sale on Aug. 14 are ready to be turned over to the new company, with the exception of the Schufeldt distillery in Chicago, which is in operation now, mashing 2,700 bushels a day.

In the new play by Clyde Fitch, called "Mistress Betty; or, the Career of Betty Singleton," produced by Mme. Modjeska at the Garrick Theatre last night, the scene of the first act is the greenroom of one of the Theatres Royal in London one night in the middle of the eighteenth century. A performance is supposed to be in progress on the stage.
ALBANY, Oct. 15. -- In a brief letter accepting the Democratic nomination for Mayor, John Boyd Thacher says:

Jack Ballister's Fortunes" is rattling Eood book for boys, and from a historical standpoint has much in it to interest older persons also. It is as full of adventure as the most exacting reader of romance could, wish, and withal is healthy and clean, although it is founded on kidnapping and piracy.

Application was made to Surrogate Abbott, in Brooklyn, yesterday, for the removal of Charles S. Williams and Robert Osborn as executors of the estate of Mary C. Osborn. The application was made by John Osborn.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 15. -- With the blowing of whistles, the clanging of bells, and the booming of a hundred guns, the centennial celebration of Fort Wayne was ushered in at 6 o'clock this morning. Never in its history has the city donned so gay a gown. The principal streets, with their merry crowds, are overhung with huge arches, which look like mighty gates of marble in the bright sun.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- Lawrence J. McParlin to-day sent his formal declination of the nomination for Attorney General on the People's Party ticket to the Secretary of State, McParlin is the People's Party nominee for County Surrogate in Niagara County, and claims that he has a good chance of election, which would be impaired, he says, by running on the State ticket.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15. -- Senator Thurston, National Committeeman from Nebraska, who is in this city, said to-day, regarding the Republican Presidential candidate and the next convention city: "My State is rather inclined toward McKinley, but I hear Allison and Reed frequently referred to as available and safe men for the place.

ALBANY, Oct. 15. -- County Clerk Walsh has received a letter from George S. Root of Lincoln, Neb. asking for information relative to a published statement that the heirs of Anneke Jans were to receive $120,000,000 by a decision in the Trinity Church controversy. Mr. Root inclosed a clipping from a newspaper, which stated that Mrs. George Puntemney of Superior, Neb., is one of the heirs.

Dr. Philip F. O'Hanlon, the Coroner's Physician and Tammany Hall politician, was under arrest yesterday before Judge Giegerich for contempt of court. The order for his arrest was obtained by H. O'Neil Co., the dry goods merchants.

Woodward Emery, Chairman of the State Board of Docks and Terminal Facilities, and also Chairman of the Board of Harbor and Land Commissioners of Massachusetts, and Hon. J.R. Leeson, have returned from their trip of inspection abroad in the interests of the Dock Board. Before going abroad Mr. Leeson and Mr. Emery made a careful inspection of the dock system in New-York and of the results of public ownership here.

Three massive flagstones in front of Charles Contoit's brownstone house, 728 Fifth Avenue, were blown into the air by an explosion of gas at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. The lower part of the dwelling was wrecked.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 16. -- Princeton's football team was scored against to-day by the eleven of the Princeton Theological Seminary. This game was arranged as a makeshift after the Franklin and Marshall management had canceled their game here, and Capt. Lea thought his team would have such an easy time with the Theologians that he could play several substitutes.

CAMBRIDGE, Oct. 16. -- At 12 o'clock last night, after earlier in the evening refusing to say anything about the official statement of Yale's position on the Harvard-Yale controversy, Prof. Ames, Chairman of the Harvard Athletic Committee, submitted the following facts:
The first part of an English consignment of many valuable books was disposed of yesterday at auction by Bangs Co. Some of the books and prices were:

Senator Hill put in a hard day's work at the Democratic State Headquarters, 27 Madison Avenue, yesterday. He devoted much of his time to the task of bringing about harmony in the legislative districts of this city and Kings County. He was obliged to leave for Washington last night. Before going he was asked for his views on the political situation, and he said:

The Board of Education decided yesterday to authorize School Trustees in the various wards where there is a lack of school accommodation for children to lease premises for classrooms as soon as possible. There are over 6,000 children in the city who are without school accommodations.

The Elephant Clubhouse alleys of Brooklyn were well lined last night with an enthusiastic gathering of bowlers. The Orchards of this city were pitted against two Brooklyn clubs. It was the first appearance of the New-York team in the Carruthers National tourney, and speculation was freely indulged in regarding their ability. They did not bowl any too well, barely winning one game. The Waverlys made a clean sweep.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15. -- The correspondence passing between Yale and Harvard regarding the football game was given out by the Yale management to-day. The statement purporting to come from the Harvard Athletic Committee, the main points of which were published in Monday's NEW-YORK TIMES, led to the action, and a long communication was sent to The Yale News.

The quarrels that divide the Democratic' Party in the Senate and Assembly districts in this city are ignoble. They spring mainly from selfishness and spite. One faction wants everything. The other can get nothing, so it becomes an ally of the Republican enemy. The Brooklyn state of affairs is not much different.

I trust you will allow me to differ somewhat from the views of The London Times quoted in your editorial of this morning as to the condition of Cuba and the causes of the present revolution. In my opinion, too much importance is given in that review of the situation to the influence of the fall in the price of sugar. It is one of the causes, and only one.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- There are few visitors to the National capital who do not make the ascent of the Waishington Monument. The view from the top is superb, covering as it does the entire District of Columbia and portions of Maryland and Virginia. The Duke of Marlborough, who was here last week went to the monument within an hour after he reached the city.

Lewis L. Delafield, nominee on the Good Government ticket for Justice of the City Court, has written a letter to Charles Stewart Davison, Chairman of the Convention of Good Government Clubs, in which he says that he will not run, believing that the Good Government ticket will jeopardize the success of the campaign against Tammany.
ST. JOHN, N.B., Oct. 16. -- Premier Blair's Government was handsomely sustained today in the elections for Legislative Assembly throughout the different counties.

ALBANY, Oct. 16. -- The Brooklyn Board of Education has notified Superintendent Charles R. Skinner of the State Department of Public Instruction, that there is nothing in the school census law passed by the last Legislature which requires the Brooklyn board to take the school census in Brooklyn.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 16. -- "The Traffic in Girls," a paper read before the Purity Congress yesterday by Mrs. Charlton Edholm, produced startling results. First, the pictures of depravity and wretchedness described as belonging to certain quarters of every city caused a sensation. Subsequently a party of ladies, delegates to the congress, agreed to make a slumming trip, with a view of seeing for themselves if such scenes as pictured were to be observed in Baltimore.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Arrangements were to-day perfected for the trip of President Cleveland to the Atlanta Exposition. A special train, under the management of Second Vice President Baldwin of the Southern Railway Company will convey the President, his Cabinet and their wives.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Oct. 16. -- The Lindens, the country establishment of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Grace of 52 East Seventy-ninth Street, New-York, was the scene to-day, at noon, of the marriage of Miss Olive Alice Grace, a niece of ex-Mayor William R. Grace, to Mr. Henry Scanlon Kerr.

That the racing rules greatly need revision by the next National Assembly of the League of American Wheelmen has been frequently demonstrated during the passing season, and by no events more than by the fact that even so wise a judge as Chairman Gideon of the Racing Board has been unable to interpret them and escape entanglements.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 16. -- Amherst beat Wesleyan to-day on Pratt Field by a score of 12 to 10. This was the first game of any importance played on the home grounds, and it was well attended by the students. Amherst was weakened by the loss of Capt. Pratt, who was injured in Tuesday's practice. Tyler, '97, acted as Captain. Wesleyan had the kick-off, and Wilson kicked to Amherst's twenty-yard line.

A committee from the Manhattan Single Tax Club, composed of Alfred Bishop Mason, Chairman; Charles F. Adams, E. Lawson Purdy, Daniel Cavanagh, J. Whiden Graham, Alfred B. Cruikshank, and G.W. Everett, called on Mayor Strong yesterday afternoon and presented to him a voluminous petition calling his attention to alleged discrimination in real estate assessments in this city.
At a mass meeting of independent citizens of the Eighth Assembly District at Walhalla Hall, 48 Orchard Street, last night, Mayor Strong made his first speech during the present campaign. He said:

Machine Republicans, who have been trying to force the excise plank in their party platform to the background in this campaign, were anything but pleased when they read Warner Miller's speech yesterday.

A policeman of the West Twentieth Street Police Station found a little girl, apparently about two years old, crying on Eighth Avenue, near Twenty-second Street, Tusday night. The child was unable to talk, and was taken to Police Headquarters.
When George Ringler, the brewer, died, he left a will tying up his estate so that his two children could not get the bulk of it until they reached the age of thirty-five years.
David G. Thompson, who had lived at the Westminster Hotel, Sixteenth Street and Irving Place, for two years, was found dead in his rooms at 11 o'clock yesterday morning.

BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- The Sheriff's Court at Erfurt has fined Herr Lorenz, the State Attorney of the Erfurt Divisional Court, 59 marks for insulting Herr Hulle, the editor of a Socialist paper, and has also granted the latter permission to publish the sentence.

YOKOHAMA, Oct. 16. -- A dispatch from Seoul, the capital of Corea, states that the body of the Queen, who was reported to have been killed during the recent attack on the palace by the King's father and his followers, has been found.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 16. -- The second day's session of the Synod of New-Jersey was attended by almost every delegate from the different Presbyteries.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 16. -- The hundreds of commuters living along the line of the New-York and Long Branch Railroad, including cottagers at Long Branch, Elberon, Ocean Grove, Belmar, Spring Lake, and Point Pleasant, are to hold a mass meeting at this place Saturday afternoon and protest against the train service on the Central Railroad of New-Jersey, which runs over the New-York and Long Branch road.

The Fall meeting of the Parkway Driving Club began yesterday under favorable auspices. The first race was run off in one-two-three order, with Ring Gold always in the front. The only interesting incident connected with this race was the fining of M.P. Devy for not properly withdrawing his entry, Portrait. It was afterward shown to the judges that Devy was not wholly to blame in the matter, and the fine was remitted.

The Criterion Theatre, Fulton and Grand Avenues, Brooklyn, was crowded to the doors last evening with an enthusiastic audience of men and women who gathered there to hear the doctrines of the Democratic Party Reform Organization expounded by Edward M. Shepard, the party's candidate for Mayor; Charles J. Patterson, candidate for District Attorney, and Charles S. Fairchild, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the State Democracy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- A cable dispatch from London, received to-night, says that the British Foreign Office has been made acquainted with the contents of a dispatch forwarded by Secretary Olney to Ambassador Bayard, bearing on the Venezuelan boundary dispute. The tone of this dispatch, it added, is such that the Ministry will be forced to give much time to its consideration.

The investigation of the Dock Department under the management of Commissioners Phelan, Cram, and White was resumed yesterday afternoon in the Stewart Building before Commissioners of Accounts Terry and Dennis. Mr. Terry conducted the examination of witnesses and Delos McCurdy cross-examined them.

Of course there can be no question that the Sultan, in accepting the programme of Armenian reform laid down for him by the powers, has yielded merely to superior force, and has yielded with extreme reluctance. All the abuses that have excited the indignation of Christendom are necessary incidents of his Government.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- General officers of the Freight and Passenger Departments of the Western lines held sessions to-day to work on the adoption of agreements which will stop the demoralization of rates which has been for so long going on. The sessions are being held in accordance with orders received from the executive officers, who recently held a secret meeting and recommended radical action.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Miss Banks of the Englewood Field Club again won the lawn tennis championship of Vassar College here last week. Her most formidable antagonists were Miss Thallon of Brooklyn, Miss Sanders of NewYork, and Miss Platt, another Englewood girl. The full scores follow:
Edmund Clark, a chemist of the Health Department, was severely censured yesterday by Chief Justice Van Brunt, in the General Term of the Supreme Court.

The vital statistics of the first nine months of the present year in this city, when compared with those of the corresponding period in each of the four years immediately preceding, afford interesting testimony as to the efficacy of diphtheria antitoxine. The new remedy was first introduced (on this side of the Atlantic) in New-York, and this was the first American city to have an establishment for the production of the curative serum.

The Board of Police Commissioners at a special meeting yesterday agreed that the State Democracy was entitled to have its emblem, a rooster, and its complete State and local ticket printed in a separate column on the official ballot.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 16. -- The attendance at the exposition is growing steadily. Chief Felder of the Admissions Department states that the increase this week so far over last for the corresponding dates, is 28 per cent. Everything points to an enormous attendance on Cleveland Day, next Wednesday. Excursions are coming from points 400 miles away. The National Road Parliament meets to-morrow.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 16. -- The Saugus track was wet and heavy to-day. The air was raw and the conditions were adverse to fast time. Two thousand persons, despite these disadvantages, witnessed a great afternoon's sport. Robert R. had no trouble in winning the deciding heat in the 2:22 pace, after the judges gave Gatcomb a good dressing down.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad was held this afternoon in the office building of the company, in this city. Comparatively few stockholders were present when President C.P. Clark called the meeting to order at noon.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The annual report of Brig. Gen. R.N. Bachelder, Quartermaster General of the United States Army, has just been made to the Secretary of War. Among a great variety of statistical information are the following points:

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The Times will to-morrow publish a Constantinople dispatch, dated Oct. 15, saying it is believed that the decline in prices on the Bourse and the general depression is due to the spreading conviction that Mohammedan discontent will shortly reveal itself in action which will be the opening of a long and dramatic chapter.
The sale is reported, for an estate, of a piece of property on Broadway near Spring Street at $300,000.

Two missionaries, fresh from the field, served to make yesterday afternoon's session of the American Board very interesting. They were the Rev. F.W. Bates, who, for the last two years, has been in Gaza Land, in East Central Africa, and Dr. John C. Berry of Japan. The physician looks far more like a clergyman than does the Rev. Mr. Bates, who is short and stout, and might well be taken for a medical man.

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 16 -- The First Presbyterian Church was crowded to-day with representatives of the most prominent families of New-York, Baltimore, Washington, Philadelphia, Boston, Chicago, and of cities from round about the Oranges for the marriage of Miss Charlotte Doremus Pierson of this place to Mr. Horatio Whitridge Garrett of Baltimore.

John M. Finkbone, an alleged lawyer, was sentenced to ten years in State prison yesterday by Judge Allison in the Court of General Sessions for swindling small tradesmen and washerwomen by means of worthless checks.

The new home of the Crescent Athletic Club, 25 and 27 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, was informally opened last night with a reception to newspaper men. To-day, for the first time, members will be allowed within the doors. Many of them applied for admission last, but, beyond the members of the Building Committee, all were turned away.

Monroe Republicans, like Herkimer Republicans, are as zealous as WARNER MILLER in their advocacy of the "maintenance" of the Sunday laws, but, like a number of Herkimer Republicans to whom THE NEW-YORK TIMES has invited attention, they are apparently opposed to the enforcement of the law.

The Police Board has decided to give the State Democracy a separate column on the official ballot, containing the Democratic candidates for State offices and headed by the emblem of the rooster. In this the board follows the general principle of the decision of last year, which gave that organization a separate ballot, containing the names of the regular candidates for State offices.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- The attitude taken by the residents of Larchmont Manor against boarding houses and hotels, as told in THE NEW-YORK TIMES to-day, has stirred up much indignation among boarding-house keepers all through this part of Westchester County. They say the residents of Larchmont Manor are trying to surround themselves with a sort of golden wall, and have altogether erroneous ideas about individual rights in Larchmont Manor or elsewhere.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Sir Philip Currie, the British Ambassador to Turkey, telegraphed to Lord Salisbury this morning that the scheme relative to reforming the administration in Armenia, which was submitted to the Porte, May 11 last, by Great Britain, France, and Russia, had been accepted by the Turkish Foreign Office, and that it only awaited the Sultan's signature preparatory to being put into effect.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 16. -- Miss Helene Hawes, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John B. Hawes of Eagle Rock Road, and Mr. Hiland Porter were married at 5 o'clock this afternoon in St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church h the .rev. Vlllim Montague Geer, rector of St. Bur.hlornew's Church, New-York.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 16. -- The American Bankers' Association discussed proposed amendments to its constitution to-day and listened to a single gold-standard speech by Judge George N. Aldridge of Texas. Judge Aldridge is the humorist financier of the Lone Star State. He entertained the bankers for two hours with an address on "Sound Money" and a denunciation of "silverites."

There was a rehearsal before Magistrate Brann, in the Yorkville Court, yesterday morning, in an Irish farce comedy, known as "Maloney's Raffle." The principal characters were Miss Maggie Weston, James Fulton, the former manager of the company, and James C. Connors, Miss Weston's husband, who played the part of a soap agent in the cast. The other members of the company were not present, although they are deeply interested in the somewhat tangled case.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- The National Liquor Dealers, in convention in this city, this morning adopted resolutions declaring that they are engaged in a legitimate trade, from which a larger revenue is exacted than from any other business in the United States, and such being the fact, they insist that all citizens are entitled to enjoy the largest measure of personal freedom consistent with good government.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 16. -- The fourteenth annual convention of the Women's Home Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church began here to-day, with Mrs. Clinton B. Fisk of New-York, the Chairman of the society, presiding. Mrs. R.S. Rust of Cincinnati is Corresponding Secretary; Mrs. F.A. Aiken of Cincinnati Secretary, and Mrs. J.W. Mendenhal of Delaware Treasurer.

-- Astonishing results have recently been accomplished by Louis C. Tiffany in experiments with glass. The results of his investigations may now be seen at the rooms of the Tiffany Glass and Decorating Company, on Fourth Avenue near Twenty-sixth Street, where there are on view numerous vases, jugs, and different attractive and artistic forms of glassware, curious and entirely novel both in color and texture.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 16. -- When the House of Deputies of the Episcopal Convention reassembled this morning, the joint committee appointed to consider the regularity and validity of the order of the Church in Sweden, presented a report setting forth reasons why no minister of the Swedish Church should be allowed to officiate in any church under American jurisdiction. Objection was made to the immediate consideration of the matter, and it went on the calendar.

It is upon the whole to be regretted that there is to be no game at football this year between Yale and Harvard. Not only is a football match an exciting thing to be concerned in or to witness, but, under proper rules and with fairly good temper, the chances of accident are not unduly great.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 16. -- The most important work of the Farmers' National Congress to-day was the adoption of resolutions in favor of protection to American shipping in the foreign trade, and to cotton, corn, wheat, and other agricultural staples, a portion of which are exported.

Mr. WARNER MILLER plainly thinks that the National issues between the two great parties are very important in the State election this year. If he did not think so he would not devote to them the greater part of his chief speech in the campaign. But from the way in which he presents these issues it would seem that their importance inspires him with timidity rather than courage.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark, Oct. 16. -- A conference regarding the proposed fight took place at the Arlington Hotel this afternoon. Gov. Clarke, Judge Duffie, Sheriff Houpt, States Attorney Teague, the Citizens' Committee, and their legal representatives participating.

The representatives of the Committee of Fifty, the State Democracy, and the Republicans had further conferences yesterday over the candidate for City Court Judge on the fusion ticket, and agreed on a candidate.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 16. -- The Armenian committee has ordered reopened all the shops of Armenians that have been closed since the outbreak of the trouble here.

It was an open club day at the Morristown Golf Club yesterday, and more golf clubs were represented as competitors than has hitherto been the case at Morristown. A special team match had been arranged, and, besides the home team, the Shinnecock Hills, Tuxedo, and Lakewood Golf Clubs sent strong teams of four men each to fight for the handsome silver cup presented by the Morristown Club.

The Berkeley School football team of this city played a match game at Berkeley Oval, Fordham Heights, yesterday afternoon with a team from Betts Academy of Stamford, Conn. During the game Frederick Mynders, eighteen years old, Captain of the Betts team, was caught in a scrimmage and seriously injured internally.

Major McNULTY, candidate for the Senate in the Sixth District, which consists of a part of the City of Brooklyn, puts rather a strict construction upon the oath which members of the Legislature must take before entering upon the duties of their office, but he is quite right in resenting a demand for a distinct pledge as to how he will vote upon a specific proposition if elected to that body.

Dr. Ernest J. Lederle, assistant chemist of the Health Department, made a further report to Coroner Dobbs yesterday of the analysis which he is making in the Otto Odendahl poisoning case. He found that there were ten grains of strychnine crystallized to the ounce of epsom salts which young Odendahl took just before his death.

The controversy between the Good Government Clubs and the Committee of Fifty presents a dilemma which cannot be resolved by the accepted rules of political ethics. The clubs have done the best they could to nominate good men for office, and they have thus followed the path of strict morality; yet it is admitted that they will poll an insignificant vote.

BOSTON., Oct. 16. -- The battleship Indiana was given a preliminary run over the official trial course to-day, and so successul was the trial that when the boat reached the upper end of the course Edwin S. Cramp decided that it was unnecessary to speed her back again.

ALBANY, Oct. 16. -- Gov. Morton to-day appointed the members of the commission provided for by Chapter 500 of the Laws of 1895, to test, examine, and recommend a magazine breach-loading rifle for the use of the National Guard. The gentlemen selected are Col. Albert B. Shaw of Watertown, Prof. Robert Henry Thurston of Ithaca, and Eliphalet W. Bliss of Brooklyn.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. -- Motherly looking women with gray hair and earnest faces were largely in evidence at the second day's session of the National Purity Congress. Among those who have devoted years to aiding and comforting their more unfortunate sisters who have given way to human weaknesses and have become social out-casts were scattered a number of laymen and clergymen who, too, have identified themselves with the work.
Maurice Daly and Frank Ives announce a series of billiard tournaments, for which they offer prizes aggregating $8,000. The following was drawn up and signed yesterday afternoon:

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- The threatened division of the Presbyterian Synod over the licensing of Frank B. Seeley by the Otsego Presbytery occurred this afternoon, and though the vote that was taken did not seriously affect the body of the Synod, it showed clearly the attitude of the majority of its members to the General Assembly.

The powers that interfered in behalf of the Armenian Christians had really, as representatives of humanity and civilization, no choice but to interfere. They would have partaken the shame that belongs to Turkey, which can bear any amount of shame quite comfortably, if they had stood by and seen continued the atrocities of which they had ample proof.

" The criminal, his social and legal status, and the philosophy of reformation," were the subjects of a paper read before the New-York State Medical Association yesterday afternoon by Dr. William A. White of Broome County, at the Mott Memorial Hall. The paper was at once an amplification, corollary, and complement of ex-President Austin Flint's discourse of Friday night, while the questions were more broadly, not to say daringly, treated.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Coach Marshall Newell is giving the Cornell football punters a shake-up this week. The work of the team has shown that something is radically wrong. The first awakening came in the game with Pennsylvania State College, when Cornell failed to score. Last Saturday the score against Western Reserve was only 12, and the Westerners made one touchdown.

Messrs. Jarvis Slade and others have sold, at $100,000, the six-story business building 98 and 100 Franklin Street, north side, 61 feet west of Church Street, 37.5 by 78. The property is rented for $7,500 yer year.

The beginning of the opera season, the Marlborough-Vanderbilt wedding, and the Paget-Whitney wedding are, of course, the most important events in the near future. The coming-outees, however, should not be lost sight of, for they are more or less of importance in the doings of people of fashion.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 17. -- The Briggs case and the placing of Union Theological Seminary under the ban of the General Assembly bobbed up unexpectedly this morning at the session of the New-Jersey Synod here, and for a time it blocked all other business, and the ground was debated pretty fully.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 17. -- An imperial trade has been issued approving the scheme for the reform of the Turkish administration in Armenia, drawn by the British, French, and Russian Embassies in conjunction with the Porte.

Gen. CAMPOS seems to have spoken with much frankness to the correspondent of The London Times in an interview at Cienfuegos, on the 5th inst. Though he professed to regard the situation as hopeful, he failed to indicate a single point where it had improved. On the contrary, he bemoaned the difficulties of transportation, and naively remarked that it would be "necessary to extend the railway system."
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- Following is the weekly bulletin of the League of American Wheelmen, issued by Chairman Gideon:

The special cable dispatches of THE TIMES from Buenos Ayres yesterday brought reports that Brazil, Chile, and Argentina are ready to join with the United States in recognizing the belligerent rights of the Cuban rebels. We have reason to believe that Spanish-American Republics nearer to the United States would take part in a common movement of the New World Nations to accord the benefits of recognition to the Cubans.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 17. -- The Constitutional Convention devoted the entire day's session to the discussion of the section providing for a homestead law. The convention struck out all the special provisions in the section as reported, leaving the section providing for a simple homestead exemption of $1,000 worth of real estate and $500 worth of personalty.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 17. -- Robert Goelet will erect new villa here in place of his Summer residence now standing on the Cliffs. The present villa is a modern structure, but it is of wood, and recently has been surpassed in elegance by the houses of the Vanderbilts and Ogden Goelet. The house that is to be erected will cost several million dollars.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- In accordance with instructions from Pope Leo, submitted through Mgr. Satolli, a decree will shortly be issued by the Archbishops of the country, informing Catholics that they are not to take part in religious congresses. The letter to the laity is couched in the most inoffensive language, but the instructions to the priests, who will direct the congregations, will be more explicit.

Col. Henry T. Chapman, Chairman of the Exhibition Committee of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, has decided that the nude in art is all right when the model for the picture has been a female one, and all wrong when the model has been a male one.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 17. -- The regulation Denver day, clear and pleasant, greeted the circuit chaser for the five days' meeting of the Denver Wheel Club, in the National circuit, and owing to this being the annual feast day of the city the attendance was large. Ex-Chairman of Racing Board Raymond was the referee, and A.C. Willison, the President of the League, was a judge.

The Dock Board held its regular meeting yesterday, and before it appeared Augustine Forget, agent of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique at this port. He was accompanied by Lawyer E.K. Jones, who was there in behalf of the French steamship company.

" A Democratic Voter" has recently asked in the public press why friends of reform, who found it possible to join in the movement led by the Committee of Seventy, find it impossible to support the fusion candidates this Fall. How are the conditions changed? he asks. It would hardly be extravagant to quote, as the condition actually existing, his own statement of a condition of affairs which would justify such action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Mr. Morton, the Secretary of Agriculture, has completed his annual report for the last fiscal year, and it will be soon laid before the President. It contains some very interesting figures concerning the exportation of meat products, and some strong recommendations regarding the inspection of meats intended for home and foreign consumption.

There was but one stake event on the card for decision at the races of the Westchester Association run yesterday afternoon. In the past, Withers's Day has been one of the great days of the racing season. But this year the stake closed so late that the engagements for it were not numerous, nor were they of the highest class.
The monthly meeting of the Empire State Society of the Sons of the American Revolution was held at the Hotel Normandie last evening.

Once in a while a steamship Captain takes it into his head to ignore for the time being the customs regulations at this port. There may be in it that sort of satisfaction which comes from talking back to a policeman when one is temporarily in a safe position. But the triumph is always a brief one.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 17. -- James Coulson, who lives on Stanley Place, thought he had caught the burglar who has been ransacking the town. The man he caught proved he was not the burglar, but Mr. Coulson has been laughing ever since.

Our English friends are very much interested, even agitated, just now by what they call a "race question." It is, perhaps, needless to say that the question does not concern any of the numerous races with which they have themselves to deal, or the remnants of those, not rare, races that they find themselves forced, as Mr. KIDD has it, by their resistless altruism gradually to exterminate.

Debates in the Synods and Assemblies of the Presbyterian Church are apt to indicate that Presbyterianism, either of the orthodox or of the liberal variety, is by no means incompatible with a lively sense of humor. But to divines endowed with that sense such a spectacle as has just been presented in the New-Jersey Synod must be objectionable as tending to bring the body that presents it into public ridicule.
The cart-tail campaign of the Good Government Clubs begins to-night in real earnest. It is going to be a serious and a vigorous crusade.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The Daily News will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Constantinople giving a description by an eyewitness of the rioting at Trebizond. He says that four separate Moslem mobs surrounded the Armenian quarters at 11 o'clock on the morning of Oct. 8, and began to pillage the shops.

The number of candidates for Assemblymen and Senators is greater this year than ever. The new Constitution increased the number of Assembly districts from 128 to 150 and the number of Senate districts from 32 to 50. But, aside from the larger number of candidates due to this reapportionment, there are more independent candidates than a year ago.

Advice of a Chicago physician to a gentleman who came from Peoria with his daughter for treatment in a Chicago hospital for a severe rheumatism: "Take your daughter home, give her all the Londonderry Lithia Water she will drink and no medicine, and in a little time she will be entirely well.

JERSEY CITY, N.J. Oct. 17. -- The wheelmen of Hudson County had a lantern parade this evening under the direction of the Hamilton Park Wheelmen, and there were delegations in line from the Hillside, Clio, Catholic Club, Castle Point, Hudson County, Lafayette, Young Men's Christian Association of Brooklyn, and Jamaica Wheelmen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Now that the attitude of this country with relation to the boundary dispute between Great Britain and Venezuela has been made known to the British Foreign Office, popular interest in the outcome of the controversy is increasing. The cable dispatch from London referred to in these dispatches last night bore out the assertion previously made that Secretary Olney's last dispatch on the subject was calculated to develop the British position.

CHATHAM, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Taking into consideration the lateness in the season and the short time in which to make their arrangements, the committee in charge of the Chatham Wheelmen's third annual twenty-five-mile road race have had remarkable success. Fifty entries are now in the hands of F.P. Prial for handicapping.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- The Chicago and Alton Railroad Company has decided to ignore the ruling of the Illinois Railroad and Warehouse Commission, which decided that this company had no legal right to charge live stock shippers $2 per car for switching cars to and from the Union Stock Yards. The Alton claims that it has its stock yards in Chicago, which shippers may use if they desire.

Miss Helen Varick Boswell was the principal speaker at a meeting held at Exchange Hall, in East Eighty-sixth Street last night under the auspices of the Republican Campaign Committee of the Thirtieth Assembly District for the purpose of ratifying the State and County tickets.
All the property of the Fifth Avenue Transportation Company, Limited, held by Receiver Daniel T. Hoag, was sold at auction by Smith Ryan at the Broadway Real Estate Salesroom, yesterday, for $10,450.
Both Sides to Submit Propositions Today -- State Democracy Will Ask for No Less than One-third of the Senators.

The Campaign Committees of the German-American Reform Union and of the United Societies for Liberal Sunday Laws held a joint meeting on Wednesday night at the Exhibition Palace, Forty-fourth Street and Lexington Avenue.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17. -- A meeting of the Yale University crew was held last evening to decide upon Yale's course in regard to rowing Harvard or an English eight next Summer. It is pretty well known that if Prof. Ames of Harvard has anything to say in the matter it will be impossible for Yale and Harvard to meet in any branch of athletics.

Police Commissioner ANDREWS put in a strong plea before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday for an allowance of a quarter of a million dollars to establish a police signal system in this city. New-York is behind other cities in this matter, as it is in respect to many other appliances for prompt and efficient municipal service, on account of the neglect of past years.

EASTHAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 17. -- A caboose attached to a construction train on the Long Island Railroad was wrecked near Rocky Point, east of this place, early this morning and a number of workmen injured. The construction train was backing at full speed. The workmen were being conveyed from Amagansett to Fort Pond Bay, the terminus of the new extension of the road.
Hugh McShane told a most romantic story yesterday before Judge Beckman, in the Supreme Court, Special Term.

The Rev. Dr. Richard S. Storrs of the Church of the Pilgrims, Brooklyn, was unanimously re-elected President of the American Board of Foreign Missions yesterday, and he promptly accepted the honor, though he said he had hoped to be relieved of the cares of the office.

BUFFALO, Oct. 17. -- The veterans of the Union Veteran Legion were confident this morning that they could finish all their business by noon, but the contest for the commandership proved so stubborn that another session had to be provided for, and the legion adjourned until to-morrow morning, with but two officers elected and two ballots taken for commander.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Oct. 17. -- The skill of Asa B. Reading of Flemington Junction as a bicycle rider saved him from being robbed last night. He is one of the best riders in this section, and every evening rides from this place to his home in Flemington Junction. Last night, just as he turned a curve in the road, he discovered that fence rails had been placed across the roadway.

President Murray of the Excise Board and Police Commissioners Parker and Andrews were the principal speakers last night at a packed meeting of the City Vigilance League, in the Central Methodist Episcopal Church, Fourteenth Street and Seventh Avenue. C.E. Lawton, leader of the league in the Seventh Assembly District, acted as Chairman.
Ex-Speaker Thomas B. Reed has made it about as clear as he could in any way short of a flat declaration that he is a Presidential candidate and proposes to "lie low" for the present.

JAMESTOWN, Oct. 17. -- The officers of the recent Democratic, Prohibition, and Populist Conventions in Chautauqua County have failed to file certificates of party nominations with the County Clerk. The time for filing such party nominations has expired, and the Republican county ticket is the only one on record, and will, consequently, be the only one printed on the official ballot in Chautauqua County.

Little "Budsy" Hagan, whose aunt, Mrs. Annie Osborne, was fined $25 in the Third District Police Court, Brooklyn, Wednesday for hanging the little fellow by his feet from a door knob until blood ran from his nose, is now in the hands of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- Senator Hill to-day engaged the attention of the Justices of the Supreme Court for an hour. He appeared on behalf of the State of New-York, in its controversy with the United States, over a claim growing out of the war of the rebellion.

An order was granted by District Attorney Fellows yesterday for the examination of the stomach of Otto Odendahl, fourteen years old, of 658 East One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, who died from poison thirteen days ago, after having taken a dose of epsom salts, in which was strychnine. The order was sent to the Supreme Court for the signature of one of the Justices.

BUFFALO, Oct. 17. -- The investigation into the methods employed in the Public Works Department, which was begun yesterday, produced a sensation this morning, when John Finan, formerly a foreman of street-cleaning gangs, testified that at the instigation of Cashier Howard D. Herr, he inserted on the time book, and turned into the department, fictitious names.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- The steamer Waesland, on Saturday, will carry from this port to Liverpool thirty Mormon saints, who, under the fostering wing of Elder W.W. Kiddle of Salt Lake City, will for the next two years roam at large over England and the Continent in quest of "converts." On Saturday of next week another delegation of these missionaries will start from Salt Lake City, bound for Philadelphia on a similar errand.

The Rev. Dr. John Hall, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, has taken firm ground against any modification of the present Sunday laws, and against local option on the question of the Sunday opening of saloons. He stated his position clearly and unmistakably in a letter to the Excise Committee of the Board of Aldermen, which was read at the public hearing before that committee yesterday afternoon, as follows:

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- A dispatch from Beyroot dated yesterday says that there is much excitement in Lebanon, owing to conflicts between the Druses and Mutualis. A number on both sides have been killed. The Mutualis, pleading that it is impossible for them to obtain justice from the Turkish officials, have assembled to the number of 4,000 men, all armed, in the vicinity of Marghiloum to march against the Druses.

Senator SHERMAN last week expressed the opinion that the Republicans and Democrats in the United States Senate would "compromise" -- divide up the patronage and the responsibility -- leaving the Populists, of course, out in the cold. This opinion was uttered, presumably, after consideration of the ascertainable facts and a conviction as to what will be wisest and best.

Trading in cotton held chief place in speculative and financial interest yesterday, although the activity which excited the market earlier in the week had subsided. Opposing forces put forth their powers against each other all day, swinging the market in one direction and then in another. The close of business, however, found only slight variations from Wednesday's prices.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 17. -- The American Bankers' Association elected officers to-day. E.H. Pullen of New-York was chosen President, and R.J. Lowry of Atlanta Vice President. The features of the day were the speeches made by W.P. St. John of New-York and Edward Atkinson of Boston. Mr. St. John argued for a double standard and the opening of the mints again to silver.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 17. -- The track was fast at Saugus to-day, but a strong breeze made good time out of the question. Barney sold for $50, the field $40, in the 2:08 class. Paul was the field horse counted on, and the only mile he went on the pace all the way he won. Barney won the other heats easily. The other two races are unfinished.

ALBANY, Oct 17. -- An extended conference was held in the Executive Chamber to-day. with a view to rearming an adjustment of the troubles which have lately arisen between the members of the Grand Army of the Republic and Superintendent Easton of the Stale Department of Public Buildings, in consequence of the discharge, Out. 1, of the petitioners and other war veterans front employment in the Capitol and other State buildings here.

SANTA FE, N.M., Oct. 17. -- In the presence of the largest congregation ever assembled in a church in New-Mexico, the pallium, the sympol of archiepiscopal authority in the Catholic Church, was conferred on Archbishop Chapelle in the cathedral of this city to-day. The investing prelate was Cardinal Gibbons of Baltimore, who arrived here last Tuesday.

A handsome solid silver loving cup, with a capacity of ten pints, was presented yesterday to Joseph Larocque, President of the New-York Bar Association, by his associate members of the Committee of Seventy, over which he presided as Chairman.

There were signs of unusual activity and patriotic demonstration in and near 149 West Twenty-seventh Street yesterday. The United States flag floated in front of the house, and Japanese lanterns and big posters further adorned the building.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17. -- The Yale students from the Hawaiian Islands, who were detained at San Francisco owing to the cholera scare from Hawaii, have just arrived at the college. Albert F. Judd, Jr., and James R. Judd, sons of the Chief Justice of Hawaii, in discussing their experience, said to-day:

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- The opposition to the election of John Raines, the regular Republican candidate for Senator in the Forty-second Senatorial District, is increasing daily. Evidences of this are everywhere apparent, and but for the reluctance of prominent Republicans throughout the county to declare themselves, and thus provoke criticism as to their party fealty, hundreds would openly bolt his nomination.

The consideration of the provisional estimates for 1896 submitted by the Police and Fire Departments engaged the attention of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment at its meeting yesterday. As the members of the board, with the exception of Controller Fitch, were new to the task, the work progressed slowly.
GUATEMALA LA NUEVA, via Galveston, Oct. 17. -- The Government of Guatemala and the Guatemala Central Railway Company are at war.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city. Is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

A plan for the reorganization of the Union Pacific Railroad has been prepared by a committee composed of Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, Jacob H. Schiff, Chauncey M. Depew, T. Jefferson Coolidge, Jr. Marvin Hughitt, and Oliver Ames, second. In the working out of this plan the committee will have the co-operation of Kuhn, Loeb Co., the managers of the reorganization syndicate.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- All nature smiled on firemen of this city to-day the when they had their parade with a large number of visiting companies from many parts of Westchester County. The sun shone brightly, and the highly burnished fire apparatus dazzled the eyes of the crowds which lined the sidewalks, in some places a dozen persons deep.
Philosophical reflections seem as much a part of a practical cooking lesson nowadays as the regular scientific culinary deductions.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 17. -- President Cleveland will arrive here at 4 P.M. Tuesday, Oct. 22, on a special train on the Southern Railway, accompanied possibly by Mrs. Cleveland and certainly by all the members of his Cabinet, excepting Mr. Olney, and their wives. The party will be quartered at the Aragon Hotel and will remain at the hotel during the afternoon.

There is to be a show of live stock in this city next month. This will be a novel show for New-Yorkers, but one that is likely to be very successful. This show will be given by the Live Stock Society of America in the Madison Square Garden, and will be a stock and farm show and of the products of the soil and dairy.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- Andrew Davidson, the Deputy Secretary of State, in speaking this morning of the right of the State Democracy to have the names of its nominees printed on the blanket ballot, said:
Frank D. Pavey, Republican candidate for the Senate in the Fifteenth District, moved his headquarters yesterday from the State Club to the Hotel Metropole.
TACOMA, Washington, Oct. 17. -- Over 4,000 Indians, representing twelve tribes, have been assembled this week at the State fair at North Yakima, Washington.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 18. -- Edward Cannon Bald and Charles Murphy, the veteran, ran a dead heat for the mile invitation race at the second day's racing of the National Circuit meet in this city to-day. Both lowered the mile competition record of the world, taking 3 1-5 seconds off the time made by Bald in a race paced by a triplet at Chicago in August.

PASSAIC, N.J., Oct. 18. -- The burglar who came here yesterday morning about 1 o'clock, and between that hour and dawn visited eight houses without invitation and then abused the forced hospitality by gathering some $800 worth of valuables, came back this morning.

COWES, Oct. 18. -- The steam yacht Valhalla, with Lord Dunraven on board, arrived here from Newport, R.I., at 9 o'clock this morning. The Captain of the Valhalla, which is owned by Mr. J. Frederick Laycock of Portsmouth, reports having had a pleasant voyage since sailing from Newport on Sept. 28, though the yacht was delayed by headwinds and proceeded under sail most of the time.
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment, which is now engaged in considering the provisional estimates for 1896, took up the estimates yesterday submitted by the Board of Education.

CHATHAM, N.J., Oct. 18. -- Although the last open handicap of the season, the Chatham Wheelmen's twenty-five-mile race to-morrow will undoubtedly be a fitting finale of the year's list of road contests. The struggle will take place over a particularly favorable course, and the rider among the fifty entered who makes the best net time will get a NEW-YORK TIMES medal.

When that amazing aggregation of statesmen and reformers which last Winter made Albany an almost sacred place passed a law which forces registration officials to question and examine would-be voters as if they were habitual criminals in a police station, the new measure struck everybody as so imbecile, from all possible points of view, that the comments then made were marked with more of levity than of indignation.

A serious charge, in which the two official city examiners are implicated, has just come light through the exactment of fees by one of these examiners for work done in the insane pavilion of Bellevue Hospital, for which he is supposed to be compensated by an annual salary.

The Metropolitans scored a double victory last night in the Carruthers National Bowling Tourney of Brooklyn. Their bowling was quite a feature, and interested a large crowd of spectators. The team is composed of Fisher, Lee, and Whittlesey, who rolled last season on the champion Oxford Club team in the Inter-Club League. Leuly of the Columbian Athletic Club of Hoboken, and Sawyer of this city.

Judge Henry A. Moore of the Court of Sessions, Brooklyn, is to retire from the bench on Jan. 1 owing to his having passed the age limit. There will be two county Judges after Jan. 1, and the work will not be as tiresome as at present.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- Information of a fatal accident that caused a change in the programme for the launching of the gunboats Nashville and Wilmington at Newport News, Va., to-morrow reached the Navy Department this morning.

The widow of a workingman who died of typhoid fever last year in Ashland, Wis., has brought suit against the Ashland Water Company for $5,000 damages, alleging that the corporation permitted its water to become polluted by typhoid germs and that her husband's death was due to this pollution.

The Duke of Marlborough, whose wedding with Miss Consuelo Vanderbilt is arranged for next month, was arrested yesterday, while cycling in Central Park. He violated a Park ordinance by "coasting" down the hill near McGown's Pass.

-- Commodore B.F. Sutton has sold his schooner yacht Loyal to Mr. Nash of Boston. The Loyal this season was the best in her class, winning twelve out of thirteen races. It is probable that Mr. Sutton will have a seventy-foot schooner next season and tackle W. Gould Brokaw's Amorita.
The house of United States Marshal John H. McCarty, at 8 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth street, was entered by burglars about noon on Thursday, and jewelry worth about $500 was carried off.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- Suit has been brought in the United States Circuit Court to prevent the reorganization of the so-called Chicago Gas Trust.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 18. -- Between 500 and 600 delegates from thirty-eight States and Territories, representing nearly 300,000 members of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union congregated at Music Hall this morning to attend the twenty-second annual convention of the society. As Miss Frances E. Willard, National President of the army of women, entered the main hall she was greeted with the Chautauqua salute by an audience that filled the auditorium to overflowing.

Ex-Senator Warner Miller was to have been the star orator at a meeting in the Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, in West One Hundred and Fourth Street, last evening, but, to the great disappointment of a large audience assembled in anticipation of hearing the ex-Senator's opinions on the observance of the Sabbath, he failed to appear.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 18. -- Candidate Gleason issued his first campaign literature yesterday. It consisted of large sheets of cardboard, on which are printed pictures of schoolhouses, the battle-axe emblem of his party, and an excellent picture of the candidate. In flaming red and jet black letters Mr. Gleason is announced as a candidate "For Mayor and Good Schools."

LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., Oct. 18. -- A young couple, evidently in a hurry to get somewhere, although they did not know exactly where, passed through here late last night. They were in a buggy and when last heard from were headed toward Flemington.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

Miss Howland Ford won the Ladies Championship Cup at Morristown yesterday for the third time, and became the absolute possessor of the trophy. The cup was presented to the Morris County Golf Club just a year ago, by its President, Miss Nora Howland, for scratch competition, semi-annually, by the ladies in the club. Miss Ford won the first contest last Fall by a score of 96 strokes.

Mr. Percival R. Benson's small volume, mainly devoted to religious discussion, is written with singular force and directness. The continuity in it is slight. It might be considered as a contrast between the two men -- Weston, rather a free thinker, and Henry, who is a rigid orthodox churchman. Weston is master of a country school in some New-England village.

ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- The Secretary of State's office and the Attorney General's office are at odds. From the former comes the complaint that by the promiscuous opinions issued from the Attorney General's office regarding election questions it is kept in constant hot water.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- The following call for a State Canal Convention, to be held in this city Oct. 31, 1895, has been issued by the Central City Canal Improvement League, which was lately organized by Capt. W.C. Clark, the canal agitator:

The American Society of Civil Engineers have bought two lots, 50 by 100.5 feet, on the south side of West Fifty-seventh street, between Seventh avenue and Broadway, adjoining the Central Presbyterian Church to the west. A clubhouse will be erected on the site. One lot was bought from Samuel Inslee and the other from Amos R. Eno. The price paid is supposed to be about $80,000.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 18. -- Martin Julian in town to-day on his way to Hot Springs. It was believed he came here to induce D.C. O'Malley to supply the missing stake money, but he declined. Julian says he has a party who will put up the money, but declines to give the name. He says Fitzsimmons will not go into any limited round contest for points, and only wants a fight to a finish.

The most picturesque and interesting person at the anniversary of St. Luke's Home for Aged Women yesterday was Miss Mary Hopkins, who first entered the home when the corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street was surrounded by shanties and town commons, where goats and geese held high carnival.

Commissioners of Accounts Terry and Dennis listened to further testimony yesterday afternoon in their investigation of the Department of Docks, as it was managed and conducted under Commissioners J. Sergeant Cram, J.J. Phelan, and Andrew J. White. Delos McCurdy appeared, as at former sessions, in the interest of Mr. Phelan.

The library formed by Mrs. Norton Quincy Pope, the marvels of which had excited for many years the emulation, the despair, or the envy of all sincere book lovers, is to be exhibited by Dodd, Mead Co. Oct. 22 and sold.

A rousing mass meeting in the interest of Edward M. Shepard and the other candidates of the Democratic Reform Party was held at Broadway and South Eighth Street, Brooklyn, last night. It was the opening meeting of the reform campaign in the Eastern District. Fully 1,500 men were present.

There has been something particularly revolting and horrible in the revelations made during the trial that issued yesterday in the sentence of MORRIS SCHOENHOLZ to imprisonment for forty-eight years, which in his case undoubtedly means for life. No Governor is likely to pardon him out until not only has his crime ceased to be practiced, but until the recollection of his crimes and the crimes of his accomplices has passed away.

ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- Adjt. Gen. McAlpin to-day made public the report of Lieut. Col. Guy V. Henry of the Fifth Cavalry, Brevet Brigadier General of the United States Army, who was detailed by the War Department to inspect the work of the National Guard at the State Camp of Instruction at Peekskill during the past Summer.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 18. -- The result of the conference held in New-London on Thursday between Capt. Brewer and Prof. Ames of Harvard and Capt. Lea and Mr. "Phil" King of Princeton was made public to-night by the Harvard parties. The announcement comes from Harvard, as Harvard had asked for a day in which to consider a proposition of Princeton.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 18. -- The prosecution rested to-day in the case of John Mullins of Jersey City, charged with conspiracy in his dealings with the State. The defense moved the dismissal of the cases against Mullins and Ford, on the evidence, and under the statute of limitations. This motion being denied, A.R. Vreedenburgh outlined the defense.

The Bultusrol Golf Club, near Short Hills, will be the rallying point this afternoon for several hundred of the fashionable folk who have country houses along the line of the Morris and Essex Railroad from Orange to Morristown, and from Netherwood, Scotch Plains, Fanwood, and from Tuxedo Park and thereabout.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- It is understood here that the report of the engineer commission which visited Nicaragua last Summer will favor the construction of an inter-oceanic canal, but that it will not recommend the entire route already surveyed and upon which it is claimed that work costing in the aggregate several millions of dollars has been performed.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 18. -- The 1895 meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association closed to-day. Fully 9,000 people were present. In the two-thousand-dollar Wilson Stake for 2:25 pacers there was an old-time struggle. The four-year-old mare Rachel won two heats, lowering her record in the first heat. When victory seemed certain for the mare, Geers sent Morelia out and won the third heat by a head.

In an editorial paragraph in these columns last week we referred to the local political situation as one "full of doubt and danger." Now that the nominating bodies have all held their meetings, and all the tickets are in the field, the situation has not materially changed. It is still full of doubt and danger.
Reviewing the wool market for the week, The Textile Manufacturers' Journal will say in to-day's issue:

With the gradual development of the plans of the Metropolitan Traction Company the economies expected from the consolidation of the various interests involved become more manifest. An important move in the direction of simplifying the executive management has been determined on. Soon the general office of the Metropolitan Traction Company and the Metropolitan Street Railway Company will be removed to the new cable building in Twenty-fifth Street.

Mrs. Burnett is probably the most popular living writer of children's stories. Since the great triumph of "Little Lord Fauntleroy" four other books of children's stories from her pen have been widely read, and now comes another, as clear and simple, as interesting and touching, as the best of them.

Even those who regret, as I do, that there should be any persistent demands for opening the licensed saloons for sales during any portion of Sunday, must admit that this demand, as now being made, requires the serious attention of all thoughtful citizens. A powerful public opinion is being formed on the subject under circumstances very unfavorable to wise conclusions.
