The American short story continues to thrive. Three volumes of it come under notice this week, and in each of the three there are some ripe and well-formed examples of the art in which our writers of fiction excel.

There was a lot of log-rolling going on among the coterie of big Republican politicians who were in this city yesterday. There was no formal meeting of the Executive Committee of the Republican National Committee, although there were enough of its members in town to hold one.

GLASGOW, Oct. 9. -- The failure of the Valkyrie to bring back the cup has roused a crowd of champions who are intent on fighting "Uncle Sam" for its possession. Mr. Herbert Moir of the Colonial Finance Corporation, Limited, is the latest arrival among the champions, and so far has proved himself an adept at financiering.

That the revolution in Cuba is being carried on by men who prefer death to longer servitude under the yoke of Spain has been recognized by Americans, but that among the most prominent of the revolutionists are many men of Spanish birth, to whom the injustice of the Government has become unbearable, is a fact known to few outside of the residents of the island.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 18. -- In the Constitutional Convention to-day the following section of the article on finance and taxation was adopted after a long discussion and several amendments had been put in:
The American Board of Commissioners of Foreign Missions concluded its eighty-sixth annual convention in Brooklyn yesterday, and during the closing hours the Academy of Music was crowded.

Less than 125,000 shares changed hands in to-day's market, and nearly 40 per cent. of the business was confined to three stocks -- St. Paul, Sugar, and Tennessee Coal and Iron. The Granger group moved within narrow limits and closed practically unchanged. The general list was irregular, the changes at the close being about equally divided between small fractional advances and declines.
BUFFALO, Oct. 18. -- The Union Veteran Legion finished the business of its tenth Nation encampment this morning and formally adjourned.
The Board of Trustees of the American Institute of New-York adopted on Thursday resolutions upon the death of Charles Wager Hull, saying:

There will be about 400 portraits and as many miniatures in the second annual loan exhibition of portraits for the benefit of St. John's Guild and the Orthopedic Hospital which will open at the National Academy of Design on Wednesday, Oct. 30. On Thursday the Artists' Committee will begin to judge the pictures and arrange for their hanging.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- "The statement sent out by the American Protective Tariff Association," said Mr. Worthington C. Ford, Chief of the Bureau of Statistics, to-day, "that the Wilson tariff is responsible for the depreciation of value and number of sheep in the country is erroneous and misleading. As compared with the value of other farm animals sheep amount to only 4 per cent. of the total.
-- Mr. Crawford's novel, "Casa Braccio," will be issued in book form by Macmillan Co. on Nov. 1. It will contain the original illustrations by Castaigne.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 18. -- A. K. Ward, Secretary, Treasurer, and Manager of the Memphis Barrel and Heading Company, has been missing since Tuesday.

Mr. Tirebuck takes an old theme, the struggle between capital and labor, but, no matter how often the subject has been treated, he knows how to discuss it with exceeding originality and dramatic force. The contrast he shows is between the high and lofty Brookster family, the owners of the famous Beckerton coal pits and the minors who work for them, typified by the humble Ockleshaws.

FORT SCOTT, Kan., Oct. 18. -- The aggregate of the embezzlement from the State Bank of Cashier J.R. Colean is declared by Vice President J.J. Stewart to be fully $50,000. The amount stolen is two-thirds of the paid-up capital stock, and more than the other third will be required to collect on the securities.

BOSTON, Oct. 18. -- In her official trial trip between Cape Ann and Boone Island, a distance of thirty-one knots, the battleship Indiana to-day made an average speed of 15.61 knots for four hours. This is 61-100 knots above the speed required by the Government, and as there was a premium offered of $25,000 for every quarter knot made over fifteen, the Cramps will receive $50,000 as a bonus in excess of the contract price.
The Police Board, after its regular meeting yesterday, took up the protests against certificates of nomination filed with the Election Bureau.

" The people of New-York and Brooklyn would undoubtedly be surprised to know that a large share of the apple crop has been literally baked on the trees on which it grew," said a member of the firm of John Nix Co., 281 Washington Street, yesterday, to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES, with whom he talked respecting apples and the supply of that fruit in this city.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 18. -- The National Council of the Daughters of the American Revolution met to-day in the Congress Hall of the Woman's Building at the exposition. There are 600 women here attending the meeting of this society and the assembly of Colonial Dames.

Every one knows how fearful is the burden of taxation borne by the unfortunate Cuban people, but few probably understand how intolerable would be the increase of this burden if Spain should succeed in crushing the insurrection and impose upon the island, as she did after 1878, the payment of the cost of its own subjugation.

" I am going to use an expression I dislike," said Mrs. Rorer to her as usual enthusiastic audience yesterday afternoon at the Madison Square Garden, "the new woman. There is no new woman. Women are always the same, but the women of to-day are going to change places with the men. They are going to do the business, and the men will do the cooking. They will do it better."

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- At the fourth day's session of the Presbyterian Synod Mr. Scribner of the Board of Publication presented a report on the new hymn book, which is claimed to be the best for the purpose yet published.

The official announcement of the tax rate for 1895-6 in Brooklyn will be made Monday, when the Kings County Board of Supervisors will meet to declare it. In the meantime the figures are kept closely guarded from the public eye, because the Republican managers do not want unpleasant questions asked about it when they hold their mass meeting in the Academy of Music to-night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- First Lieut. Warren H. Cowles, Sixteenth Infantry, has been found "guilty of neglect of duty, to the prejudice of good order and military discipline," by a court-martial convened at Fort Douglas, Utah, and has been sentenced to "be confined to the limits of the post at which he may be serving for a period of three months, and to be reprimanded in general orders."

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 18. -- The Coroner's jury which has been investigating the death of George Philip Roll, formerly Assistant Secretary of State of New-York, who was found dying at the foot of the steps leading from the kitchen to the cellar of the house where he lived with his common-law wife, Lulu Van Zandt Northrup, concluded its work this evening by rendering a verdict of accidental death caused by a fractured skull.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 18. -- At a meeting held Wednesday night of the six Ambassadors of the powers which sent the joint note to the Porte relative to the recent rioting here it was decided to send a collective address to the Armenian Patriarch, asking him to use his influence to stop the agitation that is being carried on among the Armenians.

The effort to bring about Democratic harmony in the legislative districts of this city progressed yesterday to this extent: The Conference Committees of the State Democracy and of Tammany submitted their propositions to the Sub-Committee of the Democratic State Committee. The Sub-Committee considered the propositions and talked with the representatives of the two organizations, and then submitted a proposition, or ultimatum, of its own to the opposing factions.

The Colored Republican County Organization held a special meeting last night at 114 West Fifty-third Street, for the purpose of receiving and considering the report of a conference committee appointed at the last meeting to "confer with the Chairman and officers of the regular Republican County Committee relative to the indorsement of the fusion ticket and the recognition and compensation for such."

BAYPORT, L. I., Oct. 18. -- Eight-year-old Maud Smith was frightfully bitten by a bull dog yesterday in front of her home. The child's father had been away for two weeks and Maud ran out into the street to meet him as he walked from the railroad station.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Daniel Meskil was a cadet at the United States Military Academy. He resigned and took to married life and farming. On the outskirts of this town is the extensive plot of ground where he has tried for years to raise pumpkins that would make his neighbors green with envy.

In a plain, clear, straightforward presentation of his views on the question of consolidation, Edward M. Shepard, candidate of the Democratic Reform Party for Mayor of Brooklyn, yesterday replied to inquiries as to his attitude on that subject, made by William C. Redfield, President of the League of Loyal Citizens of Brooklyn, and George W. Chauncey, Secretary of the Real Estate Exchange.

The plan for the reorganization of the Union Pacific Railway Company, just issued, has an encouraging look. It is a compact and businesslike scheme and it aims directly at the financial rehabilitation of the property on strictly business principles. If any assurance were needed that this plan is proposed in good faith, such assurance would be found in the names of the members of the committee which framed it.

Morris Schoenholz will "make" no more fires. He was taken to Sing Sing yesterday, where, unless he should manage to receive a pardon, he will probably spend the rest of his life. If alive when the term of his sentence expires, he will be eighty-two years old.
David P. Salzman, said to be a Baptist minister, who has been acting as an agent for the Society for the Prevention of Crime, was arrested last night on a charge of extortion.

HIGHLAND LIGHT, Mass., Oct. 18. -- The schooner Eliza Levensaler of Thomaston, Me., Capt. Kellog, from Boston for New-York in ballast, went ashore on Race Point early this morning. The crew were taken off in breeches buoy by Capt. Fisher of the Race Point Station.

Stephen Crane is very young -- not yet twenty-five, it is said -- and this picture he presents of war is therefore a purely imaginative work. The very best thing that can be said about it, though, is that it strikes the reader as a statement of facts oy a veteran. The purpose of the book is to set forth the experiences of a volunteer soldier in his first battle.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Oct. 18. -- Shall Mamaroneck and Rye Neck he consolidated and incorporated? is the one question uppermost in the minds of the residents of the two villages. Even the issues of the coming election have become of secondary importance.

Precious historic treasures abound in the quaint, sequestered little hamlet of East Chester, situated at the northernmost point of the territory recently annexed to "Greater New-York." The locality is only seven miles from the Harlem River, but the surroundings are almost as primitive as they were during the periods of Colonial and Revolutionary "times that tried men's souls."

Euphemia Brandon, with her brain filled with vague ambitions and her soul with vaguer enthusiasms, returned from boarding school to her widowed mother's luxurious home in the metropolis resolved that her education was beginning, not ending, and that she had a work to do of personal and general advancement.
Chauncey M. Depew spoke last night in the Brooklyn Academy of Music in the interest of the Republican Party and Frederick W. Wurster, the Republican nominee for Mayor. The building was crowded.

The Commissioners of Charities and Correction have under consideration a complete change of the system by which the consulting and visiting staffs of physicians and surgeons connected with the City Hospital on Blackwell's Island have been heretofore appointed. The first step in this direction will be the abolition of the staffs now in charge of the hospital.
ZANZIBAR, Oct. 19. -- An English Captain commanding a company of native troops has been shot dead by rebels near Gazi, on the African mainland. His body was not found.

With weather that was simply charming and a card promising good, if not first-class, sport, the Westchester Racing Association had at its track yesterday an enormous attendance. The crowd was the largest seen at any of the tracks this year, excepting the Brooklyn Handicap, Suburban, and Futurity days.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Clear, bright days, bracing October air, and brilliant foliage in the uplands and near the lake, where the frost has left its touch, have made this village in the pines an ideal Autumn resort this week.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 19. -- There was a noticeable falling off in the attendance in the House of Deputies at the Episcopal Convention to-day, and a roll call developed the fact that fully one-half of the lay delegates were unrepresented.

-- Baltimore is at present enjoying an exhibition of Napoleonic and Wellington relics. The latter comprise the sword, cocked hat, and cloak worn be the great Duke at the battle of Waterloo; his eyeglass, medal, and telescope, his gold-mounted swords, presented to him by William IV. and the Emperor of Russia; a snuffbox with an exquisitely painted miniature of Napoleon set with brilliants, and the sword of Napoleon in a case containing three scabbards.

Warner Miller has been in this city since he made his speech last Tuesday night, and not a day has passed that some of his acquaintances have not congratulated him on his independence in proclaiming the doctrine of the party as laid down at Saratoga, Mr. Miller evidently enjoys this. He is far from troubled by anything which Mr. Platt, Mr. Lauterbach, or any other New-York City Republican may say or think of his utterances.

The report of Brevet Brig. Gen. Guy V. Henry, United States Army, on the National Guard of New-York, on duty at the State camp this season, published in THE TIMES yesterday, is just now causing much discussion among guardsmen. On the whole, it is considered a very fair report, but some of the recommendations are considered inconsistent.

John J. Duffield, a Director of the Harlem River Bank when that unfortunate institution was wrecked, in May, 1894, was arrested yesterday on an indictment for perjury found against him by the Grand Jury.

ALBANY, Oct. 19. -- The action of Private Secretary Ashley W. Cole in delegating unto himself powers of the Executive in directing Superintendent of Public Buildings Easton to reinstate discharged orderlies is severely criticised by Republicans about the Capitol. They consider it an unjustifiable interference. Col. Cole's explanation is that he did not want to annoy the Governor with the squabble between the retired employes and Superintendent Easton.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 19 -- The Connecticut Historical Society, which has its headquarters in this city, is the owner of unique portrait of George Washington. The canvas is a diminutive one, but is valued highly by the authorities of the society. It is an original, and, so far as known, no copy of it exists.

Discussing the market yesterday, ex-Gov. Flower gave it as his opinion that we could not expect a renewal of the bull movement until about the middle of November. By, that time the leading railroad systems would all be showing heavy earnings, which would justify another forward movement in prices.

In his book of "Recollections of Forty Years," Senator JOHN SHERMAN republishes a speech of his made in 1876 which he regards as the best presentation he can make of the true policy of the Government. It contains the following passage:

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 19. -- The oldest historic building in this city is the house that was occupied by the second Governor Of Connecticut, Edward Hopkins, who first assumed the duties of the office in 1640. The structure is still standing on its original site, in Governor Street. It is occupied as a tenement block.

Mme. Modjeska has gone from us forever and taken Mr. Clyde Fitch's new play with her. Her absence will be deplored. She drew crowds at the Garrick Theatre in her fortnight there, and is certainly as popular as ever, and as young. But she knows her own business best, and she says she will never act here again.

-- There are indications that Thurlow Weed Barnes is getting a little taste of the medicine he tried to force Frank D. Pavey to take. Mr. Barnes ascertained, on application, that Mr. Pavey would do as he pleased about going into caucus if he were elected a Senator from the Fifteenth District. Then he bolted Mr. Pavey, in plain, unmistakable terms.

In defense of the fusion ticket, the Committee of Fifty has issued a statement to the public. The fusion candidates, it is declared, will give the city better service than any other candidates who have "the slightest chance of polling a plurality of votes." The statement follows:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- It was genuine football weather that the cadet and Tufts College football teams enjoyed to-day. The game was not a close one, and the visitors did not at any time seriously threaten West Point's goal. It was expected the cadets would pile up a much larger score, but there was considerable fumbling in the first half, and the visitors made desperate efforts to hold the soldiers down.

News is a commodity just as much as butter or nails. Some men steal watches and silver spoons, and some steal news. News has a definite commercial value. When it is true and important it is valuable. To steal such news is, of course, profitable. When, however, a news item turns out to be false, its possession, obtained in an irregular manner, is more disastrous than marked greenbacks or watches with other people's monograms.
The annual Fall field meeting of the Columbia College Athletic Union was held yesterday afternoon at Columbia Oval, William's Bridge.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 19. -- The State Republican Committee received a telegram this morning from the Darke County Republican Committee that C.W. Hoeffer has withdrawn from the ticket as a candidate for the Legislature.

The amount of large game killed in the forests of Northern Franklin County, Me., this week has far exceeded the most sanguine expectations of the hunters and guides, many of whom have been of the opinion that deer, moose, and caribou would be much more scarce than last year, which was considered an exceedingly good year for game.

A meeting was held last evening at West Farms, One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Street, to ratify the nominations of John J. Hart for State Senator in the Twenty-first District. At the rear of the room was spread on canvas in large letters, "No carpet baggers." It seems that the Tammany candidate, L. Guy, and the Republican candidate, George Drake Smith, have but recently moved into the district.

In its record of prosperity the University of the City of New-York will mark yesterday as one of special interest and importance because of the formal opening of the Hall of Languages, the gymnasium, the laboratory of chemistry, and the Ohio field for athletics, and the breaking of ground for the library and administration building.

One of the most interesting museums in Boston has been removed to Hartford -- the museum of curiosities collected during seventy-five years by the missionaries of the American Board, and for many years displayed in cabinets in a little dark room in the Congregational House. The collection is to be deposited in the library of the Hartford Theological Seminary, and Boston will know it no more.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore of the American Museum of Natural History yesterday delivered the second of the Fall course of lectures to teachers. The professor had just returned from the meeting of the School Superintendents at Newburg, where, on Thursday evening, he delivered a lecture on Niagara, illustrative of what the Superintendents will be expected to deliver before the schools under the new law.

ALBANY, Oct. 19. -- A party of seventy men from West Troy to-day proceeded to the down-town wards and registered, it is alleged. District Attorney Burlingame took immediate steps in the matter, and secured the names of nearly all of the persons who are supposed to have registered fraudulently.
A private letter from Constantinople, received in this city, puts on the Armenians themselves the blame for the harsh treatment they have received from Turkey. This letter reads:

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Prof. James F. Riggs, D.D., of New-Brunswick, delivered an interesting lecture here Thursday evening, in the Bergen Point Reformed Church, his former pastorate. "The Iron Duke" was his subject, and it was treated in a masterly manner. Prof. Riggs will lecture here Thursday evening upon "The Defense of Plevna." He was connected for many years with the American College situated in Constantinople.

Henry F. Reed of the firm of Reed Teller, 122 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, committed suicide yesterday afternoon in Central Park. He shot himself through the head with a revolver, and died at once.

CHATHAM, N.J., Oct 19. -- The Chatham Wheelmen's twenty-five-mile handicap this afternoon created as much excitement as a circus. Its side features were a pulling match between Detective Gregory of Newark and a Morristown teamster of the name of Combs, and a collision between a cyclist and a carriage. The detective won his bout and the collision was a draw. Each, however, caused the greatest excitement for the time being.

Miss FRANCES E. WILLARD is President of the "Women's Christian Temperance Union of the World." She delivered her annual address on Friday, before a large and enthusiastic audience in Baltimore, and it contained much that was sensible, not a little that was eloquent, but some that was very foolish.

DEDHAM, Mass., Oct. 19. -- The quaint old town, with its deeply shaded streets and its quiet, ancient, and aristocratic atmosphere, has been forced into prominence by the fact that one of its most gifted ciizens, Mr. George Fred Williams, is the candidate of the Democratic Party for Governor of the Commonwealth.

Sitting on the piazza of a hotel, and watching the whirling flight of the thousands of cyclers as they stream along the boulevard, every observer is constrained to notice the great variety of positions. Now passes a staid merchant or minister, in the fifth or sixth Shakespearean stage of life, sitting the saddle with a "swayback" pose and clinging to the handlebars as if to save himself from falling upon the rear wheel.

A little less than 200 years ago, when John Churchill, Earl (at the time) of Marlborough, was confined in the Tower of London for having displeased William III., a certain Jan Derbildt was serving as a Corporal in the guards of the Staathelter, a the King of England was always called in his own Netherlands.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 19. -- A pleasant Mother Goose fair and festival were held by the Verona Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon and evening in Johnson's Hall.

There was nothing last light to indicate that there would be any adjustment of the factional disputes in the Legislative districts of this city. Efforts toward harmony had practically failed. The huge form of Thomas Costigan was the mountain upon which Tammany and the State Democracy pretended to split.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Putting aside all sensational stories, the Venezuelan trouble with Great Britain is regarded in the best-informed quarters here as having reached a stage which approaches the danger mark.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- A great deal of confusion is often occasioned from the fact that the cars on the Hudson River Division and Harlem Division of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad are painted and lettered in the same way. Along the top, over the windows, are the words, "New-York Central and Hudson River."

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- Washington's Headquarters, at Newburg, contain an attractive collection of Revolutionary documents and relics. The building itself is a curiosity, and the associations connected with it make it doubly interesting. Its architectural design would not be called beautiful in this day, but the solidity of its walls and the stout timbers of its roof show that Jonathan Hasbrouck intended it as a permanent domicile for his descendants.

" Which I reckons," remarked the old cattleman, as he tilted his chair against the wall and began arranging a smoke, "which I now reckons this yere was the only catyclism in trade Wolfville suffers; the only time it comes to what you-all Eastern sports would call a show-down in commerce. Of course that's the laundry war I mentions to you aforetime, but that's between females, an' don't count.

A careful study of the full list of candidates for the Senate and Assembly which we printed on Friday shows that only sixteen members of the present Senate and forty-nine members of the Assembly have been renominated. Though one-half of the Senators are candidates for re-election, they would constitute less than one-third of the new Senate if they should all be returned.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The Driggs Ordnance Company has protested to Secretary Herbert against the action of Capt. Sampson, Chief of the Bureau of Ordnance, in ordering fifty rapid-fire guns to be built at the Washington Navy Yard. The company, commenting on the matter, says:

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- At the session of the Legislature last Winter a bill was passed appropriating to Cornell University the sum of $150,000 for the purpose of building a veterinary college. This appropriation is for the building alone, the State agreeing to the following resolution, which was adopted by the Board of Trustees of Cornell University June 20, 1894:

There is yet something to be done in pioneer telephone work in Mexico. A Mexican newspaper urges that the further development of the telephone industry should be stopped, as it will ruin railways and hotels by rendering traveling unnecessary. This suggestion is on a par with that of the American who proposed that a sudden end be made of electric traction because it lowered the price of horseflesh.
Company G of the Twenty-second Regiment has locked horns with regimental headquarters over the question whether its selection of a Captain shall be influenced by the officers at headquarters.

A report comes from Washington that the Secretary of the Treasury will recommend to Congress, when it meets, the imposition of a tax on beer and of a tax on checks. Both are perfectly legitimate internal revenue taxes and would give a handsome addition to the income of the Government.

The office of The United Press Loeal News, whose service Is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public' interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

A never-ending stream of pilgrims doing homage to a great man's memory flows every year to Stratford-on-Avon. Most of these pilgrims visit the birthplace of the poet, the supposed home of his wife, the grammar school where he learned "small Latin and less Greek," and the church where all that was mortal of the great master was laid to rest, but few visit the home of his mother.

Ralph W. Pope, Secretary of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, and oldest surviving brother of the late Franklin Leonard Pope, who was killed by electricity at his Great Barrington home on Sunday last, returned to New-York Friday.

The experiment of having vacant city lots cultivated by the otherwise unemployed in large cities has been made with considerable success by the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor in this city.

All day Friday and Saturday Assistant Secretary Hyde of the National Horse Show Association and his clerks were kept busy receiving entries for the show, which is to be held at Madison Square Garden during the week of Nov. 11-16, inclusive. The entries, which closed last night, are numerous, as usual, and include a number of exhibitors who have not previously competed at these exhibitions.

One of the humors of the Brooklyn political campaign is the deep interest taken in the fortunes of Frederick W. Wurster, the Republican nominee for Mayor, by the men who were sent to Crow Hill Penitentiary in 1893 for complicity with John Y. McKane in the Gravesend election frauds.
The Police Commissioners held another special meeting yesterday morning to hear protests against certificates of nominations filed at the Bureau of Elections. Commissioner Parker was at the meeting.

The little girl preacher, Claretta Norah Avery, of whom there has been so much talk in the up-country, is now in Charleston, and has during the last week been preaching at the Morris Street Baptist Church before large audiences. Yesterday the little girl preached morning, afternoon, and evening, and the crowds were larger than before.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 19. -- This being Queens County's first year as a Senatorial district, considerable interest attaches to the contest for the State Senatorship. The district was formerly composed of Queens and Suffolk Counties. Suffolk always gave a Republican majority, and with the divided Democracy in this county elections usually resulted in the choice of a Republican.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 19. -- The Museum of the American Board of Foreign Missions, embracing the curios, manuscripts, inscriptions, and rituals which have been accumulated by the missionaries of the board during the last seventy-five years in the foreign field, has been transferred from Boston to the Hartford Theological Seminary, and will remain here for the future.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Oct. 19. -- The Board of Commissioners held another meeting last night and discussed further the trouble with the Atlantic Coast Electric Railway Company. The trolley people were well represented at the meeting and had consents from the residents of Cedar Avenue allowing them to lay tracks. When the company received its franchise it agreed to pave the streets through which its tracks crossed.

There are many situations in which individuals are called upon to orient themselves where the conditions are not so simple as in that which at the moment I have in mind. For instance, when a man has been suddenly "knocked into the middle of next week," as the phrase is, an experience to which I imagine that most of us have unhappily been exposed at some time in the course of a checkered existence.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct. 19. -- The committee appointde by the Board of Control of the Patchog'ue ,'heelmen to secure funds and to superintend the construction of a bic'cle path across Long Island from the place to Port JeiYerson has called a public meeting to be held at Port Jefferson to-morrow night in order to present the plans of the boa rgl to wheelmen generally.

Judge Beach, in the Supreme Court, yesterday appointed John Delahunty as receiver of the Mercury Publishing Company of 3 Park Row. The appointment was made on the application of Albert L. Reynolds, counsel for George H. Morrill, judgment creditor for $999.41.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Controller Bowler has rendered an opinion holding that Matt W. Ransom is entitled to draw his salary as United States Minister to Mexico under his last appointment by the President. It was the knowledge of Controller Bowler's intended action that caused Secretary Carlisle to direct some weeks ago that Minister Ransom be paid.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 19. -- The delegates were prompt in their attendance on the opening session of the second day of the great White Ribbon conclave at Music Hall. The auditorium was well-filled with representatives and visitors when Miss Willard tapped the desk with her gavel.
Horace J. Hoffman is evidently a gentleman with a fine sense of humor, though it is questionable if this fact is appreciated around the District Attorney's office.
SUMMIT, N.J. Oct. 19. -- An enjoyable "photo sociable" was given by the Ladies' Circle of the First Baptist Church, Millburn, in Barnard Hall, Tuesday evening.

In most cases "risings in Macedonia" are the work of sympathizing or restless outsiders, who organize bands of Christian "brethren." These crusaders cross the frontiers, are shunned like the pest by the bulk of the wretched people, and are ultimately cut down by the Turks, Pomaks, or Arnauts, or else driven back whence they came.

Two young women now performing at Koster Bial's, in Thirty-fourth Street, are attracting a great deal of attention. They do all sorts of wonderful feats upon the trapeze, high up in the auditorium of the theatre. They hang in every conceivable manner from one or the other of trapezes of different sizes.

There exists in the old and historic town of Albany the oldest one of the few societies composed entirely of women whose objects are of a scientific nature. The Dana Natural History Society of Albany was organized Nov. 21, 1868, and named in honor of the eminent scientist, James Dwight Dana of Yale College. It continued a prosperous career, and was incorporated May 30, 1888.

Mme. Rattazzi de Rute, a. cousin of Emperor Napoleon III., has, our Paris correspondent says, had a run of ill luck with her jewelry. Five years ago her cook was abroad carrying with him several thousand pounds' worth of diamonds and pearls longing to her. She has now been victimized for the second time.
CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- A fire which threatens the destruction of a large amount of property is burning in the Northwestern Fertilizing Company's immense establishment.

The Good Government Clubs assembled last night in formidable numbers in the Recital Hall of Carnegie Music Hall and discussed at great length the various matters connected with their ticket and the running of their candidates.

Rumor during the past week concerned itself more with Broadway property than any other. A number of buildings were reported sold which are under negotiation for sale, and as many more which are not even being bargained for. Among the things not sold is the property at 525 Broadway, extending to Mercer Street, owned by the Sternberger estate.
The District Attorney's office is investigating a peculiar story told by Mrs. Mary L. Goldstein regarding the manner in which she lost title to a piece of Harlem real estate worth $6,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The Government Directors of the Union Pacific Railway Company have submitted their annual report to the Secretary of the Interior. The Directors are E. Ellery Anderson, Fitzhugh Lee, J.N.H. Patrick, William J. Combs, and F.W. Doane. Mr. Combs gave publicity to his individual views yesterday.

GREENPORT, L.I., Oct. 19. -- That athletics flourish on the east end of Long Island is largely due to the activity and interest awakened by the Sterling Athletic Club of this place. The club is the oldest athletic organization in this section. It was formed May 20, 1884, by a handful of determined young men. That the club has lived and flourished is largely due to its charter members.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 19. -- Gov. O. Vincent Coffin and staff and the First Company, Governor's Foot Guard of this city, Major E. Henry Hyde, Jr., commanding, with Colt's Military Band of twenty-seven pieces -- in all, about 150 persons -- left at noon to-day in a special train consisting of a baggage and five Pullman cars for the Atlanta Exposition. They will be absent a week.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Monmouth County Grangers with grievances against the Legislature and Borough Council, and commuters who want better accommodations on the railroads, flocked to Asbury Park to-day and held indignation meetings.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Helen May Hoagland, the fourteen-year-old daughter of a Bucks County (Penn.) farmer, who eloped night before last with Burroughs Wolverton, aged twenty-two years, who is married and has two children at Pennington, this State, was caught here late last night with Wolverton, and both were sent to jail.

Mr. WARNER MILLER, in his unwitting and involuntary capacity of a vote getter for Tammany Hall, has been achieving results very unexpected, no doubt, to himself. But also he has been furnishing a very strong argument for the local option in regard to the Sunday clauses of the excise law which his mission was to oppose.

What is there in the Anglo-Saxon nature that makes Anglo-Saxons the prize snobs of the world? Other races have their weaknesses, but this weakness they do not share with us. We sneer at foreign titles, yet in no country are titles so openly sold. We look with lofty disdain at some Italian or German Count, whose ancestors have been Counts for unnumbered generations.

Some 500 or more guests gathered in the banquet hall of the Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon and evening to show their appreciation of and interest in the Teachers' Mutual Benefit Association, which received half the gross receipts of the day.

NEWPORT NEWS, Oct. 19. -- The launching of the gunboats Nashville and Wilmington to-day was made the occasion of an unusual naval demonstration, Admiral Bunce assembling the North Atlantic squadron in Hampton Roads, opposite the shipyard, and Secretary Herbert, with a distinguished party, coming from Washington by special steamer to participate.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 19. -- The Secretary of the Historical Society has sent the following letter to the college press:

In the early days of her married life the Archduchess Maria Theresa is said to have found the atmosphere of Vienna somewhat stifling; she resented being tied hand and foot by the traditions of dead-and-gone Hapsburgs. It was at this time that she used to work off her superfluous energy by those rides that made the hair of her Court ladies stand on end.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The protests which have come to the Agricultural Department against the order recently promulgated regarding the inspection of meat products, to go into effect Jan. 1, were orally presented to Secretary Morton and Dr. Salmon, Chief of the Bureau of Animal Industry, by Robert Ganz of New-York. Mr. Ganz, speaking for the packing trade, said objection lay against both the law and the department's interpretation of it.

LONDON, Oct. 19. -- [Copyright, 1895, by THE NEW YORK TIMES.] -- It is really playing with words to call the diplomatic arrangement which has been arrived at in Constantinople a settlement. Nothing has been settled. England has been forced to choose between open rupture with her ostensible colleagues or accepting their plan for letting the Sultan down easily, and very reluctantly has taken the latter course.
LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., Oct. 19. -- Mrs. Annie Jordan, the wife of a well-to-do farmer residing about two miles from this city, was stopped by masked highwaymen last night.
Mrs. New-Hampshire is very greedy. Little Bo Peep has said so, and who should know better than Bo Peep, who has cared for Mrs. New-Hampshire for eight hours daily for many years.

The Bureau of Elections, acting under directions from the Board of Police, has issued a set of instructions to voters regarding the manner of voting at the coming election. As the blanket ballot has never been used at an election in this State, the instructions will be very timely.

The most remarkable drought of the closing quarter of the century has been broken so far as the Middle Atlantic and New-England States are concerned. There have been heavy rains in Massachusetts. New-Hampshire, Connecticut, and adjacent States, and showers extended southward into Delaware and Maryland.

The meeting of the Heine Memorial Fair Association at the Arion Hall Friday night was the largest held so far, and in numbers, as well as in financial results, eclipsed all others. Both Richard Katzenmayer, Chairman of the Fair Association, and Mrs. M. Ams, President of the Ladies' Auxiliary Society, presided, and the reports, which indicated excellent work on the part of the various committees, were received with applause.
ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 19. -- An enjoyable reception was tendered Herbert Garahan of Parrow Street on Monday evening, in celebration of his return from Fort Montgomery.

Cotton broke sharply in yesterday's market, and the two hours of dealings at the Cotton Exchange furnished not only high excitement there, but dwarfed interest in the other down-town markets. The break did not come without warning. Prices had, seemed topheavy for several days, and operators were prepared for a quick downward movement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- Speaking of the reported arrest of the Duke of Marlborough in Central Park, New-York, for infringement of local regulations by "coasting" on his bicycle, one of the attaches of the British Legation to-day said:

FLUSHING, L.I., Oct. 20. -- A small boat containing Frederick Brennen of 502 Lorimer Street, Brooklyn, and his brother-in-law, Luke Rowling of the same address, was capsized in Flushing Bay late last night, and the two men were in the water for a long time before being rescued.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 20. -- The most interesting event of the week just past was the occasion of the Dudleian lecture by the Rev. Dr. Brook Herford, now of England, but formerly preacher to Harvard University. The Dudleian lecture is an annual affair. There are four different subjects assigned, so that the cycle is completed every four years.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- Armed with a repeating rifle, Caius S. Merwin defied the police and everybody else for sixteen hours -- from 11 o'clock last night until 3 o'clock this afternoon. Mr. Merwin is a man who grew wealthy in the iron trade and retired some time ago.

Dr. T. De Witt Talmage yesterday preached farewell sermons in New-York and Brooklyn, which were listened to by vast congregations. He will to-day, with his daughters, start for his new home in Washington.

Tree labels are useful in a botanic garden, no doubt. But it is a pity that they are found necessary in Bronx Park. Wild nature suddenly tames and the wood nymphs flee before the man with labels and a tack hammer.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 20. -- There is great rejoicing at Harvard over the prospect of a Princeton game. Much disappointment was expressed when the announcement was made that the conference at New-London had not resulted in anything. But great also was the joy when the matter was settled Friday.
PLATTSBURG, Oct. 20. -- The total registration in Plattsburg is 2,400, a falling off of over 200.. In the county the total registration will fall at least 600 short of last year.

Upward of 10,000 cyclers and 3,000 horsemen were out on the Coney Island Boulevard yesterday reveling in the October air and sunshine and the scenery of this famous route from the city to the sea. It was as if all lovers of wheeling and carriage riding had in concert sought to seize from the fleeting season the opportunities of a Sunday too perfect to be repeated before the time when snowflakes fly.

The proprietor of a wrecked saloon and the owner of a wrecked face stood opposite each other before Magistrate Brann, in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday, and each tried to show that the other was the cause of his injuries.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 20. -- The Hudson County Wheelmen had their final race meeting of the season at Guttenberg race track yesterday. It proved very successful and was greatly enjoyed by many spectators. The track was damp and heavy, while a stiff breeze that blew over the Guttenberg hills retarded the progress of the racers when they got the wind in their faces.

The game of tenpins is booming along merrily in Brooklyn, and before the first of November nearly a dozen tournaments will be in full swing. The season thus far is remarkable for the low scores, but this is partly accounted for by the fact that nearly every team has undergone a change since last season, and it will require some time to break in the new material.
NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 20. -- The wife of Ludlow Mahan missed her husband at tea time to-night and went to look for him, finding his body at the bottom of a pool of water.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 20. -- A committee of the members of the class of '96 has the duty of selecting a play to be given by the class. It is hoped that the committee will omit such objectionable features as were embodied in the one given by the class of '95.

The enforcement in this city for the last three or four months of the provision of the excise law forbidding the sale of liquor on Sunday has brought forth strange dissensions. Among these the strangest is that which assumes the incapacity of city people for self-government and the necessity of submitting to the restraining or directing influence of the wiser and better population of the country to save them from moral, social, and political perdition.

Prof. Felix Adler's first Sunday lecture of the season before the Society for Ethical Culture was delivered in Carnegie Hall yesterday, and the subject, "Perils of the Political Reform Movement," was treated as follows:

RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Capt. A.H. Chamberlain of the Union County Roadsters has completed the arrangements preliminary to the opening of the bowling season of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- The Rev. Dr. Benjamin F. Millard, a prominent and influential Presbyterian clergyman of Naples, Ontario County, extended an invitation on behalf of the Republicans in this vicinity to Dr. Parkhurst to visit this district and aid in the overthrow of John Raines, who is the Republican candidate for the Senate. In his communication to Dr. Parkhurst, he said:

The feature of the century run of the Riverside Wheelmen, from Jamaica to Patchogue and return, yesterday, was the remarkable time made by a tandem team, unpaced, and the riders in the fast division. Henshaw and Hedstrom, the Greenwich scorchers, were on the double machine, and, starting twenty minutes after the first pack, they caught and passed it and finished in 6 hours and 35 minutes.

There has been much interesting speculation during the last month, both in the American and the English press, about the tenor of the diplomatic communications from our Government to the Court of St. James in the present revival of the great and very grave questions of territorial rights at issue between Venezuela and Great Britain.

The contest for the regular Democratic Assembly nomination of the Thirty-fourth District has been amicably settled, Herman Sulzer having withdrawn in favor of the Tammany Hall nominee, Bernard H. Malone. The following letter, which will be placed in the hands of the Tammany Hall Chairman of that district to-day, will explain why Mr. Sulzer did not press his protest before the Police Commissioners last Saturday:

PARIS, Oct. 20. -- Mrs. John W. Mackay, mother of John W. Mackay, Jr., who died yesterday from the effects of injuries sustained by being thrown from his horse, reached Paris this evening. She is almost completely prostrated with grief.

The Republican organization in Brooklyn would undoubtedly gain strength which it needs if it could make the taxpayers believe that its candidate for Mayor would run the city as Mr. A.T. WHITE has run the City Works Department. But there are serious difficulties in their way.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 20. -- A fire started in Algiers, opposite this city, at a late hour last night and continued burning until 9 o'clock this morning, when it was got under control, because very little else was left to burn.

Politics was again a subject of discussion at yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union. Ex-Police Inspector Williams seemed to be the especial object of attack, and if the workingmen who live in the Twelfth Senatorial District should vote as the delegates in the Central Labor Union spoke, Mr. Williams will not have a seat in the Senate. They all regarded him as the enemy or labor.

ST. PETERSBURG, Oct. 20. -- The Czar has granted a pension of 5,000 rubles annually to Prince Lobanoff-Rostovsky, Minister of Foreign Affairs, for services rendered the State during his recent visit to France.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 20. -- Since affairs here have assumed a critical phase a close watch has been kept upon the students at the various schools, it being known that there was a tendency among the young men to agitate for revolutionary action.
MASSILLON, Ohio, Oct. 20. -- Senator Sherman spoke to 4,000 people here last night. It was the first speech he had made during the State campaign. In the course of his address he said:

The bronze bust, a memorial of Peter Turner, through whose agency the first Catholic church on Long Island was built, was unveiled in the churchyard of St. James Pro-Cathedral, in Jay Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- The Athletic Association of Vassar College will hold its first field day on Saturday, Nov. 2. The committee in charge consists of Miss Nan Banks, Miss Ella Love, Miss Ida Shallon, Miss Elizabeth Vassar, and Miss Nell Haight. Bicycle races, foot races, hundred-yard dashes, basket-ball and battle-ball contests, and sports of similar nature are planned.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- At the annual election of the sophomore class last week Harry Martin Smith of Springfield, Mass., was elected President for the ensuing year. At the installation meeting motions were passed by the sophomores sanctioning the underclass contests arranged by the Student-Faculty Committee on Underclass Athletics.
PANAMA, via Galveston, Oct. 20. -- Gen. Cassabianca, commanding the Army of the Atlantic Coast, who has been here for the last few weeks, will leave on Monday for Barranquilla.

The tax rate in Brooklyn is going up. Last year it was $2.68. Next year it will be $2.72, or higher. The Schieren administration has brought the city $l,000,000 nearer to the debt limit than it was when the so-called reformers took charge of the municipal administration.
The exploration of the site of the new botannical garden at Bronx Park was the object of the visit of the Torrey Club to the park Saturday rather than the collection of botannical specimens.

More evidence of gross overcharges for goods delivered to the Police Department during a part of the time John C. Sheehan was Chairman of the Committee on Supplies has been discovered by Commissioners of Accounts Terry and Dennis and presented to Mayor Strong in a carefully itemized report.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Oct. 20. -- The contest over the right of the 700 or 800 inmates of Sailors' Snug Harbor to vote in Richmond County has not been entirely settled by the decision of Justice Gaynor. The politicians are still disputing over the matter, and the old sailors are very indignant at being disfranchised.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 20. -- The following is a list of the officers on duty at the Naval Academy and the positions to which they are assigned for the academic year beginning Oct. 1:

HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 20. -- The first issue of Life came out on Thursday. It contained a summary of the different class and society elections, besides the usual college chat, and what was of especial interest, the offer of a banner to be given by Stevens Life to the winner of the interclass football games.

A horse and carriage driven by a fashionably dressed woman, apparently about thirty years old, who refused to give her name at the Central Park Arsenal, drove against a horse and wagon that Philip Lewisohn of 392 West Broadway was driving at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The woman was thrown out of her carriage, but was uninjured.

After negotiations covering a period of six years the Rothschilds have acquired an interest in the Anaconda Mining Company of Butte, Mon. Four different times the Anaconda's property has been priced to the Rothschilds, each succeeding price being greater than the one previously named, and finally their syndicate has concluded a purchase of one-fourth of the company's stock.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 20. -- For the last two days the arid gales and blustering winds of Arizona and New-Mexico seem to have been transferred to the American and Canadian Northwest. The chief difference is that, instead of the scorch of an equatorial sirocco, the icy blasts of the poles have held sway.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 20. -- Commander George A. Converse, United States Navy, who has been appointed to take charge of the supervision of the work of constructing the two torpedo boats, the contract for which has been awarded the Herreshoffs, states that a beginning will probably be made this week.
LANSING, Mich., Oct. 20. -- The first snow of the season fell yesterday afternoon, but melted as it struck the earth.

Martin Marsick, the famous French violinist, arrived on the French liner La Touraine yesterday. He is going to star through America under the management of N. Herlofsen, and his first appearance will be at Carnegie Music Hall Nov. 1, with Walter Damrosch. He will be there the following night also, and after that will appear in concerts and in special engagements.

Negotiations for harmony between Tammany and the State Democracy were at a standstill yesterday. It any one said anything on the subject which has had such a prominent place in the campaign during the last few days, it was simply that no harmony was in sight.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20. -The series of intercollegiate debates between Yale, Harvard, and Princeton, which was initiated last year, will be repeated this season. The American Whig and the Cliosophic Societies of Princeton appointed a Joint Committee on Arrangements some weeks ago, and this committee reports that arrangements for the debates are well under way.

Agents King and Pisarra of the Gerry society, who are stationed at the Harlem Police Court, arrested William Dietz, twenty-nine years old, of 17 Newtown Street, Astoria, in Newtown, L.I., yesterday, on a warrant issued by Magistrate Flammer and indorsed by Justice Smith of Queens County, for abandoning his three-year-old boy, "Willie," in this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20. -- A New-York paper printed this morning a dispatch under a Washington date to the effect that Senor de Lome, the Spanish Minister at Washington, would probably be recalled by his Government. The dispatch was shown to the Minister, who immediately authorized The United Press to make the following statement.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton preached on "The Sunday Saloon -- Shall It Be Suppressed or Converted?" in All Souls' Church, at Sixty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue, yesterday, and in the course of his sermon said:

It would be impossible to have better proof that The Jockey Club means just exactly what it says as to its determination to have honest racing than the action taken on Saturday evening by the Stewards of the Westchester Racing Association. The Stewards of the Westchester Association, Messrs. August Belmont, A.J. Cassatt, and Dr. G.L. Knapp, are also members of The Jockey Club.
With few exceptions, the Sunday excise law was rigorously observed yesterday, and the police were if possible, more active and watchful than on the Sundays preceding.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 20. -- The prospect of having the athletic differences of Harvard and Princeton entirely wiped out, so that the elevens of the two universities can meet annually on the gridiron, as they did previous to the difficulties which followed the 1889 game, and as the baseball teams are doing now each Spring, has given an added interest to the athletic side of Princeton College life.
BERLIN, Oct. 20. -- The Emperor and Empress arrived this morning at Potsdam from their trip to the Reichsland. Both are in good health.

Patterning after the great motocycle race between Bordeaux and Paris a short time ago, Chicago will have a similar contest on Nov. 2. An astonishing number of entries have been received, and it promises to create widespread interest. Local attention will be drawn to the event through the entries of New-York manufacturers, and by reason of the recent exhibitions of horseless carriages here, which caused so much discussion.

The Commissioners of Charities and Correction have abolished the Consulting and Medical Boards of the several hospitals under their charge, and adopted a new system of appointing physicians and surgeons for the various hospitals connected with the department. The changes are carried out in the following resolutions adopted yesterday:

Thomas McCord of 1,109 First Avenue is lying at his home suffering from a stab wound in the region of the heart, and his wife, Kate McCord, from whom he has been separated for a year, is a prisoner. There is some mystery about his wound, but he refuses to make any complaint against his wife.
Ex-President Benjamin Harrison came to this city yesterday morning from Saratoga. He went to the Fifth Avenue Hotel, which is alive with Republican politicians these days.

The first lecture of the mothers' kindergarten course for this year was given at the Teachers College yesterday afternoon. This mothers' course, in connection with the kindergarten work of the college, was begun several years ago. It has been patronized by women belonging to the most cultivated class of New-York society, and its teachings have been pronounced invaluable.

Commissioner Alfred T. White of the Department of City Works, Brooklyn, who Saturday made public the work so far accomplished during his term of office in the matter of paving streets, yesterday reported to Mayor Schieren on the work done in his department of sewer construction.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Special Treasury Agent Ayer has just submitted his report covering the tin-plate industry of the United States for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1895.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Burglars were busy again early this morning in this town, where, for four successive nights, they have visited different houses and have been more or less successful in securing valuable plunder.

Magistrate Brann spent thirty-five minutes in the Yorkville Court yesterday trying to settle a dispute over the possession of a cat between Mrs. Mary Hall of 59 East Forty-first Street and Mrs. Anna Staubstaudt of 57 East Forty-first Street.

We suppose that a majority of the people of Newfoundland are honest, but they have shown a curious and persistent preference for rascals as rulers and lawmakers. They refused to support the movement for the overthrow of the Whiteway party after nearly all the leaders of that party had been convicted of corruption and bribery at elections, and by their loyalty to the disgraced organization invited the financial collapse which afterward prostrated the colony.

There was a fine bit of dramatic action yesterday in an otherwise uninteresting murder trial before Judge Fitzgerald in the Court of General Sessions. The defendant was Antonio Caldaro, charged with killing Michael Pasento during a free fight at 345 West Broadway on Aug. 4 of this year.

Mr. T. Pearsall Thorne is a persevering young man, and the copy book tells us that "Perseverance conquers all things." This may be true in some walks of life; but never yet has perseverance conquered a lack of natural gifts in music. If it had, Karl Klindworth would be a greater pianist that Joseffy, and Reinecke a better composer than Brahms.

Chairman John A. Mason of the Executive Committee of the Democratic State Committee has not been saying very much since this campaign opened, but he has been making a very careful canvass of the situation and of the Democratic chances. He has heard from every section of the State. He has examined the registration in the rural districts, and he has come to the conclusion that the Democratic State ticket will win.

There still lingers in the minds of many Americans the notion that the clergy of the Established Church in England are maintained out of the taxes in a state of enviable comfort, if not of luxury, and this notion is probably at the root of that rather warm opposition to a State Church which is irrelevantly, but not infrequently, expressed in our religious papers, and sometimes in our pulpits.

MONDAY, P.M. The very sharp break in cotton, while beneficial so far as it will undoubtedly influence the foreign exchange market, had a disquieting effect on stocks, particularly those in which Southern interests are concerned. Tennessee Coal and Iron, for instance, was at one time quite weak, owing to sales by Southern bolders, the object being to protect their cotton margins.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 21. -- Negro Day brought the largest attendance the exposition has had. The colored people made a great success of the day set apart for their race. They had an ode, an oration, and addresses by State and exposition officials. Their purpose was expressed in the opening stanza of the ode by Daniel Webster Davis of Richmond.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- President Cleveland made three brief speeches to-day and listened to three others. The several occasions on which the respective remarks were made were the presentations of three new diplomatic representatives of foreign countries, accredited to the United States. It was a sort of clearing-up day, prior to the President's departure for Atlanta, for the reception of foreign Ministers recently arrived in America.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Chief Justice Fuller, in the United States Supreme Court today, announced the advancement on the calendar for an early hearing of numerous cases, mostly appeals in criminal cases, in which the United States is a party. Among them were the following of more than ordinary interest:

Members of the Republican County Committee were at headquarters, in West Thirty-eighth Street, yesterday, with faces wreathed in smiles. They looked happy. They shook hards with one another. They got together in groups and told good stories. They went into the inner rooms and sat in little knots, as if they were at a club.

While Park Commissioner Squier of Brooklyn is striving to purchase lands for new parks in that city, and is paying, as it is alleged, exorbitant prices for the property, thus wasting the money of the city and county, there are several who are striving to prevent him doing it. Patrick H. Flynn is one of the men, and Fred C. Cochen is another.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The Globe publishes a note saying that, as the British ultimatum to Venezuela has not yet reached its destination, it is not considered desirable to publish any of its details. It is proper to state, however, that the document is worded in terms of firmness and force.

Four trucks, Illuminated with six Chinese lanterns apiece, drew up in front of Good Government Club Y, at 175 Eldridge Street, last evening at 8 o'clock. They were common trucks, without any attempt at luxury or ornamentation except the lanterns and a slip of canvas on each side, bearing inscriptions of "Down with the Bosses," and "Vote for the Good Government Candidates."
An interesting fight going on in the order of the Knights of Labor, and serious charges of mismanagement and insincerity are made against the leaders.

PARIS, Oct. 21. -- The night preceding the accident by which John W. Mackay, Jr., died, Mr. Digby, who was with Mr. liackay when he was thrown from his horse, had a nightmare, in which he saw a horseman tn Jockey costume, wearing the colors of the deceased, killed in a race. He related the dream at luncheon, but nobody heeded it further.

After the curious and sorrowful experience of Frederick W. Wurster at the Academy of Music mass meeting Saturday night, there is no longer any doubt in the minds of the Republican politicians that he has already lost, and is continually losing, the support of large numbers of the members of his party in his contest for the Mayoralty.

When is Summer over, and when does Fall begin? It is easy to say "Look in the almanac. The evidence of that respectable volume is not conclusive, because the seasons glide into each other by slow degrees. One day is sharp and raw, yet the almanac says "summer." Another is hot and enervating. "It is autumn," declares the same authority.
The annual meeting of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union was held last night at the Astor House. The clubs represented and the delegates present were:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The effort of the holders of the second mortgage bonds, known as the equipment and income bonds, of the Burlington, Cedar Rapids and Minnesota Railroad Company to compel the Burlington, Cedar Rapids and Northern Railway Company to pay the bonds met an adverse fate in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day.

Mr. SHEPARD'S letter accepting the nomination of the Reform Organization of the Democratic Party for the Mayoralty of Brooklyn is a very remarkable paper. It fully justifies the estimate of the man which we submitted recently when we argued that he would be the best possible candidate for the Democrats to unite in naming.

The Democratic Convention that met in Ogden on Sept. 7 and nominated candidates for United States Senators, Representative in Congress, and State officers will to-day reassemble in Salt Lake City in response to a call made by the unanimous agreement of the State Committee at a special meeting held on Oct. 14.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Coon hunting in the mountains back of West Point is now all the rage, and a night seldom passes without half a dozen or more enthusiasts scouring the woods in search of that distant relative of the bear.

The combined efforts of the Mayors and Controllers of New-York and Brooklyn, together with the deliberations of the Bridge Trustees, failed again yesterday to come to a decision on the question of granting a portion of the plaza, at the Brooklyn terminus of the bridge, to certain surface railroads for a terminal station.

The so-called business administration of Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn has now been finally weighed in the most conclusive balance of all -- the tax rate -- and has been found wanting in every element of economy and reform.

I am much impressed with the fact that Mr. William B. Hornblower has written a letter, and with the apparent surprise of The Evening Post that it is a "sane letter." I am gratified to find that Mr. Hornblower has "great respect and regard for many members of the Good Government Clubs" it would give me the utmost satisfaction to be assured that Mr. Hornblower numbered myself among those thus honored.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- Mr. Dixon Kemp, the well-known yachting authority and editor of The Yacht Racing Calendar and Review, has furnished to The United Press exclusively the substance of a second interview had by him with Lord Dunraven.

The Riverside Wheelmen will have a gala time on election day. The club races will be decided during the afternoon, and in the evening to the racing team will be given a "Dutch" at the clubhouse in West One Hundred and Fourth Street. These races will close the season for the Riversides, and as they evolve the club champions, unusual interest is manifested in them.

We directed attention a few days ago to evidence disclosing a conspiracy on the part of certain prominent Republican journals and McKinley politicians to misrepresent the condition of the woolen industry. Without the least regard for their own trade reports and news dispatches these journals had, with one accord, been asserting that the industry of manufacturing goods out of wool in this country was most deplorably depressed and on the brink of ruin.

Whenever a store or a man in this city is robbed, the foes of our present Police Board see in the crime clear proof that the patrolmen, wearied by their toils as enforcers of the excise law, have no energy or attention left for bestowal on burglars and highwaymen. The argument is a pretty one, but somehow it seems to break down when an attempt is made to apply it across the river in Brooklyn.
The unveiling and presentation of the memorial bronze bust of the late William Wood took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Normal College.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 21. -- The morning session of the third working day of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union Convention was devoted to hearing reports from National Superintendents on methods of promotion and to a memorial service conducted by Mrs. Clara C. Hoffman of Missouri. The delegates and visitors were early in their places, and the work of the convention was dispatched with unabated enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- There was a report in circulation here to-night that the force of men at the Washington Navy Yard gunshops had been divided into three shifts, and that work was being prosecuted day and night on guns designed for the warships. All sorts of warlike rumors, with the Venezuelan boundary question as a foundation, grew out of this statement.

The Twenty-eighth Senatorial District comprises the Counties of Saratoga, Schenectady, and Washington. Of these counties, Schenectady only is ordinarily Democratic, but conditions this year, coupled with the strength and suitability of the Democratic candidate, ex-Postmaster Charles O. McCreedy of Ballston Spa, give room for hopefulness that the district may be redeemed from the Republican machine, which has counted confidently upon it for the purposes of Mr. Platt's Senatorial ambitions.

The actual intentions of Great Britain toward Venezuela have not yet been announced. The signs and portents which usually appear when she is about to engage in a dirty and ignoble piece of business are already visible, however. One of these signs is the swaggering and truculent tone suddenly assumed by some of the minor London newspapers.

The Brooklyn Bicycle Club bowlers were compelled to lower their colors to last season's champions of the Wheelmen's League in a series of match games which were played last night on the Brooklyn Bicycle Club alleys. There was quite a gathering when Umpire Drumpelmall called play, and the "rooters" were once more in their element.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Over 1,000 delegates to the sixteenth National Conference of the Unitarian Churches of the United States and other religious bodies holding kindreds beliefs have already reached this city, and as many more are expected before the opening of the business session to-morrow morning.

The games last night at the Caruthers National Tournament in Brooklyn were well attended by an enthusiastic contingent of bowlers, the Adelphis coming in for the lion's share of the "rooting." They deserved it, for their two victories were a treat to lovers of the game. The Fearless team broke the record of the tournament for the highest team scores, putting up a total of 873 pins. The scores:

Ex-Police Inspector Alexander S. Williams is making the liveliest kind of a canvass in the Twelfth Senatorial District. He thinks there is not the slightest doubt in the world that the people will elect him Senator. Every night after dinner he leaves his house at 109 East Tenth Street, and starts out on a trip of the Twelfth, Fourteenth, and Sixteenth Assembly Districts.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst was a busy man last night. With engagements to speak at three places, and handicapped with a severe cold, he succeeded in making two of the speeches, and in impressing his opinions and convictions on audiences composed, for the most part, of young men.
Chester B. Lawrence was appointed Fire Commissioner by Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn yesterday, in place of Frederick W. Wurster, resigned.

Edward M. Shepard, leader of the Reform Democracy of Brooklyn, yesterday issued his letter of acceptance of the Mayoralty nomination, tendered him unanimously by the City Convention of that organization.

BOSTON, Oct. 21. -- About 200 members of the New-England Cotton Manufacturers' Association left Boston this evening for Atlanta. After inspecting the exposition they will visit many of the manufacturing districts in the South on the line of the Southern Railway. On their return they will stop at Rome, Ga., Chattanooga, and Nashville.

Georgia Cayvan, the popular American actress, is at home again. After spending nearly a year in Europe resting, recovering her health and looking for new plays for her coming starring tour, she returned on the steamship New-York Saturday, and on Sunday received her friends at her pleasant home in Harlem.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 21. -- The managements of Harvard and Princeton football teams announced to-night that they had completed arrangements for the game between these two universities. F.W. Moore, graduate manager of Harvard, arrived in Princeton early this morning, and spent the day inspecting the grounds and conferring with President Milbank of Princeton.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- Ephraim Scott of 28 Le Count Place, died at his home this morning, after nearly three weeks of severe suffering, which originated from ivy poisoning. The immediate cause of death was eczema.
BUENOS AYRES, Argentina, Oct. 21. -- Representatives Varela and Vigil have been found guilty of selling their votes and are to be expelled from the Uruguayan Congress.
The Frank L. Fisher Company has sold for P.T. Radiker, at about $75,000, the three three-story brick and brownstone dwellings 329 to 333 West Eighty-fifth Street, each 20 by 52 by 100.

Racing will be resumed at the Westchester Association's track this afternoon with a fairly good card, the feature of which is the Hunter Stakes at a mile for three-year-olds. Rey el Santa Anita is in the list of acceptances for the handicap at a mile and an eighth, and he may be a starter, as his entry was made before the Stewards decided to accept no more entries from "Lucky" Baldwin's stable.

Roger S. Tracy, Register of Records in the Health Department of this city, has sent a report to President Wilson of the board, showing the excellent results of using antitoxine for diphtheria in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- A sensation in naval circles was caused to-day by the announcement that Rear Admiral William A. Kirkland, commanding the European naval station of the United States, had been detached from duty and ordered home. It is expected that Admiral Kirkland will apply at once to be placed on the retired list.
Spanish officials have evidently laid to heart Voltaire's saying: "Go on lying, go on lying; there will always be something left of it."

John C. Sheehan, who was removed from office as Police Commissioner by Mayor Strong, received further attention yesterday from Commissioners of Accounts Terry and Dennis, who on Sunday made public part of Mr. Sheehan's doings as Chairman of the Committee on Supplies of the Police Department.

Col. Waring, the Street Cleaning Commissioner, has been engaged for six months in removing gutter bridges which are not constructed in accordance with the city ordinances and which are not kept clean, and under which filth and rubbish are allowed to accumulate. Over 300 of these bridges have been removed in the last four months and carted off to the incumbrance yards of the Street Cleaning Department.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 21. -- One Hundred of the striking garment workers, including seventy-five men and twenty-five women and girls, left this city for New-York at 10 o'clock this morning. This is in accordance with the plan of Secretary Reichers, who has promised to furnish all of the tailors positions in other cities.
The New-York School of Applied Design for Women presents one of the most interesting of all the educational exhibits now to be seen at the Food Show, at Madison Square Garden.

Bankers and brokers in the purlieus of Wall Street will be interested in knowing that the "dead line" in which they placed so much confidence exists no more, and that they are now as liable to invasion by a gang of thieves as in the old days were the ordinary mortals who did business north of Liberty Street. Acting Chief Conlin says the line never existed.

GREENOCK, Oct. 21. -- Thomas Bradley, who has been employed as a fireman in the service of the Congo Free State, has just returned to this place, and in an interview with a representative of The United Press relates some of his experiences in that country. He had for comrades there, he said, the overseers of his work, a number of black navvies, two Norwegians, and one American.
A delegation of pilots appeared before the Pilot Board yesterday and filed a report recommending a reduction in the number of boats.

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- The St. James's Gazette says the statement is absolutely untrue that the peremptory dispatch or ultimatum to Venezuela was delivered to Senor Rodriguez, Venezuelan Consul here. As the German Government has consented to temporarily take charge of the interests of British subjects in Venezuela.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- The contention of Edward M. Shepard in regard to immediate proceedings being taken for the construction of the New-York City Rapid Transit route has been upheld by the Court of Appeals.

It has fallen to the lot of Assistant District Attorney O'Hare to prosecute nearly all the excise and disorderly-house indictments found by the Grand Jury, and almost every time one of these cases is called for trial it is flung in the Assistant District Attorney's face that he is actuated in prosecuting by a fear of calling down on his head the wrath of Dr. Parkhurst.

NORTH EASTON, Mass., Oct. 22. -- Ex-Gov. Oliver Ames died at his home in this village this morning. For the last five years his health had been gradually failing, and for the past three years he had had a medical attendant almost continually at his side.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 22. -- The Protective Association, which is going to rid the place of burglars and other undesirable visitors, has two New-York detectives on duty. These sleuths spent last night prowling about looking for the robbers in case they should attempt to return to the village after giving it a rest of about two weeks.

The columns of this journal yesterday contained two pathetic remonstrances on behalf of the "remnant," one from Mr. BOUDINOT KEITH expostulating with Mr. WILLIAM B. HORNBLOWER upon a letter which the alienists of The Evening Post pronounced "sane"; one from Mr. PRESLE TUCKER expostulating with Mr. THEODORE ROOSEVELT for having said that in the case of the Good Government people the "conscience vote" had "gone silly."
The Stewards of the Westchester Racing Association meeting have directed that the following letter be forwarded to Mr. E.J. Baldwin in reply to his communication, under date of Oct. 21:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Diplomatic circles are growing somewhat skeptical respecting the correctness of the London dispatches which announce that an ultimatum has been sent by Lord Salisbury to Venezuela, and it is believed that these dispatches are misleading, if they are not, in fact, somewhat exaggerated.

Chairman James D. Smith of the America's Cup Committee yesterday made public the conditions framed by his committee to govern the races next year for the America's Cup. The conditions were sent to Mr. Percy Thellusson, Secretary of the Royal Victoria Yacht Club, last week. The committee expresses its appreciation of the spirit of Mr. C.D. Rose's challenge, and the confidence he has shown the committee.
-- Frederic Harrison has in hand a biography of William the Silent, and is about to visit Holland to study portraits, manuscripts, sites, and books connected with his history.
