Contracts have just been awarded for important railway terminal improvements at St. George, on Staten Island, which indicate that it is the intention of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company to Make that point its principal New-York terminal for both freight and passengers.
The committee recently appointed by the Business Men's Democratic Association made public its address to the voters of this city and State last night.

The observer who may be only a little ichthyological, has less trouble in specifying fish than has a person slightly ornithological, in identifying with some precision the shore birds he may come across. Generally, we lump together the shore birds, and say they are plovers, or snipe, or sandpipers, or curlews, and blunders are frequent.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22. -- The Directors of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, at a special meeting held in this city to-day, Approved the articles of organization of the proposed Joint Traffic Association, and authorized its execution by that company.

The twenty-eighth annual meeting of the New-York State Baptist Pastors' Conference was begun at the Marcy Avenue Baptist Church, Marcy Avenue and Madison Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. The Rev. Cornelius Woelfkin of Brooklyn presided, and the Rev. C.A. Clausen of Brockport was Secretary.
The mass meeting which will be held in the Cooper Union to-night under the direction of the Democratic State Committee will be one of the most important events of the campaign in this city.

The open letter from Preble Tucker to Theodore Roosevelt, which was printed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday, has provoked a sharp retort from the Police Commissioner. The trouble was begun by a speech made by Mr. Roosevelt in which he spoke of the Good Government campaign as "the conscience vote gone silly."

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- The Chronicle, in its issue to-morrow, will recall the old rumor that Lord Salisbury will withdraw from the Premiership in favor of his nephew, the Right Hon. A.J. Balfour, now First Lord of the Treasury, and will mention a report that the Prime Minister intends to relinquish the foreign portfolio in favor of Lord Dufferin, the British Ambassador to France.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Secretary Herbert has requested all the departmental bureau Chiefs to eliminate from their reports as much as possible all matter save that which will form a record of the year's progress and action. This order is meant as a discouragement to suggestions and recommendations, save such as are absolutely necessary in maintaining the efficiency of the service.

A good crowd saw a fair lot of sport at the track of the Westchester Racing Association yesterday. In spite of the chilling wind that blew across the track, the bettors were kept warm by the favorites or well-backed second choices winning all the races up to the last. After that last one they were positively hot, because Prince Lief could do no better than run third.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 22. -- President Cleveland and his party arrived here about 4 o'clock this afternoon. Twenty thousand persons were massed in the streets which converge at the Union Station, and they greeted the President with cheers as he stepped upon Georgia soil.
It looked for a time yesterday as if Charles W. Brooke and A.B. Randall would indulge in a fist fight before Judge Gildersleeve, in the Superior Court, Special Term.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Oct. 22. -- The Democratic Convention met this morning, in pursuance of a special call issued by the State Committee, for the purpose of deciding on some plan of action in the matter of the interference of the Mormon Church in the political affairs of the Territory.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 22. -- The most intense interest of any session of the Women's Christian Temperance Union Convention so far held was developed this afternoon, when the report of the Committee on Resolutions was under discussion for nearly three hours. Nearly every delegate offered an amendment, a suggestion, or gave her views as to at least one of the planks of the platform.
Tammany ratified the Democratic State ticket and its own local ticket last night.

RHINECLIFF, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- The loan exhibition and sale of fancy goods which takes place at Ellerslie to-morrow afternoon and the following afternoon will give the people hereabout who are not on calling terms with Governor and Mrs. Morton a chance to inspect the interior of one of the handsomest homes along the Hudson.

Chauncey H. Depew was at his best last night, when he spoke at Carnegie Hall. He was full of wit and anecdote, and when the audience was not laughing at some of his stories it was wildly cheering his allusions to the work of the Republics Party and reform. He started out in a characteristic way.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- George W. Robertson of this place, who was repudiated by his Republican constituents and thereby failed to get a renomination for State Senator, has failed to register this Fall, although he lives within a hundred yards of the place where the Board of Registry in his district met several days and evenings. He therefore cannot vote this Fall.

Mr. PERRY BELMONT in his speech at the ratification meeting last night very properly gave great prominence to the question of local home rule, for that is the main issue in the State campaign. It is the one clear issue demanding attention from the legislative authority of the State, and it is the one issue upon which the party division is distinctly marked.

PUEBLO, Col., Oct. 22. -- One thousand persons attended the National Circuit meet of the Rover Wheel and Athletic Club in this city to-day. The weather was very chilly, and altogether it was one of the most uncomfortable race days of the year. The circuit party leaves for Salt Lake to-night.

The Reform Democracy of Brooklyn held a great mass meeting last night in the Academy of Music. It was their first big demonstration in the present campaign, and in point of attendance and of enthusiasm displayed, the occasion was notable.
ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- The Justices of the four appellate divisions of the Supreme Court in this State, created by the new Constitution, held a convention in the Senate library this afternoon.

The house 19 Jumel Place, one of a row of frame dwellings, was occupied Oct. 2 by James Coughlan, and on the afternoon of the next day took fire from some unexplained cause. Damage to the amount of $1,800 was done, and the tenant moved. The occupants of other houses in the row followed his example.
Charles A. Berrian, the real estate broker and auctioneer, had an exciting experience last Saturday on the Hudson River Just above Spuyten Duyvil.
Patrolmen who are jealous of their rights in the matter of their exercise of the franchise are keenly interested in the question of their status on election day.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Oct. 22. -- The Episcopal Convention, on this, its last day, showed an apparent minority of delegates remaining, evidently only enough to constitute a quorum for the winding up of necessary business details. A message was received from the House of Bishops containing a joint resolution constituting the missionary district of Northern Texas. The action was concurred in without debate.

Ruggiero Bonghi was a learned philosopher. Born at Naples, March 20, 1828, he published in his eighteenth year a translation of Plotinus "On the Beautiful" and, a year later, commentaries on Plato's "Philebus." When the revolutionary storm passed over Italy, he was at Florence, and founded a journal, I1 Nazionale, which, with his active political canvassing, provoked his exile from the Kingdom of Naples.

Signs are multiplying on every hand in Brooklyn that the better class of Republicans, as well as of Democrats, are going to vote for Edward M. Shepard for Mayor. They are going over to the side of Mr. Shepard all the time from the ranks of both parties.

The Government, when it undertakes to estimate in an official document the mineral value of deposits of ore, should not, it seems to us, exclude from its list of reporting experts the most famous of all the persons who have inspected the property in question.

Thus far this has been a prosperous month for the railroads of this country, particularly those in the West and Northwest. The grain shipments are very large, the receipts at Chicago last week showing an increase of about 3,000,000 bushels over the receipts for the corresponding period of a year ago.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

The Consolidation League of Brooklyn yesterday issued a lengthy statement of its reasons for favoring a union of the city with New-York. After stating that the business interests of the two cities are identical, the league says it is able to make the following declarations, which it challenges any one to controvert:

People of social prominence are unusually quiet at present, and seem to have buried themselves at Tuxedo and other places where fashionable folk go for the Autumn. Tuxedo, usually gay at this period of the year, is absolutely dull now, but the annual Autumn ball, on Nov. 1, will mark the beginning of a round of gayety.

With a great show of indignation, and doubtless with great sincerity, the Executive Committee of the State Democracy on Oct. 12 repudiated the bargain by which ex-Police Inspector Williams received the State Democracy's indorsement for the Senate in the Twelfth District, in return for the Republican indorsement of State Democracy Leaders W.F. Grote and Jacob Kunzenman for the Assembly in the Sixteenth and Fourteenth Assembly Districts, respectively.

When the Republicans of Ohio held their State Convention and Senator JOHN SHERMAN appeared as the leader of that curious combination in which MCKINLEY and FORAKER were the other parties, the Senator took occasion openly to join the two questions of a protective tariff and the currency and to declare that they were logically and practically inseparable.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- There is considerable indignation in New-Rochelle over the recent destruction of a row of elm trees in Huguenot Street, just in front of the old Lawton homestead, one of the oldest residences in New-Rochelle. It is one of the original Huguenot houses.
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment considered yesterday the provisional estimates of the Street Cleaning Department and the Health Department for 1896.

Only an amazingly perfect confidence in either the stupidity or the dishonesty of its readers can make it possible for a newspaper to say, as does The London Globe, that even the strictest application of the Monroe doctrine does not in any way affect England's refusal to allow Venezuela to occupy a part of British Guiana.

We Americans are, of all people in the whole world, the ones most devoured by worship of ourselves. Stop! I had almost forgotten the Chinaman -- but still be modifies our case but slightly. When the genuine Yankee is unmuzzled upon the shores of Europe he commences by a search for some one into whose ears he can pour the story of our greatness.

PRINCETON, Oct. 22. -- A large number of ladies, most of them gray-haired and having severe-looking spectacles astride their noses, strolled about the city to-day, taking in what sights there are to be seen, and giving emphasis to the severely aristocratic bearing of the place. The ladies were the members of the New-Jersey Society of Colonial Dames, and they were here for the purpose of commemorating the establishment of the College of New-Jersey in 1746.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.
Cart-tailing with Good Government stump speakers through the east side after nightfall, however profitable it may be, is very picturesque, and at all times free from monotony.
ELIZABETH, Oct. 22. -- In the Union County Republican Convention to-day Charles N. Codding was nominated by acclamation for the Assembly.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 22. -- State Treasury Addison B. Calvin again has become picturesque. In behalf of his candidacy for reelection, he is making a personal campaign as a newspaper man. A letter has been received here, which is addressed to a "Dear Brother Editor," in which the "dear brother" is thus advised:

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- The general court-martial convened to investigate the charges against Lieut. Samuel S. Pague of the Fifteenth United States Infantry for shooting at Col. R.E.A. Crofton of the same regiment on Oct. 3 commenced its proceedings at Fort Sheridan this morning. Attorney Frank P. Blair of Chicago appeared for the accused, who was his classmate at the West Point Military Academy.

Some heavy, dark shades were drawn down over the windows in Republican county headquarters yesterday afternoon. The rooms were dusky even when the bright October sunshine was streaming in golden bars just outside. Fred S. Gibbs walked through the rooms with noiseless footsteps.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- The Scarsdale gang of burglars has been broken up, and about all the plunder in the recent burglaries at the homes of B.W. Tone and Col. A.B. Crane has been recovered.

The investigation of the Dock Department as it was managed under Commissioner J. Sergeant Cram, Andrew J. White, and J.J. Phelan was resumed yesterday afternoon at 2 o'clock by Commissioners of Accounts Terry and Dennis, in the Stewart Building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The naval constructors and engineers are greatly surprised and disturbed over an order issued by Secretary Herbert, taking out of their hands entirely the construction of two torpedo boats, the contract for which has been awarded to the Herreshoff Company.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Oct. 22. -- The Deep Waterways Convention was called to order in the Opera House in this city to-day by Capt. J. Bryant of New-Orleans in the presence of one of the largest gatherings ever assembled in Vicksburg. The building was tastefully decorated and ornamented with flags, and all classes of citizens gave the delegates to the convention a cordial greeting.

The St. James's Gazette goes too far for its own case when it declares, as to arbitration, that "it is the usual thing when there is recourse to this kind of international tribunal for the arbitrators to find against England and the weight of evidence." The inference from this statement is either that international arbitrators are usually unfair, which is improbable, or that England is usually in the wrong, which is not improbable at all.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 22. -- A local paper has received 118 replies to a letter sent to every member of Congress containing this query: "If the special Nicaraguan Canal Committee, appointed by act of Congress, makes a favorable report on the feasibility of the canal, will you probably favor Government aid looking to its early construction?"
Mr. J.C.R. Eckerson has sold the plot at the southeast corner of Riverside Drive and Eighty-fourth Street. 74.7 1/4 by 126.8 3/4 by 80 by 111.3.

It is quite safe to discredit the announcement about the Cuban rebellion that is said to have been sent from Havana to Madrid, and that seems certainly to have been sent from Madrid. The announcement is that the chief lieutenant of MACEO has held a conference with his friends, at which it was admitted that further resistance to the Spanish forces was hopeless, and counsel was taken as to what was best to be done.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The formal three days session of the sixteenth annual conference of the Unitarian and other Christian churches, was opened this morning, in this city. In the absence of Senator Hoar of Massachusetts, Dorman B. Eaton of New-York presided.

ALBANY, Oct. 22. -- The State Railroad Commissioners gave an adjourned hearing this afternoon on the application of the New-York and Pennsylvania Railroad, which is to run from Hornellsville to the northern part of Pennsylvania, for permission to construct its line. Assemblyman John B. Stanchfield of Elmira appeared for the application, and J.H. Stevens, representing the Erie Railroad Company, was present in opposition Decision was reserved.
At Berkeley Oval, Morris Heights, yesterday afternoon, the Hamilton Institute football eleven was defeated by the Cutler School team, the score being 40 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Secretary Olney is utilizing all the agencies at his command to secure the preservation of the Alaska fur seals. He is convinced from the reports of Treasury experts that the animals are being rapidly diminished, as the result of pelagic sealing, and he assumes that if some steps are not taken to prevent their indiscriminate slaughter they will within a few years be exterminated.

MERIDEN, Conn., Oct. 22. -- The biennial session of the General Convention of the Universalist Church opened to-day. Alter the preliminaries of the afternoon meeting the reports of the Treasurer and Board of Trustees, and the report of the Convention Secretary, the Rev. Dr. G.L. Demarest of Manchester, N.H., were read at the evening session.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Third Assistant Postmaster General Craige, in his annual report, shows the vast bulk of second-class mail matter transmitted, and the comparatively small compensation received. He says:

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 22. -- The forty-ninth annual meeting of the American Missionary Association convened in the First Congregational Church here this afternoon with a good attendance. After organization, the Rev. H.P. Deforest made an address of welcome on behalf of the churches of the city, and a letter of welcome was read from Gov. Rich, Vice President Washington Gladden made the response.

BUFFALO, Oct. 23. -- Edward Jacobs and Frank J. Connors, iron workers, employed on the Elliott Square Building, have been quarreling for several days over the ownership of some tools. The argument was resumed at the noon hour to-day, and was getting warm when the whistle blew and the men ascended to their work again on the tenth floor.

The Spaniard is not generally a skillful dissembler. His habits of personal pride and bigotry of convictions incapacitate him for successful hypocrisy. Facts are not seldom inconvenient to him, and he would fain suppress or disguise them; but the task is not congenial, and he generally bungles in the overzealous endeavor or "gets mad" in the course of the distasteful process and nullifies it all in an outburst of vigorous sincerity.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- To-morrow The Standard will say that the Pope has communicated to several Cardinals another letter to the English regarding their return to the Church of Rome. It is believed that the objections urged against the former letter will be combatted with studied moderation, that explanations will be given, and that all concessions possible will be made by his Holiness.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- According to a letter received at the Navy Department from the commander of the United States steamship Yantie, the steamship San Francisco left Montevideo Sept. 16, with more than 1,200 Spaniards enlisted for service in the Spanish Army in Cuba.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct 23. -- President's Day at the Cotton States Exposition was bright and beautiful. Incoming trains brought tens of thousands of visitors, and the streets were crowded at an early hour. The President remained in his apartments until the committee called for him. Secretary Carlisle and Vice President Stevenson were out early, however, for a stroll.

ALBANY, Oct. 23. -- An official interpretation of the alcoholic and narcotic amendment to the general school law has been sent out to school officers and Superintendents by Superintendent of Public Instruction Skinner. Mr. Skinner opposed this law from the start. He begins his circular to the school officers with these statements:

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 23. -- Patrick J. Boyle, the Democratic candidate, was re-elected Mayor to-day over William Hamilton by 350 majority, the largest Democratic majority ever reached here. Boyle is the first Democrat to carry the Third Ward, John S. Coggeshail (Rep.) is re-elected City Treasurer by a large majority.
Every clergyman in Brooklyn will receive this week a copy of the following address sent by a committee of fifty:

Just as the New-York Yacht Club had finished concocting and promulgating "as a basis for discussion" the conditions for the races for the America's Cup next year, comes the news that Mr. ROSE has withdrawn his challenge. The fact is mainly noteworthy as indicating the extent of the interest that is taken on the other side in this particular contest.

Charles Day Rose has withdrawn his challenge for the America's Cup, and the chances of an international yacht race here next year are looking anything but bright. Yesterday morning Secretary J.V.S. Oddie of the New-York Yacht Club received this cablegram:

The Health Board yesterday came to the assistance of bicyclists by asking the Street Sprinkling Association to leave all asphalt pavements dry for a space of three feet next each curbing. The object of the request is to render the streets less dangerous to wheelman. It was also requested that a strip of six feet wide be left dry on all raliroad crossings.

The special sale of trotters, road, and coach horses of Reed Fritz of Easton, Penn., at the American Exchange yesterday, was fairly successful. An unusually large crowd was present, and the bidding was spirited throughout. The highest price obtained for a pair was paid by Max Casperri of this city for Major and Mack, $580. They will be shipped to Europe.

The steamship City of St. Augustine, which, only recently had a prominent place in New-York daily newspapers under the display caption of missing or lost, has finally made a spectacular exit from the world afloat. That much is known, but there is no hint as to what has become of the crew.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 23. -- The American Antiquarian Society held its annual meeting at its rooms to-day. The Treasurer's statement showed the total investments and cash on hand Oct. 2, 1895, to be $127,201.86. The market value of the several investments amounts to $136,317.36, and the price paid was $127,201.86.

In the Carruthers National bowling tourney of Brooklyn the Reinecke, Aurora, and Clover Clubs last night competed for championship honors. Capt. Walters successfully piloted his clever team of Reinecke Club bowlers through two games. The Aurora of South Brooklyn won the odd game. The scores:

Private letters from Constantinople say definitely, what every one acquainted with the general situation already believed, that the disturbances were primarily the work of the Armenian revolutionists, secondarily the expression on the part of the Moslems of their hatred for Christians.

Prof. Charles A. Collin declared in open court yesterday that "the City of New-York will receive from the Union Railway Company [known as the "Huckleberry Road"] a larger percentage of its gross receipts and a larger total amount than the city will receive for any other franchise it has ever granted."

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 23. -- Archbishop Langevin, representing the Catholic party in Manitoba, has made a proposal in regard to the parochial school difficulty that may be accepted by the Manitoba Government, and further hostilities between Catholics and Protestants avoided.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 23. -- The largest score the Yale football eleven has made this year was rolled up against the Williams eleven this afternoon at the Yale Field. The final figures stood 54 to 0. The play was at times brilliant by both teams, Dewitt, Jerrems, and Rodgers covering more than half the field in runs, and Williams twice rushing the ball within the Yale twenty-five-yard line.

" Boys," observed to his staff the Kentucky editor, who was also a Colonel, "yo' should make the papah consist. It doesn't look well to have an ahticle in one paht of yo' papah contradicting an ahticle in anothah paht of yo' papah." We know not why the obligation of consistency is not as binding upon a party meeting as upon a "papah."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23. -- The sixth annual convention of the National Association of Life Underwriters began to-day in the drawing room of the New Century Club. Two hundred and fifty delegates, representing the principal life insurance companies of the country; are in attendance.

The sincerest and most zealous advocates of the "fusion" ticket, those most in sympathy with the cause of municipal reform, maintain that the paramount issue at the coming election is the defeat of Tammany. They also maintain that the only possible chance of accomplishing that result is by the election of the "fusion" candidates.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 23. -- The Princeton football eleven made a poor showing against the Union team here to-day. Only 22 points were secured by the Tigers in two halves of twenty and fifteen minutes each. The small score was not due to the strength of Union, but rather to the poor work of the Tigers.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- The nine-million-dollar Canal Improvement bill is receiving a notable boom in Syracuse, and the plans for the convention favoring the appropriation, to be held here on the morning of Oct. 31, promise a very large attendance and an enthusiastic consideration of ways and means to secure a full and intelligent vote at the coming election.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- In the National Unitarian Conference an address upon the "Character, Influence and Teachings of Christ, as Shown in the New Testament," was interpolated in the programme by the venerable Dr. Furnass of Philadelphia, who completed his education at Harvard seventy-five years ago, and is the oldest living graduate of that institution, being ninety-five years of age.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment should not be deterred from granting to each department of the Municipal Government the funds necessary for the most efficient execution of its work by any fear that the total amount of appropriations will exceed that of previous years or that the tax rate will be increased.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 23. -- A large crowd stood on the platforms of the Long Island Railroad station at Hempstead to-night upon the arrival of the Duke of Marlborough, who is the guest of James L. Kernochan, and who will hunt with the Meadowbrook hounds to-morrow.

A novelty in century runs will be inaugurated on Sunday in the hundred-mile trip to be held under the auspices of the Century Wheelmen of New-York. It will consist of a stop for breakfast. Heretofore on all century runs the participants who desired to keep up even with the leaders have had to be satisfied with a sandwich or whatever else they could get until the stop for dinner was reached.

Question regarding good title to the Clearing House property, at Pine and Nassau Streets, for which Donald Mackay of Vermilye Co. contracted to pay $725,000, came up for consideration at a special meeting of the Clearing House Association yesterday. It had been referred to the Executive Committee of the association.

Judge Cowing of the Court of General Sessions gave those liquor dealers who still defy the law a severe shock yesterday. He placed himself on record as intending to uphold the Police Board in enforcing the laws as they appear on the statute books at present, and gave warning that no mercy is to be expected in his court for willful excise violations.

The second day's races of the New-York Steeplechase Association, run over the grounds of the Westchester Racing Association yesterday, were decidedly tame. One of the races proved to be a walk-over, and two of them had but two starters. The jumpers were in good form again, as on the opening day, and able to go the course, not a tumble occurring in the steeplechases.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- Mr. Dixon Kemp, the yachting authority and editor of The Racing Calendar and Review, through whom both of the recently cabled Dunraven interviews were furnished to The United Press and by the London manager of the association accepted as authentic, had written to The United Press the following note under to-day's date:

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 23. -- Forest fires are still sweeping across Kewaunee and Ahnapee Counties and part of Brown County, between Green Bay and Lake Michigan, the burning district extending over a territory thirty to fifty miles long and ten to twenty miles in width. West and southwest of this city a large territory is also in flames. The wind is blowing a gale from the south, and fires are spreading in all directions.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Oct. 23. -- The unveiling of the monument to the late Sir John Macdonald took place here to-day. The weather was clear and crisp, the sun shining brightly, and the audience was very large, people coming from all parts of the country.

Democrats of the regular organization in Brooklyn are becoming more and more disgusted with the activity which ex-Register Hugh McLaughlin is displaying in behalf of the canvass of Edward M. Grout for Mayor. Because of this feeling many regular Democrats have abandoned their organization and have gone over to the independents.

Enthusiasm as vehement as it was sincere was the feature of the great mass meeting of Democrats held last night in the Cooper Institute. Had the hall been four times as big it would not have accommodated the vast crowds that tried to enter.

Senator Sherman's "Recollections," which he has just embodied in book form, are causing some angry discussion in New-York, especially the parts of the book which deal with the nomination of Gen. Garfield for the Presidency at the convention held in Chicago in 1880, and with the position of Roscoe Conkling in the campaign which followed.

The big "bosses" of the Republican Party met in this city yesterday and discussed National politics. A call was issued for a meeting of the National Republican Committee, to be held Dec. 10. At that meeting it will be determined where and when the next Republican Convention will be held, and other matters which demand attention will be disposed of.

Charles Montagu Ward, the club man, is in trouble again. He was arrested yesterday under three indictments for forgery found against him on Monday by the Grand Jury. The complainant in the case is C. F. Wakely, Manager of the National Life Insurance Company, for which Ward solicited business.

Five railroad companies in the Vanderbilt system have formally approved the new joint traffic agreement. They are the New-York Central, the West Shore, Michigan Central, Lake Shore, and the New-York, Chicago and St. Louis, (Nickel Plate.) Regular meetings of the Directors of the companies named were held in Mr. Vanderbilt's office at the Grand Central Station yesterday, and each board authorized the affixing of the seal of its corporation to the new agreement.
In front of No. 12 Park Place is an interesting illustration of perfected safe building.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23. -- The statement of the b,iness of all lines of the Pennsylvania ilroad for September was issued to-day.

" They went up the broad stairway in the Gilsey House, turned to the right at the first landing, then went straight down a long, narrow hall, turned and went up some more stairs, and into a big room fronting on the Thirtieth Street side. That was the last I see of them. If they had the stuff with them, it was hid in their pockets. There wasn't no gripsack in sight."

There are a great many interesting things at the food show now going on at Madison Square Garden of which the public is not aware, because it does not usually connect charitable associations with an exhibit of this kind.

The New-York Civil Service Reform Association, of which Carl Schurz is President, some time ago sent letters to the Republican and Democratic candidates for State offices asking them whether in the event of their election they would give their aid in securing a faithful compliance with the terms of the present civil service law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Attorney General Harmon's first argument in the Supreme Court of the United States was made today when he opened the discussion of the case of the United States versus the State of Texas, brought to determine the question of the ownership of 1,511,576 acres of land, known as Greer County, Texas, and claimed by both parties.

There is to be a very interesting test of sentiment, or opinion, on the woman suffrage question in Massachusetts at the coming election. The Constitution of that State empowers the Legislature to extend "municipal suffrage" to women, and of course it has been besieged by the professional suffragists to exercise this power, notwithstanding the fact that comparatively few women avail themselves of the privilege accorded years ago of voting for elective school officers.

The funeral of Miss Elizabeth Clarkson Jay, daughter of the late Peter Augustus Jay, and granddaughter of Chief Justice Jay, was held in the Church of the Incarnation, at Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, yesterday.

" Aunty" Broad died in Bellevue Hospital yesterday. For over twenty years she had been a familiar figure in Mrs. Wyckoff's boarding house at 85 Washington Square. Her name was Mrs. Rebecca Broad, and according to some accounts, she was one hundred and four years old. "She came to me twenty-three years ago," said Mrs. Wyckoff, "and she must have been over eighty then."
CHXOAGO, Oct. .The earnings of the Chiua, llukee end St. Pmul Railway for week of October were $F2,06k; far the sane period ist year, $669,060, m.-Luce-se of' $1,92,99/.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The case of the United States against Jane H. Stanford, administratrix of Leland Stanford, deceased, was docketed in the United States Supreme Court to-day. The case comes up on appeal from the Circuit Court of the Northern District of California. The records in the case make two large printed volumes of over 1,000 pages.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 23. -- The sessions of the American Missionary Association were largely attended to-day. In the morning committees on Chinese and Indian mission work were appointed, and the remainder of the session was largely devoted to a review of the work done by Congregational missionaries among the Chinese and Indians.

A petition in the name of Charles A. Whelan has been presented to Attorney General Hancock, in which he is asked to institute proceedings to prevent the American Tobacco Company from doing business in this State. The petition sets forth the following in connection with the company:

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23. -- Miss Carrie Cunningham was called to the stand in the Durrant trial this morning. She testified that she was a reporter on The Examiner and had until recently acted in that capacity on The Chronicle. She had known Durrant since Aug. 18 last, and from that date until Oct. 5 had visited him daily.

A communication in the form of a petition to Mayor Strong, signed by about 100 merchants in the vicinity of Park Row and Broadway, between the bridge and Fulton Street, and asking for an abatement of the pushcart nuisance, seems to have gone astray.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 23. -- Addison Ely, counsel for Floyd W. Tompkins, Floyd W. Tompkins, Jr., and Elliot D. Tompkins of Brooklyn, to-day applied to Vice Chancellor Reed for an order restraining ex-Judge Dennis McKoon of New-York from disposing of certain lands in Bergen County, N.J.

Politicians were wondering last night whether some one had laid a trap for the Republican State candidates or had stolen them from the machine. However the result may have been brought about, an announcement was made which caused more of a sensation than anything which has happened since Warner Miller made his excise speech.

The second-class battleship Texas arrived in port last night, and anchored off Tompkinsville, S.I. She comes from the Norfolk Navy Yard, where she was built. She is to go into dry dock at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the Norfolk dry dock, in which she had been previously docked, having been found inadequate to receive her after she had been weighted with her full armament.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- The Echo says it is probable that Sir Charles Cameron Lees, Governor and Commander in Chief of British Guiana, who is now on his way home on leave of absence, will not return to South America, but will be sent to some other station and a man of greater fighting disposition sent to replace him in British Guiana.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- All silver coinage, except that of subsidiary silver, has been ordered suspended after Nov. 1 next by Secretary Carlisle. In carrying out this policy, the New-Orleans (La.) Mint will be practically closed and dismantled after that date, and its seventy employes furloughed without pay.

William F. Grote, who is the combination candidate of the State Democracy and the Republicans for the Assembly in the Sixteenth Assembly District, appeared at the State Democracy's headquarters, 28 East Twenty-third Street, yesterday afternoon and was warmly welcomed by the astute man who is in charge of the headquarters.

The last ten years have been a trying period for Kansas. Her crops for a majority of those years have fallen far below a fair average yield. In two instances there have been almost complete failures of crops. The boom has come and gone, leaving behind it a trail of failures and broken confidence.

Judging by the inquiries sent to legislative candidates by the "liberal Sunday" people, the changes which they are going to demand in the existing laws are really too modest. They will be content, it seems, if the saloons are open on Sunday from 6 to 10 A.M., and from 1 to 12 P.M. That is only fifteen hours.
HAVANA, Oct. 23. -- A band of rebels to-day attacked and set fire to the station at Hato Nuevo, in the province of Matanzas. Several houses were burned.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 23. -- The most successful convention ever held by the Woman's Christian Temperance Union, and in many respects the most important ever held by women in any age or in any country, had a brilliant closing to-night.
Street-Cleaning Commissioner Waring made answer yesterday to the statements made by Controller Fitch before the Board of Estimate, on Tuesday, regarding his department.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 23. -- An interesting case involving the value of a copyright has just been decided by Judge Colt, in the United States Circuit Court for the District of Massachusetts. The William B. Dana Company are the publishers of The Commercial and Financial Chronicle and of four other publications, issued in connection therewith, namely, The State and City Supplement, The Street Railway Supplement, The Investors' Supplement, and The Quotation Supplement.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- Charles H. Van Wyck, ex-United States Senator from Nebraska, is suffering from a stroke of paralysis. He was stricken on Monday afternoon, and lies at his hotel in a stupor.

Superintendent Stevenson Constable of the Building Department created a small sensation yesterday when he called on Mayor Strong and threatened to resign his office unless the Board of Estimate and Apportionment would allow him a large increase in his salary list.

" People wonder how 'Pittsburg Phil' gets his money, do they?" said a race-track frequenter. "I know Phil weil, and one 'off day' -- that is, when there was no racing on the Lig tracks around New-York -- there was a party of us went down to play Brighton Beach. There was no anti-bookmaking law then.

Paderewski is in New-York again, and music lovers are glad. He arrived yesterday on the White Star steamship Teutonic, and will be heard on the evening of Nov. 4 at Carnegie Music Hall. He appears to be in excellent health.

Henry of Navarre, generally conceded to be the best horse in America, yesterday won the right to go to England and try conclusions with the best there. It was done in a race of a mile and three-quarters, run over the track of the Westchester Racing Association. In that race he defeated Rey el Santa Anita and Clifford considered the two best horses in the country aside from Henry of Navarre, with consummate ease.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- President Cleveland and party returned to-night from the Atlanta (Ga.) exposition, arriving here at 8:12 o'clock, eighteen minutes ahead of schedule time. The President led the party, after alighting from the train, through the Pennsylvania Railroad Station to the sidewalk. where carriages were waiting to convey them to their homes.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 24. -- The movement to have the next Republican National Convention held in San Francisco has assumed tangible form, and the entire Pacific coast is alive with the project. Men of capital and influence have already contributed half of the entire amount necessary to pay off the debt of the National Committee, though no particular canvass has been made.

HYDE PARK, Mass., Oct. 24. -- A tail-end collision, by which two persons were fatally hurt, three or four seriously injured, and some twenty others more or less bruised, occurred directly in front of the Hyde Park Station of the Providence Division of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, about 5:30 P.M. to-day.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan was in Chicago yesterday on his way from St. Paul to New-York. Mr. Morgan said that it was not his desire to discuss the new agreement, or Senator Chandler's attacks upon the same. The agreement was framed for the purpose of maintaining rates, and no infractions of the Inter-State commerce laws was contemplated.

Joy reigned at Republican headquarters yesterday, for it was "boodle" day. The Committee of Fifty proved to be far less hard-hearted than "Fred" Gibbs, George Reisenweber, Cornelius Van Cott, and others had predicted, and the hope which Amasa Thornton held out two days ago, when he said, "They'll pay to our pot," was changed to rich fruition.

Anthony Comstock of the Society for the Suppression of Vice and George Oram visited Brooklyn last evening and made a raid, aided by three Brooklyn detectives, on persons who were, it is alleged, conducting a bicycle lottery.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- An exhibition quite unique to most Philadelphians will be opened at the gallery of the Art Club, on Chestnut Street, to-morrow night, with a reception and music by the Hungarian Band of New-York. There will be shown a comprehensive collection of drawings and paintings by the leading illustrators of the day among our American artists, and, besides, several foreigners will be included.
The Town and Country Club, another new club for women, opened under very pleasant auspices in the headquarters, 12 East Twenty-second Street, yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 24. -- The best pacing contest ever witnessed in New-England was completed at the Saugus Track to-day, when Paul won the 2:08 pace left over from yesterday. Paul was full of pace, and never lifted his nose in the two miles. Both he and Mascot, Jr., were too fast for Barney, who showed a quitting streak.

The performance yesterday of a Special train from Chicago to Buffalo is the most striking and remarkable exhibition of railroad speed that has ever been given. It is so, in the first place, because the train covered a longer distance than had been covered before by a train directed at "the record."

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 24. -- The breast of every loyal Hackensackite swelled with pride this morning when it was reported that one of the citizens had shed the blood of the bold, bad burglar who has been robbing the houses of the wealthy residents, despite the efforts of the Chief and the Captain of police, and the special watchmen and detectives.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Many cases of diphtheria, malaria, and kindred diseases have been, within the last few weeks, active in New-Rochelle, and there have been fears of an outbreak of typhoid fever. During the same space of time there has been a war between the Board of Health of the village and the Board of Education.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 24 -- Delegates from towns and cities along the Ohio River held a convention in Cincinnati the other day. They agreed that navigation conditions were most unsatisfactory, and that something should be done to better them. Though none of the visitors was a stranger to the Ohio's attenuated appearance, one of the steamboat companies invited them to spend an afternoon in cruising about near the city.

At a large meeting of the West Side Republican Club in its house, 102 West Eighty-second Street, last night, Mayor Strong told the reasons that governed him in his appointments, and incidentally said that he removed Messrs. Murray and Kerwin from the Police Board after having prayed for light. The light, he said, came to him at 4 A.M.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- This week's bulletin of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen contains the following items of interest:

Park Commissioner Squier Brooklyn, who has purchased a great deal of property for new parks in that city, and one large tract of land in Queens County for a park, is at present paying his attention to the purchase of valuable lands for the proposed shore driveway.

Mrs. Rorer had an audience and a subject after her own heart yesterday in her first evening lecture at the Madison Square Garden. It was the night for the lecture upon clubmen's dainties -- terrapin, oysters, and chops -- and men were particularly invited to be present.

Unless the General Term of the Supreme Court annuls a decision handed down yesterday by Judge Fitzgerald in the Court of General Sessions, Sheriff Tamsen will have to stand trial for the escape of the Post Office robbers from Ludlow Street Jail on July 4. Judge Fitzgerald overruled the demurrer entered by the Sheriff to one of the indictments found against him in connection with the escape.

Nothing could be more unfair -- in fact, nothing could be more absurd -- than to judge either the record or the financial needs of the Street Cleaning Department by a comparison of the quantity of dirt and refuse carted from the city streets in different years and parts of years and the cost of collecting and disposing of the quantities compared, even supposing that they are correctly stated.

Street Cleaning Commissioner Waring's statement, published yesterday, that Controller Fitch's comparative table as to the cost per cubic yard for the removal of material by him and his predecessors "is of no value, so far as the earlier years are concerned, and only probably approximate for the latter years," was disputed yesterday by Antonio Rasines of 88 Gold Street.

The ratification meeting of the State Democracy, held at Cooper Union last night, drew a crowd that filled the building to the doors. The rear of the stage and speakers' table were tastefully draped with the Stars and Stripes, and the pillars nearest the stage were entwined with the National colors. One woman had a place on the platform.

We commend to the consideration of certain McKinley journals and statesmen a little transaction completed last week and involving the investment of more than $7,500,000 in an American industry the products of which were put on the free list by the Democratic Party last year.

SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 24. -- About 400 persons representative of the society of Summit and vicinity gathered in the spacious and handsome music hall of the Hotel Beechwood to-night to witness the exhibition of Mrs. Jarley's wax works for the benefit of the Fresh Air and Convalescent Home, the great charitable institution of this locality.

ALBANY. N.Y., Oct. 24. -- Gov. Morton today received word from ex-Congressman Weaver of Plattsburg, who, with ex-Sheriff While of Clinton County, filed charges with the Governor, asking for the removal of Gen. Austin Lathrop, the Superintendent of State Prisons, stating that he would have twenty-five or thirty witnesses to be examined orally.

Wheelmen will figure more in politics in the present campaign than has ever been the case before. United they make a most formidable party. Their leaders realize this, too, and are making their plans accordingly. The Good Roads Association of Brooklyn, composed largely of cyclists, has taken a step that is likely to bring the candidates for office to curry favor with the riders of the silent steed.
WALDRON, Mo., Oct. 24. -- The Denver-St. Louis fast express on the Burlington Road was wrecked here at 7:30 o'clock this evening, and ten persons were hurt, two of them seriously. The injured are:

A convincing proof that the Constantinople riots were premeditated and organized by the Armenian revolutionary committees is to be found in the fact that Armenian newspapers, published out of Turkey announced a few weeks before the occurrence of said riots that they would take place at Constantinople.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- The Lighthouse Board will construct another composite light vessel, No. 67. Bids have been called for, to be opened Nov. 8. The ship will be 112 feet in length, with a breadth of 28 feet and 6 inches, and a depth of hold of 13 feet. The ship will have a steel frame with steel-plate keel and steel beams.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 24. -- The annual convention of the New-Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs was opened in the Belleville Avenue Church to-day, and will be continued to-morrow. Delegates from the various women's clubs throughout the State, whose objects are to promote social, literary, artistic, and scientific culture, were present.

In response to Mayor Schieren's request for a statement concerning the financial condition of the city, Controller Palmer yesterday sent a detailed report to the Mayor. It covers every fund over which the Controller has jurisdiction.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- There is a desperate condition confronting the Naval Engineer Corps, and Commodore G.W. Melville, the Engineer in Chief, has made it the subject of a pointed communication to Secretary Herbert. The situation is deemed of sufficient urgency to warrant a prompt remedy.

The meeting in this city of the Republican bosses of New-York and Pennsylvania is not really so important as either their friends or their opponents seem to think that it is. It is assumed that each will, in the next Republican National Convention, control the delegation from his State, and that if the two combine they will have such a solid body of votes with which to traffic that they can practically determine the nomination.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Commander Nicoll Ludlow, at one time in charge of the Naval War College, was examined by a board few weeks ago for promotion to the grade of Captain. The board recommended him for advancement, and Secretary Herbert approved the recommendation and passed the report on to the White House.
In a very interesting article on the evolution of the bluejacket, which is reproduced in the last issue of The United Service Gazette, (British,) Vice Admiral P.H. Colomb says:

The Manuscript Society is an association of musicians and music lovers devoted to the performance of unpublished works by American composers. A year or more ago this club seemed likely to degenerate into a close corporation of local composers who were able to find their way to the public only through the exertions of its activity.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- The Van Cortlandt Chapter, Daughters of the Revolution, of this city were honored by the President of the General Society and other officers and prominent guests at a tea this afternoon, given by Miss S. M. Westbrook, the President of the local association, in the Westbrook mansion, in Paulding Street.

Corporation Counsel Francis M. Scott, United States District Attorney Wallace Macfarlane, Gen. Asa Bird Gardiner, David Leventritt, Henry D. Hotchkiss, and George Walton Green all made arguments before Justice Beach yesterday in Supreme Court, Chambers, to prove and disprove the right of the State Democracy's rooster to a place at the head of the third column of the blanket ballot.

News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

" Sam" Devere, the minstrel, appeared as defendant before Judge Gildersleeve, in the Special Term of the Superior Court yesterday, in an action that has been brought against him by Josephine Conery Devere, in which she is trying to establish a marriage, alleged to have been entered into thirty-three years ago.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 24. -- Two hundred and fifty members of the New-England Cotton Manufacturers' Association met at the Auditorum at the exposition this morning. This is the organization's fifty-first session, and it was the first it has ever held outside the New-England States.

Senator Timothy D. Sullivan, the idol of the Bowery and a candidate for re-election, is a very busy man nowadays. A reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES went out yesterday to find him, and to learn the progress of his campaign. The Senator was seen standing in the doorway of the Comanche Club, talking with a man who very much resembled a physician.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Oct. 24. -- Town and village officials were severely scored and their methods in the conduct of the municipal affairs was roundly denounced by the speakers at an indignation meeting of citizens of this village to-night. Never before has there been such enthusiasm for reform.

That the Democratic State ticket is going to be elected this year was the fixed and firm belief of the party managers at the Democratic State Headquarters yesterday. There has been a marked change in the past few days. A week ago the party managers had hope. Now they have great confidence.

There is a possibility that either by proceedings in court or by the action of the State Board of Canvassers a vote for the Democratic State ticket under the Rooster Emblem may fail of recognition. Two members of the Board of Canvassers, the Republican Secretary of State and the Attorney General, have already declared against the right of the State Democracy to place the names of the State nominees upon their ticket.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 24. -- The crew of the steamer St. Augustine, which was burned at sea, is safe, having been picked up by the New-England and Savannah Line steamer City of Macon, Capt. Lewis, from Savannah, Ga., which arrived here this morning, Capt. John H. Gaskill, the commander of the St. Augustine, makes the following report:

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- William T. Stead, formerly editor of The Pall Mall Gazette, publishes an article in The Westminster Gazette, in which he says that England ought not to belittle the significance of the outburst of American sentiment over the Venezuelan question. The Americans, he says, have built up a navy which they have reason to be proud of, and the Monroe doctrine is now one of national faith.

Messrs. C.R. Gregor Son have sold for Oppenheimer Metzger the four lots, 420 to 426 West Twentieth Street, 100 by 109, recently bought from the Delamater estate. Mr. Livingston will erect three five-story flats on the site.

William McDonald, milkman, could have been seen in the vicinity of the Chambers Street Ferry all day yesterday. Most of the time he spent peering into the muddy water of the slip and watching the flotsam that came to the surface when the wheels of the ferryboats churned up the water. Mr. McDonald was looking for a horse and wagon and load of milkcans which he had lost in the river early in the morning.

Ex-Assemblyman Ernest H. Crosby, who introduced the High License bill in the Assembly several years ago, and is now President of the New-York Social Reform Club, of which the Rev. Dr. Rainsford, Father Ducey, Prof. Felix Adler, Edmond Kelly, Samuel Gompers, Mornay A. Williams, Prof. Giddings, and other prominent gentlemen interested in reform matters are members, made the following statement last evening:

Postmaster Dayton has received information that, by collision with a wrecked freight train, near Newport, Penn., at 2 A.M. on Thursday, 24th inst., four mail cars on the mail train on the Pennsylvania Railway, which left Jersey City at 9 P.M. on Wednesday, were destroyed by fire, with their contents.

SOUTHAMPTON, Oct. 24. -- The American Line steamer St. Louis, Capt. William G. Randle, which sailed from New-York Oct. 16 for this port, arrived here at 6 o'clock this evening in charge of the ocean tugs Ajax and Hercules, which had been sent out to meet her in response to signals.

Prof. Bemis, employed until a short time ago as a University Extension associate professor in the University of Chicago, was detached from that institution by action of the Board of Trustees. The report was circulated that his connection with the institution had been dictated by John D. Rockefeller, Mr. Yerkes, and other liberal patrons of the Chicago University.

The second series of the the tournament of nations, which is now in progress at the Knickerbocker Field Club, Flatbush, was rolled last night. The competing nations were the Turks, Indians, and English. The English proved themselves the most powerful in the first and second games over the Indians and Turks, respectively, winning both games.

When the members of the City Vigilance League come together, formally, as it were, around the public banquet table, subjects of grave municipal importance are sure to be discussed. Such was the case last night, on the occasion of the third annual dinner of the league, which was held at the St. Denis Hotel.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Oct. 24. -- It is thought here that Mrs. Delia T.S. Parnell, the mother of the late Irish agitator Charles Stewart Parnell, will leave for New-York in a few days to live there permanently. All the household effects belonging to Mrs. Parnell were sold yesterday and brought only about $500.

Charles Davis of Binghamton, who was associated with Col. Daniel S. Lamont when he was Secretary of the Democratic State Committee, was in the city yesterday. Speaking of the outlook in Broome County, he said to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES:

There was much bustle and activity at the headquarters of the German-American Citizens' Union, in the Plympton Building, Stuyvesant and Ninth Streets, yesterday, Moses Oppenheimer, who is in charge, was busy arranging for the district meetings, which will be held nightly until election.

The Advisory Committee of the Committee of Fifty held its first meeting at its headpuarters, in the Gilsey House, yesterday-Cornelius N. Bliss, J. Kennedy Tod, Elihu Root, Charles S. Fairchild, Peter B. Olney, and A.H. Steele were present.

David F. Hannigan was yesterday afternoon placed on trial for his life, before Justice Ingraham, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. The work of getting a jury at once begun. When, at 7 o'clock in the evening, the court adjourned until 10:30 o'clock this morning, only five jurors had been selected:

Matters are shaping themselves very well in Rensselaer County for the Democratic State ticket. Col. George T. Steenburg of that county was one of the callers at the Democratic State Headquarters yesterday. He said to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES:

There was a terrible racket going on in Room 110 of the Coleman House, the headquarters of the I.C.O., at 4:27 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Prolonged shouts, loud guffaws, shrieks, and yells were heard. A colored bellboy was sent post haste to see what was going on.

Much to the relief of fashionable people, the list of weddings announced for the Fall grows smaller each day as Novemger approaches. Teas and dancing lessons will come with November. According to arrangements which are now being made with caterers, the florists, and the orchestra leaders, there will be a large increase in the number of teas this Winter, and many of them will be large affairs.

A four-story brick tenement house at 317 East One Hundred and Eleventh Street, occupied by a dozen Italian families, was completely burned out last night. No lives were lost, but the tenants, many of whom had retired early, escaped in many instances by the merest chance.

The morphine habit and its fearful results were discussed at the Academy of Medicine last night, and the consensus of opinion arrived at was that the use of the drug was becoming less prevalent. Incidentally, the doctors admitted that the members of their profession were largely to blame for the victims that the drug now has.

Many are the motives of suicide, but no man ever gave a more fantastic excuse for taking his own life than the late Adolphe Receste, who killed himself because the Anarchists declined to blow him up. The singular ambition of his wayward career was to die of a bomb, and as no bomb would explode in his neighborhood, naught remained but to blow out his brains with a common pistol.

BOSTON. Oct. 24. -- The embarrassments under which the Democrats labor this year are not sufficient to prevent their making an energetic campaign. Less ardent partisans would have been dazed by an opposition plurality of 65,000 and by the adventitious circumstances which have this year combined to make the Republican candidate the especial favorite of the Democratic rank and file.
The Executive Committee of the Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers' Association of the State of New-York, at a special meeting held yesterday, at Terrace Garden, indorsed the Democratic State ticket.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 24. -- The Christian Endeavor societies of this city, the Protestant churches, and a number of organizations that are closely connected with the churches, are engaged in perfecting the arrangements for the International Convention of Christian Workers, that will be held in this city for one week, beginning Nov. 7.
The Law Committee of Tammany Hall, of which Civil Justice Daniel F. Martin is Chairman, sent the following letter to President Theodore Roosevelt of the Police Board yesterday:

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Oct. 24. -- Frightened to death by her son Edward, Mrs. Hannah Knappenberger, a widow, fifty-eight years old, of this city, died at her home last evening. The wayward young man, who is twenty-four years old, had caused his mother a great deal of anxiety of late, and yesterday's lapse on his part brought on the fatal crisis.

It may have been a political dodge, and it hardly seems likely, but he was certainly pointed out as one of "Fatty" Grote's lieutenants when a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES stepped in at the statesman's liquor store in East Houston Street yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- James M. Wilcox, who for many years was engaged in the manufacture of United States bank note paper at Glen Mills, Penn., in which business he introduced many original and useful ideas, and who later was the President of the American Cement Company, died Wednesday night at Haverford, Penn.
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday resumed in the Mayor's office the consideration of the provisional estimates of the various city departments for 1896. Mayor Strong presided.
The Good Government Club members propose to carefully investigate the registration lists on a hunt for frauds.

The Commissioner of Street Cleaning received on the 20th inst. from the Supervisor of the Harbor, Lieut. Commander DELEHANTY, a letter of considerable importance. This letter gave notice that after April 1, 1896, no permits would be issued for scows laden with garbage to dump the same either in the harbor or at sea.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 24. -- The American Missionary Association at this morning's session selected Boston as the place for holding the jubilee annual meeting next year. The Committee on Chinese work recommended that pastors of Congregational churches should pay more attention to the spiritual needs of the Chinese in America, advocated the erection of a new mission building in San Francisco, and commended the establishment of a Chinese mission at Salt Lake City.
HONOLULU, Oct. 17. -- It is twenty-nine days since the cholera epidemic ended, and fifteen days since the last one of three scattering cases.

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Oct. 24. -- An exciting run of ten miles across country after the hounds was held by the Meadowbrook Hunt Club to-day in honor of the Duke of Marlborough, who is visiting James L Kernochan. The run was over the finest hunting country on Long Island, many fences, some over five feet high, and numerous deep ditches, were jumped with comparative ease by the entire party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Lieutenant Commander Cowles, the naval attache of the United States Embassy in London, has informed the Navy Department that the Royal School of Naval Architecture at Greenwich will hereafter decline to receive any constructors of the United States Navy. No reason for this action is assigned.

A general meeting of the New-York Yacht Club was held last night, Commodore E.M. Brown presiding. The meeting was well attended and the yachtsmen talked freely of the action of Mr. Rose in withdrawing his challenge. No action, however, was taken on the matter at the meeting.
COLON, Oct. 24. -- Senior Bora, an influential native of the Isthmus of Panama, is pressing the Government to recognize the Cuban insurgents as belligerents.
The various Hebrew charitable institutions throughout the city are making preparations to hold the biggest fair that New-York has seen for many a day. It is to be known as the Educational Fair.
Commissioner Alfred T. White of the Department of City Works, Brooklyn, has made another report to Mayor Schieren regarding certain work that has been prepared in the City Works Department.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- The second day's session of the National Association of Life Underwriters was a breezy one. The question of rebates was thoroughly discussed, and the debate resulted in a victory for those who were fighting the evil.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 24. -- A great deal of chagrin has been caused in local militia circles by an ambitious new policeman named Estoragano, who appeared in the police court yesterday and swore out affidavits against the leading officers of the State militia for discharging firearms within the city limits last Sunday.

Henry L. Horton, senior member of the banking house of H.L. Horton Co., gave a dinner last evening in the Union League Club to the Duke of Marlborough, which was attended by about fifty leading business men of the city.
Mr. and Mrs. J. De Ment Thompson have returned from their Summer outing, and will entertain extensively this Winter.

Joseph Jefferson was the guest of honor at the reunion of the Associate Alumnae of the Normal College, in the college chapel, yesterday afternoon, and the members, dating from last year back to the days of the college's first graduating class, received him with all the ingenuous enthusiasm of the matinee girl and her favorite actor.
Reporting the wool market for the week, The Textile Manufacturers' Journal will say in to-day's issue:
Mr. Wurster has assured the people of Brooklyn that if elected to the office of Mayor he will continue the policy of Mayor Schieren.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 25. -- The Educational Congress of the exposition was opened in the auditorium at the exposition grounds this morning by the National Educational Association. Among those present were Prof. Newton C. Dougherty of Peoria. Ill., President of the National Educational Association; President William R. Harper of the University of Chicago, Commissioner W.T. Harris of Washington, A.E. Winship of Boston, and Charles A. Skinner, Superintendent of New-York State Schools.

There was a jolly party at Thumann's alleys, 98 Gansevoort Street, last night, when the second series of three games was bowled in the tournament of the Bank Clerks' League. The competing teams were from the National Park Bank, Bank of America, and Continental National Bank. The latter had the weakest team of the three, and was beaten in both games.

Secretary of State Palmer, the Republican candidate for re-election, was the only one of the State candidates who came to the front at the State Club's mass meeting, in Cooper Union, last night. It had been advertised that all the candidates would be there. After this notice had been promulgated, the fact was made prominent in various parts of the State that this was to be an anti-Platt meeting.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 25. -- Chauncey M. Depew was interviewed last evening at the St. Nicholas Hotel on Senator Sherman's book. In reply to a question, he said that he had not seen the book and did not want to say much before reading it.
Strong pressure has been brought to bear to induce the convention of the Good Government Clubs to withdraw its ticket, and efforts have been made to induce the candidates to decline.

Col. George Wilson, Secretary of the Chamber of Commerce, recently wrote to George Haven Putnam, who is a member of the Committee of Fifty, asking his position as regards the fusion ticket, and Mr. Putnam made this reply:
" You have been wounded several times, General. How does it feel to be shot?"

The loan exhibition of portraits for the benefit of St John's Guild and the Orthopoedic Hospital will open at the National Academy of Design next Wednesday. The opening day will be in a sense a society reunion, and the attendance of fashionable people will undoubtedly be large. The price for tickets for that day will be $3.
The Co-operato, a self-supporting home for respectable women, situated at 301 West Eighteenth Street, was the beneficiary at the "high tea" at the Madison Square Garden last evening.

-- There is a triangular fight for member of Assembly in the First District of Queens County. The district, under the new apportionment, is composed of Long Island City and Newtown. There are two Democrats and one Republican in the race. Former Assemblyman James Robinson is the candidate of the Gleason Democracy, Jacob Stahl, an undertaker, is the nominee of the Jefferson faction, and Charles Beckel is the Republican candidate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The Daily Chronicle of Sept. 27, a newspaper published at Georgetown, Demerara, containing the full text of the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain's letter to the Governor of British Guiana, was received here to-day. The salient points of the letter appeared in the London dispatches of The United Press a week ago.

The Police Board decided yesterday, after a long consultation at Headquarters, to order the Martin B. Brown Company to begin the printing of the city election ballots with the rooster emblem and a full State and county ticket in the third column, and with the Good Government local ticket in the last column but one of the official ballot. The Republicans will contest this action, so far as the Democratic State ticket is concerned.

Before Jacob went to sea and was miscalled Yawcob by sailormen, he dwelt in dark woods, capered up jungle trees, and swayed vaingloriously from jungle boughs. Jacob had two unornamental twin brothers then, and two unseemly parents. But the graceless quintet knew aught of vanity; the three younger blemishes never thought of their appearance, and the matron never inquired if her tail was on straight.
DENVER, Col., Oct. 25. -- According to a dispatch from Washington to a local paper, Senator Teller speaks out plainly about Presidential candidates and the campaign.

More evidence in the dredging job at the American Line pier during the regime of the former Dock Commissioners was brought out yesterday in the continued investigation by Commissioners of Accounts Seth Sprague Terry and Rodney S. Dennis. The dredging at this pier was done by the Morrison Cummings Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Prince Cantacuzene, who has represented the Russian Government at Washington for three years, left to-day for New-York. He will sail on the French steamer to-morrow for Havre. On his arrival in France he will proceed at once to St. Petersburg, where he will remain until Spring.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The most talked of incident in the Navy Department to-day was the remarkable case of Commander Ludlow, who has lost his promotion to the grade of Captain as a result of unsubstantiated charges he made against Lieut. Commander Sperry of the New-York Navy Yard, and which nearly cost the latter officer his privilege of advancement.

Frederick W. Wurster, who heads the Republican city ticket in Brooklyn, is the only candidate for Mayor who has not condemned the bridge management. He indorses all the mistakes of the Schieren administration, including the action of Mr. Schieren last Summer in voting to retain James Howell at the head of the bridge administration.
The Board of Estimate and Apportionment considered at its session yesterday the estimates for charitable institutions.

Acting Captain Walter L. Thompson of the Oak Street police has received many complaints lately of daylight burglaries which have been committed in his precinct. About ten days ago he detailed Policeman Charles A. Schultz to catch the burglars. As a result of the policeman's good work Capt. Thompson, and Policeman Schultz, with Detectives McCrory and Barlow, last night raided a gang of "crap shooters," who were gambling in the basement of the Pulitzer Building.

The Commissioners of the new East River bridge will hold a meeting next Wednesday, when the Presidents of the various railroad companies in Brooklyn will tell what terminal facilities they shall want at the Brooklyn station of the bridge.
ALBANY, Oct. 25. -- Gov. Morton to-day granted a pardon to Mrs. Mary O'Hearn of New-York City. She was, on Sept. 11, convicted in the Court of Special Sessions of violating the excise law.

For the fourth time in the last six weeks a fire occurred at midnight Thursday in the basement of the five-story brick tenement at 545 East One Hundred and Forty-third Street, occupied by 108 tenants.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25. -- The case of J.C. Davis, who was charged with cheating jewelry firms a few months ago by drafts, has been set for trial Nov. 7. The chances now are that Davis will not be convicted, owing to the suicide of Detective Coffey, to whom he made a statement after his arrest.

Edward Denechaud, a restaurant keeper, of 51 Columbus Avenue, was arraigned before Magistrate Brann, in the Yorkville Police Court, late yesterday afternoon, on a charge of illegally selling a drink of whisky to Policeman Gannon of the West Sixty-eighth Street Station last Sunday morning.

" I am sorry to give you skim milk when you expected pie," said John Brooks Leavitt to the crowded and expectant audience that assembled last night in Arlington Hall, under the auspices of the Good Government Club of the Fourteenth Assembly District, to hear the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst "pay his respects" to Alexander S. Williams, the regular Republican and State Democracy nominee for the State Senate in the Twelfth Senatorial District.
Samuel Lewis, eight years old, the son of a Lewis Street tailor, was thrown from a horse at Stanton and Lewis Streets last night, and the animal stepped on his right hand, fracturing the wrist.
Ex-Secretary FAIRCHILD made a brief but powerful appeal for the Democratic State ticket at the meeting of the State Democrats on Thursday. He said:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 25. -- Miss Marie Wainwright and company gave at the new Grand Opera House to-night the first presentation of "His Puritan Wife," a play by Florence Schaffel, founded on New-York society life. The plot deals almost entirely with that class of society which is supposed to have little if any regard for the conventionalities of life.

It is difficult to overestimate the importance of the news from the far East. There seems to be no doubt that the Russians have ordered the Japanese out of Corea and have made preparations to enforce the order. The dispatch to The London Times from Hongkong seems to be equally authentic and is even more disquieting.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Two men were found dead on the tracks of the Pennsylvania Railroad near the Hackensack Meadows shops at 7:20 o'clock this evening. It is not known how they were killed, but it is believed they were struck by a train going west, because no report of any accident has been received at the company's offices here.

MATAWAN, Oct. 25. -- Smith Davis of Englishtown and Miss Mary Pyne of Richmond, Va., both colored, have been sweethearts for a long time. They decided to get married, coming to the church here today with that purpose in view. The Rev. Edward Elliott, the pastor, was notified, and put on his best clothes to perform the ceremony.

The falling off in registration in the district bounded by Fourteenth Street, Seventh Avenue, Forty-second Street, and Fourth Avenue, is causing the fusion leaders and the Committee of Fifty to abate somewhat the strength of their assertions that their ticket will be elected.
Two more jurors were obtained yesterday in the trial of David F. Hannigan for murder in shooting Soloman H. Mann, the betrayer of his sister, Loretta Hannigan.

Asiatic cholera has been stamped out in Honolulu by the health authorities, and the prevalence of the disease there is no longer to be feared by the people of San Francisco or other cities on our Pacific coast. It was by no means an easy matter to prevent a general epidemic, owing to the ignorance of the natives and of the Chinese and Japanese immigrants, and their opposition to the enforcement of sanitary laws.

Aside from the arrest of Col. S.B. Lawrence, President of the Westchester Racing Association, nothing new developed yesterday in Peter De Lacy's little war of personal revenge on the gentlemen who are giving a race meeting at the Westchester track.

KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 25. -- News received here to-day states that Gen. Maceo has by forced marches reached the province of Matanzas, and that last Monday, with 3,000 Cubans, he engaged a cavalry force of 2,800 Spaniards in the San Juan Valley.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 25. -- The recent attempts in this country to break railroad records have awakened more than a passing interest on Long Island because of the flier Austin Corbin sent over the rails of the Long Island Railroad between this city and Amagansett yesterday. Despite the time made on other roads, Mr. Corbin holds that his line can run trains as fast as any road in the country.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- The Young Men's Christian Association of the First District began a three days' convention this afternoon in Association Hall. A General Secretarys' and Physical Directors' Conference was held at 3:30. Addresses were delivered by General Secretary R.R. McBurney of New-York, and David McConaughy, the General Secretary of India.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Adjt. Gen. and Mrs. Edwin A. McAlpin, who live in this village, will celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of their wedding in Hillside, their charming home here, next Tuesday evening.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 25. -- The robberies committed in the Meadowbrook Hunt Clubhouse during the golf games and hunt last Saturday have turned out to be more serious than was at first reported. The members of the club have endeavored to hush the matter up, and have employed four detectives, with the hope of recovering the stolen property.

There will be racing at Morris Park as usual this afternoon, and, as usual, the racing will be conducted wholly within the provisions of the law regulating and governing the sport.
