No interference with the sport is expected unless Peter De Lacy shall be able to further use the courts and the Police Department for the purpose of satisfying his personal revenge.

That stout statesman, Charles W. Hackett, who is Chairman of Mr. Platt's Republican State Committee, has been averring in his sleepless moments that Mr. Platt's ticket would carry the State by anywhere from 40,000 to 50,000 plurality.

C.D. Gilson of Indian Lake, Hamilton County, who has but recently recovered from wounds received in an encounter with a bear, in which, however, Mr. Gilson came out first best, narrates an interesting story of the fight.

An unusually interesting meeting of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs was held last evening at the Columbia, in East Fourteenth Street. Eighteen clubs were represented. Chief Consul Robert M. Gentle of New-Jersey sprang a pleasant surprise on delegates by announcing a plan which, if carried out on the lines suggested, will result in giving to the association the country clubhouse so long desired.

A.E. Brooks of this city has recently added to his museum of arms and war relics two fine specimens of oak stumps from the battlefield of Chickamauga. The larger is about 9 feet long and from 14 to 16 inches in diameter, showing on its surface a gnarled and uneven front, caused by the growth of the wood over bullets, grapeshot, and pieces of shell.

This is not a bad little book, and gets through the difficult task of laying a wreath of words at the feet of one who has been honored by the purest intellects of the time. Prof. Raleigh brings out the essence of Stevenson's literary character in a very creditable manner, although he throws no new light upon it.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 25. -- At the annual meeting of the Great Northern Railway Company this afternoon Henry W. Cannon of New-York was elected a new member of the Directorate of nine. Sir Donald A. Smith of Montreal and Jacob H. Schiff of New-York were re-elected Directors. One hundred and ninety-four thousand shares were represented.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Oct. 25. -- The National bicycle circuit meet at the Hot Springs track, in this city, to day, was a success. In the one-third-mile race. "Tom" Cooper went after Wells, who had made his usual run, and caught him. Murphy fought close to Cooper, and Bald was held in by some of the local men in the race.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 25. -- Senator David B. Hill lectured before a large audience in University Hall to-night, his subject being "Old Landmarks."

ALBANY, Oct. 25. -- The appeal was argued in the Court of Appeals to-day in the suit brought by James J. Belden of Syracuse, who owns fifty bonds of $1,000 each in the Columbus, Hocking Valley and Toledo Railway Company, to compel the defendant, Stevenson Burke and certain others associated with him, to pay $8,000,000 and interest to the railway company for the benefit of the bondholders.

The proposition made by School Commissioner Strauss to extend the noon recess of the schools to an hour and a half, and close the schools at 3:30 instead of 3 P.M., has caused considerable discussion. In regard to the invitation of the Commissioners to parents to send letters expressing their opinion, Clerk McMullin of the board said yesterday:

After twenty minutes' deliberation, a jury yesterday found Dr. Orlando E. Bradford guilty of having in his possession two metal plates for printing counterfeit one-hundred-dollar bills. John Nixon, who was tried jointly with Dr. Bradford on the same charge, was exonerated and discharged from custody.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 25. -- Joseph Trepannia, a coachman in the employ of Sherman D. Porter of this city, was shot by a burglar at Mr. Porter's residence, 51 Federal Street, to-night. Mr. Porter discovered the man on the second floor veranda, attempting to get into one of the windows, and called his coachman, and together they attempted to capture the fellow.

The appearance of the Taylor brothers of Tennessee -- ex-Gov. Bob and ex-Congressman Alf -- at the Savannah Theatre last night was an event that will long be remembered by those who were fortunate enough to hear their original and inimitable "Yankee Doodle and Dixie."

Smith M. Weed's enterprise, the San Domingo Improvement Company, which acts as general guardian for that republic, collecting its revenues, paying its expenses, and taking chances on a surplus or deficit, is preparing an application to list a series of San Domingo bonds, known as reclamation consols, at the Consolidated Exchange.

Assistant District Attorney Robert Townsend, who was arrested Thursday night, charged with having insulted Miss Mary Malten of 230 West Twenty-ninth Street, and her two companions, was discharged yesterday by Magistrate Wentworth in the Jefferson Market Police Court, as Miss Malten failed to appear to press the charge.
TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 25. -- The publishers and booksellers of this section gave a dinner to-night at the National Club to Hall Caine of England.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 25. -- The time for the filing of regular nominations in New- Jersey will expire to-morrow. In all the counties the tickets which will appear in the election next November have been made up, although all of the acceptances have not been filed. The Essex County Democrats will not file their Assembly nominations until to-morrow.

The Committee of Fifty has prepared a circular entitled, "What Municipal Reform Has Done and Will Do for You." It is a brief summary of what has been accomplished by the present municipal administration. Several hundred thousand copies, printed in English, German, and Italian, will be distributed.

Police Commissioner Roosevelt and the Rev. Thomas J. Ducey addressed a very large audience last evening in the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, in West Forty-eighth Street, near Broadway. The meeting was arranged by the Wesleyan League, the Young People's Association, of which Arthur M. King, son of the Rev. Dr. James M. King, pastor of the church, is President.

It was bound happen just as sure as night follows day. What was once the most restful, quiet, soporific place in this city is now the resort of a noisy, clamoring, turbulent crowd. Shrewd politicians might have foreseen the result, and, as the Stecklers come under that heading, it was very likely a carefully planned scheme to catch the voters when they put those folding beds into the I.C.O. headquarters, Room 110 Coleman House.

Los ANGELES, Cal., Oct. 25. -- Lieut. Gov. Millard died at 11:55 o'clock last night. He passed a quiet day up to 5 o'clock, when a decided change for the worse appeared. Mr. Millard was conscious up to the time of his death. As the end drew near he seemed to realize his condition, and became most solicitous in attention to his devoted wife.

A warm discussion was called forth at Mrs. Rorer's lecture yesterday afternoon by her refusal to admit that green vegetables should be soaked in salted water before cooking. The subject was Brussels sprouts, cauliflower, and spinach.

There is another example of the confusion of ideas, which seems to have become so common just now, in the remarks of. Mr. ERNEST H. CROSBY on the Sunday excise law which we printed yesterday. Because he considers the Sunday closing provision "unwise" and its strict enforcement productive of more harm than good, he does not "sympathize" with the policy of enforcing it.

The Field Trial Committee of the National Beagle Club of America, at a meeting in the rooms of the American Kennel Club, 55 Liberty Street, received the following entries for the sixth annual field trials, to be held at Hempstead, L.I., during the week commencing Nov. 11:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The Venezuelan yellow book for 1894 which has been received here, contains two letters of special interest at the present time, in view of the situation between Great Britain and Venezuela. Both of these concern the Uruan incident, which in the yellow book is called the "incident on the right bank of the Cuyuni."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 25. -- Gov. Altgeld has not received any communication from the Navy Department at Washington asking if the State authorities have sold the brick model of the battleship Illinois, which was one of the attractive features of the World's Columbian Exposition.

Messrs. M. Hess have sold for Philip Weinberg and Louis Clark, Jr., to Albert Jeske, at $285,000, the six-story semi-fireproof business building 828 Broadway, 25 by 120, and the connecting property at 63 East Twelfth Street, 27 by 108.

The friends of honest government gathered in large numbers last night at the Grand Central Palace, to listen to addresses on that subject by Dr. Parkhurst and Police Commissioners Roosevelt and Parker. Every seat in the large hall was occupied long before the meeting opened, and the galleries were filled by ladies and their escorts.

The Anti-Gambling League very possibly comprehends in its membership some worthy and conscientious citizens. When they discover to what base uses their interest in religion and morality has been put, it is to be presumed that they will seek some other channel for the manifestation of that interest.
Brooklyn politicians were somewhat surprised at the result of the registration yesterday. There had been a big falling off in the first two days this year, compared with the same days of last year.

If judicial effort and good-will can bring the Simons, husband and wife, together again, they ought certainly to become reconciled some time in the future. Judge McAdam, in the Superior Court, spent the best part of a week some months ago in an endeavor to bring about a reunion, and yesterday Judge Gildersleeve, in the same court, tried his hand at the task.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 25. -- Dust is not permitted to settle on anything around the headquarters of Candidate Gleason, who expects to be the next Mayor of this city. "Activity and plenty of battleaxes" is the motto there.

ALBANY, Oct. 25. -- The fish and game protectors have their hands full just now in watching mysterious and suspicious packages which are offered to express and transportation companies. These packages oftentimes contain game which has been killed out of season, and their ultimate destination, in most cases, is New-York City.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 25. -- The members of the New-York Press Association were much at home to-day at the formal house-warming of New-York's handsome State building. The New-York State Building has been open ever since the exposition began, but not until to-day was it opened formally. One hundred editors from the Empire State and a large party from the National Editorial Association were the guests of the New-York Commissioners.

Mrs. Sarah Sigalore became hysterical yesterday in the Special Term room of the Superior Court, when her daughter was taken from her by force. She followed the girl, screaming at the top of her voice, and finally fell to the floor in a faint. An ambulance call was sent out, but before the ambulance arrived the woman had been restored and her friends took her home.

Central Office Detectives Clark and Butler arrested two professional thieves in the Bowery on Tuesday morning, and the capture gave the literary bureau at Police Headquarters another opportunity to contrast what is termed Byrnes's methods with those of Acting Capt. O'Brien, to the great exaltation of the latter, who really had nothing to do with the arrests.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- In a cablegram from Minister Terrell, dated at Constantinople to-day, and addressed to Senator Mills and Congressman Sayres, A.W. Terrell makes the following statement:

AMHERST, Mass, Oct. 26 -- Amherst won from Massachusetts Institute of Technology to-day by a score of 20 to 4. A close and exciting game was looked for, as Amherst and "Tech" have always been pretty evenly matched in football. In the first half, Amhert played a loose game, allowing "Tech" to score, but in the second half Amherst played her best game of the year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- The boilers of the tug Morford exploded at 3:55 o'clock this morning while the vessel was in the river near Seventeenth Street. The tug O.B. Green was also wrecked by the explosion.
Prof. C.J. Owens of the Orangeburg Collegiate Institute writes us of his travels in its interests:

I cannot remember a time when I did not dislike Lemuel Welles. As a playmate, he was boastful, cocksure, and arrogant; as a fellow-student at the university and an associate in the medical faculty of the metropolis, he remained boastful, cocksure, and arrogant still. Our paths, however, did not run on a parallel.

Contrary to general expectation, the famous Crailo manor house is not to be demolished. This will be extremely interesting news to many people throughout the United States, but more particularly those of Eastern New-York. The historical old place stands in one of the picturesque streets of sleepy Greenbush, just across the Hudson River from Albany.

No better evidence that the tide in Brooklyn is setting strongly toward Edward M. Shepard is needed than the fact that J. Edward Swanstrom, President of the Board of Education, has come out openly in favor of the reform Democratic ticket.

The horse-show entry list closed this year with about 1,300 entries, an increase of 26 over last year. This is the largest number ever made, the highest previous record being 1,291, in 1890. The 114 classes of last year were increased to 121 classes this year, some of the old ones having been withdrawn, and new ones substituted and added.

General Headquarters at Albany, it is understood, will shortly issue orders adopting the new drill manual prescribed for the United States Army for the Krag-Jorgensen rifle. The matter is now being considered, and some modifications of the manual will be made. This will mainly be in the loadings and firings which in the army manual are prescribed for a magazine gun.

In one of the Broadway cars, yesterday, was a little boy, perhaps seven years old. He was accompanied by the regular number of parents, and from the assortment of citified handbags and countrified baskets which the party carried it was evident that they had just returned from a somewhat lengthy stay amid scenes more peaceful than those offered by the street through which they were passing.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

In a small room of Dodd, Mead Co.'s shop, in cases, like jewels in coffers, one may see the Pope books. They are a rare gift, of graceful lines and vivid colors to the eyes; they are an excellent education to the mind in an hour. There are libraries which are the silvery foam at the edge of the ocean.

All those who remember the struggles of their early school days in trying to master the intricacies and inconsistencies of the spelling of English words will be interested in the efforts of the American and English philologists to establish a more rational system.
SUMMIT, N.J., Oct. 26. -- A pleasant dinner and a dance were enjoyed at the Hotel Beechwood to-night by the members of the Bon-Ton Bicycle Club and their friends.

WATERBURY Conn., Oct. 26. -- The corrupt practices act, which was passed by the last General Assembly, was subjected to its first practical test at the local elections, which took place throughout the State the other day. This new venture in legislation in a State which, owing to the evenly balanced political conditions, has been notorious for extravagant campaign expenditures, is just now attracting general attention.

A number of horses in training, the property of J.R. F.P. Keene and other owners, were disposed of at auction at the Morris Park track yesterday. Hornpipe, the winner of this year's Brooklyn Handicap, brought the top price of the sale. He was secured by J. McCormack for $3,500. Good prices were realized for the Keene lot, the seven head averaging $1,718 each.

A comparison of the sales recently reported by real estate brokers seems to indicate activity only among a small class of buyers. This class includes the larger investors and speculators, or speculative builders. The amounts involved are also large, the transactions ranging from $100,000 upward. Pending negotiations, of which there are very many are also for pieces of expensive property.

The Woman's Christian Temperance Union is soon to have a National home for its wornout workers in the childhood home of Miss Frances E. Willard, the society's President. Friends of the union are now preparing a deed of transfer of Forest Home, where Miss Willard lived until she was nineteen years old, situated on the banks of the Rock River, and adjoining Janesville, Wis., a town of about 15,000 inhabitants.

People up Tuxedo way, over on Long Island, down in New-Jersey up at Westchester, and at the various country houses along the banks of the Hudson, are discussing the coming marriage of Miss Consuelo Vanderbilt to the Duke of Marlborrough. The discussion, however, amounts to little, for the arrangements for the marriage are known only to Mrs. W.K. Vanderbilt, her daughter, and the Duke.

There was no new action taken yesterday by the Tammany Law Committee in reference to the rooster ballot controversey. Some of the braves were in favor of attempting to secure an injunction that would prevent the Martin B. Brown Company from going ahead with the printing until after Judge Beach had given his decision, but it was thought best to await the result of the Judge's action.

Without considering myself quite qualified to say what English poet of the present day should be made Poet Laureate, and being myself shut out of the race by not being English, if a poet, I should say, judging by the quality of his verse alone, pre-eminently Algernon Swinburne. Among all the ruck who are writing, it seems to me that he is the nearest approach to a poet.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 26. -- Bamberger, Bloom Co., proprietors of one of the oldest dry goods houses in Louisville, made an assignment this afternoon to the Columbia Finance and Trust Company for the benefit of all creditors. The liabilities are estimated by the firm at $1,200,000, and the assets are nominally valued at about the same amount. About $100,000 is due Louisville banks.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct. 26. -- Suffolk County politics are peculiar. Here in this good old county, men can be of opposite political opinions and still be partners. Neighbors run for office on their respective tickets, and the canvass is nearly always a most friendly one.
The problem of how to get streets which are less noisy by day and by night than those paved with granite or trap is one which is engaging the ever-increasing attention of the people of this city.

Louisa A'hmuty Nash in The Boston Transcript. I have been deeply interested in an article (copied into several journals) entitled "Story of an Author's Child," because it relates to a very dear friend of mine, so dear that I have refrained up to this time from sharing any of my memories of her with the public, but the slight inaccuracies of this "story" urge me to tell my story, too.

The Knollwood Country Club, at Elmsford, Westchester County, will hold the largest golf tournament on its course next Saturday that has ever been played there. This will be an open tournament for a handsome silver cup, the cup to be played for twice a year over the Knollwood links, until one player has won it three times, when the trophy will become that person's property.
William McShane of 114 West Forty-second Street is promised a dose of the law that will last him a lifetime.

Richard Watson Gilder, who was Chairman of the Tenement House Committee, appeared yesterday before the Reinhard Assembly committee, which is investigating "sweatshop" abuses, in the Common Council Chamber.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Gen. Craighill, the army Chief of Engineers, is engaged on a large project for the defense of Baltimore. He has recommended to the Secretary of War that a battery of heavy guns be located at North Point, on the Maryland shore, memorable as the landing place of the British, in 1812.

The finest linen, beautiful hand embroidery, real lace, and the most exquisite hand work in various materials make up that part of the trousseau of the future Duchess of Marlborough now in process of preparation.

With so many persons taking to it for reasons of health, the feeble to grow strong, the fat to get thin, and the thin to gain fat, cycling has acquired a reputation as a panacea for all manner of ailments, and it is rapidly coming to be regarded as a kind of elixir of life that is both recreative and preservative.

Mr. Maitland Armstrong of this city, who was assisted in the design of his work by his daughter, Miss Helen M. Armstrong, has just completed and sent to its destination, at Clifton, near Cincinnati, Ohio, one of the largest and most elaborate windows ever erected in any church in this country.

I noticed in your issue of yesterday something about the non-appearance of The International Magazine on the date originally chosen. To set all speculation at rest, I think it better to explain that the real cause of the postponement was a doubt with which I was suddenly confronted respecting my right to print in the way I desired Clark Russell's interesting sea, story, "The Tale of the Ten."
Miss Jennie Sherman Peters was married to Abbott Dean Granger by the Rev. Cornelius Woelfkin, pastor of the Greene Avenue Baptist Church, Brooklyn, last night.

There is something almost pathetic in the comments of the religious press on the utter failure of the various attempts it Christian union. For eight years that has been the chief topic up for discussion. Occasionally overpowered in the Presbyterian Church by the Briggs controversy and in other churches by various similar minor matters, it has at last come out into the open and had a fair field and full discussion.

It is not strange that people gaze at the shaft surmounted by the bronze figure of Stephen A. Douglas, overlooking the lake, as they pass by the spot where the remains of the electric statesman are at rest.

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- An evening with John D. Teller, the Democratic nominee for Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals, is an event of interest. The eminent jurist, usually comfortably ensconced in a great armchair, and engaged, possibly, in reading the evening papers, rises when the caller is ushered into the cozy library, and with the courtliness of manner which wins friends makes the welcome cordial.

The Tuxedo Club golf men had a busy and lively day yesterday. Two cups were played for, and there was a tie in both cases for first place. The regular tournaments took place in the morning. The ties were played off in the afternoon, when one was finished, but in the second contest the result ended again in a tie, and another attempt will be made this week to determine the winner.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 26. -- Hot Springs is getting to be a great resort for bridal couples. No less than six have been spending the last week here. A favorite excursion for them is from here to Natural Bridge and return.

Two remarkable cases of longevity were recalled recently by a conversation between several gentlemen in Athens, Ga. They were discussing the death of the Rev. George McCall, the veteran Baptist preacher, when it was authentically stated that Mr. McCall's great grandfather lived to the ripe old age of 127 years. He was a bachelor at 100 and took a notion to get married.

President Roosevelt of the Police Board talked yesterday about Edward A. Denechaud, a restaurant keeper, who was arrested for selling whisky last Sunday. Denechaud, when arraigned in Yorkville Court yesterday, claimed that Commissioner Roosevelt told him he could sell drinks with meals on Sunday.

CANANDAIGUA, Oct. 26. -- There is no Senatorial contest in the State of more general interest than that between John Raines and J. Henry Metcalf in the new Forty-second District. From the first it has been a sensational canvass, and the village of Canandaigua, where Mr. Raines resides, has been the political centre of the district.

Impressions derivable from Niagara Falls, where the grandeur of nature awes the observer, are not lessened when another element presents itself, and that is the potential factor. The rush of the waters, the magnificence of the scene, are not lost, rather increased, when we think of a power existing here the limit of which can scarce be recorded in figures, and which is some day to be turned in its entirety to man's usage.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 26. -- Arrangements are practically completed for the crowning social event of the season, which will be the marriage of Miss Ethel V. Phelps-Stokes and John Sherman Hoyt at high noon at Trinity Church next Thursday, Oct. 31. Mrs. Stokes has been very busy over the details of the affair and has been in New-York many times to make arrangements there, which are now completed.

Although the discussion excited in Republican circles by Senator SHERMAN'S memoirs has become somewhat acrimonious and has taken a wide scope, it has not yet touched directly the memorable controversy between the Senator and Gen. ALGER concerning the diversion of the votes of a large number of colored delegates from the Senator at a time when he had great need of them.

It seems to me that the terms of your invitation exclude any but one reply, and it might almost seem that they were framed expressly to exclude another. Indeed, if the appointment of the laureateship be not made exclusively according to the quality of the candidate's verse, what other standard can there be that can be anticipated before the appointment is made, or that can be respected afterward.

" A River Between" is the title of a charming little story that is to appear in the November number of a well-known New-York monthly. When it is known that it is a local story, it is not difficult to form some idea of its substance, and if a rough guess should be made that the writer was a dweller in the city across the bridge, it would not be wrong.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct- 26. -- Five thousand persons saw Harvard defeat Cornell today at football by the score of 25 to 0. In the first half Harvard failed to score. By instructions, the quarter-back, Harden, tried only certain plays, which proved, absolutely unsuccessful.The plays of Harvard during this half were directed largely at the ends, but Cornell's clever end rushers, Lyle and Tausigg, stopped every attempt to gain.

Charles F. Reiher, a dealer in braids at 432 Broome Street, who lives at Paterson, N.J., was arrested yesterday on a bench warrant charging him with being the receiver of stolen goods. He furnished ball in $1,500 and was released.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 26. -- The Princeton University men came here this afternoon with their regular 'Varsity football team and played against the Orange Athletic Club eleven, but, work as they might, could not score, although they managed to keep the pigskin in Orange territory for the most of the time during both twenty-minute halves.

It was with sympathy and affection that Mr. Sartain referred to the genius of Edgar Allen Poe, and the old magazine publisher, George Rex Graham, who died in July last in the Memorial Hospital, Orange, N.J., penniless and without friends; for it was in Graham's Magazine, at one time the leading journal in the country, that many of his best miniature engravings were published.

Over the teacups with Miss Georgia Cayvan is a pleasant thing under any circumstances, but when Miss Cayvan is just back from a long stay abroad and her vis a vis across the dainty polished board, brave with snowy diapery, delicate serres, and glittering sliver, is a newspaper woman, it is not only pleasant, but profitable as well.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 26. -- The east-bound Chicago and Grand Trunk passenger train due here at 1 o'clock this afternoon was wrecked at a culvert on the Kankakee marsh, seven miles west of here, shortly after noon. A number of people were injured. They are:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Ex-Senator Charles H. Van Wyck, who died Thursday evening in this city as the result of a stroke of paralysis, had not withdrawn long enough from public life to have lost his identity with Washington or to have faded out of the recollection of those who had been associated with him for many years at each end of the Capitol.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- [Copyright, 1895, by THE NEW YORK TIMES.] -- There seems to be no doubt that Queen Victoria is passing again through one of those phases of semi-insanity which recall that she is George III.'s granddaughter. These in the seventies were rather frequent; of late years they have recurred less often, but for six weeks now the worst of the series has been giving everybody about Balmoral much anxiety and ceaseless trouble.

One of the attractions of the Higbee ranch, near Santa Barbara, Cal., are two lusty California lions, strong as oxen, but tame as kittens. They were captured up in the San Francisquito Mountains of Ventura County. Four Santa Barbara young men -- Elmer and Charles Higbee, Henry Roberts, and Albert Pumering -- effected the capture, although the credit for the actual capture of the cubs belongs to Elmer Higbee and Mr. Pumering.

The largest cargo of silk ever brought to Tacoma arrived in the city last evening at 9 o'clock aboard the Northern Pacific steamship Victoria, Capt. Panton, from China and, Japan. The silk aboard the Victoria consists of 1,869 bales, each valued at $500; 94 cases of silk goods, and 125 bales of waste silk.

It was a dingy-looking shop as viewed from the street, for the windows looked as if they had never seen water, and the few signs within could not be read for the dirt which had gathered upon them. There was little show, and unless one peered closely into the interior he would never have discovered what kind of business might be transacted in the place.

Eliza Putnam Heaton, writing from Detroit to The St. Louis Globe-Democrat, gives the following account of an enterprising attempt to learn by personal observation, something about the methods of the log rafters on the great lakes.

The registration in this city yesterday was 47,270, making the total 281,085 for the four days. This is a falling off of 27,316 from the total registration last year, but is an increase of 15.177 over that of 1893.

The circulation of Paris newspapers is not generally known. There is only one, the Petit Journal, that, having a circulation of 1,000,000, ornaments constantly the dead walls with these figures. M. Rochefort has claimed, at different times, 160,000 readers for his diatribes, but his sheet only circulates this number in periods of great political effervescence.

The lobster had the honor of receiving all the attention of Mrs. Rorer and her audience at the Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, an honor greater than was granted Homarus vulgaris's very distinguished and aristocratic brother of the table, the terrapin.

I think it was about the Summer of 1814 or 1815 (I cannot at the moment say for a certainty which) I was sitting in my college room. I then occupied the ground floor of No. 26, and was reading The Edinburgh Annual Register, in which a very striking and beautiful account is given of the burial of Sir John Moore.

By a vote of 27 to 11, the Young Men's Democratic Club of Brooklyn last night indorsed Edward M. Grout and the entire city and county ticket of the regular Democratic organization. There were thirty-eight members present at the meeting, and a two-thirds vote was necessary for the indorsement of any candidate. The adherents of the regular Democratic organization therefore carried their point, with one vote to spare.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- To be Duke of Marlborough is, for an intelligent and ambitious young man who possesses character, self-restraint, imagination, and a sufficient fortune quite the best thing in England, if we leave the throne itself out of account. The present bearer of the title may be spoken of as having nearly all of these qualifications.
TONAWANDA, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The official test of the feasibility of towing canal boats by the trolley system took place here this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- The charter of the American Spirits Manufacturing Company to do business in Illinois was filed to-day with the County Recorder. The articles were issued by the Secretary of State Sept. 12, the day after the subscription books were closed and the Directors of the corporation elected.

LEIPSIC, Oct. 26. -- The Emperor arrived here at 11:30 o'clock this forenoon for the purpose of laying the cornerstone of the new building to be occupied by the law courts. The Kaiser entered a carriage at the railway station and was driven through decorated streets, lined with people, who cheered him all the way from the station to the Augustusplatz, where the new building is to be erected.

Before the racing was begun at the Westchester track yesterday it had been noised about that Corporation Counsel Scott had advised the police to make no more arrests at the track for alleged violation of the laws against gambling and lotteries, except on warrants duly issued. When that story was told there was a sigh of relief from the men who were in the habit of laying the odds.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The Spectator to-day says it believes that most thoughtful Englishmen respect and approve the essential principle of the Monroe doctrine, and do not desire to challenge or prevent its operation. "We do not," it adds, "want to add to our possessions in America, and are therefore willing not to dispute when the United States gives us notice that she will consider herself injured if we try to increase them.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 26. -- A fight, in which a man was shot, and another beaten with a blackjack, occurred in Michael O'Neill's saloon, Jefferson and Newark Streets at 2 o'clock this morning. The place is an all-night house, and is usually well patronized by milkmen and marketmen.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Oct. 26. -- The Plainfield Choral Society held its first rehearsal of the season Tuesday night. The music taken up was "Arminius." One hundred and fifteen members were present, and the season promises to be one of the most successful in the society's history.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Oct. 26. -- Official circles in Alaska are considerably agitated over the expose recently made by a Juneau paper, to the effect that the whisky ring of Puget Sound had been successfully outwitting the authorities, while large shipments of contraband liquor have been surreptitiously introduced into the Territory in direct violation of the laws, and disposed of to good advantage.

The foothold which the bicycle has gained this year in different branches of the public service means a heap in the labor of burying the remaining doubts of those who still profess to believe the wheel is not a practical means of transportation. Fifty-odd Inspectors of the Street Cleaning Department will soon be pedaling on their daily rounds, and letter carriers awheel are not uncommon sights in several cities.
The Hahnemann Hospital was the admirable excuse for the "high-tea" gathering at the Madison Square Garden banquet hall last evening.

In the West Indies, the dried leaves and prepared portions of the stem are used as packing materials. Fresh leaves are used to shade young coffee or cacao seedlings in nursery beds, and to cover cacao beans during fermentation. The young unopened leaves are so smooth and soft that they are used as "dressing" for blisters.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- All the prominent Western roads have been notified by the Secretary of the Inter-State Commerce Commission that actions have been brought against them for alleged violation of the fourth section of the agreement of the inter-State commerce law, or, in other words, for ignoring the long and short haul clause on triffic to Colorado, and also to Missouri River points.

The Emir Ameen Araslan, a young Druse Prince of the Lebanon Mountains, Syria, is in Paris, editing an Arabic paper called the Kashf II Nicub -- Lifting of the Veil -- and here he is determined to keep pounding away at the Turkish Government until his betrothed is given to him or until he knows the reason why.

The term "patent" by no means always meant in old times what it does now. It was at the best but a loose form of expression -- merely a shortening of "letters patent." These were an authority from the Sovereign, confirmed by the Lord Chancellor under the great seal, to do certain things which did not necessarily require the consent of Parliament.

The arrest of French spies in Germany and of German spies in France has long ceased to possess the element of novelty or to attract more than passing attention. But it is none the less true that an incident of this sort, if it came at a moment of international ferment, might serve to excite passions on both sides of the Vosges as readily now as a quarter of a century ago.

Specie gains of $1,299,800 reported for the week in the statement of the associated banks yesterday, following specie gains of $990,000 in the previous week, occasioned much favorable comment in the financial district, where the common understanding is that specie, when reported by the banks, means gold.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Another hotel, the Palmer House, has been added this week to the establishments which have opened their doors for another season. Mr. James R. Palmer, who returns as manager, arrived several weeks ago, and under his supervision the house has been much improved.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 26. -- The football game at the Yale Field this afternoon between the Yale University and Boston Athletic Association elevens resulted in a stubborn contest, neither side being able to score after twenty-minute halves. The largest crowd of the season was present, about 2,500 spectators cheering the efforts of the Yale team in its unsuccessful attempts to score.
Mr. W. Frederic Grote heard recently that the Stecklers had established a literary bureau and were flooding the city with campaign literature. That settled it.

BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- The dispatch from the Hongkong correspondent of The London Times, announcing that Russia has acquired the right, by a treaty recently concluded with China, to anchor her fleet at Port Arthur and connect Vladivostock with that port by railway, as well as securing other military and commercial advantages, was cabled here yesterday, and attracts considerable attention.
ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 26. -- The annual meeting of the Morris and Essex Foreign Missionary Societies of the Baptist Church was held here yesterday. Dr. and Mrs. Johnson of India made addresses.

BAKERSFIELD, Cal., Oct. 26. -- Hunting wild geese on the plains and along the Missouri and Mississippi River bottom lands is great sport, but there are scores of hunters in Southern California, and especially in the San Joaquin Valley, who say that nowhere else in the United States are there better opportunities to hunt geese and ducks than in this region.

Over fifty years ago there was born in that desolate region of Southern Oregon, now known as the Lava Beds, an Indian girl, the daughter of Se Cot, a Modoc chief. Among the white men who penetrated into the Modoc country a few years later in the search for gold was a young Kentuckian, named Frank Riddle.

PARIS, Oct. 1. -- The new drama by Paul Hervieu gives measure to an author of superior order. The "Tenailles," as given at the Comedie Francaise, does not take a new theme, since it treats of married life and of adultery, but it gives a plain, a possible picture, of a common situation -- at least in many distressing points.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26. -- At a meeting to-day of the California Press Association, supplemented by delegations from the press of Utah, Nevada, Arizona, Washington, and Oregon, a memorial was adopted urging the members of the National Editorial Association to use their influence with the Republican National Committee to induce it to send the National Republican Convention to San Francisco.
PITTSBURG, Oct. 26. -- The Executive Board of the citizens' committee to work to secure the next Republican National Convention for the City of Pittsburg met in the Mayor's office this afternoon.

Remarkable examples of what may be called machinery as applied to medicine are shown in the Zander Institute, at 9 East Fifty-ninth Street, which is under the direction of Dr. Carl Fallen. The institution derives its name from Dr. G. Zander of Stockholm, who was the inventor of most of the apparatus used.
President Cleveland stepped down from the stand to the bottom of the steps leading up to it. Then began a rush.

The long-continued drought throughout the country has caused a general suspension of navigation on the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers that has seldom been equaled in the history of navigation on Western waters.

The mineral deposits are generally allowed to be exceedingly rich. Much uncertainty exists in this matter, because trustworthy statistics are not furnished, but certain definite results have been achieved. Silver and gold, iron ore, and coal are known to exist. The two former are mined in Yunan and Shanse.

When I first stepped ashore in British Guiana it seemed as though I had come into fairyland. It was only a few Winters ago -- it seems like yesterday. We had crossed the mouth of the vast Orinoco -- so muddy and big that we had no difficulty in telling where our ship had brought us to -- and at last we entered the Esequibo and into the jurisdiction of Great Britain.

In THE TIMES of Sunday I was very glad to see the dissertation upon old college songs, and several months ago some reminiscences of Benny Havens, an old-time dispenser of good cheer near West Point, also attracted my attention. These two articles reminded me of what I am pleased to consider a very grave omission -- the college song, which was popular in the fifties, called "Benny Havens O!"

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26. -- Pennsylvania defeated Lafayette to-day by a score of 30 to 0. Although the score is larger than hoped for by the Red and Blue enthusiasts, the game played by the eleven was not at all satisfactory. Lafayette, with a weak offense, jammed very frequently through the centre, much to the discomfort of Pennsylvania's coachers, although they did not at any time threaten Pennsylvania's goal

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- With the advent of October and frosty weather it is noticed that most of the city people who have country houses pack up and return to their city homes. In thus taking their departure from the country in the month of October, they make their greatest mistake, for, of all the months in the year, October in the country is the most delightful in many respects.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- Dartmouth and the cadets played a rattling football game of twenty-five and twenty minute halves on the parade grounds to-day. The field was in perfect condition, and just enough breeze came down from "Cro' Nest" to keep the contestants cool and comfortable. A large number of spectators lined up against the ropes.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Oct. 26. -- The death of Mrs. Eustis was announced here this forenoon. She had summered at Dinan, a seacoast resort in France, had returned to Paris in excellent health, and was spending the Fall months at the shooting lodge of William Eustis Lagore, near Rotoath, County Meath, Ireland, where she had joined her daughter, Mrs. George Eustis.

ALBANY, Oct. 26. -- The dull period about the Capitol, which antedates all general elections, has set in in earnest. There are just enough clerks about the several offices to do the limited amount of business which comes to hand on the eve of an election, the greater number having gone to their homes to "get the boys in line."

Forehandedness has come to be a desirable part of Christmas preparation, and though the Thanksgiving turkey has not yet been eaten, is in fact still in the country poultry, yard, taking unto itself needed avoirdupois with unconsciously fatal greediness, ways and means for the greater holiday of the year are being discussed.

Col. Daniel S. Lamont, Secretary of War, came to this city yesterday for the especial purpose of registering. He met both Chairman Hinkley of the Democratic State Committee and Chairman Mason of the Executive Committee, and had long talks with them.

Lord Palmerston was not merely Lord Aberdeen's predecessor and successor. He was his exact opposite in his conceptions of diplomacy. He had no idea of subordinating the little to the great. Wherever British interests were threatened, wherever the British citizen was injured, he thought it his duty to speak with the voice of a Minister conscious that he had the strength of England at his back.

ROME, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The jury in the case of Adeline Niles of Oneida, as administratrix of Charles Niles, deceased, which has been on trial here in the Circuit Court for a week, this afternoon brought in a verdict of $15,000 for the plaintiff.

The Williams College team met the Crescent Athletic Club team in a football match at Eastern Park yesterday. About 2,500 persons were on the grounds and were rather disappointed in the one-sided contest. The Williams boys were not a match for the Crescents, and were beaten by a score of 43 to 0. The teams lined up as follows:

Florence, the Athens of Italy, had banished the Medici family, after having put them in power, and had just burned Savonarola at the stake, after having regarded him as an idol and a prophet. The city was governed by a grand council. Trade was prosperous; certain families had immense riches.

A rally in the market ought not to be far off. It has been going down most of the time during the past week, and being very narrow can readily become oversold. Railroad stocks have been steady, the drop has been in others. Conspicuous among these has been Leather, preferred and common, out of which the bottom seemed to drop.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 26. -- The hall and reading room of the Bloomfield Woman's Christian Temperance Union were thrown open to the public this afternoon.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 26. -- The Fall games of the Cornell Athletic Club were held here to-day on Percy Field. The track was in fine condition and the weather favorable, but no records were broken. The events, although well contested, lacked spirit. Summaries:

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 26, -- Miss Consuelo Vanderbilt's diamond and emerald skirt pin, which was supposed to have been either stolen or lost about Oct. 19 while driving from the country seat of ex-Secretary William C. Whitney, on the Wheatley Hills, to that of James L. Kernochan, at Hempstead, has not been recovered.

It is seldom that the use of any agent is the treatment of disease has met with the complete and lasting success that has attended the use of antitoxine in diphtheria, cases. The success in its use in this city has been marked, and it is a conservative estimate to say that since it has come into use, the mortality from diphtheria has decreased one-half.

The question is still asked: "But what may we eat? You reformers tell us we must not eat this, and that, and the other article; but you are very slow to tell us what we may eat. In truth, it sometimes seems as though little, if anything, were left us."

Whatever may be the result of the present fusion against Tammany, it is impossible to deny that, as a means of promoting purity, it has its drawbacks. From of old the Republican machine in this city has been recognized to be another and smaller but not in the least more reputable or more promising Tammany.

The third series of games in the tournament of the Wholesale Drug Trade Bowling Association was played yesterday afternoon at Reid's alleys, 198 Church Street. This is the third season for this organization, and there has been a marked increase in the interest and membership. The association was formed with six clubs.

James Park won the handicap tournament from a field of six entries yesterday at the St. Andrew's Golf Club. The contest was for a silver cup offered by the Vice President of the club, W.D. Baldwin, and was open only to the winners of the six monthly handicaps held since May.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- In the absence of home events, which might furnish material for newspaper discussion, the papers supporting the Government are indulging in a prolonged and bellicose chorus of comments on all the foreign happenings in which Great Britain is interested. In the meantime the Government is on the eve of opening another little war.
Senorita Maria Vilardell, who will soon appear on the stage as a professional, was the recipient of a benefit at the Berkeley Lyceum last evening.

There is no more interesting spot in the Madison Square Garden during the present Food Show than the pavilion on the main floor presided over by members of the Metropolitan Trained Nurses' Club of 15 West Forty-second Street, who, in simple gowns and neat white caps, are almost as soothing to the eye in the turmoil of the great crowds as they are at the patient's bedside.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20. -- There is a constant booming of the big guns out at the Presidio in these days. The army experts are experimenting with the destructive machinery which the United States Government has placed in position for the defense of San Francisco Harbor. The result has been most satisfactory.

BOSTON, Oct. 26. -- In a well-contested game played at the Cedar Street grounds, Newton Centre, this afternoon, the Chicago Athletic Association team defeated the Newton Athletic Association eleven by a score of 6 to 0. The only touch-down was made by Brown, ten seconds before time was called.

Even in this day of increasing civilization of the Indian race there remain many intelligent persons who still believe that "the only good Indian is the dead Indian." The life and work of Dr. Charles Eastman, a full-blooded Sioux, are a most convincing proof of the fallacy of this once popular belief.

England and America have had numerous translations from Hans Christian Andersen's works, but up to the present time, although he has been dead some twenty years, we have had no satisfactory biography of him. It has been reserved for Mr. Bain to bring us close to the man with whose writings old and young are familiar.

International copyright has joined British authors in a common guild with our own. Their language and literature are ours as well, and the American market is becoming the best market for their best productions. We have thrown it freely open to them. In reply, then, to your question concerning the vacant laureateship, I do not see why an American may not state his own opinion and preference.

ALBANY, Oct. 26. -- The State Board of Law Examiners his been in session here for the past week. The members are Austin G. Fox of New-York City, Chairman; William P. Godelle of Syracuse, and Franklin M. Danaher of Albany, Secretary and Treasurer. The examination of the papers of those candidates for admission to the bar who took the examination of the State Board, which was held at Syracuse Oct. 9, has been completed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The naval ordnance office has obtained nearly all its supply of projectiles necessary for ships of war. All the contracts which were made for shell have been completed, with one exception. This is a lot of eight-inch shell for the battleships, and the contract calls for 3,000 projectiles.

The Arnauts, Shkipetars or Albanians, are a remnant of the Illyro-Thracian race, who in some places are Catholics, in others Greek-Orthodox, and in others again Mohammedans, but who seldom allow the religious professions, on the strength of which they hope to be admitted into heaven, to hamper very considerably their goings on upon earth.

The freshmen of Columbia College were defeated at football by the Berkeley eleven at Berkeley Oval, Morris Heights. yesterday afternoon. The score- was e to 0. It was not until the second half that the touch-down was made. Then Berkeley get the ball on a fumble, and Bayne went across the line.

There was a large and enthusiastic meeting of German citizens at the Cooper Union last night, under the auspices of the German-American Citizens' Union, to protest against the action of the German-American Reform Union in supporting the Tammany ticket, and to indorse the ticket of the Committee of Fifty.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 26. -- All doubt about the Gleason faction of the Democracy having the State nominees on their ballot was set at rest to-day by the decision given by Supreme Court Justice Cullen. John P. Madden, the Jefferson candidate for Mayor, sought to restrain County Clerk John H. Sutphin from placing the State ticket on the Gleason ballot, the County Clerk having announced his intention of so doing.
Michael Rice, five years old, was terribly mangled by a vicious cat in his mother's apartments on the second floor of the tenement house 1,864 Third Avenue, yesterday.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 26. -- All doubt about the Gleason faction of the Democracy having the State nominees on their ballot was set at rest to-day by the decision given by Supreme Court Justice Cullen. John P. Madden, the Jefferson candidate for Mayor, sought to restrain County Clerk John H. Sutphin from placing the State ticket on the Gleason ballot, the County Clerk having announced his intention of so doing.
Michael Rice, five years old, was terribly mangled by a vicious cat in his mother's apartments on the second floor of the tenement house 1,864 Third Avenue, yesterday.

One of the most recent acquisitions to the list of prominent Jewish charities of New-York is the Lebanon Hospital, situated on the east side of the annexed district. Although created and maintained by Israelites, it is a non-sectarian institution, and is the only place in that section of the city where that class of patients known as "outdoor poor" receives medical treatment free of charge.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- George A. Howard, Auditor of the Treasury for the Post Office Department, in his annual report to Secretary Carlisle, states that the two years' accumulation in this office of unassorted money orders is something of the past. All of the money orders received have been assorted, and the demands of late Postmasters for the adjudication of their money order accounts have been silenced by their settlement.

The scientific and ethnological side of the caste question has been exhaustively treated, but a stranger, even after he had digested the mass of erudition which has been accumulated on this subject, would still find difficulty in distinguishing one sub-division from another, and even in many instances in discriminating between Hindus and Mohammedans.
Freshmen and sophomores of the School of Mines of Columbia College met in a cane rush at Columbia Oval, Williamsburg, yesterday, and there was a Homeric struggle for supremacy.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Oct. 27. -- The most important land suit ever tried in the Federal Court in West Virginia is now on before Judge J.J. Jackson. The case is one involving the possession of about 2,500,000 acres of land in Mingo, Logan, Wyoming, and McDowell Counties, West Va.; Pike County, Ky., and Buchanan and Tazewell Counties, Va.

It is not yet too late for the Manhattan Elevated Road to save itself from the decadence into which it seems to be falling, even as the horse railroad has fallen, "this many years in Gotham." If Uncle SAGE would but permit the lighting of his elevated trains by bright gas, instead of dingy oil lamps, passengers might be willing to ride with him once in a while.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- The District Attorney has completed his preparation for conducting the prosecution of H.H. Holmes on the charge of murdering Benjamin F. Pietzel, and when, to-morrow at 10 o'clock, the accused is placed in the dock, it is confidently expected that there will be no further instance of the proverbial delays of the law, but that the case will be carried straight through to a prompt conclusion.
BRIDGETON, N.J., Oct. 27. -- A vivid imagination, coupled with too much Jersey "applejack," has landed John Sickler into a heap of trouble, and also into the County Jail.

The Century Wheelmen of New-York, in their second century run, yesterday, repeated the success of the run which was held earlier in the season. At 5 o'clock in the morning, long before any indications of dawn had appeared, the cyclists who had entered, gathered at Fifty-ninth Street and the Boulevard, the place selected for the start.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 27. -- The work of the Princeton 'Varsity football team during the past week has been a great disappointment to followers of the orange and black. Thus far this season Princeton students have waited and watched in vain for the development of interference and organized play, and it now seems likely that Princeton will go into the Harvard game with no sort of organization, but every player playing for himself.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 27. -- The most noteworthy event at Princeton last week was the visit of the Society of Colonial Dames to the old university town, and their commemorative celebration of the one hundred and forty-ninth anniversary of the founding of the college. This occurred Tuesday, Oct. 22, the College of New-Jersey having been founded on Oct. 22, 1746.

Sir Henry Irving arrived in this city last night from Boston, and registered at the Plaza Hotel. Miss Ellen Terry and those members of his company who had not left Boston Saturday, were also on the train. They occupied nearly an entire car.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct.27.-The meet of the Southern Wheelmen closed yesterday. The track is a new quarter-mile cement track, completed only a month ago, and was pronounced by visiting bicycle experts as one of the fastest tracks in the country. The times made by the local men were very fair, but not remarkably fast.

M. HENRI ROCHEFORT opens the brilliant preface to the "Adventures of My Life," just begun in Le Jour, with this pertinent remark: "To say to a well-known man, 'You ought to write your memoirs' is a polite way of giving him to understand that he is no longer good for anything else."

A policeman of the West Twentieth Street Police Station arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday Frank Roberts, twenty-five years old, of 216 West Twenty-fourth Street; Horace Lewis, twenty-eight years old, of 111 West Twenty-second Street; Boone Buchan, twenty-four years old, of 408 West Twenty-third Street; William J. Merrick, thirty years old, of 408 West Twenty-eighth Street, and William Hamilton, twenty-three years old, of 322 West Twenty-third Street, on the charge of being common gamblers.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 26. -- The Duquesne, Central, Pittsburg and Manchester Traction Companies, representing a total par value capitalization of $14,125,000, this week notified their stockholders that on Dec. 23 next they would be requested to vote on a proposition to lease their respective properties and franchises to the Consolidated Traction Company for a period of 950 years.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27. -- There now remains but about a month before the Princeton game, and the Yale eleven must soon be definitely decided upon in order that team-play may be carried to the same degree of perfection that it has been in past years. The practice this last week has been especially hard and severe, as result of the poor showing made against Orange.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 27. -- The new members of the Faculty who began their work at the university this term are Prof. Edward Washburn Hopkins, Prof. E.G. Bourne, Dr. Charles Sears Baldwin, C.M. Lewis, and Dr. Irving Fisher. They are popular with the students.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach nut only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

The answer of ex-Police Commissioner John C. Sheehan to the report of Commissioners of Accounts Terry and Dennis charging that from 150 to 1,250 per cent. in excess of market prices had been paid in the Police Department for supplies was made public yesterday. Mr. Sheehan declares the charges are unfair, and defends his conduct as Chairman of the Committee on Repairs anad Supplies.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 27. -- Two bombs have been found in this city, and the local police are trying to solve the mystery. The first was found in the Capitol park, while the second was found in the yard of H.I. Veerhusen of the tailoring firm of Oleson Veerhusen, whose employes went on strike recently.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The first service conducted by the Rev. T. De Witt Talmage as co-pastor of the First Presbyterian Church to-night was without notable incident. Dr. Talmage's only reference to his new relation was in his opening sentences. He said:

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 27. -- A fire to-day that originated in the southwest corner of the public hall of the University of Virginia destroyed the main building of that institution, with some of its contents, and caused a loss of about $100,000.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 27. -- Much excitement prevails at Harvard over the prospect of the game of football with Princeton. Probably 500 students will go down to the game. Special rates have been obtained both by boat and rail.

BERLIN, Oct. 27 -- Following the memorial ceremonies of consecrating the painted windows of the Emperor Frederick memorial and the unveiling of the monument to the Empress Augusta, grandmother of the Emperor, both of which took place Oct. 21, the principal society function of the week was the ropening of the Royal Opera House on Wednesday, after a complete renovation of the interior of the theatre, at a cost of more than 500,000 marks.

In the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 551 Fifth Avenue, yesterday morning the Rev. Dr. Frank London Humphreys made an earnest plea for the higher education of the clergy and for the encouragement and stimulation of the spirit of scholarship in the Church colleges.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 27. -- The burglar who was arrested last Sunday morning after having assaulted William A. Lewis and Thomas Carey, the Central Railroad agent and watchman, respectively, at Danforth Avenue Station, and who gave his name as William Allman, has been identified as William Leonard, a son of Henry W. Leonard, formerly a Justice of the Peace at Bayonne, who now has a law office at 202 Broadway, New-York.

Considering that yesterday was only ten days before election day, there was less excitement and more dullness at the various political headquarters than hardened politicians have known for a generation.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 27. -- There has been a noticeable change within ten days in sentiment in this State regarding the head of the Democratic ticket, Gen. P. Wat Hardin, and if this sentiment should continue the Democratic ticket will be elected.

" The majority of Republicans and Democrats are Puritans," said Police Commissioner ROOSEVELT on Friday night. "You will get no change in this law until you have convinced the people that the opening of saloons on Sunday is for the best. You must change them from Puritans to Cavaliers."

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 27. -- As the campaign stands now in New-Jersey, both sides claim a victory. The Democrats are content with estimating on a small plurality of from 2,000 to 5,000, but the Republicans are adding just 1,000 each day to the plurality that they expect to get early on the morning of Nov. 6.

The leading politicians of Brooklyn devoted Sunday to statistics. They went over the registration figures by districts and wards, and the Republicans and Democrats came to conclusions which did not agree by any means.
Prof. Felix Adler addressed the Society for Ethical Culture at Carnegie Hall yesterday on "The Sunday Question in New-York." He said:

Many of the more prominent clergymen in this city preached yesterday on the issues that are to be more or less determined on election day. They differed to a great extent on the subject of local option and the manner in which Sunday should be observed.

BERLIN, Oct. 27. -- In the second day's harness trotting of the West End season Mr. Fleischmann's Shadeland Delmonio won the Great International Handicap. The third day's racing was spoiled by rain, but Shadeland Delmonio manage to get the second place in the International race.

ALBANY, Oct. 26. -- The week has been interesting in the way of news affecting local securities. The trading has been at advancing prices, and quotations held firm. Albany Railway is quoted ex dividend, the books having closed on Tuesday. The Municipal Gas Company has declared a dividend of 2 per cent., payable Nov. 1.
Our esteemed contemporary, Dun's Review, published the following remark on the 26th inst.:

The armored cruiser Maine, which was yesterday made the subject of lay criticism by a morning newspaper, will sail for Gardiner's Bay this morning, where her battery and its fittings will be tested in target practice.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 27. -- The senior parlor at Vassar was formally opened Saturday at the reception given by the seniors to the Faculty of the college and to the class of '98. Miss Mary Noxon Sanders of New-York, President of '96, was assisted in receiving by Miss Louise Chamberlain, President of '98, and Miss Marie M. Champney, '96.

WEST NEW-YORK, N.J., Oct. 27. -- The new Catholic Church of Our Lady of Help of Christian was dedicated to-day by Bishop Wigger. The mass was celebrated by Father Berghold, the rector. Father Weyland of St. Nicholas Church, Jersey City, was deacon, and Father Grieff of the Holy Family Church, Union Hill, sub-deacon.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 27. -- John R. Lynch, the colored ex-Congressman of Mississippi and Southern leader, who was President Harrison's Fourth Auditor of the Treasury, is here, stumping the State for the Republican ticket. He stated to-day that the story that Platt of New-York went to the convention of 1888 pledged to support Senator Sherman for the Presidency was absolutely false.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 27. -- The three Mayoralty candidates in this city will be busy during the coming week. Each party has at least six meetings scheduled for each night in the week, while there will be a number of side shows in the way of banner raisings, parades, and a general all-round hustle for votes.

Gov. Morton has sent a letter to Charles W. Hackett, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, in which he expresses a desire for a good working Republican majority in both houses of the Legislature.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- Discounts were firmer during the week. The rate for three months' bills was 3/4 per cent., and for 30-day bills 1/2 per cent. Further remittances on account of the Chinese loan are expected, and the first installment of the Japanese indemnity is nearly due. The probable method of the remittance is much discussed. Silver was unsteady in the early part of the week, but the market closed firmer.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- At the Union College Faculty meeting held Thursday the following rule was adopted: "All applications for change of course or of studies in a course must hereafter be made during the first week of the term for which such change is desired."

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Estelle Colton, only daughter of Dr. Edward G. Colton, the well-known dentist of Brooklyn, whose residence is at 66 Livingston Street, Brooklyn, drowned herself under peculiarly sad circumstances at Piermont last evening.

It is not easy for the friends of reputable racing to be patient under the malicious and stupid persecutions to which they have of late been subjected. Horse racing is an honorable and gentlemanly sport when reputably conducted. It has been conducted by gentlemen honorably and reputably at Westchester, under the supervision of State officers appointed in accordance with the terms of the law which permits and regulates it.

The London Spectator, in its latest number, discusses with remarkable candor the subject of the "Unpopularity of England," and it starts out by admitting that, of all the nations of the earth, its own is the least liked and the most cordially hated. It gives a variety of evidence to support its proposition, which really for the purposes of discussion needed no proof but its own admission.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 27. -- Details have been received from a Turkish source of the recent rioting at Erzingen, in Asiatic Turkey. It is said that the trouble had its origin in the killing of a Mussulman priest by an Armenian. The murder bitterly incensed the Mohammedans against the Armenians, and an attack was made by the former upon the latter.

TIFFIN, Ohio, Oct. 27. -- In an attempt early this morning to avenge the murder of August Schultz, Tiffin's popular City Marshal, who was shot down in cold blood by Leander J. Martin, alias Williams, a farmer of Hopewell Township, last Wednesday evening, two more victims were added to the tragic affair.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Incendiaries visited this section to-night, and in a short time set two fires. The first started about 8 o'clock in the large stable of Mrs. Joseph H. Palmer, on Saw Mill River Road. The stable, one horse, the farming implements, and a quantity of hay were destroyed.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- The new dormitory system of the Pennsylvania University is progressing rapidly toward completion. Since the work was begun, in the Summer, there has been no opportunity for appropriate exercises at the laying of the cornerstone. As a consequence, the cornerstone laying has been delayed while the rest of the structure has been pushed as rapidly as possible.
Election predictions based on the registration count for less than usual this year. They are not nearly so good as enlightened guesswork.

A new baseball association will be in the field next year, known a the Atlantic Association of Professional Baseball Clubs. It was formed in this city Oct. 5. The organizers are D. A. Long of Toledo, W.E. Ellis of Grand Rapids W. S. Wright, manager of last year's Grand Rapids team and Sam Crane of this city. Sam Crane was elected President, Secretary, and Treasurer.
MADRID, Oct. 27. -- An official dispatch confirms the report of the stranding of the Government launch Caridad, near Sierra Morena, Cuba, during the hurricane that recently passed over that island.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 28. -- The career of Henry H. Holmes forms the most romantic story in the annals of American police history. Having received a liberal education, being of genteel appearance, possessing convincing powers of speech and a nerve and shrewdness that bordered on the phenomenal, he was ably equipped to prey upon his fellow-men.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The marriage of Miss Jeannette Payson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Payson of this city, to Raymond Le Ghait, Secretary of the Belgian Legation, and son of the Belgian Minister, Mr. Alfred Le Ghait, took place at noon to-day, at the residence of the Payson family, and was attended by their friends in the diplomatic and resident circles.
Messrs. Hoffman Brothers have sold for Warren E. Dennis, to Henry G. Trevor, the business building 323 Pearl Street, extending to 80 Cliff Street, 23.2 by 170 by 19.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Secretary Herbert this afternoon made the following official statement about the defects in the Maine:
There are at present on view in the office of United States Marshal John H. McCarty, in the Federal Building, seventy-two fine oil paintings.
Out in Chicago abides a man with an imposing faith in womankind and in telephones and such. His name is Albert Corri, and he is a bachelor. Therein lies the wonder.

Whenever a Republican politician addresses a public meeting he asserts with much elaboration and emphasis that the sole cause of the panic which began in the Spring of 1893, and from which we have been recovering rapidly since March last, was the prospect of a revision of the tariff by the Democratic Party.
The criminal prosecution of police officers and patrolmen growing out of the Lexow exposures is practically over.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Electricity will supplant the old system of gas lighting now in vogue at the Capitol. Extensive improvements are now being made, and hereafter the House and Senate will receive their illumination from a finely equipped electric plant, which has just been installed. As a consequence of the introduction of electric lights, the old gas pipes in the dome will probably be removed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The State Department people are not entirely satisfied with the status of the diplomatic incident with the Turkish Government, which grew out of the cowardly assault on Miss Melton, an American teacher at the Mosul school. The assault occurred at Daree, a mountain village in the wild district of Koordistan, many hundred miles from Constantinople, and near the extreme limit of the Ottoman Empire.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 28. -- President Collier of the exposition has been compelled to relinquish the duties of his office temporarily on account of his health. He started for New-York last night, via Savannah and will reach there Wednesday. He will remain in the metropolis one day only, and will return to Atlanta. He goes for the sea voyage.

The drift of the local campaign through multiplied complications toward an end that baffles all the prophets has tended to confirm the opinion expressed by THE TIMES when the list of candidates was first made up that none of the tickets is from top to bottom worthy of support. Dr. PARKHURST and THE TIMES stand together in the belief that a satisfactory ticket can be made up only by the exercise of the scratcher's privilege.

" As we are on cake baking, I may as well give you the best of it," said Mrs. Rorer, with an air of resignation, yesterday afternoon, at her cookery talk at Madison Square Garden. Old-fashioned cake was the subject for the afternoon, and Mrs. Rorer talked, and worked, turning out simultaneously jumbles and good advice, apple slump and didactic remarks upon the evils of American living.

The Rev. Isaac M. Haldeman, the Rev. Richard Hartley, and the Rev. A.C. Dixon at the Baptist ministers' meeting yesterday discussed the salient features of a paper on "Ecclesiastical Hedonism," by the Rev. William Guilym, pastor of the Macdougal Street church.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- Herman W. Mudgett, alias H.H. Holmes, was arraigned in the Criminal Court to-day on the charge of having murdered Benjamin F. Pietzel in this city Sept. 2, 1894.

Sailors frequently desert their ships, but it is rather unusual for a ship to desert its men. The British Vice Consul, Gilbert Frazer, took that view of the case when the twenty-three mariners of the steamship Ludgate Hill, whose vicissitudes were told in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday, appeared at the Consulate and told the story of how they had been left behind.

The death of CALLAHAN is not the first fatal result that has ensued from the idiotic practice of "bridge jumping." Since the days of SAM PATCH everybody who has kept up the practice has finally fallen a victim to it. "When the jumper survives he has neither proved anything nor in any possible sense has rendered a public service.

A test case as to the legality of racing as conducted under the Percy-Gray bill, and another as to the right of men to make wagers at races, were made in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday. All of the accused bookmakers were discharged from custody, as related elsewhere, and so there will be racing at the Westchester track to-day.
Physicians of Brooklyn are greatly interested in a case of lockjaw that was treated in that city a few days ago by the use of the antitoxine of tetanus.

" We deem it unfortunate for both the Democratic State ticket and the local "fusion ticket" that they cannot be printed together on the official ballot under a single emblem and party designation, but we are not in the least surprised at Judge BEACH'S decision to the effect that the State Democracy is not entitled to a full column on the ballot, including the names of candidates for State offices.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 28. -- Private advices from an American source report the occurences of a terrible massacre near Baibut, on the road between Erzeoum and Trebizond. These reports allege that 500 Mussulman laizes, armed, and supported by the Turkish inhabitants, made an unprovoked attack upon the Armenian inhabitants of several villages.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 28. -- A destructive fire has been raging since Saturday in the oil regions, south of here.

There was a lively discussion at the meeting of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen yesterday afternoon when Alderman Haubert moved that the Board of Audit, consisting of the Controller, City Auditor, and Alderman Haubert, employ expert accountants, temporarily, to examine the books of the Controller, Tax Collector, Register of Water Rates, and Register of Arrears, in order to ascertain the exact amount due to the city.
There is a firm confidence in the result of the election at the Democratic State headquarters, 27 Madison Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 28. -- Coroner Hawkins to-day received a letter, signed by George Reynolds, announcing the writer's intention to commit suicide. In it Reynolds virtually accuses the counsel for Durrant of conspiracy to implicate Pastor Gibson of Emmanuel Church in the murders of Miss Lamont and Minnie Williams. Reynolds, in his statement, says he, with four other men, named Smyth, Dugan, Stewart, and Taylor, were to be witnesses for the defense.

There was such a diversity of opinion among the members of the City Club present at a special meeting at the clubhouse last evening, called for the purpose of considering the present political situation and to determine what action, if any, should be taken by the club, that no decisive action was ordered.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 28. -- "I think Judge Barnard's decision has probably been erroneously reported," said Attorney General Hancock to-day. "He will undoubtedly have something further to say, so that it will be clearly understood what his interpretation of the election law with reference to registration really is.

The ninetieth annual meeting of the Medical Society of the County of New-York was held last night at the Academy of Medicine. Dr. Robert H. Grandin presided. There was a large attendance. The reports of the standing committees were read.

How many people we meet who plainly show that they are not in the best of health, and who experience many unpleasant symptons which denote a weak spot in the system. They feel the need of something to restore their lost vitality, but yet are at a loss to know what to do. They know they ought to take some remedy, but, which one to take is a question they cannot decide.

President Theodore Roosevelt of the Police Board addressed a large audience in the banquet hall in the Hotel Brunswick last evening. He used as a text I. Corinthians, xiv., 26. The verse reads: "How is it, then, brethren, when you come together, every one of you hath a psalm, hath a doctrine, hath a tongue, hath a revelation, hath an interpretation.
ALBANY, Oct. 28. -- The article headed "The Boss and the Courts," published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES this morning, has been read with great interest in this city.
