" If the weather is favorable, we will have the largest parade of German-Americans ever seen in a political campaign in this city," said Herman Sulzer, the Grand Marshal for the parade next Thursday of the United Societies for Liberal Sunday Laws and the German-American Reform Union.
The total registration in this city this year is 281,008, a failing off of 27,393 since last year, and a gain of 15,100 over 1893.

The "star chamber" in the Stewart Building, where the Dock Board investigation is being conducted, was the scene of some sharp tilts yesterday between ex-Dock Commissioner J. Sargent Cram and Commissioner of Accounts Seth Sprague Terry.

Such a startling statement of the present condition of affairs at the Almshouse on Blackwell's Island was made before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment at its meeting yesterday, by Dr. C.E. Bruce, the President of the Medical Visiting Board in charge of that institution, that the members of the board decided to make a personal visit to the Almshouse.

PARIS, Oct. 28. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Rouanet, Socalist, made an interpellation in regard to the Southern Railway scandals, and condemned the Government for making Senator Magnier a scapegoat while shielding much worse culprits than he.
ALBANY, Oct. 28. -- The following is a copy of a notice just issued by the examination department of the University of the State of New-York to all medical schools in the United States and Canada:

WASHINGTON, N.J., Oct. 28. -- There is every indication of serious trouble here within the next few hours. The employes of the United States Pipe Line Company, which is constructing a line across the States of Pennsylvania and New-Jersey to pump oil to tide water, and rival the Standard Oil Company, and those of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, are lined up here in battle array, and both are determined.

Judge Beach, in the Supreme Court, decided yesterday that the State Democracy rooster could not be permitted to head the third column of the official ballot, and that a list of the State Democratic nominees could not be placed under the emblem. Only the nominees for local offices, the Fusion ticket, the Judge declared, can legally be printed under the rooster.

The State Democracy candidate for the Assembly in the Fourteenth Assembly District is Jacob Kunzenman, who served in the Assembly of 1885, 1887, and last year. The State Democracy candidate for the Assembly in the Sixteenth Assembly District is William F. Grote, better known as "Fatty" Grote.

LONDON, Oct. 28. -- Frederick K. Rasch, member of Parliament for Southeast Essex, represents the situation there as being extremely grave. The Sultan, he says, sees nobody at all. He has become completely unmanned from fears of assassination and keeps himself in strict seclusion.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The report which comes from Atlanta that the Exposition Managers have postponed the proposed demonstration in favor of the Cuban patriots from Nov. 6 to Dec. 17, because of the objection of President Cleveland to an expression of this kind pending the meeting of Congress, cannot be verified in Washington, but there is a general feeling here that it is well founded.

The political contest which, is now going on in New-Jersey has some unusual features. It is more clearly a contest of purely State politics than we often see. Each party stands clearly enough on its own ground so far as National issues are concerned, but these are not figuring in the campaign, nor does it appear to be disturbed by any merely local divisions.

OGDEN, Utah, Oct. 28. -- The National Circuit meet of the Wahsatch Cycle Club to-day in this city was attended by a fair crowd. Both of the open race went to Bald, who fought game finishes every time. In the half mile and in the mile. Kiser, the Dayton boy, was the worthiest opponent of Bald and Murphy. The fields included ten men in each of the open races.

HAVANA, Oct. 28. -- The trial by courtmartial of Lieut. Gallegos, the commander of the small Spanish guardboat Dos de Mayo, which was captured by insurgents near Santiago de Cuba on Oct. 12, has resuited in his acquital by vote of 4 to 3.

As a result of a collision in the North River yesterday the Pennsylvania ferryboat Chicago is laid up for repairs and the steamship Alvena of the Atlas Line will require several new plates before she can go to sea again.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Representative John C. Tarsney of Missouri takes a hopeful view of the future prosperity of the country and of his party.
In a letter sent to The United Press yesterday, Charles E. Cochrane of 247 West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, says:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The convention which Secretary Olney and the British Ambassador, Sir Julian Pauncefote, will frame looking to the payment of damages to Canadian vessels seized in Bering Sea, as provided in the Paris award, will provide, it is believed, for a mixed commission to assess the amount due.

" The Committee of Fifty," said Secretary Wakeman, late last night, "are distinctly in favor of volunteer, unpaid watchers. It is not true that arrangements have been made to put 8,352 watchers at the polls, at an estimated cost of $41,760.

If that St. Louis restaurant keeper who has ordered his waitresses to dress in bloomers should find Imitators In half a. dozen other cities, the bicycle costume problem will cease from troubling with great suddenness. Skirts? Why, the wheelwomen would all wear trains.
The legal status of horse racing and betting on racing is now in a fair way to be definitely settled.

Further evidence of the drift of the voters of Brooklyn toward Edward M. Shepard was made plain yesterday in the announcement that John Gibb, the well-known business man, had declared in favor of the Reform Democratic ticket.

It transpired yesterday that while some of the railroads, which do not desire to make a charge for the transportation of bicycles, may be forced into such a transaction, they will not recede from their present position without a protest. The Erie Road, which has had considerable experience in the matter, having tried both plans, considers it "good business" to favor the wheelmen by carrying their machines free of charge.

The Salamanders, South Brooklyn's crack bowling organization, rolled two clever games in the Carruthers National tourney of Brooklyn last night. They passed the 800 mark in both games, and defeated Waverly and Bushwick with ease. The scores:

A solemn requiem low mass was celebrated yesterday morning by Father Ducey in St. Leo's Church, in East Twenty-eighth Street, for the repose of the soul of John W. Mackay, Jr., who was killed recently in France.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Oct. 28. -- The police force has been brought into the Mayoralty fight in this city. Several patrolmen have not come out in enthusiastic support of John P. Madden, the candidate of Henry P. Sharkey and the Jefferson Democracy, and they have been given to understand that in the event of Mr. Madden's election they will be promptly "broken."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The Westchester County Historical Society held its annual meeting to-day in the Court House, at which there was a good attendance of members from nearly all quarters of the county.

A ten-round bout at catch weights between Albert Griffiths, or "Young Griffo," of Australia and George Dixon of Boston in the gymnasium of the New Manhattan Athletic Club last night ended with cries of "More! more!" "Let them fight!" from several thousand spectators.

The arrival of John Curtin Kent in this country recalls the fact that Senator T.C. O'Sullivan was instrumental in securing his release from Portland Prison, where he was confined for political reasons.

Mr. THOMAN'S final estimate of the corn crop, published yesterday, is 2,400,000,000 bushels. This exceeds by 13 1/2 per cent., or about 290,000,000 bushels, the largest crop (1889) heretofore harvested, is almost double the size of last year's crop, and is larger than the crop of 1893 or that of 1892 by nearly 50 per cent.

Police Inspector McCullagh and twoscore of Central Office men and police officers in citizens' dress were at the Westchester race track yesterday afternoon, detailed there, it was said, at the orders of Acting Chief Conlin to arrest any person who should be found recording a wager. Magistrate Kudlich was also at the track, prepared, so it was reported, to discharge any person who should be arrested on any such flimsy charge.
Mr. SHEPARD refuses to promise that, if elected Mayor of Brooklyn, he will abstain from enforcing any law. That is right.

PRINCETON. N.J., Oct. 29. -- A rousing Democratic meeting, supporting Chancellor Alexander T. McGill for Governor of New-Jersey, was held here to-night. The students turned out in full force, with fireworks and illuminations, and, led by a band, they proceeded to University Hall to listen to the speeches of prominent alumni and members of the Faculty of Princeton College.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 29. -- Coroner Castor of this city, who held the inquest on the charred remains of little Howard Pietzel, announces that he will go to Philadelphia just to secure a glimpse of Holmes. He thinks Holmes is a hypnotist of the very highest order, and he further believes that it will be his purpose to get the jury in his power.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Oct. 29. -- Advices from Aleppo say there has been continuous fighting in Marash, ninety miles northwest of Aleppo, for the last three days between Turks and Armenians. The situation in the Asiatic provinces generally excites uneasiness.

A meeting of newspaper and general advertising agents was held in the offices of L.H. Crall, in THE TIMES Building, yesterday, in memory of Frederick W. Nostrand, who died Sunday at his home in Glen Ridge, N.J. Fully a score of Mr. Nostrand's friends and former business associates were present to do honor to his memory.
The utmost confidence prevailed yesterday at the reform Democratic headquarters in Brooklyn. There was enthusiasm over the number of accessions from the ranks of the regulars, which is growing daily.

The criticism passed upon the Commissioners of Charities and Correction by the County Medical Society because of the reorganization of the consulting and visiting staffs of the City Hospital, on Blackwells Island, and the outlying hospitals, does not appear to give the Commissioners much concern.

The fashionable folk of the city and neighborhood will be found this afternoon at the Academy of Design at the opening of the Portrait Show. This exhibition for charity is in every way a worthy one, and the interest that people of social prominence have taken in it insures its financial success. Tea will be served to-day in the library of the building, and there will be music by the Hungarian Band.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- One of the most brilliant social functions of the season in Westchester County was the silver wedding of Adjt. Gen. Edwin A. McAlpin and wife at their charming home, Hillside, on the northern outskirts of this village, this evening.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 29. -- Congressman George L. Wellington, Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee, made the startling announcement this afternoon that Senator Matthew Stanley Quay of Pennsylvania is helping Senator Gorman in his fight to retain his power in Maryland.

ALBANY, Oct. 29. -- The Court of Appeals to-day reversed the judgment of the lower courts and ordered new trials in the cases of James F. Malcom against the New-York Elevated Railroad Company and another, appellants, and Jacob Bockman, against the same, appellants.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Oct. 29. -- The mutilated body of a man was found on the beach at Whitestone Point early this morning by Maurice O'Connor, keeper of the lighthouse there. The only clothing on it was a white undershirt that was drawn up over the head.

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- George E. Baldwin, son of Truman H. Baldwin of New-York, and Miss Julia Frances Fraser, daughter of Mrs. Olive Fraser, were married today in the Reformed Church. The wedding was termed a "yellow and white chrysanthemum wedding," and the church was trimmed elaborately in these colors.

There was an unusually pathetic scene yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, where David F. Hannigan is on trial for the murder of Solomon H. Mann, when Sigmund Mann, father of the dead man, took the stand.
There were 375 members of the police force, including Captains, Sergeants, and Roundsmen, transferred yesterday by the Police Commissioners, at the recommendation of Acting Chief Conlin.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 29. -- The low water which has prevailed in this vicinity since Saturday night, and which has caused a blockade of vessels in Lake St. Clair, has also caused a loss to vessel interests which cannot be estimated.

The annual live bird tournament for the championship of Dexter Park, L.I., was commenced yesterday morning and continued until dark. Nine teams competed, each man shooting at twenty birds, but owing to darkness, not over three men of each team were able to complete their score. The other two men of each team will complete their work to-day.

Sorosis went to school yesterday. Its members, all in their most charming Fall gowns, and "shining afternoon faces," to paraphrase the Bard of Avon, collectively and as one person sat for nearly two hours at the feet of a sweet-faced feminine Gamaliel, listened, asked questions, recited, and went away happier and wiser parliamentarians.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29. -- The session of the Durrant murder trial this afternoon was enlivened by the most dramatic incident of the case, when Eugene N. Deuprey, of counsel for the defense, who has been confined to his bed for a couple of weeks with a paralytic stroke, was wheeled into court to make his address before the jury.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Judge Lochren, Commissioner of Pensions, has submitted his annual report to the Secretary of the Interior. It shows that up to June 30, 1894, there were 969,544 pensioners, and during the past year 39,185 new pensions were granted and 4,206 restored that had been dropped from the rolls, making an aggregate roll of 1,012,935.

Unlike that of last year, the portrait exhibition this Fall is not limited to canvases of women only, but has been opened alike to the sterner sex and to children. Nearly 600 works are shown, but as at the press view held yesterday afternoon only a few advance sheets of the catalogue were to be had, and those of a most incomplete and scrappy order, extended criticism necessarily is deferred until a later date.

There is much activity being displayed at the German-American Reform Union headquarters at present. The arrangements for the monster parade to-morrow night monopolize the time and labor of the officers and corps of assistants of the United Societies for Liberal Sunday Laws and the German-American Reform Union.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29. -- The utmost secrecy is being maintained at the daily practice of the Princeton football eleven. No students were allowed inside the university field to-day except players and a few upper classmen chosen to assist in guarding the secrecy of the practice. These guards were stationed at the various entrances and kept a close watch on all persons approaching the grounds.
The mass meeting at Cooper Union last night in favor of the canal amendments that are to be voted upon next Tuesday drew such a crowd as has not been equaled there in this campaign.

The London Times recently published the opinions of Sir HENRY TYLER about the projected Panama Canal. At that time it had not received the report of its own representative, Mr. A.R. COLOUHOUN, whom it had sent to Nicaragua and the isthmus. This report is now made public, and its estimates and conclusions are greatly at variance with Sir HENRY'S.

The first day of the Parkville Stock Farm sale resulted very satisfactorily. A larger number of persons than usual were present at the one-fifth of a mile covered track at Parkville, L.I., where the sale was held. A cold breeze made an out-door sale too uncomfortable.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The trial of the first case in the United States of alleged libel of an Ambassador of a foreign power was begun in the local courts to-day, when Celso Caesar Moreno was called upon to plead to an indictment, charging him with uttering a criminal libel upon Baron de Fava, Ambassador to the United States from the kingdom of Italy.
VIENNA, Oct. 29. -- Herr Lueger, leader of the Anti-Semites, was elected Mayor of Vienna this morning, by a vote of 93 to 44, in the Municipal Council.
Charles P. McClelland, who is the Democratic candidate for Senator in the Westchester district, said yesterday to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Old Fire Island Light, a familiar mark for ocean steamers and ships approaching New-York, is to be abandoned. The Treasury Department recently installed an expensive plant at this place, with an idea of giving the light a greater power, and correspondingly increasing its value to mariners, who complained that the light was indistinguishable in hazy and foggy weather.

A meeting of about thirty of the largest creditors in this city of Bamberger, Bloom Co., wholesale dealers in dry goods, in Louisville, Ky., was held yesterday at the office of Myers Anable of 45 Wall Street.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 29. -- Miss Katharine Kimball, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David P. Kimball, and John Harsen Rhoades, Jr., son of John Harsen Rhoades of New-York, were married at the Arlington Street Church to-day. The church was so crowded that it was necessary for the police to make a way for the bride and her attendants to reach the altar.

Justice Ingraham, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday handed down a decision dismissing the indictments against former Police Captain Doherty, suspended Capt. John J. Donohue, and ex-Sergt. Felix McKenna.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 29. -- Upon James J. Van Alen's arrival last evening, Deputy Sheriff Kaull was summoned to Wakehurst, and, with Samuel R. Honey, who is managing the local end of the difficulty under the direction of Mr. Van Alen's New-York lawyers, was in consultation with Mr. Van Alen until a late hour last night.
BERLIN, Oct. 29. -- Sir Edward Malet visited Friedrichsruh to-day and took a cordial farewell of Prince Bismarck.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29. -- Joseph H. Manley, the member of the Republican National Executive Committee from Maine, arrived yesterday noon. Mr. Manley declares his visit to the coast is for pleasure only and he declines to discuss politics. He is stanch for San Francisco, however, as the meeting place of the Republican National Convention.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Government officials are in ignorance of any information confirmatory of the statement printed in San Francisco to-day that troops, organzied and drilled under the inspection of revenue officers, are now in Alaska north of Juneau, to protect American miners in their rights.

PARIS, Oct. 29. -- President Faure spent the whole day in consultation with leading politicians, including Gen. Zurlinden and MM. Lebon, Poincare, and Leygues, of the Ribot Ministry. Problems involved in the budget were the chief matters of discussion.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- Fifty cases of typhoid fever are reported in this city and several deaths from the disease have occurred. A similar epidemic of this disease which occurred last Spring was attributed to the water supply, which was contaminated by sewage from other towns on Black River, where the disease had been somewhat prevalent.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- A dispatch to The Globe from Hongkong, under to-day's data, says that Wong-Chi-Chuan was appointed last Fall by an imperial edict to go on a special mission to Russia, ostensibly to congratulate the new Czar Nicholas II. upon his succession to the throne, but really to convey to St. Petersburg a secret treaty conceding the right to Russia to carry the Siberian Railway through Manchuria to Vladivostock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The President has not yet taken up the question of a successor to the late Fish Commissioner McDonald, and may not till the vacancy for some time. There are several candidates and the friends of each have been quite active of late. So far as can be learned the President has not given any indication of his preference, if he has any.

Edward M. Shepard, the reform Democratic candidate for Mayor of Brooklyn, has not dodged the excise question, as has been done by Edward M. Grout and Frederick W. Wurster. Mr. Shepard gave out yesterday a public statement, wherein were set forth his views fully and unequivocally on the subject of local option and Sun day observance.
Half a dozen prominent New-York men expressed their opinions last night, on local option and Sunday saloons to a large audience in Chickering Hall.

Henry Irving opened his New-York season last night in Abbey's Theatre in "Macbeth." It was a large, well-dressed, prosperous-looking audience that faced Mr. Irving, or Sir Henry, as he has come back to us. It could not have been other than a prosperous audience, for orchestra seats sold at $3 each, and every seat in the house had been sold.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Since the statement was made recently in The Daily News that Lord Salisbury intended to choose a Poet Laureate from the ranks of journalism to succeed the late Lord Tennyson, many conjectures have been indulged in as to who would be selected to fill the office.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

Arrangements for the tournament of the bowling teams of the cycle clubs of Brooklyn have been completed. The tourney will begin on Nov. 6, and continue until Feb. 18. The schedule, as prepared by Chairman Boe of the Bowling committee, is as follows, the games being played in the alleys of the club first named:

All cyclists living along the route from Patchogue to Port Jefferson, L.I., are deeply interested in the proposed bicycle path between those points. The subject is one which has long been talked about, but for which little or no action has been taken until recently. Several meetings have been held during the past month, and the prospect seems bright for the ultimate success of the scheme.
" Little boy," said a man, severely, "I wouldn't act that way --"
Following are the entries for the steeplechases to-day, the last regular day of the New-York Steeplechase Association meeting:
Cyclists wishing to joint the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Capt. Calvin L. Hooper of the revenue cutter Rush, who was last year in command of our revenue marine patrol in Bering Sea, has been summoned to Washington to confer with the State Department and Treasury officials in regard to the proposed new treaty for a mixed commission to establish the damages suffered by Canadian sealers in Bering Sea.

The proposition of the New-York pilots to reduce the number of sailing boats from twenty-one to seven, and the subsequent substitution of steam craft for the seven sailing boats, received further and very substantial recognition at the hands of the Pilot Commissioners at their regular meeting yesterday.

Mr. Samuel L. Parish has sold to Ottinger Brothers, at $87,500, the block front on the east side of Morningside Avenue, between One Hundred and Twentieth and One Hundred and Twenty-first Streets, 200 by 100.

The substitution of steamers for the beautiful little vessels which the New-York pilots have always used will doubtless increase the efficiency of the service and therefore cannot be criticised. None the less is the change one that is to be sorrowfully contemplated as another of the many which have robbed the sea of so much poetry and which have already made the old-fashioned sailor and his virtues almost things of the past.
BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- The Chicago A.A football team added one more scalp to its belt this afternoon on the South End grounds by easily defeating the Technology eleven by a score of 46 to 0.

The Republican district leaders have a new grievance. They find that the new ballot law is so confusing in its terms, and so uncertain in its application, that a force of paid interpreters will be required on election day to explain to intending voters how to mark a ballot so that it will count a vote for each office to be filled.

Into the life of Benjamin R. Weeks, able seaman, has been crowded more thrilling and amazing misadventures than usually fall to the lot of the coasting mariner -- a class of men to whom disaster is not obsolete and danger never new.
" I love to prepare meats," said Mrs. Rorer at one of her lectures at the Madison Square Garden. "I should like to have a chance to show you how to do it."
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Edward Tracey of Ridgewood Park, proprietor of a horseshoeing establishment at 146 West Thirty-fifth Street, New-York, was killed last night on the West Shore Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Lieut. Albert P. Niblack, United States Navy, to-day submitted his report to the Secretary of the Navy on the annual tour of duty of the First Battalion of the Naval Militia of the State of New-York.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 29. -- The Constitutional Convention took a yea-and-nay vote this afternoon on the proposition to allow woman suffrage with property and educational qualifications. The proposition was rejected by a vote of 121 to 26.

The Presidents of the trunk line railroads and their Western connections will meet in this city to-day for the purpose of appending their signatures and affixing the seals of their respective corporations to the elaborate traffic agreement recently framed.

HAVANA, Oct. 30. -- A dispatch from Puerto Principe says it is reported there than Gen. Maximo Gomez, the Commander in Chief of the insurgents, has resigned his command, and will leave the island for the purpose of having the wounds in his legs cured. It is said that he is now taking leave of his followers prior to departing, but his destination is not mentioned.

Oswald Ottendorfer was asked yesterday by a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES if he had any reply to make to Theodore Roosevelt's strictures on his letter which was read at the meeting of the Excise Reform Association, and commented on by Mr. Roosevelt Tuesday evening at Chickering Hall.

A number of Federal prisoners convicted at the October term of various offenses were sentenced yesterday by Judge Brown, in the United States Circuit Court, criminal branch, to terms of imprisonment varying from three to six years.

The Committee of Fifty held a grand mass meeting at Cooper Union last night. Every seat and every foot of room in which persons were allowed to stand were occupied by 7:30, and thereafter hundreds were turned away from the doors.

The session of the old Dock Board investigation held before Commissioners of Accounts Terry and Dennis was unusually long yesterday. It was unusually interesting, too, and the room in the Stewart Building was crowded to the doors.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 30. -- The official investigation into the charges of mismanagement and immorality in the conduct of the affairs of the anti-Cruelty Society was begun to-day in the County Court House.

I would like a word with your Jamaica correspondent, from an extra-territorial corner of the earth that he can scarcely expect to hear from. I have read his strictures upon the government of the island, because of the reluctance to admit Florida plants and buds, without inspection, and his insinuation that the officials of the botanical gardens are rather scientific than practical.
TYLER, Texas, Oct. 30. -- Mrs. Leonard Bell, wife of a prosperous farmer living near Kilgore, visited her mother Sunday night, and on her way home was assaulted, killed, and mutilated.

Justice William J. Gaynor replied yesterday to the criticism of him made by Edward M. Shepard in his speech at the Reform Democratic mass meeting in the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Tuesday evening, Oct. 22.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Oct. 30. -- At the conference of the Trans-Mississippi Freight Rate Association to-day representatives of the Utah Jobbers' Association made their plea to have Salt Lake and other Utah points put on a more equitable basis as regards freight rates. The Southern Pacific proposition was discussed most of the day without any conclusion being arrived at.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 30. -- St. Patrick's Church here was the scene of a brilliant wedding to-day, the contracting parties being James J. Potts, former Assistant City Treasurer, and Miss Katie E. Fuhrman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otis Fuhrman of Elizabethport.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Oct. 30. -- Beginning today the Hightstown Baptist Church is holding a five days' series of meetings, commemorative of the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the establishment of the Baptist Church of Hightstown.

It is fortunate for the people of Kings County that Judge GEORGE B. ABBOTT is the candidate of both the Democratic organizations for the office of Surrogate. This ought, under even ordinary conditions, to secure his election. But apart from any party reasons he should be elected because he is an eminently fit man for the extremely responsible position.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- There are ten presumed agents of the Merchants and Manufacturers' Employment Bureau on the Hudson River, who mourn the departure for the Pacific coast of W. Allen Shephard, who took with him $200 or more of the hard-earned cash of each. Shephard was the head and front of the concern.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Some of the Treasury Department officials have been making interesting discoveries in the method of bonding public officers. It is found that 106,000 officers are under bond to the Government, the amount involved being more than $163,000,000. Most of these officers, 104,000 in number, are Postmasters.
A number of rare books on Mormonism and other subjects in Part 11 of the Berries Library were sold yesterday by Bangs H Co., among them being the following:

No special meeting of Good Government Club A will be held to decide whether to indorse or not to indorse the Good Government Club ticket. The petition asking that such meeting be called, signed by some of the most prominent men in the club. has bee withdrawn.

WESTWOOD, N.J., Oct. 30. -- Lyman Wardle, the fourteen-year-old son of Druggist John W. Wardle of this place, disappeared from home on Monday afternoon, and has been seen but once since by those who know him. This was at Closter about 3 o'clock on Monday afternoon, and he was going toward the river.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 30. -- The man who said at the time of the opening of the campaign in this State that the Democrats had a chance to win was hooted at and vigorously ridiculed. But the fact is that the possibility of Democratic success is now clearly established and some of the best-informed men in the State declare that Judge Babb, the nominee for Governor, is certain to win.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- It is interesting to observe what medical science think of Holmes from a study of his mental traits as revealed by his picture. The portrait of Holmes was shown to Dr. Horatio C. Wood, one of the most famous of experts in criminology, with a request for his opinion. After looking at the picture carefully, Dr. Wood said:

A mass meeting under the auspices of the Republican Club of the City of New-York, arranged by the East Side Young Men's Republican Club of the Eighth Assembly District, was held in Irving Hall, 216 Broome Street, last night. The audience was large and noisy. It assembled early, as Mayor Strong had been announced as the chief speaker.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Secretary Lamont issued an order this morning naming the fortification at Sandy Hook Fort Hancock, in honor of the late Gen. W.S. Hancock, the hero of Gettysburg.

There was another affecting scene yesterday at the trial of David F. Hannigan for the murder of Solomon H. Mann. It came when Charles Lex Brooke, son of the chief counsel for the defense, opened the case for Hannigan in a short dramatic speech. Mr. Brooke pictured the home life of the Hannigans before the disgrace came to Loretta, the youngest of the family.

The only doubt now existing in the minds of the leaders of the German-American Reform Union as to the successful outcome of their mammoth parade and mass meetings to-night is in reference to the elements. Should the weather be propitious, the men in charge of the affair promise a great demonstration.

BELLEFONTE, Penn., Oct. 30. -- Two students have been expelled from the State College and fourteen indefinitely suspended for hazing, and, in addition, most of them, or may be all of them, may yet get into the criminal courts before the affair is entirely at an end.

CLIFTON, S.I., Oct. 30. -- Dolly Beatty, thirteen years old, daughter of James Beatty, a traveling salesman, jumped off a pier into the upper bay this afternoon, and started to swim toward deep water. Two men jumped after her, and, bringing her ashore, took her home.

Two young shopgirls narrowly escaped being trampled last evening by the great crowd of passengers that is discharged during the "rush hours" every evening at the Brooklyn end of the East River Bridge.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Oct. 30. -- James J. Corbett is safely housed under a friendly roof in Hot Springs. By the articles of agreement which bear his signature, he guarantees to be in this city to-morrow, prepared to contest for continued possession of his present title of champion heavyweight of the world.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Congressman Meyer of Louisiana and Col. J.D. Hill, representative of the sugar planters' Executive Committee, to-day made application to Mr. Baldwin, Auditor for the Treasury Department, for certification of the claim of John N. Pharr, for $4,537.50, and of Cleophas Legarde, for $4,274.55, payable out of the $238,000 sugar bounty appropriation.

I have your letter, and beg you to convey to my Albany friends and warm neighbors at the Democratic ratification meeting this evening my cordial congratulations upon the wise and patriotic declaration of their State platform concerning the leading questions before the American people, and the assurance of my earnest wish for the success of our excellent State ticket.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 30. -- A pretty wedding took place in the First Reformed Church, East Orange, to-night, when Miss Cynthia Badeau Matthews, daughter of Charles B. Matthews, and Walter Palmer were married by the Rev. Dr. George H. Bishop, the pastor of the church.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Oct. 30. -- Springfield was visited at midnight by one of the most disastrous fires in its history.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- Harry Cromwell, George Lamoreaux, and William Wise, while out hunting yesterday in Posket's Woods, near Schunnemuk, were attacked by wildcats and barely escaped with their lives.
NORWALK, Conn.. Oct. 30. -- Burglars entered the Darien Post Office last night and' blew the safe into small bits with guncotton or some other high explosive.

Secretary HERBERT'S decision that the Detroit Dry Dock Company, although the lowest bidders for two of the new composite gunboats, cannot be allowed to build them at their yards, follows the decision of his predecessor in the case of the Bancroft. It was then held that the treaty of 1817 forbade the construction of a war vessel on the lakes.

UTICA, Oct. 30. -- The closing week of the campaign in this county is proving one of the most exciting in its history, and while most of the interest centres in the election of Senator, the State tickets are by no means entirely forgotten.

Messrs. William Hall's Sons have bought from the Bruner estate the block front on the east side of Lexington Avenue, between Ninety-seventh and Ninety-eighth Streets, 201.10 feet on the avenue, 195 feet on Ninety-seventh, and 70 feet on Ninety-eighth Street; and, also, four lots on the south side of Ninety-eighth Street, 100 feet east of Park Avenue.

There seems to be no doubt that tile patriot army in Cuba has been reinforced. Almost fifty nlen from somewhere or other, possibly from America, have landed on the island and enrolled themselves under the standard of revolt. This, of course, will force the royalists to import at least 50,000 more conscripts, and will delay active operations on the part of CAMPOS even longer than the recent thunder sho'er did.

The Emma Willard Association held its fifth annual banquet at the Windsor Hotel yesterday afternoon, and 200 early members of the Emma Willard School gathered around the long tables in an upper banquet hall, where they discussed an excellent menu, as well as the work of the association in which they are so greatly interested.
The police of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station are at a loss to account for the disappearance of a milk can which, until a late hour Tuesday night, was in the precinct station house.

There were at least two spoons in the Madison Square Garden concert hall last evening, where Mrs. Rorer was giving her second cooking lecture to men, and, consequently, two correspondingly happy individuals.

There appears to be a serious hitch in the final adoption of the much-discussed joint traffic agreement The new scheme, which has been in process of formation since last June, and which readily received the formal approval of the Directors of several railroad companies, failed of ratification at a full meeting of the Presidents in this city yesterday.

The Committee of Fifty and the Campaign Committee of the Good Government Clubs came to a mutual understanding yesterday in regard to the equipment of the polls on election day with efficient watchers. The Good Government Campaign Committee will make all the arrangements for watchers.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. Oct. -- Miss Katherine Onderdonk Weller daughter of Surrogate A.N. Weller of Queens County, was married to Charles Lambert Addison at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon in the Cathedral of the Incarnation. The ceremony was performed by Bishop Littlejohn of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, assisted by the Rev. Samuel Cox, Dean of the cathedral corporation.
BOSTON, Oct. 30. -- The sixteenth annual meeting of the Woman's Home Missionary Association was held here to-day.

Those who wanted to have the privilege of sitting in the front row of boxes at the Madison Square Garden during the week of the Horse Show met in the Concert Hall of the Garden yesterday afternoon and purchased the boxes at auction. The attendance was quite large, and the members of the Hunt and Country Clubs were well represented.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- Visitors to the gallery of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange to-day witnessed a scene of excitement such as can only be evoked by a crash in the stock market.

Joseph H. Deutsch, the private detective who was charged with violating the postal laws by sending a threatening letter to Edward M. Brown, Commodore of the New-York Yacht Club, in June, 1894, was discharged in the United States Circuit Court yesterday, the jury having returned a verdict of not guilty.

It is still a common remark that while the new ballot makes "straight" voting very easy, it makes voting a "mixed ticket" difficult. It is only a relative matter, and, in point of fact, voting any kind of a mixed ticket is not in the least difficult for any one who can read names printed in the English language.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- The Pague court-martial held its eighth and final session at Fort Sheridan to-day, and the court has only to consider its verdict. At the opening of the morning session, Major Girard again took the witness stand for the purpose of testifying to the mental condition of the accused as shown by the evidence of the witnesses.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 30. -- William H. MacCracken of 61 Prospect Street was arraigned before Police Justice Douglass to-day, charged with embezzling $581.47 of the funds belonging to the Second United Presbyterian Church. The complaint was made by Samuel C. Meginnis, President of the Board of Trustees.

There was nothing inactive about the Stecklerite campaign last night, when the colored citizens of the Fifteenth Assembly District gathered in Central Hall to hear the Independent County Organization candidates. There were about fifty persons present. What they lacked in number was made up in enthusiasm.

The Fall meeting of the New-York Steeplechase Association was brought to a close at the Westchester race track yesterday. The card was a good one, the sport first class, with good, sharp contests over the jumps, but the attendance was not what it should have been. The cool weather had much to do with that, however, for it was altogether too cool for comfort, unless one wore good, heavy clothing.

At a meeting of the Board of Estimate in the Mayor's office, yesterday afternoon, Controller Fitch presented the budget of estimates for the year 1896, doing so, as he said, under protest as to the increase over the last year's appropriations.

In answer to a query from the Civil Service Reform Association as to whether, if elected, he would give his slupport to a measure designed to extend the operation of the civil service laws as the Constitution requires, John J. Kinney, the Democratic candidate for member of Assembly in the Second District of Jefferson County, N.Y., replied that as far as the Constitution and laws exist, he would upheld them until repealed.

The chief topic of discussion yesterday in Brooklyn in connection with the campaign was the meeting which Sheriff Buttling and the other lieutenants of Jacob Worth held Tuesday night in Controller Palmer's office in the City Hall, for the purpose of raising funds for Frederick W. Wurster, the Republican Mayoralty candidate.

Assistant District Attorney John Maguire of Brooklyn has been suspended from duty by District Attorney James W. Ridgway for neglect of duty. Mr. Ridgway yesterday notified County Treasurer Taylor of the suspension.

The new East River Bridge Commission devoted itself yesterday to hearing representatives of the Brooklyn surface and elevated roads which deposit passengers in the neighborhood of the Brooklyn end of the proposed bridge. All the members of the commission were present except Mayor Strong, although Mayor Schieren appeared only in time to hear the railroad men talk.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 30 -- The First Presbyterian Church of South Orange was thronged by notables this evening, when Miss Margaret Stevenson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Stevenson, and Frederick W. Tolley of Providence, R.I., were married by the pastor, the Rev. George L. Spinning.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 30. -- The Board of Police Commissioners caused an upheaval last night in the police force. Twenty-nine patrolmen were summarily discharged, fourteen of them being Republicans and fifteen Democrats. There were no charges against any of the dismissed men, but the board claims that their places can be better filled.

ALBANY, Oct. 30. -- An informal proposition has been made by some men who have taken the trouble to ascertain the facts that Gov. Morton and Attorney General Hancock take steps to recover from the State of Pennsylvania the expense of repelling an invasion of the peaceful borders of New-York. The matter has not yet been laid before the Governor.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 30. -- To-night marked the revival of an old-time custom at Princeton, the midnight cane spree. Not since the Fall of 1891 has this event been permitted by the Faculty till to-night, and no undergraduate now in college had before witnessed the old custom, which was conducted by Princeton students from time immemorial.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 30. -- A Newfoundland dog, owned by Expressman William Marshall of Main Street, Millburn, was, it was supposed, affected with rabies and ran wild for about an hour yesterday afternoon, until he was shot by Lincoln Ellis.

Since ex-Inspector Alexander S. Williams has taken to politics, his neighbors have had more experiences than would fill several books. They have reached a stage where they are prepared for anything, but they are not courting trouble, and they take the precaution these days to double lock their doors, bar their windows, and chain their door mats.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 30. -- A number of Republican employers of labor in this city and vicinity, when the Wilson Tariff bill was under discussion, did not hesitate to say that if it was passed their business would be ruined. This was particularly true in the cases of hosiery and handkerchief manufacturers.

The rooster emblem adopted by the State Democracy to designate that faction of the Democratic Party received another setback yesterday by the decision of the General Term of the Supreme Court, which unanimously affirmed the decision of Justice Beach, made on Monday. The effect of this action is to relegate the rooster emblem from the third to the seventh column on the ballot.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- "The change in the French Ministry may, perhaps, delay an adjustment of the Waller case," said a well-informed official this morning, "but it cannot affect the interests of the Madagascar ex-Consul one-half so prejudicially as the ill-advised efforts of his friends here have done.

ORANGE, N.J. Oct. 30. -- Miss Minnie Louise Wolfe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Wolfe of Steuben Street, East Orange, and Frederick James Hull of Newark were married to-night in the First Congregation Church, East Orange, by the Rev. Charles C. Winans of Watsessing.

Every wheelman who has ridden on the famous Coney Island cycle path will be pleased to learn that there is every prospect of a return path being laid in the near future. In fact, work has already been started in this direction. The outcome of the labor may not be a cycle path as fine as the one now in use, but it will be a path to all intents and purposes.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 30. -- Harry S. New, editor of The Indianapolis Journal, was in the city to-day. Speaking of the many interviews regarding the candidacy of ex-President Harrison and otherwise, Mr. New said: "That is a question no man except Gen. Harrison himself can authoritatively speak upon.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- The members of the congregations of the First Presbyterian Church and Immanuel Chapel last night gave a farewell reception to the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. John Reid of the former church, who are about to remove to Detroit, Mich., where Dr. Reid is to become the pastor of the Fort Street Presbyterian Church.
BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 30. -- Congressman George L. Wellington, Chairman of the Republican State Central Committee, reiterated to-day his charge that Senator Quay is helping Senator Gorman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The negotiations which were begun on Monday last by Sir Julian Paunceforte and Secretary Olney, looking to the preparation of a convention for a settlement of the seizures of Canadian vessels in Bering Sea, were resumed at 10 o'clock this morning. Sir Julian was accompanied by Sir Mackenzie Bowell and Sir Charles Tupper of Ottawa.
The Democratic State campaign is running along in a way that ought to prevent the Republican managers from going to sleep.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 30. -- Natalie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Henry Wilson of this city was married this evening to Thomas Andrew Bassett of New-Haven.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 30. -- The action yesterday of Councils' Committee of Inquiry, requesting that citizens holding receipts for money paid into the office of the City Attorney during the last decade submit them for examination, is having results. The very first receipt received by the City Controller this morning for money paid on a compromised lien proves a damaging piece of evidence.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- Umpire Moyle held Pennsylvania down to 12 points to-day in the game between Brown and the University of Pennsylvania. It is impossible to say what would otherwise have been the result, but certain it is that Moyle absolutely prevented any higher score. In the first half, on not a single occasion did Pennsylvania gain ground but the ball was recalled where it had been put in play and given to Brown.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- The annual report of Capt. W.T. Sampson, Chief of the Naval Bureau of Ordnance, which has just been presented to the Secretary of the Navy, is voluminous and comprehensive concerning the operations of ordnance work during the year. It shows the character and extent of work done, and contains an estimate of $6,457,984 for carrying out the plans of the bureau for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1897.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 30. -- Natalie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Henry Wilson of this city was married this evening to Thomas Andrew Bassett of New-Haven.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 30. -- The action yesterday of Councils' Committee of Inquiry, requesting that citizens holding receipts for money paid into the office of the City Attorney during the last decade submit them for examination, is having results. The very first receipt received by the City Controller this morning for money paid on a compromised lien proves a damaging piece of evidence.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30. -- Umpire Moyle held Pennsylvania down to 12 points to-day in the game between Brown and the University of Pennsylvania. It is impossible to say what would otherwise have been the result, but certain it is that Moyle absolutely prevented any higher score. In the first half, on not a single occasion did Pennsylvania gain ground but the ball was recalled where it had been put in play and given to Brown.

Society was out in full force at the Academy of Design yesterday afternoon at the opening of the Loan Exhibition of Portraits in aid of St. John's Guild and the Orthopedic Hospital. It was the first large gathering of fashionable folks this season, and really marked the opening of the gayeties of late Autumn and the Winter.

Mayor Strong, notwithstanding the rain and his gout, addressed a Republican mass meeting last night, in the rooms of the Charles Marks Republican Club, at One Hundred and Seventh Street and Lexington Avenue. He was accompanied by J. Seaver Page of the Union League Club.

OWEGO, Oct. 31. -- It was Mr. Platt's idea at Saratoga to say nothing on the question of excise in the Republican State platform. In the little conference in the United States Hotel on the Sunday night previous to the convention the question was discussed fully and freely, and, as a matter of course, the other conferrees agreed with Mr. Platt.

Many persons, if they were asked about it, would say without hesitation that these last days of October are the real Indian Summer. The term is vaguely employed, and at one time or another has been stretched to include almost all the attractive weather with which we are blessed between the close of August and the 1st of December.

President Roosevelt of the Board of Police appeared before the Excise Committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday and talked to it about the present excise law, and what modifications he favored. Nearly one-half of the Board of Aldermen was present, and Morris Tekulsky, formerly President of the Liquor Dealers' Association, was an interested auditor.

ANDERSON, Ind., Oct. 31. -- The ten-thousand-dollar damage suit of Mrs. Dr. Hilligoss against W.R. Covert is on for trial in the Superior Court. This case has attracted widespread interest. It involves the question of spiritualism for the first time really brought into the court.

PARIS, Oct. 7. -- I have a friend who tells me constantly of the past glory of a country house "built around a grand piano." Such is the case of the "Navarraise" of M. Massenet -- the grand piano is Emma Calve. I might say that she is the orchestra, soul and body; for the mere episode taken from a novel of M. Claretie is only a Neuville picture.

That the City of New-York will be appropriately represented by the business community at the Atlanta Exposition on Manhattan Day was definitely settled at a meeting of prominent citizens held yesterday in the Governor's Room in the City Hall, over which Mayor Strong presided.

We gave an account yesterday morning of the narrow escape of some young girls from being trampled by the crowd at the Brooklyn terminus of the bridge. According to the testimony of the guards, it is not an unusual occurrence, and any one who is forced to use the bridge during the period graphically and accurately described as the "crush" hours can easily see that such occurrences are inevitable.

Is Mr. RICHARD CROKER familiar with the rhymes of Ironquill, the Kansas bard who wears Arcturus for his bosom pin, and who married to immortal verse the tragic story of the brass-eyed bird-pup that played in the path of the cyclone? If he is, he must remember how

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- This week's bulletin of the Racing Board, out to-day, contains no reference to the "fixed race" case of Titus, Cabanne, and Murphy. It is said that the board is still receiving testimony, and that its decision will not be made known for at least two weeks to come. The important items in the bulletin are as follows:
Within a few days the campaign of 1895 will have become a matter of history.

PITTSFIELD Mass., Oct. 31. -- The marriage of John Sherman Hoyt of New-York and Miss Ethel Phelps Stokes, second daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anson Phelps Stokes of New-York and Lenox, was celebrated at Trinity Church in Lenox this noon, and was one of the most brilliant social events which, the town has ever seen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The report that Mgr. Satolli, Apostolic Delegate to the United States, was to receive additional honor at the hands of Pope Leo XIII., was verified at the legation to-day, when Dr. Rooker, the Delegate's secretary, officially announced that Mgr. Satolli would be created a Cardinal at the Consistory to be held in Rome about the middle of November.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The Navy Department, on being informed that the new cruiser Indiana had touched bottom on her trial trip up the Delaware, caused a careful examination of the vessel to be made at the Cramps' shipyards. The examination was exhaustive, and showed that the ship had not been damaged in any manner whatever.

It was a very good day for the defense in the Hannigan murder trial yesterday, but an exceedingly trying one for the defendant. It was good for the defense, because the four witnesses who appeared, swore, without exception, that Hannigan's conduct just prior to the shooting of Solomon H. Mann on May 23 last was irrational and queer, and the most prolonged and persistent cross-examination by the prosecution could not shake them in their belief.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The Grand Jury of the District this afternoon returned an indictment against Miss Elizabeth Flagler, daughter of G.M. Flagler, Chief of Ordnance of the army. She is charged with manslaughter in the shooting of Ernest Green, a young colored boy, last August, while he was picking up a pear from under a tree in the yard surrounding the Flagler residence.

The difficulties of transportation between New-York and Brooklyn are to be relieved, for Sorosis is to build a bridge. That was a motion which was made and carried at the Sorosis School of Parliamentary Laws yesterday afternoon, at any rate.

Arthur Von Briesen has sent a letter to Joseph H. Choate, replying to the strictures, passed by him and several other speakers at the fusion mass meeting Wednesday night, on the Good Government men who refused to withdraw their forces.

Edward M. Shepard, reform Democratic candidate for Mayor of Brooklyn, made a brief reply yesterday to Supreme Court Justice William J. Gaynor's published statement containing strictures on Mr. Shepard and the other reform leaders.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

While the provisional estimates for next year's city budget show an increase of something more than $5,000,000 over the final appropriations for the present year, by far the greater part of it appears in items regarding which the Board of Estimate and Apportionment had no discretion and was therefore absolutely unavoidable.

There is a notable and happy change, in this canvass, in the spirit in which civil service reform is treated. It has now become pretty well settled in the minds of the people of this State, and especially in the large cities, that the essential purpose of the reform is to abolish patronage, to take the offices out of politics and politics out of the offices.

The Republicans made a new move last night by resolving to hold a mass meeting in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. Among the speakers at the meeting will be Chauncey Depew, Elihu Root, Frank Hiscock, Edward Lauterbach, and Mrs. Helen V. Boswell.

ALBANY, Oct. 31. -- The case of Erastus Wiman, charged with forgery by R.G. Dun Co., came before the Court of Appeals to-day. The District Attorney of New-York appealed against the decision of the Supreme Court, which was favorable to Mr. Wiman, following the certificate of doubt by Judge Barrett.
Hall Caine, the English novelist, returned to this city yesterday afternoon with his family from Canada, and to-night he will be the guest at dinner of the Aldine Club of 75 Fifth Avenue.

ALBANY, Oct. 31. -- A clause in the new Constitution cuts off at least $3,000 a year revenue and deprives the State of a certain amount of protection to its forest lands and its game. The clause in question provides that the lands owned by the State constituting the forest preserve shall not be leased, sold, or exchanged.

A solemn and impressive service was held last night in Holy Trinity Church, Brooklyn, in memory of Charles Henry Hall, D.D., for twenty-six years rector of the parish. There was little attempt at decoration, two large bunches of chrysanthemums and one of handsome white roses being all the flowers in the chancel.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 31. -- The Gorman Democrats have practically given up all hope of electing Hurst Governor. The Democratic politicians to-day took down the money they had up for bets. The expectation is that Lowndes will sweep both city and State. A petition for an anti-Gorman mass meeting Saturday night was circulated to-day on the Corn and Flour Exchange, and was signed by two out of every three Democrats.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- Three supposed tramps waylaid Thomas Baxter, the assistant agent of this small station on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, in plain view of Sing Sing Prison, this morning. This agent is a young telegraph operator who works all night for the convenience of Vice President Webb, who lives near by.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Oct. 31. -- The new harbor defense ram Katahdin had her official trial over the Long Island course today, and, although her actual time did not bring her within the specified limit, it is confidently expected that allowances for currents, , will raise her average above the required 17 knots.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The sympathy of Washingtonians for the cause of Cuba was put to the test to-night and responded in tones in which there was heard no note of discord. The drizzling rain of to-day made an uncomfortable night for a mass meeting, but soon after the hour announced Metzerott's Hall was filled, amny ladies being present.

BUFFALO, Oct. 31. -- Erie County has, on a conservative estimate, 120,000 German-American citizens. The population is said by some to be one-half of foreign birth or extraction. If that be true, then the estimated 120,000 is too small.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Oct. 31. -- Commodore David Banks, formerly of the Atlantic Yacht Club, was before Justice MacKenna's court here to-day to press the charge of grand larceny against William H. Clark, who was steward of his schooner yacht Water Witch last Summer.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Chicagoans were alarmed at few minutes after 5 o'clock this morning by feeling a distinct earthquake shock. The vibrations, which were felt plainly all over the city, were severe enough to shake objects on the mantels or desks in the tall buildings, and milkmen and other early risers, fearing that some of the sky-scrapers might take a tumble, made haste to get on streets where there was less danger.

James P. Archibald, Warden of Ludlow Street Jail, prominent in the councils of the State Democracy, and ex-labor agitator, was a prisoner in the West Thirtieth Street Station last night, charged with intoxication.
There is a widespread and as yet uncontradicted rumor that the local Prohibitionists made no uncomplimentary remarks about yesterday's weather.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 31. -- From all appearances "Bob" Fitzsimmons is not likely to be at liberty to participate in a prizefight for several days to come. To-day's legal proceedings were brief and inconclusive, but they indicate that, while Judge Martin will not strain the law against the lengthy Australian, neither will he hurry the proceedings along in order to oblige the pugilistic contingent.

The German-American Reform Union and the League of United Societies for Liberal Sunday Laws had a mass meeting last night at Cooper Union. The rainstorm that prevailed seemed to have but little effect on the German citizens, for when the meeting was called, nearly every seat in the big hall was taken, and a number of persons stood in the back part of the room.

Controller Fitch has a very treacherous memory. The conversation I quoted took place in the Mayor's room, where plenty of people were walking to and fro near us; it was in no way confidential. Mr. Fitch said nothing about any party indorsing us. What he said was that my conduct in enforcing the law would prevent such a ticket as that which won last year from getting 30,000 votes this year.

The rain drowned out the Republican mass meeting at the Clermont Avenue Rink in Brooklyn last night. The band played dismally in front of the great building for half an hour, and then marched inside, followed by a hundred persons or so. At 8 o'clock there were not over 400 in the rink and there were less than a dozen on the stage.

MONTREAL, Oct. 31. -- Dr. Seward Webb of New-York is in this city and has had a conference with Sir William Van Horne of the Canadian Pacific in connection, it is said, with a new branch line the New-York Central intends building from Beauharnois to Caughnawaga.

I find in some of the morning papers to-day an account of L. sermon delivered from a text in St. Paul's first epistle to the Corinthians, by Theodore Roosevelt, last evening, in which he is reported as having said. "Controller Fitch said to me some time ago. 'You won't poll 30,000 votes,' speaking of the fusion ticket."

An explosion of accummulated gas in a sewer at Centre and Worth Streets about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon blew the cover of a manhole about fifty feet into the air and shook buildings for five and six blocks in the neighborhood. The explosion sounded as if a tall building had collapsed. Fortunately no one was injured.

The Feast of All Saints will be celebrated with great solemnity in St. Patrick's Cathedral to-day. Masses will be said at 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9 o'clock A.M., and at 10 o'clock A.M. a high mass will be sung. At the conclusion of this service the exposition of the Blessed Sacrament will take place.

-- Now we have the Summer number of Modern Art, and presently Mr. Bowles will have caught up with the times as to the date of the issue of his beautiful magazine. But the publication is behind time only in that respect. In everything else it is much ahead of any of its competitors, and stands quite unrivaled as a most exquisite and artistic piece of bookmaking.
President Cleveland's strong indorsement of the Democratic State platform and ticket has stirred matters up in State politics.
READING, Penn., Oct. 31. -- Six persons were injured by the derailing of a passenger train between Mertztown and Shamrock this morning. Those injured were:

The accompanying letter of W.M. Thackeray's, written to a relative during his American tour, has just come into my possession. Strange to say, it has been in the same hands for over forty years, and came to me direct from the house to which it was originally addressed. It is in the original envelope bearing Thackeray's monogram, and is marked "per Cunard steamer, April 6."

" The rafting season has practically closed," remarked Secretary George Watson of the Lumbermen's Exchange. "The general public has little conception of the effect this fact has upon the army engaged in the lumber business The disappearance of the long, low rafts, moving down the river with a steamboat at either end, tells as surely that Winter is nigh as the thermometer kept by Prof. Frankenfield.

Mrs. M.T. Cotes has sold the southeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Sixth Street, 100 by 100.11. A church is to be erected on the site. The other half of the block is now occupied by a Presbyterian Church.

The good work done by the United Hebrew Charities for the relief of the Jewish poor of this city during the past year was outlined in the reports of President Henry Rice and the General Manager, Nathaniel S. Rosenau, read at the annual meeting of the association, held Wednesday in the vestry rooms of the Temple Emanu-El.

The October Grand Jury adjourned at noon yesterday. Before the adjournment Foreman Cross, on behalf of the jury, handed to Judge Allison, in the Court of General Sessions, a presentment condemning the overcrowding of the Tombs and Ludlow Street Jail, and the unsanitary condition of the latter prison.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 31. -- To-day the Southern Pacific Railroad started the first train of its "Sunset Limited," which will run regularly this Winter, leaving New-Orleans every Monday and Thursday. The splendid train consists of one composite car, two double drawing-room ten-section sleepers, a dining car, and one ladies' parlor and compartment car.

PARIS, Oct. 31. -- M. Bourgeois has succeeded in forming a Cabinet, all the portfolios having been accepted, with the exception of that of the Foreign Ministry. The new Cabinet is constituted as follows:

" Won't you always tuck my handkerchiefs into my pocket for me?" said Nathan Ladon of Menominee, Wis., yesterday afternoon, as he looked down at pretty Mary Frank, manager of Siegel, Cooper Co.'s handkerchief counter, who was coyly poking a bit of blue-bordered linen, which he had just purchased, into the breast pocket of his coat.
