It is the boast of ex-Inspector Williams that his political campaigning goes on, rain or shine. Accordingly the ex-Inspector was out yesterday "hussling," as he terms it, as usual. A long mackintosh dangled to his heels, his head was incased in a hat that defied the rain, and for additional protection he carried a stout umbrella, and wore an enormous pair of rubbers.
The storm last night kept many persons away from the mass meeting of the Audubon Republican Club, at the Athenaeum, One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street, near Amsterdam Avenue.

It was to be expected that after the efficacy of the diphtheria antitoxine serum had been clearly shown there would be attempts to deal with other infectious diseases in the same way, that is, by hypodermic injections of the blood serum of animals which have been immunized by repeated injections of the characteristic poison or toxine of the disease in question.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- "Bill" Smith is dead. On Sunday last the old hermit, one of the characters of the Adirondacks for the last twoscore years, was found dead in his lonely hut on the "Oregon Plains." His dogs, faithful companions during his life, kept vigil over the dead body.

S.M. Bixby Co., the well-known corporation which manufactures shoe blacking, harness oils, , at 194 and 196 Hester Street, went into the hands of a receiver yesterday, on the application of the Directors of the company, who stated that the concern was insolvent, and unable to meet obligations coming due.

There was a surprisingly large attendance at the Westchester track yesterday, considering the atrocious weather that prevailed. It was colder than the glad hand of T.C. Platt when he meets Warner Miller, and poured down the sort of stuff that a Prohibitionist would like to force the German-American Reform Unionists to drink for the remainder of their lives.
The meeting of the German-American Citizens' Union, in Grand Central Palace, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street, last evening, was in point of numbers and enthusiasm a decided success.

The closing of the Casino Grounds at Newport and of the Casino Club to-day will mark the end of the season of outing, and within the next few days the greater portion of the fashionable people will have closed their country houses, and will be back in town, ready for the Horse Show and the opera.

WEST POINT, Oct. 31. -- Football practice since Saturday's game with Dartmouth has been devoted principally to making the substitutes familiar with the signals and putting them in shape for the Yale game. The Dartmouth contest was the hardest experienced by West Point this season. While the excitement lasted, the cadets seemed in perfect condition, but the reaction soon set in, and the team showed up in a badly battered condition.

The report on the condition and future policy of the Grand Trunk Railway, which was submitted to the shareholders in London on Wednesday by Sir CHARLES RIVERS WILSON, will have a far-reaching interest in this country. For many years the Grand Trunk and the Canadian Pacific Railways have been important -- and for the most part disturbing -- factors in the traffic operations of the great trunk lines in the United States.
It was a day of special enjoyment for both Mrs. Rorer and her audience in the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall yesterday afternoon.
" You don't remember me, I 'spose?" he queried, as he entered an office in response to a "Come in!" from the occupant.

Lenox and Stockbridge are the two historic towns of Berkshire. Lenox, high on the hills, with its beautiful homes uniting wealth and culture, is called the "goldenrod"; Stockbridge, with its hospitable and historic hearthstones, is in the valley by the river, and is the "sweetbrier" of the hills. Between these two, near the lakes, is a village, once busy in manufactures.

The Beale-Fales case, in which Mrs. Joseph Beale, the divorced wife of Haliburton Fales, is seeking to obtain the six months' custody every year of her two children, as allowed her by the decree of divorce, was before Joseph A. Thomson of 140 Nassau Street, the referee in one of its phases, yesterday.

MUSKEGON, Mich., Oct. 25. -- The life of Charles H. Hackley, the Muskegon millionaire and philanthropist, is a story of pluck and brains, and here in this city where every line is memorized by even the smallest children, its telling is an incentive to honorable ambition and its deeds a rebuke to that wealth which holds and never gives.

The midnight bulletin of the Weather Bureau, Wednesday night, announced that the conditions were favorable for rain by to-day. The ink on the bulletin was, however, hardly dry, before a gentle drizzle began, and by daylight yesterday morning rain was falling moderately in the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- H.H. Holmes, charged with the murder of Benjamin Pietzel, lost his nerve for a moment to-day and wept. The name of "Miss Yoke" as a witness was called this morning. Holmes had expected that the woman whom he had lured into marriage in the belief that he was single, would be called upon to give testimony against him, but the prospect of her appearance in the witness box completely unnerved him.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31. -- The Princeton football players are being treated with the utmost care to avoid accident or overtraining before the game with Harvard Saturday. Fear of accident to the men induced Capt. Lea to indulge in nothing but the lightest kind of practice to-day. But the dress rehearsals usually taken before a big game were gone through with on the 'Varsity grounds.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 1. -- Henry E. Tiepke, the Superintendent of Census, has made his official returns for this city, and the figures are disappointing. Providence was supposed to have a population of 160,000. Instead, it has 145,472, against 132,146 in 1890, and 118,070 in 1885.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 1. -- The City Solicitor has decided that the proposed meeting of single tax people announced for Sunday night in the Opera House here, at which Henry George is advertised to speak, will be contrary to law. The decision is practically a notification that the police will probably stop the meeting.

Messrs. Douglas, Robinson Co. have sold, for Miss Enos, as executrix, to Henry A. Van Liew, the Columbia College leasehold, 20 West Fifty-first Street, 20 by 100.5, four-story and basement brownstone dwelling.
Senator Hill came to this city from Albany last night and went to the Hotel Nor mandie. He saw Chairman Hinkley of the Democratic State Committee and several other Democratic managers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Nothing of an official character has been received at the War Department concerning the charge made against Col. Crofton of the Thirteenth Infantry, stationed at Fort Sheridan, Ill., that he used enlisted men as servants in his private household.

The sole reason why political calculations appear to be little disturbed by the excise question outside of this city is because the Sunday prohibition clause is enforced in no other city in the State and in very few towns and villages. It may not have very much effect upon the vote in Brooklyn, because there the law is not enforced and nobody expects that it will be, whichever candidate for Mayor is elected.

Our dispatches from Pittsburg have reported that at the recent meeting of the Executive Committee of the Tin Plate Manufacturers' Association "it was decided to make an effort to secure a higher tariff."

The statement in several newspapers that Chief Engineer GREENE of the Dock Department sent checks to Mr. CROKER in order to retain his place is not justified by the testimony of Mr. GREENE and is quite incredible to those who know that gentleman. Commissioner PHELAN, having resisted the order of Mr. CROKER to remove Mr. GREENE, was naturally placed in an uncomfortable situation.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 1. -- The Constitutional Convention to-night adopted the essential section of the suffrage plan. The section was adopted in the following shape:

Brooklyn has a very good chance this year to judge of the relative fitness of three candidates for Mayor. The office, thanks to the excellent Brooklyn charter, is one requiring the highest grade of ability and character. Each of the regular party machines has done its best to supply a candidate with the requisite qualifications.

" Old Bill Vosburg," the notorious bank sneak and green goods "steerer," was arrested at the Mott Haven Station of the New-York Central Railroad yesterday afternoon, while in the act of bidding a Western victim good-by. He is locked up in the Morrisania Police Station.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- It is understood that Representative Warren B. Hooker of New-York, Secretary of the Republican caucus of the House, has issued a call for a caucus of the Republican members of the Fifty-fourth Congress, to be held in the hall of the House at 8 o'clock on the evening of Nov. 30.

Several lawyers, who said they represented residents of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards, told of grievances against the Union Railway Company before the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, during a public hearing on the resolution introduced by Alderman Hall that the board should revoke the franchise of the company.

Recorder John W. Goff returned last evening from a three weeks' trip to the South. The Recorder spent five days in Atlanta, where he got a very hearty reception, and to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES the Recorder last night painted a most glowing and enthusiastic description of the wonderful Southern metropolis, its people, its institutions, and its great exposition.

Decisions on several cases of interest to many merchants were handed down yesterday by the General Appraisers. The hosiery case of Stark Nisson of Chicago resulted adversely to the importers. This firm had formerly entered goods at Chicago, passing them in bond to that city. An advance at Chicago in certain invoices led to an entry here, which was also advanced.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1. -- Everything is ready for the big football game to-morrow between Harvard and Princeton. A rattling good contest is expected, and although the visitors are very confident of victory, Princeton men think that after the contest they will have another scalp.

Thousands of Brooklynites have complained of the new terminal of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge, which, they claim, is far from being what it should be. They say that it is not as convenient as was the old one, as in that everybody walked in the same direction and there was no confusion.
There was another interesting legal fight in the Surrogate's Court yesterday over the late Benjamin Richardson's estate, which has been in litigation for several years.

VARNA, Bulgaria, Nov. 1. -- Advices from Constantinople say that three Mussulmans have been arrested there. Several houses were searched, in which were found and seized a quantity of arms. It is stated that a plot against the Sultan's palace has been discovered. The Albanian guards at the Yildiz Kiosk refused to perform their duties on Monday night and it is supposed that they had been won over by the Mussulman committees.

Though the official ballot will contain eleven columns, no voter need pay the least attention to more than four. Three of them are taken up with the tickets of the Prohibition. Socialist-Labor, and People's Parties. Any one who votes any of these is sure to vote straight and nobody else will vote any part of them. Count these out.

The teams in the Carruthers National Tournament Brooklyn last night broke even. The South Paws rolled the best game of the series, defeating the Echos by 47 pins in the first game, but were defeated in the third game of the series by the Ansonias, after a very close and exciting contest, by 2 pins. The scores:
It was prophets' day at Tammany Hall yesterday.
PARIS, Nov. 1. -- Since the announcement last night of the formation of a new Cabinet by M. Bourgeois, some changes have been made in its composition. As completed, it is constituted as follows:

LONG ISLAND CITY, L. I., Nov. 1. -- This was the third anniversary of the opening of the Astoria Hospital, and a fitting observation of the day was the laying of the cornerstone of a handsome new building. The ceremony was participated in by clergymen representing each of the denominations in the city, and was witnessed by a large gathering of friends of the institution.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1. -- Theodore Durrant has been found guilty of the murder of Blanche Lamont. The jury before which he was tried reached its verdict on the first ballot. It was absent from the courtroom but twenty-eight minutes.

It was not inappropriate that Mrs. Rorer should give her last lesson in the course at Madison Square Garden on the preparation of the so-called staff of life. Bread making was the subject of yesterday's demonstration, but the bread made was of white flour, while the whole wheat is the only thing Mrs. Rorer considers a "staff" worth having for youth, maturity, or old age.
A simple statement of facts, in logical order, will show upon what poor political and ethical supports the Good Government municipal ticket now rests:

WILLET'S POINT, L.I., Nov. 1. -- "Old Dan," one of the army mules in the engineer battalion here, was shot to-day, after which his body was cremated over a wood fire. The mule was nearly forty years old, and, having become somewhat crippled, was condemned several days ago. An order from Washington directed the authorities here to shoot the animal with the new rifle to test its effect.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 1. -- The torpedo boat Cushing, with Lieut. Roy C. Smith in command, made two attacks on the torpedo station to-night, and though each time she was picked up with the searchlight, she succeeded, by speeding very hard, in getting within "torpedoing" distance -- 100 yards -- of the station before the expiration of the two and a half minutes allowed her by the new code of rules.

Three games were bowled last night at Thumann's alleys, 107 Horatio Street, in the championship tournament of the Bank Clerks' League. The competing teams were the Importers and Traders' National Bank, the American Exchange Bank, and the First National Bank. The former won two games and the latter lost two games. Honors of high score were divided between Ferdon of the American Exchange and Haines of the Importers' and Traders'. Score:

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- The pretty St. Andrew's Memorial Church, at the corner of Livingston Avenue and Morris Street, was to-day -- All Saints' Day -- consecrated by Bishop Poker in the presence of a large congregation which filled every seat.

Referee H.H. Anderson continued the hearing yesterday of the motion of Edward Barling to compel Mrs. Hetty Green to accept his final accounting as sole surviving executor of her father, Edward Mott Robinson.

A mass meeting of the friends of Amos J. Cummings, who are interested in his election as the representative in Congress for the Tenth Congressional District, was held last night in Koster Bial's old amusement hall, in West Twenty-third Street. The hall was crowded, and the greatest enthusiasm was manifested.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

There was a wild steer chase on the east side yesterday afternoon, which began at First Avenue and Forty-fourth Street and ended In the Grand Central Station yard, where there was great excitement before he animal was rounded up.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The debt statement issued this afternoon shows a net increase in the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, during October, of $5,321,472.08.

It was wonderful how patiently the horses bore their wounds. I watched a mare having a Martini bullet taken out of her flank. No one was holding her, but she stood perfectly still, just looking round now and then at the man who was probing the wound, as much as to say, "Are you going to be much longer?" Another poor beast had a bullet through the stomach.

What appears to be the last open century run of the year will be held to-morrow under the auspices of the bicycle corps of the Eighth Battalion. It is intended to have this the model run of the season, and with this purpose in view much attention has been paid to details.

PATERSON, Nov. 1. -- Edward W. Gardner of 10 Rip Van Winkle Avenue, this city, has just learned that he was substantially remembered in the will of a man, the lives of whose daughters he saved nine years ago.

President Roosevelt talked to the Cornelius Van Cott Colored Republican Legion in Zion Church, at West Tenth Street and Bleecker Street, last night. He said he was always glad to be called upon to render an account of his work to a body of citizens. He felt that the law-abiding people were with him in the enforcement of the law, and that the dishonest ones were against him.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- The Fire Department of New-Rochelle is preparing a fine souvenir of the great firemen's parade and celebration that was held here Oct. 1. The souvenir, which will be unique in many respects, has cost a great deal of labor and money. It will be a book of thirty-two pages, handsomely printed and illustrated.

ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- United States Weather Forecaster Alfred F. Sims, stationed here, has been engaged for the past few days looking up the "election-day weather" of the past, that some estimate might be made for next week's meterological conditions. Sergt. Sims finds the percentage of days on which rain fell during the first ten days of November for twenty years past, as follows, Albany's record being for sixteen years:

Cedic Cedicsson is a handsome, good-humored, idle fellow. Practical folks, not related to him, call him "worthless." In the story he does nothing to discredit this judgment of his character. His mother is the wife of a convict, happily out of the country. Dick, as he is called, is brought up in ignorance of the family dishonor.

The Progress Republican Club of the Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Assembly Districts had a celebration last night on the north side. Mayor Strong helped to arouse the enthusiasm of the Morrisania Republicans by riding in an open carriage, gayly bedecked with German flags, at the head of a torchlight procession, in which about 1,500 stalwart Republicans marched to the music of several brass bands.
The following letter from Sir Henry W. Tyler may interest those who wish to know what the new schemes in connection with the Panama Canal are:

Ex-Police Justice Charles Welde, through his counsel, Thomas P. Wickes, asked Justice Barrett, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, for an injunction to restrain the New-York and Harlem River Railroad Company from building a station at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street so as to extend beyond the north side of One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, contrary to the law of 1892.

A.H. Steele appeared suddenly at Republican County Headquarters yesterday afternoon. As he passed through the listless, waiting throng, an animated hum of interested conversation sprung up as soon a his identity became known.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Gen. Charles Neilson, Second Assistant Postmaster General, has completed his annual report, and it will be submitted to the Postmaster General tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- It was announced to-day that application will be made to the Board of Pardons at Harrisburg, on the 29th inst., for a pardon for John Bardsley, the ex-City Treasurer of Philadelphia, who was convicted in 1891 of embezzling the city's funds, and was sentenced to fifteen years' imprisonment in the Eastern Penitentiary.

Whatever political party you may belong to, whatever political ideas you may have, there is one proposition that rises entirely above and beyond any such surroundings. The canal amendment to be voted for is of greater, interest to every voter of this great State than any other issue raised this election. It is greater than any issue raised during any political campaign in a generation.

Harriet E. Parke was the name under which a young woman was arraigned in Yorkville Police Court before Magistrate Cornell yesterday on the charge made by her brother that she was insane and incapable of caring for herself. She admitted Parke was her mother's maiden name. She is the daughter of a retired naval officer, whose name is Frothingham, who lives in Washington. Her brother, George P. Frothingham, is a naval architect.

A decision of considerable importance was recently made by the United States Circuit Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania in a case relating to alleged violations of that part of the inter-State commerce law which forbids discrimination in freight rates. It is well known that the commission has been unable to enforce this very important provision of the statute.

Any child on the east side knows the Stecklers are shrewd politicians. Shrewdness is their stock in trade. They accomplished last week one of the grandest coups of the campaign, and with becoming modesty they have scarcely called attention to it at all.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The Treasury official comparative statement of the receipts and expenditures of the Government for the four months of the fiscal year to date and for the month of October was issued to-day. The deficit for the first third of the fiscal year is stated at $16,848,335, or at the rate of $48,000,000 for the fiscal year.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Dr. James Douglass was arrested at his home in Busti this afternoon charged with being concerned, with his brother Charles, who was arrested yesterday, in the murder of Mrs. Winslow Shearman and Mrs. Cynthia Davis, committed in the Town of Busti, near this city, last December.
An enthusiastic meeting to ratify the Democratic ticket was held last evening in the Democratic Clubhouse, 617 Fifth Avenue.

I observe by THE NEW-YORK TIMES of Oct. 27 that the Society of Colonial Dames has leased New Crailo Manor House, in Rensselaer County, N.Y., for a term of years. I also notice in the same article a statement denying the antiquity of the building. On this I beg to remark:
The trial of David F. Hannigan for the killing of Solomon H. Mann, the alleged betrayer of his sister, was resumed yesterday morning in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Justice Ingraham.

The announcement comes from Boston of the engagement of Miss Jeanette Moore Stewart to Charles Graham Field of New-York. Miss Stewart is the youngest of the four daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Moore Stewart and is a sister of Mrs. Harold G. Bond of New-York. The Stewarts have a handsome residence in Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, but for the last ten years they have spent the greater portion of their time in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Mr. Shinishiro Kurino, the Japanese Minister, paid a visit to the White House to-day and presented to President Cleveland an autograph letter from the Emperor of Japan, thanking the President and the Government of the United States for the good offices exercised toward bringing about peace between China and Japan. The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst yesterday made clear his position in the present campaign. In response to an open letter written to him by a number of friends of good government, he issued an address to the public.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 1. -- The political campaign in Kentucky practically is at an end. The managers on either side are now doing their figuring, and sending out estimates of a rosy hue to arouse the enthusiasm of old-line party men and draw into the folds those who are wavering, but who want to be on the winning side.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- Holmes to-day threw himself upon the mercy of the jury. When the Commonwealth closed its case this afternoon his attorneys announced that they considered the prosecution had not made out its charge of murder, and they would rest their case upon the evidence offered by the Commonwealth and submit no testimony in defense of the prisoner.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 1. -- Corbett and Fitzsimmons will not fight in Arkansas. This proposition is settled, as nearly as anything can be settled that is not an accomplished fact. It is altogether safe to say that both Corbett and his rival would be glad to be anywhere out of this State under a promise never to revisit it.

ROCHESTER, NOV. 1. -- It is in the air that the Republican machine in this city is to be smashed next Tuesday. The campaign here is one of the liveliest in the State. The Democrats and the Good Government Clubs are leagued together solidly against the domination of Mr. Platt's lieutenant, "Boss" Aldridge, and there is an uprising which is as intense and earnest as was that against Tammany Hall in New-York City last year.
The trial of David F. Hannigan for the killing of Solomon H. Mann, the alleged betrayer of his sister, was resumed yesterday morning in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Justice Ingraham.

The announcement comes from Boston of the engagement of Miss Jeanette Moore Stewart to Charles Graham Field of New-York. Miss Stewart is the youngest of the four daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Moore Stewart and is a sister of Mrs. Harold G. Bond of New-York. The Stewarts have a handsome residence in Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, but for the last ten years they have spent the greater portion of their time in Paris.

There is one essential point in Mr. Shepard's letter on Sunday closing to which I trust you will permit a few words in reply from me as Chairman of the Kings County Prohibition Committee.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 1. -- The campaign in New-Jersey is virtually ended. A number of "rallies" were held by both parties to-night, and John W. Griggs, the Republican candidate for Governor, will speak in his home city. Paterson, Monday night. But the active work of the canvass is over, and little remains to be done beyond getting out he vote.

ROME, Nov. 1. -- This city was visited by violent shocks of earthquake at 5:40 o'clock this morning. People were roused from their slumbers and fled to the open squares, and the greatest consternation prevailed. The Convent of Santa Maria Maggiore was greatly damaged. A portion of the outer wall was overthrown, and part of the ceiling has fallen. One of the inmates -- a monk -- was injured.

FLUSHING, L.I., Nov. 1. -- The Town Board of Trustees has taken its first decided step in its proposed contention for the recovery of valuable water-front property which is said to belong to the town, but which has for years been claimed and occupied by private individuals.
The Duke of Marlborough, accompanied by Ivor Guest, started for Washington yesterday afternoon. They will be the guest in Washington of Sir Julian Pouncefote the British Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The important post of Solicitor for the Sate Department, which was left vacant through the resignation of W.D. Dabney, who accepted the chair of law at the University of Virginia, was titled to-day by the President in the appointment of Walter Emerson Faison of North Carolina.

Arlington Hall, in St. Mark's Place, was crowded last night long before the time announced for the meeting arranged by the Good Government Club of the Fourteenth Assembly District, and in the audience were many women.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- The excellent legislative nominations made by the Democrats in Western New-York this year are likely to prove an important factor in getting out the full Democratic vote Tuesday, and thus keeping down the Republican pluralities for the candidates on the State ticket in many of the strongholds of Republicansim.
The purpose that the author entertained when entering upon her work has been well carried to completion.
We favor the maintenance of the Sunday laws in the interests of labor and morality.

The regular Democrats of Brooklyn held their last great rally of the campaign last night at the Academy of Music. The building was filled in every part with an enthusiastic audience, and the reception accorded Edward M. Grout, the Mayoralty candidate, was much warmer than when he first appeared before the regular organization in the Academy of Music a week ago last Wednesday night.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 1. -- Two of Hagenbeck's lions fought on the Midway to-day. The younger one was knocked out. The old one threw the young one against the cage and fractured its skull. To-day the young one was brought into the city, and Dr. Cavines, a veterinary surgeon, and five assistants trephined the skull.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- Herman W. Mudgett, or, as he is better known, H.H. Holmes, was to-night convicted of murder in the first degree for killing Benjamin F. Pietzel in this city Sept. 2, 1894. The jury needed but one ballot to reach this decision.

The Civitas Club, which has the reputation of being one of the most delightful, as it is one of the youngest and largest, of Brooklyn's organizations of women, will open its season Wednesday afternoon of this week, when the first meeting will be held in the clubrooms, 160 Joralemon Street.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 2. -- While it is true that out-of-door pleasures are always a feature of no small importance at this resort, it is probable that the present month will bring unusual attractions. The dates for the golf tournament have been fixed for Nov. 14, 15, and 16.

Horses in training and a few yearlings, the property of A.F. Walcott, were disposed of at auction at the Morris Park race track yesterday. The old campaigner, Diablo, winner of the Brooklyn Handicap two years ago, was secured by Louis Stuart for $1,900. The three-year-old Cromwell, by St. Blaise-Flavina, fetched the top price of the sale, A.J. Joyner, paying $2,750 for him. Details of the sale:
Four o'clock in the afternoon in the Fourteenth Street lair of the Tiger.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Massachusetts next Tuesday will elect a Governor and other State officers, an Executive Council, a Legislature and county officers, and in the Sixth Congressional District a successor to the late Congressman Cogswell. The only interesting issue in the short campaign of a month's duration has been the question of the control of the American Protective Association in the Republican Party.

A characteristic specimen of English ignorance regarding all things not English appears in The Westminster Gazette. It calls POE'S Fordham cottage his "birthplace." The mistake heads some grave remarks on what a nice thing it is for the New-Yorkers to show interest in this old house, and to take means for its preservation.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- It is hard to tell how fully the average British reader of daily papers enters into the spirit of those who have latterly undertaken to provide him with profuse and detailed information about America. He got along comfortably with a minimum of such information for many years.

A careful review of the political situation a few days before election in this Territory is not of an encouraging nature to Democrats. Although Democratic gains have been made in various parts of the Territory this year, enough to more than offset the Republican majority of last year, still the hope for Democratic success is meagre indeed.

OWEGO, Nov. 2. -- Pausing in the middle of one of the poems of N.P. Willis which was written beside a brook just on the outskirts of this thriving little place, a well-known citizen of Owego, who was pointing out the places of interest, said: "And, of course, you know Mr. Platt lives here. He's about as famous as N.P. Willis."

There is nothing more pathetic in our history than the successive disappointments of great men in the matter of the Presidency. They have dedicated their lives to the service of the country with the belief that their labors would surely bring them what they earned; but after all their endeavors, they have been disappointed, and the prize has gone to men of inferior merits, as if in contempt of the rules of justice and propriety.

Meteors and superb sunsets are the distinguishing characteristics of our Novembers, and in spite of all that is sung of beautiful colorings and ever changing linings of the sunset clouds in other lands, there is nothing more beautiful to the eye than what is shown us when we watch the early setting sun in the southwest section of our immediate horizon.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 2. -- Handsome cards of invitation announce that Charles Dana Gibson of New-York will wed Miss Irene Langhorne of Richmond, Va., at noon on Nov. 7. Miss Langhorne is the eldest daughter of Chiswell Dabney Langhorne, and is well known in the society of New-York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, New-Orleans, and her own city. She is a beautiful and charming young woman with deep blue eyes, fair hair, and blooming complexion.

The Brooklyn Academy of Music was hung with bunting and beautifully decorated with flags last night for the final mass meeting of the Democratic Party Reform Organization in support of Edward M. Shepard for Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The belated army regulations are at length to appear to an anxiously awaiting service. Assistant Secretary Doe says that the entire matter is in the hands of the printers, and it will be a question of a couple of weeks for the electrotyping and reading of proofs to be accomplished.

BERLIN, Nov. 2. -- The Deutsche Kordnische asserts that it has learned from a source of undoubted authority that, contrary to the statements which have been published in England recently, Germany has maintained the same attitude throughout the negotiations with the Porte relative to the status of the Christians in Armenia and other parts of the east of Turkey.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

The sacred books of the Buddhists are perfectly appalling in their bulk. They are called the Tripitaka, the Three Baskets, and were originally written in Pali, a vernacular form of Sanskrit. They have been translated into many languages, such as Chinese, Thibetan, and Mandshu. They have also been written and published in various alphabets, not only in Devanagari, but in Singhalese, Burmese, and Siamese letters.

The youngest bantling among the worshipful companies of the City of London is a guild of the Kew gardeners -- past and present. They were organized in 1893 and appointed a committee to forward the scheme, and devise means for the publication of a journal and directory of all living Kewenians, as far as possible, and maintain communication with them.

D.A. Tompkins of Charlotte, while in Atlanta with a party of Northern mill men, was asked if any of them would make any investments that will benefit the South. In reply he said: "Many of the members of the party are already investors in Southern enterprises. They are successful people, which means that they are very conservative and cautious people.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 12. -- With the exception of this island, which has the vitality and diversity of industries, the enterprise and the credit, if not the actual capital, necessary to rise to and above the occasion, the British West Indies as a whole are in a pretty bad condition. Very troublous times are ahead, which there are apparently no means of avoiding.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 2. -- A pretty fair was held this afternoon in the parish house of St. Luke's Episcopal Church by the Junior Auxiliary of the Church Guild.

It is useless to try and disguise the fact that Wall Street at this time is feeling blue. It is not the decline which has already taken place in prices which causes this feeling. It is the fear that it may go much farther; the uneasy sensation that the bottom may be much farther off than was thought likely some time ago. That a great speculative movement progresses in waves, is a truism.
BUENOS AYRES, Argentina, Oct. 5. -- The following is Finance Minister Romero's conversion bill. It was sent yesterday for approval to Congress, with a message from President Uriburu.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- That Senator Gorman is leaving nothing undone to advance his interests in the coming election in Maryland is shown by the announcement to-night that Senators Voorhees and Palmer have addressed to him letters in which his Democracy is indorsed in the strongest terms.

There was some good racing at Morris Park yesterday, though the rain put the track in bad condition, and caused many withdrawals. The small fields made up in quality what they lacked in quantity, and the crowd met with poor success in picking winners.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- The first paper to announce that Prime Minister Salisbury had departed from his original intention not to hold a meeting of the Cabinet till the middle of November, when domestic measures to be laid before the House of Commons would be discussed, was The Birmingham Post, an organ that is inspired by the Chamberlain party.

The past week has been an indecisive one among real estate men. Few transactions of note were concluded, and most of the large operations that were pending remain so. The most notable of the purchases reported are of lots in bulk by building loan operators. In each of two instances an entire block front was bought .

In his "Art of Warre," Sir James Turner, (1683) alluding to the rapid changes in weapons then going on, cites Marshal Monluc, whom he looks upon as "an unquestionable author," he mentioning in his Commentaries that while most of the light-armed French foot were cross-bowmen, or arbalists, in a company at the beginning of Francis I., two-thirds of them were arquebusiers before its close.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Amherst beat Williams to-day by a score of 16 to 4 in the first game of the series for the championship of the triangular league. The weather was the worst for football ever seen in Amherst. Sleet began to fall about noon, and at 3 P.M. it settled down into a heavy snow storm. The bad condition of the field prevented any long runs. Both teams played without their Captains.

The campaign in Brooklyn was practically closed last night by the big mass meeting of the Reform Democrats at the Academy of Music. The managers of each of the three political organizations are feeling cheerful, and each side confidently predicts victory.

Teachers have been too often stewards who bring out only the old things from the treasury, words spoken thousands of years ago, and acts fitted to another age. They go on using a phraseology which is not understood, preaching sermons about dead controversies, and condemning heresies; long forgotten.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- It could scarcely be called good football weather that greeted the cadet and Yale football teams as htey lined up for a fifty-minute game on the parade ground this afternoon. The large number of spectators who stood outside the ropes and watched the movements of the combatants as they tusseled on the wet gridiron were well drenched, but sleet, snow, and rain could not dampen their enthusiasm.

The National Association Football League, which had so successful a season last year, will hold its annual meeting during the week. The dribbling game is slowly, but surely, obtaining a foothold in the United States, and the officials of the league fondly expect that it will supplant Rugby in the hearts of Americans as it has done with Englishmen.
ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 2. -- A three days' fair, given by the ladies of St. Venantius's German Catholic Church, was brought to a successful close this evening in the parochial school hall.

An examination of the records of the Labor Bureau, which was put in operation some six months ago, discloses some curious facts. Our readers are familiar with the general purpose and the methods of the bureau. Laborers skilled and unskilled are registered, and, when requisition is made, names are supplied in the order that they appear on the eligible list.

One good result of the enforced economy among Southern planters in the matter of grasses. For a long time the South was regarded as unfit for grass production, although men here and there demonstrated its falsity. Mr. Hilyard, a Northern man, but for many years a resident of the South, proved by actual and frequent experiments, not only that this section was a great grass country, but perhaps the greatest in the world.

The campaign is practically over. The managers at the Democratic State Headquarters, 27 Madison Avenue, had about completed their work early last evening. Senator Hill remained in the city until 1 P.M., and then left for Albany.

The firm of C. Reynolds announce a sale of early English and modern paintings, to take place at their galleries, 286 Fifth Avenue, on the evenings of Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, Nov. 6, 7, 8, and 9, at 8 o'clock. This is made necessary in order to settle the balance of the estate of the late Alfred John Reynolds of London.
New-York is to have a great skating rink, where the ice is to be made by artificial means regardless of the state of the weather.

John Kent came wearily enough down the main street of the city. In truth, the rattle of the elevated trains and the buzz of the trollies affected his strength far more than did his walk from the country since daybreak; for he was a sturdy young fellow, well set up and supple. At the corner he rested his bundle against the decayed palings and looked over the inclosure.

Society seems to have nothing else to talk about at present excepting the marriage of Miss Vanderbilt to the Duke of Marlborough next Wednesday. Even the Horse Show, which heretofore has been the great event of the Autumn season, receives little attention just now, and the marriage of Miss Pauline Whitney to Almeric Hugh Paget, which will be attended by everybody of social prominence, is for a time overshadowed by that of Miss Vanderbilt.

There is nothing like seeing. What you see you believe. But are you quite sure of that? May not your senses, not exactly fool you, but lead you at times into error? Prof. E.W. Scripture does not deal with hallucinations and all that kind of thing. He treats in his "Thinking, Feeling, and Doing," of the actual phenomena of seeing, and he explains why it is that our eyes sometimes lead us into error.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 2. -- There is another chapter in the Story of the boss and the Judges in the Seventh Judicial District. This story is in two chapters, and includes the selection of Judge Dunwell of Wayne County as a candidate for additional Judge of the Supreme Court and the appointment by Gov. Morton of the Judges to the appellate division in the Fourth Department.

One of the many unique meetings of the campaign of education incident to the coming election was that held yesterday afternoon in Arlington Hall, St. Mark's Place, under the auspices of the East Side Juvenile Protective League, the Hebrew Institute Street Cleaning League, and the Clean City Clubs of the east side.

The results of observations of lightning and the damage and destruction it causes are given in a pamphlet issued by the Weather Bureau at Washington. Among the curious facts noted is that the old theory that lightning never strikes twice in the same place does not hold good. Many instances are cited where lightning has struck in the same place not only twice, but several times.

The autonomy of the State canals is such that failure to secure popular approval of the pending measure providing for their immediate betterment will be exceptionally detrimental, inasmuch as the reinstatement before the people of this question, in the event of its present defeat, can only be attained after prolonged delay.

Although most of the work done at the Harvard Observatory is of necessity in cooperation with other observatories and meteorological stations, yet the remarkable activity which characterizes its independent work is shown not only in its observations, but also by its publications, which are numerous and extensive, covering a great variety of subjects.

LITTLE ROCK, Nov. 2. -- There will be no fight in Arkansas, neither will there be one anywhere else for that matter, unless the complexion of affairs undergoes a total and altogether unexpected change within a few hours. The pugilists have made an unconditional surrender, and the long-looked-for battle for the championship of the world passes into history as a fizzle without a redeeming feature.
In the work of constructing resting places for the dead, a departure has recently been undertaken in the mausoleum built in Woodlawn Cemetery for William F. Foster of this city.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2. -- The mass meeting of the anti-Gorman Democracy, at the Music Hall to-night, was a great climax to the most remarkable contest in the history of Maryland politics. It should be clearly understood by those outside the State, as it is generally known by those inside the State, that the fight against Gorman has been conducted by the most loyal and most prominent Democrats of Maryland.
The lectures of Prof. Albert S. Bickmore at the Museum of Natural History, have been more successful than usual this year.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Protection Engine Company Wednesday evening entertained 400 residents of Bayonne by giving a dinner in honor of the women who contributed so largely to the success of the recent company fair. That enterprise handsomely furnished the large new brick building, and left a balance of $1,000 in the company treasury.

Few people outside the medical profession have any idea of the splendid work that is being done in this country in the employment of electricity, which formerly was used almost entirely by impostors and incompetents, in the most marvelous healing and curative system that has ever been known.

On a quagmire, and in a cold, drizzling rain the football players of the Crescent Athletic Club easily slipped away from the eleven of the New-Jersey Athletic Club at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon. The score was 28 to 0.

Neil Burgess opened the New Star Theatre last night with a new play, "The Year One." He was welcomed by a house full of admirers. It is probably just such a production as might have been in vogue in the infancy of counting years. New-York never saw anything like it before.

This work opens with an account of the ancestry of Warren Hastings, and gives in entertaining sketch of the family as it now exists in the neighborhood of Hastings's birthplace. The Rev. Warren Hastings, M.A., is now the chief living representative of the family, and is curate of Churchill, the birthplace of his famous kinsman.

The Wholesale Drug Trade's Bowling Association played the fourth day's games yesterday afternoon at Reed's alleys, in Chambers Street. Six games were played. Dodge Olcott won both their games, defeating Lanman Kemp by a score of 693 to 584, and McKesson Robbins by a score of 715 to 671. Thus far they have not lost a game, and have four to their credit.

Our London correspondent sends us an account of the observance of Sunday in London, which would at any time be interesting, but which has a special value and timeliness in New-York on this Sunday before election, of all Sundays in the year. London on Sunday is not to the outward eye a gay or cheerful place.

The annual meeting of the Board of Trustees of the New-York Red Cross Hospital Association was held at 233 West One Hundredth Street yesterday afternoon for the purpose of hearing the annual reports of the officers and electing a Board of Trustees.

The musical season continued to move in the week just ended with a rather slow and dignified motion, which will presently develop into an irresistible rush. Mr. Maurice Kaufman's concert at Mendelssohn Glee Club Hall on Tuesday flight was one of those entertainments which no amount of experience in musical affairs will check.

THURSDAY, NOV. 7. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, Edward Jacobs, referee. 207 East Seventy-sixth Street, north side. 105 feet east of Third Avenue, 25 by 102.2 1/2, four-story brick tenement with stores. Due on judgment, $12,000.

HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 2. -- The steamer Obdam, of the Netherlands Line, was towed into this port this afternoon by the Penn-land, bound from Queenstown for Philadelphia. The Obdam carries the Netherlands mail.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 2. -- The Colt divorce case was fairly launched in the Supreme Court to-day by a formal motion on the part of Rathbone Gardner, counsel for Mrs. Elizabeth M. Colt, for the appointment of commissioners to take affidavits to be used in support of her petition. Mr. Gardner said that, under the new judiciary act, depositions made outside this State must be taken by duly appointed commissioners.

One of the most important and interesting cruises ever made by the United States ship Albatross has just been completed. The famous ship arrived here a few days ago, and now lies in the stream at Mare Island. Since leaving here in May last she cruised in far Northwestern waters, engaged in deep-sea fishing, and the fish she has taken are now being packed away in boxes for shipment to the Smithsonian Institution.

The Slavonian element among the foreign population in this city is not at all inconsiderable, although the Slavonians, as a rule, are unostentatious, unassuming, and desirous of living in peace with their neighbors. There are, it is estimated, nearly 80,000 of them in this city, and of this number, about 40,000 are Bohemians, 20,000 Poles, and 15,000 Slovaks.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 2. -- In Suffolk County the politicians in both parties are ready for the election. The county committees have met for the last time. The district workers have received their instructions and all is in order. The leaders are now busy figuring out a forecast of the result.

The practice of suspending and altering law by means of "Circulars," "Obligatory Interpretations," "Recommendations," and simple "Orders" has gradually become so widely spread in Russia that by this time only the lazy one amid the "non-suspects" does not resort to this means of affirming his own will. Here are a few authenticated facts: A Zemskiy Nachalnik forbids "his" peasants to obey such decisions of the Zemstvo.

NEWFORT, R.I., Nov. 2 -- The first product of the new guncotton factory, at the torpedo station, was extracted on Tuesday, and later put through the regular heat and solubility tests, a report of which has been forwarded to the Bureau of Ordnance, at Washington. The critical examination by the chemist showed the explosive to be of unusually fine quality.

The "notes" -- really thoughts and conclusions -- which Mr. Nadal has written in a delightfully sketchy form have to do with observances abroad and at home. He has a good memory, and, in connection with things observed in England and on the Continent, has referred to experiences in this country that lend color, by contrast, to his descriptions of European life.

C.C. Packard, editor and proprietor of The Toledo Journal, an independent newspaper, has come to town from Ohio on business, and his headquarters are at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

News of Jacques Boyer, his heirs, assigns, or acquaintances, is earnestly desired by a gentleman of France, whose inquiries in this direction have been addressed to the authorities of Cook County. At the same time, claim is made to the modest fortune of $15,000,000, to which the same Jacques Boyer is supposed to have been heir.

Bishop POTTER'S letter declaring his hearty sympathy with the action of the Good Government Club Committee will have a tendency to modify the tyrannizing attitude that some of the supporters of the fusion ticket have put on toward those who are unable to accept that ticket as a whole.

Mrs. Sarah J. Neal, for twenty years a clerk in the Pension Department at Washington and one of the most widely known of all Kansas women, died at Tombstone, Ariz., on Friday from injuries received a few days previous by being thrown from a carriage. The news of Mrs. Neal's death was received by her son, Conductor A.D. Fulton.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Lieut. Leonard M. Prince, Second Infantry, United States Army, died at the Presbyterian Hospital yesterday from injuries received in the famous army-navy football game at Annapolis in 1892.

ALBANY, NOV. 2. -- The employes at the Capitol at Albany and on the canals received their salaries yesterday. An order signed by the general and enigmatical name of "The Committee" was sent to every Republican capitol employe to report in the evening at the headquarters in Albany of the Sergeant-at-Arms of the Platt Assembly of last Winter. The men were informed that they must put up money for the Republican campaign.

PRINCETON, Nov. 2. -- Seven hundred Harvard undergraduates, a football team representing Harvard University, and about 2,500 of the Harvard alumni came to town in a drizzling rain to-day. They came expecting to see the Harvard eleven "wipe up the ground" with the eleven representing the University of New-Jersey in the noble game of football.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- One is reminded of a scene in fairyland or the interior of a Moorish palace as he or she enters Cryptic Hall, on Main Street, this city, at present. The crescent and the star of the East is seen everywhere. In gold and sliver and in every imaginable hue the new moon is observed.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- H.H. Holmes, whose right name is Herman W. Mudgett, was born near London, N.H. He attended the Medical School at Burlington, Vt., and while so doing was married. He then went to Ann Arbor to study medicine in the University of Michigan. With a college chum he went to Chicago and swindled a life insurance company of $12,000 by palming off a corpse as that of the chum.

The presentment by the Kings County Grand Jury, in which it condemned the new terminal station of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge and recommended that a board of competent engineers be asked to consider the matter was not at all pleasing to the Trustees of the bridge.

BUFFALO, Nov. 2. -- There is pretty lively fighting in Erie County in the Senatorial and Assembly contests. Three Senators and eight Assemblymen are to be elected. The local questions which are interfering with the smooth working of party affairs on both sides in the county campaign will enter to some extent into these Legislative campaigns.

We do not know what political motive may induce a paper supposed to be influenced by Mr. CHAMBERLAIN to raise a cry at this moment that Germany is seeking to "isolate" Great Britain. In the close game being played by the various powers over the novel and perplexing question of the far East, it may be that the Colonial Secretary sees some immediate advantage in arousing a little popular resentment toward Germany.

Charles W. Hackett and B.B. Odell, Chairmen of the State Republican and State Republican Campaign Committees, respectively, issued an address yesterday to the voters of the State, in which they appeal for legislators to support the hands of Gov. Morton in the good work he is doing by uprooting the evils of Democratic misrule.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- [Copyright, 1895, by THE NEW-YORK TIMES.] -- France has had abundant occasions for quarrel with its Parliamentary servants during the last quarter of a century, but there seems to be a general disposition in Paris to agree that this time they have done her decidedly the worst turn yet recorded.

HAVANA, Nov. 2. -- Advices have been received here that a detachment of Government troops, sixty-six strong, under command of a Captain, stationed in the Ojo de Agua district, received information last Thursday that a group of rebels had arrived in the vicinity. The detachment started on Thursday to reconnoitre, and met the insurgents near Loma de los Tardios.

That Moslems should unite with Armenian revolutionists in an effort to depose the Sultan Caliph seems on the surface to be incredible. In fact, it is a most natural result of the last twenty years' rule in the Turkish Empire. Whether the coalition is an actual fact or not, it is very certain that ABDUL HAMID II, has no more bitter enemies among the Christians than among his Moslem subjects.

The manners of people in public places were severely commented upon by Prof. Charles Elliot Norton in a lecture before the Prospect Union, Cambridge. Prof. Norton's subject was. "How to Make Cambridge Pleasanter." He said that his first thought, after he had promised to deliver the lecture, was to speak of material improvements about the city, but that he had decided later to speak on the subject of making people pleasanter, and consequently the community.
SUMMIT, N.J., Nov. 2. -- A very pleasing entertainment was given in the Hotel Beechwood Music Hall last evening by Brooks Denton and Ossman and Miss Marion Short, musicians.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 2. -- A stubbornly contested game of football was played in the rain at the Orange Oval this afternoon by the teams of the Lehigh University and the Orange Athletic Club, the latter coming out victorious by 2 points. The ground was very muddy and slippery, and few runs of more than ten yards were made.

Officials of the City Health Department were yesterday notified that cholera-infected pork is being shipped into Chicago, and as a result an inspection of more than ordinary care has been ordered at the stock yards. The information came to Health Commissioner Kerr in a letter from a dealer in pork in the central part of the State.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Serious charges have been preferred against Capt. Michael A. Healy of the revenue cutter Bear. Twenty-five officers of the Revenue Cutter Service now on duty on the Pacific coast have signed a paper addressed to Secretary Carlisle, in which the conduct of Capt. Healy during the last criuse of the Bear is severely reflected upon, and a request is preferred for an investigation.

In Andrew D. White's "New Chapters in the Warfare of Science" and Prof. Evans's "Recent Recrudescence of Superstition" (Popular Science Monthly) may be found the higher thought, contrasted with the lower grade of human understanding. Superstition is born in man. When fully considered, it must have been the beginning of belief.

By the explosion of a battery used in the naval scene in the third act of "Captain Paul," at the Bijou Theatre last evening, just before the show began, Sol De Lisser, who had charge of the stage setting for the troupe, had his right leg shattered at the thigh. The explosion caused a terrific report that shook the whole stage.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 2. -- The annual fair for the benefit of the Memorial Hospital, which is the great society and charitable event of the season here, will be held this year in Berkeley Hall. East Orange, on Wednesday and Thursday afternoons and evenings, Nov. 20 and 21, and the ladies of the sales committee of the Board of Governors will have charge.

An almost mutinous feeling exists in Company G, Twenty-second Regiment, owing to the fact that three of the best men of the organization have received their honorable discharge against their will. It is declared they are being forced out of the company because they oppose the election of Lieut. Dayton as Captain.
Tax Commissioner Theodore Sutro has written for The City Vigilant an article entitled "The Germans in the Municipal Campaign of 1895 in the City of New-York."

SYRACUSE, Nov. 2. -- Ex-Congressman J.J. Belden has come back into politics. He has a club with him and a large basketful of knives. He is worrying Francis Hendricks, who thought he had the ex-Congressman dead and buried for good. and all, in a way that makes a very picturesque campaign in this central city.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- When John Brown Judson, Democratic candidate for State Controller first saw the light of day, the country was in the throes of a great civil war. Gloversville, his present home, was a village of less than 3,000 inhabitants, and the glove industry was confined to the making of a few hundred dozen pairs of buckskin gauntlets and mittens.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- Westchester County is on the eve of one of the most bitter political battles that have ever been waged between the metropolis and the southern line of Putnam County. The indications in the political heavens as the day or final battle draws nearer points unquestionably to an old-fashioned Democratic victory in Westchester.

Isaac H. Klein, manager of the Good Government campaign, sent to THE NEW-YORK TIMES last night a letter in which he puts forward the claim of the Good Government ticket for the suffrages of independent citizens.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 3. -- Six hundred citizens of Edwards County have petitioned Gov. Morrill to sign the death warrants of Carl Arnold and William Harvey, sentenced to death by Judge Vandivert of Kinsley about eighteen months ago.

Otto Hanschild, formerly a musician in the military band at West Point, has made application to the United States Government for a rerating of his pension on the ground that his windpipe was ruptured because of the petty spite of a bandmaster at West Point, who, under threats of placing him in the guardhouse, compelled him to play in turn every instrument in the band. HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 3. -- Dartmouth's football prospects are not particularly bright considering the rapid approach of the championship games. Amherst is played at Hanover, Nov. 9, and a week later Dartmouth plays Williams at Williamstown. "Big" Bowles, the star left guard of three years, has left the team, and Randall, the old half, is endeavoring to fill the position.
LONDON, Nov. 3. -- The Earl of Derby has accepted the Lord Mayorship of Liverpool.

The event of to-day which will bring the fashionable folks out in large numbers is the annual Autumn reception at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This function takes place from 1 o'clock until 5. Gen. Louis P. Di Cesnola, the Director of the Museum of Art, has the ararngements for the reception in charge.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 3. -- The Montclair Golf Club has arranged for an all-day tournament on election day, commencing at 10 o'clock in the morning. The links, in Central Avenue, near Valley Road, are in good condition, and an arrangement has been devised whereby two courses have been laid out over practically the same ground -- a short one for women, and a long one for men.

ALBANY, Nov. 3. -- There are many "local situations" in this State which will favor the Democratic State ticket at the election Tuesday. Among these are the local contests in this city, Rochester, Brooklyn, New-York City the Thirty-ninth Senatorial District, which includes the counties of Seneca and Cayuga; the Forty-second District, which includes the counties of Wayne and Ontario, and the Twenty-seventh District, which includes the counties of Schoharie, Montgomery, Fulton, and Hamilton.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 3. -- The State election in Nebraska is for one Judge of the Supreme Court and two Regents of the State University. There are five tickets in the field: Republican, Democratic, "Sound Money" Democratic, Populist, and Prohibitionist.
The Civil Service Reform Association has had the following correspondence with local candidates in regard to the merit system of appointments to office:

The feature of the past week's work on Brooklyn bowling alleys has been the high score of the Linden Grove five in the Arlington National. The team as at present constituted is undoubtedly the strongest in this section of the country.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 3. -- The most eventful week, so far as the political status of the State is concerned, that South Carolina has ever had since the stirring days of 1876 is that just passed.

Jersey's fine macadam roads, in the vicinity of Elizabeth, were a revelation to a party of New York wheelmen yesterday. Very few imagined that the roads anywhere would be fit for cycling, especially in the country, yet within a radius of twenty-five miles of that historic little city the wheeling was better than is generally found in Central Park.
Joe, or Jim, a nervous little dog, whose breed no one determined with a certainty, was a subject of interest at the Harlem Police Court for three-quarters of an hour yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- The Treasury Department will, in a few days, ask for bids for the construction of a revenue cruiser for the Pacific coast.

The most curious feature of the Mayoralty canvass in Brooklyn is the feeling very generally expressed that if Mr. SHEPARD could get the votes of all who believe that he would, if elected, make by far the best Mayor, his election would be certain. It is not singular that this feeling should exist among those who know Mr. SHEPARD and his record in public affairs.

BERLIN, Nov. 3. -- No prosecutions for the offense of lese majeste which have taken place in recent years have so attracted public interest as the trial and conviction last week of Herren Dierl and Pfund, respectively editor and associate editor of the Vorwaerts, the leading Socialist organ, and Herr Randmann, editor of the Volksblatt, resulting in the sentence of Dierl to six months', Pfund to nine months', and Randmann to twelve months' imprisonment.

The fire which started early yesterday morning at 7 Pelham Street, in the heart of the sweat-shop district, which threatened to destroy a whole block and for a long time defied the efforts of twenty fire engines, resulted in the death of four persons.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 3. -- The American missionaries at Bitlis have complained that they are in imminent danger, and A.W. Terrell, the American Minister, and M.H. Herbert, the British Charge d'Affaires, will again demand that the Porte protect them from attack by the Moslems.

John Flood of 553 First Avenue, and Joseph Halpin, his brother-in-law, had a desperate fight yesterday morning in Flood's apartments. As a result Flood is at the point of death from a stab wound in the abdomen, and Halpin is suffering from a severe scalp wound and possible fracture of the skull.

CAMBRIDGE, Nov. 3. -- The disaster at the hands of Princeton is the only athletic event that the students at Harvard can talk about now. There is a feeling of supreme disgust with the team, and the players are all dubbed "quitters" by the students in general. There are, of course, only a few men in Cambridge who saw the game, as most of them remained in New-York over Sunday.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 3. -- Residents of Suffolk County have always asserted that the air down in this portion of Long island was conducive to longevity. It has often been published in the local newspapers that doctors and undertakers, to say nothing about cemetery corporations, never found more than ordinary business awaiting them in this county.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 3. -- The Cercle Francais, the society in college which is made up of those students who are taking French courses as a specialty, will, as usual, give a play in French this Winter. The remarkable success of the performance given last year has induced the society to undertake a harder play. It will be "Le Malade Imaginaire," a comedy of great renown in a literary way.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 3. -- Senator John Sherman, in an interview last night, gave his estimates of the abilities of his colleague, Senator Calvin S. Brice, and of President Cleveland.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 3. -- The conditions of the granting of special honors, which are conferred at the close of the senior year, are as follows: One year and two year honors may be taken in the following groups of studies: First, philosophy; second, history; third, political science and law; fourth, English; fifth, ancient languages; sixth, modern languages, exclusive of English; seventh; natural and physical science; eighth, mathematics; ninth, music.

With the election not many more than twenty-four hours off, the political prophets were chary about expressing their opinions last night. But it was evident that most of them were of the opinion that in a contest like the one in this city, the chances were that the Tammany ticket should pull through, even in a close contest.

The campaign of 1895 in Brooklyn was virtually ended Saturday night, when the Democratic Reform Party held their last rally in the Academy of Music, and the regular Democrats held their last mass meet-in the Criterion Theatre. The reform party, however, yesterday issued the following appeal:
MILAN, Nov. 3. -- The Garibaldi Monument in this city was dedicated to-day with imposing popular ceremonies. King Humbert sent a bronze crown to be placed on the monument.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3. -- The college football enthusiasts have had plenty to talk about in the past week. In the Brown game there was food for reflection to coachers and players alike, and a great deal of thinking has been done by both since. It is likely that it will result in some material change in the team. In the first place, Bull was laid off from yesterday's game for a much-needed rest.

Though Exeter Hall, as it existed thirty years ago, is no longer an influence to be reckoned with in British politics, the sentiment aroused by the agitation it represented is still strong. One of the minor questions with which Mr. CHAMBERLAIN will be called on to deal is that of slavery in Zanzibar, as to which a most zealous protest has been submitted to the Government.

The pollution of streams by the sewage of towns has been the subject of much discussion in many States, some of which began some time ago to take measures for the prevention of this disagreeable and dangerous fouling of water courses. A recent decision of the Superior Court in Connecticut indicates that injured riparian owners there have a remedy at law.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 3. -- Oliver H. Bishop, fifty-seven years old, of 18 Linden Court, Greenville, committed suicide to-day by shooting himself in the head. Mr. Bishop was formerly in the shipbuilding business in Greenport, L.I. He retired five years ago, and came to this city. Shortly after he engaged in the menhaden fishery, and lost $40,000. He established recently a laundry at 105 Danforth Avenue.
Any one desiring fair discussion cannot do better than write to your fearless and brilliant paper.
ERIE, Penn., Nov. 3. -- Freight Conductor Richard Barnett of the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway was shot and dangerously hurt to-night.

The new Church of St. Joseph, in East Eighty-seventh Street, was dedicated yesterday morning with the full pomp and splendor incident to the Catholic ritual for such a ceremonial.
The weather indications for to-day and to-morrow, as sent out from the Weather Bureau in Washington, contained the following for Eastern New-York and New-Jersey:

WEST BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 3. -- William R. Babbage, a prominent resident of Staten Island, a member of the Richmond County Country Club, and numerous other social organizations of Staten Island, and who is in business in New-York, went with a friend, Francis Sanders, to the Country Club this afternoon, and, to pass away the afternoon, started to play a game of golf on the club links.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 3 -- Two persons were killed outright and twenty-five or thirty passengers were injured by the wrecking of the Cincinnati Express, at Elm Grove, near Wheeling, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, at 10:20 o'clock this morning.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church, the handsomest and wealthiest church for many miles around, is without a pastor. The Rev. Dr. L.M. Van Bokkelen resigned two weeks ago. He has been ill for nearly a year, and the Rev. Frederic B. Howden has been the acting rector since last December.

ALBANY, Nov. 3. -- There are now forty-six Justices of the Supreme Court in New-York State. After Jan. 1 next there will be thirty additional Justices, making a total of seventy-six Justices in the eight districts or four departments.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 3. -- The principal cases in the United States District Court, which has been in session at New-Berne, were against numerous persons charged with defrauding the Government by securing pensions to which they were not entitled.

St. George's Church, in Stuyvesant Square, was thronged last evening by those who wished to do honor to George William Warren, who has just completed a quarter of a century's service as organist and choirmaster of St. Thomas's Church.

ST LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 3. -- A local paper says that the American Railway Union is on the eve of a great strike, compared with which the strike of 1894 will be a mere skirmish. Debs and his followers, it is said, are particularly bitter against the Great Northern Railway for breaking its agreement. Every road in the West and Northwest will be drawn into the strike.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 3. -- The revival of the old-time midnight cane spree at Princeton marks the beginning of what Princeton students hope will result in the reinstatement of many old customs which have been wiped out by the rapid growth and consequent changes which have taken place at Old Nassau during the past few years.

The autonomy of the State canals is such that failure to secure popular approval of the pending measure providing for their immediate betterment will be exceptionally detrimental, inasmuch as the reinstatement before the people of the question, in the event of its present defeat, can only be attained after prolonged delay.

Herman Bendel, President of the Winemakers' Corporation and the San Jose Fruit-Packing Company, has returned from a five weeks' tour of the East, with information and ideas of very great importance to the wine and dried-fruit interests of the State.
LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Nov. 3. -- The steamer Manhattan of the Maine Line had a narrow escape from going on the rocks in the East River, just above Hell Gate, about 1 o'clock this afternoon.

Along the east side of the city yesterday there were nearly as many saloons that had their blinds pulled down as there were on the previous Sunday. They were, however, not guarded by uniformed policemen. Access by the side doors was not difficult to the initiated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Under the orders issued by Secretary Morton three months ago the Weather Bureau officials have informed the Secretary that the average percentage of verifications of the official morning thirty-six-hour forecasts of weather and temperature made by the Weather Bureau for the country east of the Rocky Mountains during the month of October, 1895, was 85.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- The close of the fifth week at Cornell finds the various schools well under way, with the largest all-around attendance in the history of the university. The matters of greatest interest to the undergraduates for the past week have been the class elections. The seniors lead off with the most hotly contested election ever held.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Admiral Ramsay has collected some exceedingly interesting figures on the ordinary cruising performances of the new warships, which will be sent to Congress by Secretary Herbert, in his annual report, and which may lead to some discussion when appropriations are asked for new vessels of high speed.

A few evenings since a group of mining men were seated in the barroom of the Palace Hotel, when one of them remarked that he would wager the drinks for the crowd that no one present could tell of the first mining swindle perpetrated on the Comstock.

Gen. John B. Gordon delivered in Indianapolis on Tuesday evening his lecture upon "The Last Days of the Confederacy." The audience contained Commander-in-Chief Walker of the Grand Army of the Republic; James Whitcomb Riley, and a large number of the prominent war veterans of the city and State.

The sermons that the clergymen of this city have been preaching on the subjects that at present are awakening political interest were continued yesterday. Local option and a proper observance of Sunday were considered, and the duty of all citizens to vote for good government for the municipality rather than for party advantage was generally declared.

The District Chairmen of the Republican County Committee had a long session yesterday afternoon, at which encouraging reports of the work done were submitted. Edward Lauterbach presided.

There was no business in progress yesterday at the Democratic State Headquar ters. Chairman Hinkley was in Poughkeepsie, and Chairman John A. Mason of the Executive Committee was at the headquarters only to look over his mail.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- The University of Pennsylvania has decided to send its freshman team to play the Boston Athletic Association at New-York to-morrow instead of the 'Varsity eleven. This correspondence explians why this was done:
