COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 4.--The electors of Ohio will to-morrow choose a Governor, Treasurer, Auditor, Judge and Clerk of the Supreme Court, Lieutenant Governor, Attorney General, member of the State Board of Public Works, and a full General Assembly. The election of the Assembly is of special importance, as it will elect a successor to Calvin S. Brice, (Dem.)
The Berkeley second team defeated the College of the City of New-York yesterday by a score of 12 to 4 in a closely contested game. The Berkeley backs made steady gains. Line-up:

The Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs is to have the biggest wheelmen's bowling tournament this Winter that was ever held in this vicinity. There will be twelve clubs represented in it, and the rules of the American National Bowling Congress will govern the play.

The Committee on Watchers of the Campaign Committee of the Good Government Clubs, of which Preble Tucker is Chairman, has received $450 in five individual subscriptions from members of the Committee of Fifty. Mr. Tucker said yesterday that other small sums had also been received, and that many districts of the city were being thoroughly covered by individual Good Government Clubs.

Paderewski has returned and the town is at his feet again. Somewhat paler than of yore, and with the sunburst of hair a trifle diminished in extent, the great Polish pianist reappeared at Carnegie Hall last night, and the popular worship of two years ago began again as if it had never been interrupted.

Our report concerning the conclusion of the interesting suit of Mrs. HILLIGOSS against Mr. W.R. COVERT, tried last week in Indiana, indicates that the jury was not composed of men who exhibited "an entire willingness to be deceived." It may be recalled that with these words the late THOMAS R. HAZARD defined, to the Seybert commission, "the true spirit in which the study of Spiritualism should be approached."

The racing season of 1895 will be brought to a close at the Westchester track this afternoon. A fine card of seven races is offered that will be productive of good sport. In addition to the racing, Henry of Navarre, Clifford, Sir Walter, Lady Raymond, and others of the great racers and jumpers of the year will be shown on the track by crack jockeys wearing the racing colors.

In rummaging through the files of New- York newspapers a century and a half old, one comes across happenings that would make the modern newspaper man very uneasy until he knew all about them, and had thoroughly examined causes and results. This, however, is not at all the case with "Mr. Parker."

JAMESBURG, N.J., Nov. 4. -- The Democrats of Middlesex County closed the campaign to-night with a big parade of clubs and a rousing meeting at Fidelity Hall. George A. Helme presided. With him on the platform were George L. Record of Jersey City, Alexander Schlessinger of Camden, and Col. Ernest C. Stahl of Trenton, who made speeches during the evening.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 4. -- A rather light vote, when compared with last year and two years ago, but heavy when compared with normal elections in the State in which National issues do not enter, is promised in New-Jersey to-morrow.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I. NOV. 4. -- Gongs are clanging in the city streets to-night. Hoarse-voiced orators are proclaiming the virtues and merits of candidates from open-air platforms. Bonfires and torchlight parades have turned night into day. Long Island City elects a Mayor to-morrow.

In Atlanta this year seven murderers have escaped, one gave himself up, and one was arrested by the police. Nine murders and one arrest! This is what the record shows for the past ten months! Of the seven murderers, who escaped, only one is unknown. The others are known, and one of them made his escape by simply walking out of jail.
Judge Moore, in the Kings County Court of Sessions, yesterday swore in the Grand Jury for November. David Campbell is the foreman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- There has been considerable discussion here to-day of the report sent from Indianapolis that L.T. Michener, ex-attorney General of Indiana, Gen. Harrison's old and confidential friend, had declared war against Chairman Thomas H. Carter of the National Republican Committee because of the latter's supposed antagonism to Gen. Harrison's candidacy for another term in the White House and also because of his views on the silver question.

The President has just appointed three Commissioners, under authority granted at the last session of Congress, to "make inquiry" and to report whether it is possible to construct a deep waterway which will enable vessels engaged in ocean commerce to pass between the great lakes and the Atlantic Ocean.

Some Treasury Department officials have been making interesting discoveries in the method of bonding public officers. One hundred and six thousand officers are under bond to the Government, the amount involved being more than $163,000,000. Most of these officers, 104,000 in number, are Postmasters.

My saleswoman says that the Madrid ladies have the smallest feet she knows of Peruvians and Chileans come next. American ladies from the United States are also remarkable for their small feet. The Russians have heavy splay feet. It is impossible to classify those of Vienna, there are so many varieties there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The forthcoming report of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue will contain some recommendations of special interest to the liquor trade. He will urge amendment to the present law, to permit the bottling of goods in bond. This recommendation will be made with a view to increasing our export trade in bottle goods.

Hour by hour the Republican plurality in Brooklyn appears to be dwindling in the minds of Mr. Wurster and his campaign managers. Yesterday afternoon Mr. Wurster, in an interview with a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES, said he believed he would win by 7,000 votes.

Weakness in all the Continental markets was reflected in lower prices on the local Exchange. The foreigners were liberal sellers of all the international specialties, and the local liquidation was equally pronounced. The stocks which suffered most were Atchison, Louisville and Nashville, Kansas and Texas preferred, and Reading. Boston also sold Atchison freely.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

The equal division of the Common Pleas Judges holding a General Term upon the constitutionality of the Gray racing law raises a question which it is very desirable to have speedily settled. Without doubt the Jockey Club will take steps to procure an authoritative and final decision upon the constitutionality of the law at the earliest moment.

Mr. Thomas Turner of Mill Hill Road, Norwich, has recently unearthed a very interesting National picture. It represents the Pretender (son of King James II.) and his Council assembled at Commercy for the purpose of drawing up, signing, and sealing the declaration to the people of Great Britain and Ireland asserting his right to the crown.

Apropos of the fact that the Committee of the Court of Common Council appointed to purchase a bust of the Duke of Cambridge has allotted 350 guineas for the purpose, it is pointed out that this is the largest sum ever spent by the Corporation of London for such an object for more than a hundred years.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Nov. 4. -- At a meeting of the faculty of the German Theological Seminary of this place, held on Saturday morning last, seven students were expelled for hazing. The expulsion debars them from study and the seminary for the remainder of the year.
NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 4.--Mrs. Daniel Neeley of Belleville, aided by a number of other women, compelled a tramp to surrender to-day. Then she beat him with a club and let him go.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Under authority of the act of Congress providing for a joint Canadian and United States Commission to inquire into and report on the feasibility of establishing deep waterways between the great lakes and the Atlantic Ocean, the President to-day appointed James B. Angell of Michigan, John E. Russell of Massachusetts, and Lyman G. Cooley of Illinois as American Commissioners.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- Maryland to-morrow will elect Governor, Attorney General, and Controller. These three officers constitute the Board of Public Works having in charge the election and supervision of other officers and departments of the State Government.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- James Hodges of Philadelphia, who said that he was connected with the Fourth Battalion of Pennsylvania, committed suicide this afternoon by jumping from near the centre of the Bath Island bridge into the rapids.

" Can science or invention provide any adequate remedy for the evils of overcrowding in cities?" asked Sorosis yesterday, as she sat stately and fair in the pretty ballroom of the Waldorf enjoying her second social meeting of the season.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 4. -- The tin plate manufacturers are talking of making a concerted movement to influence Congress to increase the tariff on imported plate, and it is likely a meeting will be called for some time in the near future to consider the matter and appoint a committee to appear before Congress.
Three women were seriously injured yesterday morning in a collision between a Lexington Avenue cable car and a milk wagon, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-sixth Street. The cable car was crowded.

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 4. -- A large party of Alaskan miners, who have just arrived on the schooner Mary Buhne, which sailed from Ounalaska Oct. 20, bring accounts of the manoeuvring of the Canadian Government's forces in that country.

It was bitterly cold in the city on the 9th of March, 1892, and tiny stalactites of slowly thawing ice hung from the heavy mustache of a strongly built man who had just come in from the street outside and was resting his elbows on the mahogany writing table of one of the largest dealers in dairy produce in London.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 4. -- Thomas May of East Greenwich had twenty-one children and six wives, all of whom lived at different times in one house, which he owned. He is dead now, and his sixth wife wants his estate to support herself and the four youngest children.

If the statements of the campaign managers of the three candidates for the Mayoralty across the East River are to be relied on, three Mayors will be elected in Brooklyn to-day instead of one.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Eugene Field, the poet and humorist, died at 5 o'clock this morning of heart disease at his residence in Buena Park. Although Mr. Field had been ill for the past three days, his sudden death was totally unexpected.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 4. -- John W. Coby of 113 Lexington Avenue was arrested some time ago on a charge of larceny. He was sent to the County Jail, where to-day he was served with notice of a divorce suit begun against him in New-York by Mrs. Caroline Coby, his first wife.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4. -- The balloting in this State to-morrow will be for a State Treasurer and seven Judges for the newly created Superior Court. The candidates for State Treasurer are: Republican, Benjamin Haywood; Democratic, Benjamin F. Meyers; Prohibition, William H. Berry; People's, George W. Dawson; Socialist-Labor, George Anton.
Mary L. Hall and her stalwart colored Republicans marched out last night to brave the Tammany Tiger in the Tenderloin Precinct.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- William D. Morange fell down the elevator shaft in The Argus Building this morning, and died within an hour as the result of his injuries. Mr. Morange was a lawyer. His business was mostly with estates. He for years had visited The Argus editorial room almost daily to read exchanges.

Deep mystery surrounds the arrest of the Staten Island Country Club golf players, made last Sunday by the Richmond County police. That there is a plot of some kind behind it, the members of the Country Club feel certain. What this plot is they do not know, but they look forward with confidence to the police court hearing on Thursday night for its unraveling.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- The Rev. Lyman Cobb., Jr., and wife celebrated this evening their golden wedding, after having lived happily together for just fifty years, and the Rev. Dr. A.G. Vermilyea, who married them, was present to congratulate them.

The trial of David F. Hannigan was continued yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer for the murder of Solomon H. Mann. The first witness was De Lancey Nicoll, who told of the inquest in the case of Loretta Hannigan, the sister of the defendant. He said there was much confusion at the hearing, and that there had been much unseemly conduct.

That "a prophet is not with honor, save in his own country and in his own house," is made evident by an inspection of the colored glass windows that are to be found in the churches of New-York, for they are largely of foreign manufacture, with a few notable exceptions.
NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- In spite of protests on the part of prominent citizens of this village, the work of destroying the magnificent row of elms on Huguenot Street has been resumed.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 4. -- The great collection of paintings in the galleries of the new Carnegie Library Building was opened to-day and will remain on exhibition for one month. There were present prominent critics, collectors, and connoisseurs from all over the country, and these pronounce the exhibit to be one of the most remarkable general assemblages of important paintings ever seen in this country, excepting only the loan collection of the World's Fair.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The customary Thanksgiving proclamation was issued by the President to-day, as follows:

Many golf games are to be played to-day. One of the biggest will be the St. Andrew's Club championship contest for the John Reidgold Medal. The present holder is David G. Henderson, and he will make a big effort to retain the championship another year. Among the St. Andrew's men who will play are A.L. Livermore, L.B. Stoddart, B. Spaulding de Garmendla, J. C. Ten Eyck, W.R. Innis, G.E. Armstrong, and James Park.

The Nassau Electric Railroad Company has for some time been endeavoring to secure a lease of some railroad company in order to get to the bridge. Their routes did not take in that part of the city, and their offer to the Coney Island and Brooklyn Company was rejected.
SPOKANE, Washington, Nov. 4. -- A strike has been ordered by the American Railway Union on this division of the Great Northern Railroad.

PARIS, Nov. 4. -- Premier Bourgeois read this afternoon the declaration of policy of the new Ministry in the Chamber of Deputies. The Radical Deputies cheered the Premier repeatedly, but the members of the Centre remained frigidly silent throughout the address.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 4. -- Two suits were filed in the United States Circuit Court this afternoon, as test cases, to settle the matter of the two bounty appropriations of $238,000 and $5,000,000 which were killed by the adverse decision of Controller Bowler some time ago.

The first ladies' golf competition for the two silver cups given by W.H. Sands at the Westchester Country Club was played yesterday. The conditions governing the match were that the four ladies turning in the best scores, provided they were 55 or under, made during the last two weeks over the links, would be eligible to play for the first cup, and the four making the next best scores would play for the second cup.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Nov. 4. -- The authorities of this county this morning recovered a lot of stolen property, for which they have been searching for the last five months. Early in June last the residence of the Rev. Joshua Primmer of Sergeantville, this county, (Hunterdon,) was entered by burglars and a lot of valuable stuff taken.
Secretary of War Daniel S. Lamont arrived in this city last night to vote the Democratic ticket to-day.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 4. -Several attempts were made on Saturday and yesterday to set fire to the Speed Home for Infants.

Justice Lawrence, in the Supreme Court, yesterday issued a mandamus against the election officers of the Fifty-first Election District of the Thirty-fifth Assembly District, in which they are ordered to strike from the rolls the names of twenty-five men who registered there from the Home for Incurables, at One Hundred and Eighty-third Street, in Fordham.
The Campaign Committee of the Republican County Committee had a passionate outburst of temper yesterday afternoon which threatened to defeat the fusion ticket before the ballots were cast.

Mrs. Sophia Caroline Smith, who is charged with swindling dry goods firms by representing herself as Mrs. Collis P. Huntington, was arraigned yesterday afternoon in the Jefferson Market Police Court and held by Magistrate Mott in $3,000 for trial. The prisoner waived examination until she could communicate with her counsel, who, she said, would be ex-Judge Tenney.
The Campaign Committee of the Republican County Committee had a passionate outburst of temper yesterday afternoon which threatened to defeat the fusion ticket before the ballots were cast.

Mrs. Sophia Caroline Smith, who is charged with swindling dry goods firms by representing herself as Mrs. Collis P. Huntington, was arraigned yesterday afternoon in the Jefferson Market Police Court and held by Magistrate Mott in $3,000 for trial. The prisoner waived examination until she could communicate with her counsel, who, she said, would be ex-Judge Tenney.

BOSTON, NOV. 4. -- A vigorous but unavailing effort was made in the United States District Court, before Judge Nelson, to-day, to have quashed the indictment against the Rev. Frank Hyatt Smith, pastor of the North Avenue Congregational Church, Cambridge. Mr. Smith was present and listened attentively to the arguments of his counsel, Col. Hopkins of Worcester, as did a large number of friends and supporters of the accused preacher.

Among the letters of regret received by Messrs. Bamberger, Bloom Co. after their failure was the following from a writer in a Kentucky town, whose name is not disclosed, because of her request for secrecy:

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 4. -- The mystery surrounding the death of the man Weinhart or Reinhart, who died at the City Hospital on Saturday, after walking the streets for twenty-four hours, with a bullet wound in his body, was solved to-day.

MADRID, Nov. 4. -- Government officials will start forthwith for England to arrange for the immediate building of two torpedo catchers of 400 tons each. They will have a speed of twenty-eight miles per hour.

A large amount of railroad construction has been contracted for in this country, and within the next six or eight months several important extensions will be completed, equipped, and in readiness for operation.
It was the Tiger's night to howl. The excise issue pulled him out of retirement and he lashed his tail and wagged his mane in high old fashion in the Fourteenth Street Wigwam.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 5. -- Massachusetts made no change in her political attitude to-day, Gov. Greenhalge's plurality will be about 67,000 or 68,000, as against 65,000 last year. The vote will be somewhat smaller, but the relative position of the parties will not be materially changed.

The smooth and easy working of the new blanket ballot at yesterday's election in this city left nothing to be desired. The contrast with the confusing multiplicity of ballots of the system which has been displaced was particularly striking. In most cases the marking and the folding of the ballot were the matter of a moment or two, and few mistakes were made and hardly any ballots were spoiled.
NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 5. -- G.M. Pinney (Rep.) was elected District Attorney of Richmond County by 325 plurality.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., NOV. 5. -- Henry Loomis Nelson, editor of Harper's Weekly, who lives in Residence Park, and takes great interest in the progress of the village, denounced last evening, to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES the action of the Board of Trustees of New-Rochelle in destroying the elms in Huguenot Street.

At the front of a long bill I came upon a negro cabin, with an old man sitting on a bench at the door and two battles beside him. As he saw me he called out: "I dun wisht you'd help an old man in trouble!"
The result of the police canvass of 510 out of 625 districts in Brooklyn is as follows:

Thomas J. McManus, the State Democracy candidate in the Seventeenth Senate District, visited all parts of his district yesterday in a carriage, and he narrowly escaped being mixed up in several physical encounters.

The racing season in this State ended yesterday, and a right royal wind-up it was. The day was a perfect one for racing, and the Westchester Racing Association had provided a programme rich in attractions, and the results were fully up to expectation. The fields were well matched and the majority of the finishes well contested.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- The Republicans have carried the State by a plurality estimated all the way from 75,000 to 100,000.

The Riverside Wheelmen never held a more successful set of club races than that which attracted 3,000 persons to the Hudson County Boulevard, near Bayonne, yesterday afternoon. The contests were preceded by a club run to Salter's, near the scene of the finishes, and in this nearly 200 riders of both sexes participated. This event in itself was highly enjoyable.

A long-existing feud between the boys of the Eighth and Fourteenth Wards developed into a battle last night. Their biggest forces are always on hand election night, and they become bold enough to intrude on one another's territory.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 5. -- A cablegram was received in this city last evening from Dr. Donaldson Smith, dated Aden, bearing the one word, "Successful." This news established the safety of the plucky Philadelphia, who for the last year and a half, has been exploring the wilds of Eastern Africa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- At a meeting of the Columbia Historical Society in this city last night the following interesting and hitherto unpublished letter of Washington's was read, and elicited much discussion:

The fair but fragile heroine of "As in a Looking Glass" never really poisoned herself. Mr. Phillips said she did, so as to and his particular story about her with effect, but she has been reappearing in minor English fiction ever since, and she still lives, and enjoys tolerable health, thanks to the stimulating influence of laudanum and dry champagne. Here she is again.

At the headquarters of the German-American Reform Union, Forty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, last night, there was a jubilant gathering of prominent Germans, who shouted themselves hoarse as the telephone bulletins from THE NEW-YORK TIMES office were announced.

The balloting in this city went on in a surprisingly quiet way yesterday. Old-time politicians said that never in their experience had there been such a quiet election in this city. There were fewer rows and fewer arrests than usual.

LYONS, Nov. 5. -- The election was the quietest ever known here. The blanket ballot worked smoothly, and was generally understood. Quite a number of blanks were found. The majority of cast-outs was of that character.

It is impossible, with the defective returns from Brooklyn, to comment with any definiteness on the result of the election for Mayor, which seems to have gone to Mr. GROUT by a small plurality. Mr. SHEPARD'S vote is much lighter than had been expected by either his friends or his opponents.

At the present writing the returns from the various State elections are generally unfavorable to the Democratic Party. Definite figures are lacking; but the results are known. In New-York, while the overwhelming adverse majority of last year is largely reduced, the Republicans still gain heavily on the last election of a Secretary of State.

ALBANY, Nov. 5. -- Albany County gives 500 Republican plurality. The canal $9,000,000 amendment will have a majority of 1,000, though the vote on it falls behind the total vote considerably. The new manner of voting proved successful in all localities, and the number of ballots destroyed by confused making was much smaller than was anticipated.
Soup was one of the most important factors in the work of the women politicians yesterday.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company, which has been endeavoring for some time to bring about the consolidation of the gas companies in Brooklyn, has at last succeeded, as was published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday.
The result of the election was indicated on THE NEW-YORK TIMES' S bulletins more promptly and accurately than elsewhere last evening.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 5. -- The Pittsburg Carnegie Library, the munificent gift of Andrew Carnegie, was formally dedicated this evening. Architecturally, it is without comparison among libraries of the world, in the superiority of its design and appearance, as well as in the extraordinary combination of artistic quarters, which it embraces.
Ex-Senator C. eorge W. Plunkltt got excited yesterday afternoon. He sent this dispatch to Tammany Hall:

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- From present figures received the County of Westchester has gone Republican by about 1,000 plurality, though the official figures will probably change this result somewhat. J. Irving Burns defeats Charles P. McClelland for State Senator in the Twenty-second Senate District, comprising Westchester County and the towns of Westchester, Pelham, and East Chester, recently annexed to New-York. His plurality is estimated at 1,500.
BERLIN, Nov. 5. -- The following story, which has just leaked out, has caused a great sensation in diplomatic circles in Berlin:

Gen. John Palmer of Albany, re-elected Secretary of State, was born on Staten Island, March 22, 1842. His father was a man of moderate means. Prior to 1860 the family moved to Albany, and Mr. Palmer, the senior, opened a small paint shop. There young Palmer worked and learned the trade.

At the close of the century that New-England generation whose creed was a fervent and unmistakable protest against the harsh Puritanism of their fathers has already passed away, or nearly so, though now and again a book appears written in the spirit of their teachings. This latest work of fiction of Mrs. Ward is a case in point.

Although Tammany's candidates are elected, Tammany wins no victory. The increase from GRANT'S vote of 109,000 last year to PURROY'S vote of 120,000 yesterday is very much more than accounted for by the Germans who went over to Tammany, not permanently or from love of it, but out of resentment at the Republican Sunday excise policy.

Tammany Hall yesterday elected its entire city and county ticket by pluralities varying from 18,000 to 23,000. It has also elected nine out of twelve State Senators, and twenty-six out of thirty-five Assemblymen.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 5. -- Pennsylvania has gone Republican by about 150,000 plurality. Benjamin J. Haywood, the Republican State Treasurer-elect, estimates his majority at this figure. B.W. Meyers, the unsuccessful Democratic nominee, concedes his defeat by 125,000.

A new centre of work among the residents of the lower east side of the city was opened by the New-York Protestant Episcopal Mission Society yesterday morning, when the God's Providence Mission Chapel, in Broome Street, near the Bowery, was consecrated by Bishop Potter.

That curious industry -- the manufacture of large unclaimed or undistributed estates for gullible "heirs" -- appears to have gained a foothold in France, and the French promoters of it have placed their estates in this country. The manufacturers with whose operations we are familiar have set up their estates in England or Holland or Germany, and have hunted in the United States for "heirs."

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 5. --Iowa is heavily Republican, if the precincts already heard from are indicative in any measure of the result. The Republican plurality on the head of the State ticket is variously estimated at from 30,000 to 80,000, the former estimate being made by the Democratic leaders and the latter being given out by the Republican State Committee.

" In Sight of St. Paul's," a new five-act melodrama by Sutton Vane, author of "The Span of Life," was acted at the American Theatre last evening before a genuine holiday audience. It is a good specimen of its class, depicting virtue and vice in glowing primary colors, with a prodigal use of the familiar dramatic materials.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 5. -- The fight against Gormanism has resulted in an overwhelming victory.
LONDON, Nov. 5. -- The papers here in their issues to-morrow will give prominence to a dispatch from Rome giving the substance of a dispatch received there from Constantinople.

The office of The United Press Local News whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 5. -- The exciting campaign in Kentucky was followed to-day by a quiet election. The polls closed at 4 o'clock, but the blanket Australian ballot, with unusual scratching, made the counting very slow, and the result is yet in doubt.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- Novel writers and poets, ministers of the Gospel and men of business, editors and reporters of Chicago's daily and other journals, and public officials mingled in the parlors of the Press Club during the noon hour to-day, making a representative gathering of friends and admirers of the late poet and journalist, Eugene Field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- If there had been a National election to-day the excitement in Washington could not have been more noticeable than it has been to-night. The local papers began displaying bulletins at an early hour this evening, and thousands of people gathered in Pennsylvania Avenue to learn the news.
SALT LAKE, Utah, Nov. 5. -- Meagre reports indicate a slight Democratic gain over last year. The result, however, will be exceedingly close, though the Republicans claim everything.

Nearly all the members of the various branches of the Vanderbilt family have arrived in town, and it is said upon good authority that, with the exception of Dr. and Mrs. W. Seward Webb, all the family connections will be present, in St. Thomas's Protestant Episcopal Church to-day to witness the marriage of Miss Consuelo Vanderbilt to the Duke of Marlborough.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 5. -- J. Alden Loring, field naturalist to the United States Department of Agriculture, has returned here from a trip up the McLeod River to the Jasper Pass, within the arctic circle, Mr. Loring leaves in a few days for Washington, to make out his report of the work accomplished in the far north.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- William E. Burns, one of the Directors of the American Railway Union, who is in communication with the employes of the Great Northern Railroad, when asked in regard to the situation, said:

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 5. -- The only State officer voted for in New-Jersey at the election to-day is the Governor. His term of office is for three years. It carries with it the usual appointing power, which in this State amounts to considerable patronage. That patronage is not of special value as a whole, but is valuable in rewarding petty politicians.

We have never been able to feel since the fusion ticket was put in the field that it was the product of a winning anti-Tammany movement, and we took early occasion, without any desire to discourage the effort, to put on record the reasons for its failure, if it should fail, by way of forestalling erroneous explanations.

HERKIMER, Nov. 5. -- The Hon. Warner Miller received election returns here tonight. About 9 o'clock a large procession, with a band and fireworks, serenaded him and called for a speech. In response he appeared, and congratulated the Republicans on having carried the county by the largest majority in its history, excepting the vote given Fremont in 1856.

Joseph Magaria was arrested yesterday on the French steamer Burgundia from Marseilles. He is charged by the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique with the embezzlement of 35,000f. ($7,000) at Sfax, a seaport town of Tunis, where he was the company's agent.

A lively illustration of the curiosities of Cape of Good Hope navigation was afforded yesterday when the British bark Nellie Troop arrived in port. In the harvest from the sea, her prow has turned an unfruitful furrow. The vessel has been since April making a voyage which is habitually accomplished by less able sailing craft in about half the time the Troop was out.
The elections of 1895, in thirteen States and one Territory, have been carried, with a few insignificant exceptions, by the Republicans.
Amos J. Cummings, veteran newspaper man and veteran National legislator, left his headquarters, 303 Eighth Avenue, last evening when the bonfires in his district were lighted.
More than twenty firemen were injured at a fire which was started last night by an explosion in the six-story building on the southeast corner of Broadway and Bleecker Street.
The Republicans of the Empire State have not yet become weary of the rule of Platt.

The decision of THE NEW-YORK TIMES to give three gold medals for individual excellence in the wheelmen's bowling tournaments just organized in the metropolitan district, was received with much enthusiasm yesterday. Each prize will be competed for under liberal conditions, and the wheelmen are highly pleased with the prospect of fine sport on the alleys.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- Much interest was felt in the result of the election for Congressman in the Eighteenth District, because the question of free silver was presently squarely in the views of the opposing candidates.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Senator Sherman reached VashingtorL this afternoon. The Senator said that no Republican could but feel very good over the result of yesterday's election.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- A dispatch from Athens to The Central News says that Cretan advices are that a Revolutionary Committee was recently formed in Crete, with a military commandant, and that a body of armed Cretans repulsed a force of Turkish troops sent to capture the members of the committee.

Mr. Freedman, in regard to the Manhattan Field football games, says: "I was never more disappointed in my life than on Tuesday, when the Pennsylvania football team notified me that they would not play the Boston Amateur Athletic eleven. Well, of course, we lost a large sum of money, and the disappointment to New-Yorkers was aggravating.

The Republican majority for the New-York State ticket increased as the returns came in yesterday. From the Harlem River to Lake Erie it was almost one straight story of Republican gains. The Democratic ticket received a plurality in no county north of the Harlem except Schoharie, which remained true to the tradition that it "always goes Democratic."

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- The few persons who were about the offices in the Capitol to-day were in too high feather to have transacted any official business had it developed. They could do nothing but talk over the results of yesterday and make prophecies as to the future.

STROUDSBURG, Penn., Nov. 6. -- The determination shown by two Constables yesterday saved Monroe County the disgrace of another lynching and preserved the life of a tramp from the hands of a crowd of infuriated farmers, who sought to execute summary justice upon him for attempting to assault a woman.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 6. -William H. Crane, the player, celebrated to-day the twenty-fifth anniversary of his marriage. Presents have been arriving at the hotel for Mr. Crane and his wife from friends all over the country. Ars. Crane has not been forgotten, and she has received almost as many individual presents as her husband.

Mr. and Mrs. Wallace T. Martin and family will not return to New-York from England this month, as they had expected, but will go to Paris for the Winter. During their absence abroad their town house, on East Seventy-second Street, will be occupied by Mr. and Mrs. Wallace T. Martin, Jr.

When Committees of Fifty arraign the Bishop of the diocese for absenteeism and ignorance they ought to be sure of their ground on both counts. Bishop POTTER was undoubtedly guilty of absence, but he was not in the least ignorant. Not a man of the Fifty knew better what had been going on. The Bishop was not with the Fifty, but with the fifty thousand.

The first annual meeting of the association styled "Trustees of Scenic and Historic Places and Objects" was held in the Directors' room of the National Park Bank at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. President Andrew H. Green presided.

I, as a citizen and taxpayer, protest against the selection of the Twenty-second Regiment, N.G.N.Y., by the Adjutant General to represent the Empire State at Atlanta, Ga., upon New-York's Day, Nov. 25. We want to be represented there by not only the best National Guard regiment of the State, but by the best in the United States -- the Seventh Regiment.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The servants employed at Blenheim Palace and the other persons employed on the estate of the Duke of Marlborough were entertained at dinner to-day in honor of the marriage of the Duke in New-York to Miss Consuelo Vanderbilt.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Nov. 6. -- The election of a Mayor of this city will probably not end with an official canvass of the votes cast yesterday. The friends of both former Mayor Gleason and John P. Madden, the Jeffersonian candidate for the office, claim that their man has been elected.

Amos J. Cummings, who was elected Tuesday to fill the vacancy in the Tenth Congressional District, will be the leader of the New-York City Congressional delegation in the House of Representatives, owing to his long periods of service in National legislation.

The German-American voters of New-York City have become a pretty numerous and substantial party. On the issue of chief interest to themselves they determined the result of the election. Being possessed of an issue, they ought to have a policy. We can suggest one.

William H. Dieffenbach of Jersey City has had on trial before Judge Giegerich and a jury, in the Court of Common Pleas, since Monday, an action against the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad for $75,000 damages for injuries that he received in a wreck on the road in 1893, while en route from Binghamton, N.Y., to this city.

It was quiet in Tammany Hall yesterday. Several of the braves called there to compare notes. They were very proud of the local result. A few of the successful candidates called in the afternoon. They saw John C. Sheehan and a few of the other leaders.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 6. -- The first annual flower show of the New-Jersey Floricultural Society was opened this afternoon in the tennis building of the Orange Athletic Club and was visited by many to-night. It will be continued to-morrow and Friday afternoon and evening.

The trial of David F. Hannigan for shooting Solomon H. Mann May 23 was resumed yesterday before Judge Ingraham in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. John B. Hannigan, brother of the accused, who was on the witness stand when court adjourned Monday, was called for redirect examination by Charles W. Brooke, counsel for the defendant.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 6. -- The battery of boilers in the building of The Evening Journal exploded at 9 o'clock this morning, wrecking the buildings 45 and 47 West Larned Street, killing, it is believed, at least forty persons, wounding twenty others more or less seriously, and causing a money loss of $60,000.

The two things that have most confused and weakened the Democratic Party in public opinion have been the favor and fear shown toward the advocates of free silver and the potent though not unrebuked or unresisted influence of Gormanism. These may be regarded as permanently disposed of by the elections in Kentucky and Maryland.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 6. -- The hot contest here over the Mayoralty resulted in the election of Municipal Court Judge George E. Warner, Democrat and Good Government candidate, over Hiram Edgerton, the Republican candidate.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- The majority of John G. Gibson, the Democratic Mayor of this city, over John L. Earll, his Republican competitor, is 1,151. Two years ago Mr. Gibson was elected by 63 majority over Thomas Wheeler.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- The latest returns indicate a plurality or 161,914 for Haywood (Rep.) for State Treasurer.

The question as to which body of military shall represent New-York State and City on Manhattan Day at the Atlanta Exposition, Nov. 25, is causing some dissension among the 360 members of the Citizens' Committee that is making arrangements for the day.

In the first test of the new election law and the blanket ballot it was, perhaps, to have been expected that the machinery for canvassing the vote and declaring the results would work with some stiffness and friction, and this has proved to be the case.

COLUMBUS, Ohio., Nov. 6. -- The Republican victory in Ohio is still growing. This afternoon Chairman Kurtz of the State Republican Committee claims 114,000 plurality for Bushnell, and a majority on joint ballot in the Legislature of 87. The House, he says, will contain 88 Republicans and 22 Democrats. Two members are yet in doubt. The Senate will contain 30 Republicans and 6 Democrats. One member is still in doubt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Secretary Olney has succeeded in liberating from a British prison an American citizen, who fell a victim to English sharpers and swindlers. The American's name is John Frazer Jacques of Illinois, the Colonel of a regiment of that State during the civil war, prior to which he was a minister of the Gospel.
Efforts to enforce the excise law are not to be relaxed.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 6. -- In the Colt divorce case to-day, the counsel for Mrs. Elizabeth W. Colt, Messrs. Comstock Gardner, served formal notice upon Lawyers Colwell and Tillinghast, acting for Col. Colt, that depositions would be taken at Conway, N.H., Friday at the law office of Mr. Osgood, in that place.

Justice Beekman, in the Supreme Court, yesterday granted a peremptory writ of mandamus to compel Street Cleaning Commissioner Waring to reinstate William Carroll in his position as a section foreman in the Street Cleaning Department. Carroll is a war veteran, and was discharged without a hearing because he refused to resign.

The commercial prosperity of large cities depends so much upon the facilities afforded to their inhabitants for rapid and convenient traveling, that such an important and novel undertaking as the construction of the Central London Electrical Railway must naturally be regarded more as a public benefit than as a public enterprise.
Henry Frank, formerly a leather merchant at 13 Brooklyn Bridge, was found dead in a room at the Glenmore lodging house, 4 Chatham Square, yesterday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- The University of Pennsylvania laid, yesterday afternoon, the corner stone of a new dormitory system, which will cost, when completed, $1,200,000. The structure is to be erected in two parts -- a quadrangular section occupying the entire plot formerly taken up by the 'Varsity athletic grounds, and a triangular section of equal length and width.

LONDON, NOV. 6. -- A banquet was given here this evening on the occasion of the opening of the Natal Railway, at which Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies; Sir Charles Tupper, Canadian High Commissioner; all of the colonial agents in London, and several members of the House of Lords and the House of Commons, were present.

ALBANY, Nov. 6. -- State Committeeman William Barnes, Jr., received a black eye in the election of municipal officers yesterday. He feels, however, that he retrieved himself in the election of the county ticket, of Nussbaum for Senator by 486, and in the choice of Chester for Supreme Court Justice in the Third District, by 4,000 in the district.

John B. McGoldrick, Chief Clerk of the City Court and Reading Secretary of the Tammany Hall organization, is in a serious condition at his home, 351 West Twentyeighth Street, as the result of a stab wound. William Dowling was held in the Jefferson Market Police Court to await the result of Mr. McGoldrick's injures.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 6. -- The courts were to-day asked to appoint receivers for the Chalmette Insurance Company and the Bank of North America.

If the number of days spent at sea by two ships on ocean voyages which ended at this port Tuesday were divided by two and an average struck, the time of passage would have been made usual and commonplace. As it is, both voyages are remarkable. One, that of the Nellie Troop, was made conspicuous by its extraordinary length, 209 days from Manila; the other is a record-breaking achievement of 21 days from Hull.

Herman Kiene has one of the most remarkable curiosities in his possession ever seen in this locality. It appears to be a combination of bird, fish, and frog, and looks as if it might be a relic of the evolutionary period which failed to complete its evolution.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 6. -- Kiamil Pasha, the Grand Vizier, has been dismissed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The cablegram to The United Press announcing the date of the consistories to be held in Rome this month, was the first information on the subject received by the Papal legation.

The wedding yesterday of the daughter of a very rich American to an English Duke is noteworthy and memorable as the first avowed "alliance" between English rank and American money. There was a similar alliance not long ago between an American girl and a French nobleman, in which the bride and groom appeared not at all as lovers, but as "high contracting parties."
SALT LAKE, Utah, Nov. 6. -- The result of the election is an overwhelming victory for the Republicans.
A poorly dressed man, apparently about forty-five years old, committed suicide last night at the Chambers Street crossing of the Third Avenue cable railroad.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 6. -- Part of the train which leaves South Amboy, on the Raritan River Railroad, at 9:15 o'clock every morning, ran into the river at South River this morning. There is a drawbridge which spans the river. John Lott of South River, the bridge tender, had opened the draw in order to allow some craft to pass up the river.
The ruins of the big fire at Bleecker Street and Broadway Tuesday night attracted the attention of many persons yesterday. The fire was not fully extinguished until well into the daylight hours.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Social and club circles in Washington have been for the last two days more than ordinarily agitated by statements that had good foundation, to the effect that a difficulty had occurred between Col. Robert Neville and Prince Iturbide of Mexico of so serious a character that it required great forbearance on the part of one or both of these gentlemen to prevent a physical encounter.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- Senator Hill left his law office earlier than usual this afternoon and proceeded to his home, Wolfert's Roost, on Van Rensselaer Boulevard, where THE TIMES'S correspondent found him about sundown. The correspondent asked the Senator if he would grant him an interview on the general result of yesterday's elections in all the States.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- James K. McGuire, the Democratic candidate, has been elected Mayor of Syracuse by a fine majority, and back of him he will have a Democratic majority in the Common Council.

QUEBEC, NOV. 6. -- The Signal Service reports from Little Metis Light say that the German steamship Canadia, Capt. Hahn, of the Hamburg-American Packet Company, from Hamburg and Antwerp for Quebec and Montreal, with a general cargo and passengers, is ashore at Little Metis Light, 175 miles below Quebec, with her bottom cracked and tanks full of water.

" I will bet you a good cigar," quoth one citizen of the metropolis yesterday as he lowered an evening newspaper in which he had been reading an account of the Marlborough-Vanderbilt marriage, and gazed through a blurred window into the thick fog outside, "that every New-York paper to-morrow will make some inane joke about London fogs and ducal marriages -- the appropriateness of the fog to the occasion, or something of the sort."
LOUISVILLE; Ky., Nov. 6. -- The Republicans have carried Kentucky, thanks to "Wat" Hardin's repudiation of the platform on which he was nominated for Governor by the Democratic Party.

The investigation of the Dock Department under Tammany management was continued yesterday by the Commissioners of Accounts in Room 123 of the Stewart Building. Andrew J. White, who resigned his Police Justiceship to accept a Dock Commissionership, was closeted with Commissioner Terry for half an hour before the investigation began.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- The old brick mansion in Pelham Bay Park, which was owned and occupied by the late Philip Schuyler, grandson of Philip Schuyler of Revolutionary times, was burned this morning before daylight. The place was commonly known, as the old Schuyler homestead. It was on property that belongs to the City of New-York.

The new and many large uses which have been found for aluminium during the past year are so numerous and of such varied natures that but a synopsis can be given in covering this field. The greatest success, however, has been along the line where copper and brass are to be replaced, and in this respect there is practically no limit.

The value of the lands taken by the Pennsylvania Railroad at Delair for the approach to the new Delaware River bridge is just now under discussion in the Camden court, before Judge Miller. An element of the value is the brick-making clay which the land contains, and of which there are close to 100,000 cubic yards.

The loving cup, a testimonial to show the esteem in which Joseph Jefferson is held by the members of the dramatic profession, and a gift provided through the subscriptions of actors and actresses, will be presented to that leading comedian of the American stage at the Garden Theatre to-morrow afternoon. Every subscription entitles the giver to admission to the Garden Theatre on this occasion, his or her receipt to be accepted as a ticket.

-- Koster Bial's. -- Koster Bial's newest importation, Liberti's Neapolitan Troubadours, have evidently duplicated their successes made in Europe. The troupe comprises eight vocalists and instrumentalists of a high order, and it will prove a strong card during its stay in America. Another feature of interest is Duncan's ten marvelous collie dogs, who present the most wonderful illustration of animal training ever seen here.

An atmosphere suggestive of gloom more funereal and far more dense than the fog which yesterday overhung the city permeated the haunts of that section of the Democracy in Kings County technically described as the Democratic Reform Organization, but in vulgar parlance designated the "Shepardites."
As both sides in Brooklyn and Kings County were still claiming the election at a late hour last night, the personality of the men affected by the promised contest is of interest.

The result of the election in New-Jersey was as complete a surprise to the Republicans and their candidate, John W. Griggs, as to the Democrats of the State. On Tuesday night, it became apparent by 10 o'clock when the scattering votes came in that Mr. Griggs had been elected, but at midnight even the most sanguine failed to fix his plurality at more than 10,000 to 15,000.

The sale of the Oriole coach horses yesterday, at the American Exchange, went off with fair success. A good number of spectators were on hand, but only comparatively few seemed inclined to bid. The horses were a fine-looking lot, and should have brought more money. A consignment from D.H. Grand Co. of East Buffalo, N.Y., brought better prices.

The Republicans will have just about two-thirds of the members in each branch of the Legislature of this State next Winter, and their party will have all the responsibility for legislation. With a majority of twenty in the Senate and fifty or more in the Assembly, they cannot complain that a little knot of recalcitrant members will be sufficient to defeat the virtuous designs of a great party.

In his explanation of the defeat of the fusion ticket Mr. J. HARSEN RHOADES explains too much. He seems to think that Col. WARING has been politically mischievous, as well as Mr. ROOSEVELT, and that the people who approve of clean streets and vote accordingly are less numerous than the people who desire to stable their trucks in the highways and vote accordingly.

Daniel J. Breen, who said he was thirty-five years old, came from Mexico, and was a guest at the Imperial Hotel, was arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on a complaint preferred by William Kane, a cabman, of 151 East Twenty-second Street, who charged him with refusing to pay a cab bill of $3.

Notwithstanding the fact that the Republican politicians of Brooklyn claim that Frederick W. Wurster is elected by between 2,000 and 3,000 plurality, the regular Democrats will not accept the figures of the Police Commissioner, on which this claim is made.

The Coleman estate has sold to William Hall's Sons, at $90,000, the block front on the west side of Lexington Avenue, between Ninety-seventh and Ninety-eighth Streets, 199.10 by 100.5. The same purchasers bought, a few days ago, the block front opposite on Lexington Avenue.

When Consuelo, Duchess of Marlborough and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Vanderbilt, walked down the broad aisle of St. Thomas's Church yesterday afternoon leaning on the arm of Charles Richard John Spencer-Churchill, the ninth Duke of Marlborough, it might have been said that no fairer or bonnier a young woman ever became the wife of a member of the house founded by England's great military commander.
Why should Democratic New-Jersey go Republican by such a startling plurality this year, with such a sterling candidate for Governor as Chancellor MCGILL?

Los ANGELES, Cal., Nov. 6. -- The war between the Southern Pacific and the Santa Fe commenced yesterday. There is quite a slashing of rates to Eastern points. The Southern Pacific is selling tickets reading from Los Angeles to Chicago, St. Louis, Cairo, and other points, via New-Orleans, at the rate which prevailed up to this morning for the same trip via the Short Line.

The three banks which rolled last night at Thumann's alleys, 107 Horatio Street, in the tournament of the Bank Clerks' Bowling League, were the Hamilton National, Mechanics' National, and the Western National. The Hamiltons managed to win two games straight, the Mechanics won one and lost one, while the Westerns remained good-natured although they lost both games.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 6. -- Every branch of State and City Government was placed by the people of Maryland in the control of the Republican Party at yesterday's election. It was a triumph for which the good men of all parties worked patriotically shoulder to shoulder.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 7. -- About 250 delegates to the Christian Workers' Convention were present this morning, when the ninth annual convention of the societies of the United States and Canada opened.

The big white sign in front of the Coleman House which announced to a curious world that the I.C.O. headquarters were within has been taken down. Those little signs inside the hotel that read "I.C.O. Headquarters This Way" have been taken down, too. But the greatest change is in Room 10. The Gentlemen in Waiting would hardly recognize it now.

The best authority for the ancient haunts of the European lions in the gossipping traveler Pausanias. This natural history note is imbedded in a long catalogue of the trophies and records of athletic victories at the Olympian games, which he saw in the great temple on the plains of Elis. There stood a monument to Polydamas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7.--Secretary Olney issued instructions to Minister Terrell some time ago to take vigorous measures for the protection of American Christians in the Sultan's possessions. Information of this fact was conveyed informally to the representatives of other powers in Washington, the British Ambassador included, and this fact, it is said, forms the sole foundation for rumored joint intervention by Great Britain and the United States.

CHICAGO, NOV. 7. -- The Board of Church Extension of the Methodist Episcopal Church began its annual meeting here this morning in the First Methodist Episcopal Church. Bishop Thomas Bowman of St. Louis, the senior Bishop, called the meeting to order at 10 o'clock.

Two things stand out very plainly in the situation of the Eastern question as developed by the reported events of the last three days. One is the complete and startling departure, if the reports are entirely sustained, that has been made from the terms of the treaty of Berlin; the other is the effect which the agreement now indicated between the powers must have upon the much wider question of the far East.
The trial of David F. Hannigan for the murder of Solomon H. Mann was resumed in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday before Judge Ingraham.

In an interview yesterday, Daniel G. Griffin of Watertown, who declined the nomination for Attorney General at the the Democratic State Convention because the party in this city was not united, gave two reasons for the defeat of the Democratic ticket.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Nov. 7. -- All inquirers at the City Hall to-day were told that John P. Madden, the Jefferson Democratic candidate, had been elected Mayor by a plurality of 21. The officials refused positively to give out any figures, and City Clerk Thomas J. Murphy declined to allow any one to see the returns.
The embargo laid by the fog on ocean traffic was raised yesterday morning, and immediately thereafter there was a coming into port of belated steamships and a going out of similarly delayed craft.

The new Commander in Chief will, no doubt, be invested with large powers, and will not shrink from using them. Not the least hopeful of the many anticipations encouraged by Lord Wolseley's appointment is that he will undertake to select, and this in the most fearless, independent manner.

The sale of tickets for the Horse Show, which begins on Monday next, has exceeded anything known in the management of the affairs since its institution. All desirable seats for the season were disposed of before the public sale opened yesterday morning. Those who went to the Madison Square Garden Yesterday, hoping to obtain the crumbs for the show, found that there were crumbs only.

The candidates who ran for political offices in this county at the recent election began to file returns with the County Clerk yesterday, stating how much it cost them to be elected or defeated. Under the law they are given ten days in which to file these sworn statements.

THURSDAY, P.M. To-day's news was of a reassuring character. The Paris settlement was "satisfactorily" completed, although one large firm paid 50 cents on the dollar and secured an extension for the remainder. The firm's liabilities are placed at $1,400,000. The fact that German bankers have agreed to lend $50,000,000 to Russia for currency conversion purposes was accepted as evidence that the strain in the political situation in the East is less severe.

The stock sold at the American Horse Exchange yesterday comprised lots from Heinemann Brothers and the Chicago Horse and Carriage Company. The best prices obtained were; PROPERTY OF MESSRS. HEINEMANN BROTHERS, NEW YORK CITY.

The building of the Young Women's Christian Association, in Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, was crowded yesterday with delegates who were in attendance at the thirteenth biennial conference of the International Board of Women's and Young Women's Christian Associations.

The Board of Estimate held a five minutes' session yesterday. Controller Fitch offered a resolution to present to the Board of Aldermen a statement of the appropriations for 1896, and the reason for making them. This action is necessary, under Section 189 of the Consolidation Act. The reasons given were the usual set ones, "that they were necessary and sufficient."

The Orange and Crescent Athletic Clubs are still tangled up in a very wordy football war, and neither club seems inclined to budge an inch from the stand it has taken. The Orange men claim that Crescent set the date, Nov. 16, for their annual game without consulting them, and that they arranged a game with Yale for that date in order to show the Crescents that they could not dictate to them.

The fleet of yachts owned by Americans will be considerably increased this Winter. Several steamers are to be built here, four are being built in England, and several racing sail yachts are now being designed by prominent yachtsmen. The largest of the steam yachts is for M.C.D. Borden. It is being built by Handren Robbins, in the Erie Basin, and will be 250 feet in length.

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- The ceremony of swearing in a large number of recruits to be attached to the Berlin, Spandau, Lichterfelde, and Charlottenburg garrisons, took place this morning. The recruits were assembled at 10:45 o'clock in front of the Castle, forming an open square facing an altar decorated with military emblems and flagstaffs, and flanked with cannons, around which were wound leaves of ivy.

The plum pudding must go. With it the pumpkin pie, the fragrant mince pie, and other time-honored Thanksgiving Day dainties must be discarded if the world is to be healthy as well as wealthy and wise.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Salvator Murello, a barber, twenty-six years old, of 339 East Eleventh Street, New-York, and Frank Storetti, twenty-five years old, of 507 East Eleventh Street, New-York, came here this evening to settle, with a duel of fists, a quarrel about a woman.

The United States cruiser New-York, flagship of the North Atlantic station, anchored off Tompkinsville, S.I., yesterday morning. The vessel is from the rendezvous at Hampton Roads and comes here to have several miles of corroded piping replaced and repaired.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 7. -- The annual meeting of New-England colleges is being held with Dartmouth this year. The delegates began to arrive this afternoon, and nearly all are here to-night. The first session was held this afternoon in Wilson Hall. The following is a list of colleges and delegates:

The schedule of football games for Manhattan Field is as follows: To-morrow, Princeton vs. Cornell; Nov. 16, Yale vs. Orange; Nov. 23, Yale vs. Princeton, and Thanksgiving Day, the Carlisle Indians vs. the New-York Young Men's Christian Association. The game to-morrow will be the most important match played this year in this city, and on the basis of dispatches from both Ithaca and Princeton the game will be a hot one.

George F. Greene of 623 Amsterdam Avenue and Jacob Fernando made a bet before election over the candidates for the Assembly in the Twenty-first District. Greene bet on Martin Connellan, the Tammany candidate, and Fernando backed George C. Austin, Republican. Whoever lost was to wheel the other around the block bounded by Ninety-fourth Street and Ninety-fifth Street and Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues.

The General Term of the Court of Common Pleas, with Chief Judge Daly and Judges Pryor and Bookstaver on the bench, heard arguments yesterday on the appeal from the decision of Judge Bischoff at the Special Term denying the motion of Capt. Joseph B. Eakins of the Fifteenth Police Precinct for a peremptory mandamus to compel the Board of Police Commissioners to retire him from active service.

The Woman's Suffrage League of this city held a stated meeting at 4 Lexington Avenue last night, and took occasion to make some suggestions to Mayor Strong regarding the salaries of women teachers in the public schools.

The hundred or more prominent New-Yorkers representing the Citizens' Committee, which is looking after the success of Manhattan Day, Nov. 25, at the Atlanta Exposition, have on their hands a troublesome question. The question is whether or not Chicago shall have a bigger day at the fair than this metropolis.

The village of Argamasilla de Alba is situated on the extreme southeast corner of New-Castile, close to the source of the "weeping Guadiana." Viewed from the plain of La Mancha, its aspect is dull and unsightly, being composed of mean-looking houses built around a dreary plaza, shaded by a few fine English elms -- the only objects that lend a touch of poetry to the scene.

One may admit, too, that the whole constitution of Freeman's mind rendered him unfit to do justice to Froude. To Freeman subtlety of any kind, whether in the good or the bad sense of the word, was repellent. It mystifies him as it mystifies a child. And a complex mind like Froude's, with its curious mixture of cynicism and earnestness, skepticism and enthusiasm, was to him a sealed book.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 7. -- At a meeting to-day of the directors of the Cotton States and International Exposition, the Chairman of the Finance Committee, Samuel M. Inman, announced that he had raised, among a few citizens, cash subscriptions to the amount of $100,000, to cancel the accumulated indebtedness of the exposition.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- President Stuyvesant Fish of the Illinois Central Railroad, who was a World's Fair Director, has invited all the living members of that board, thirty-five in all, the chiefs of departments who are within reach, and a few other executive officials of the Exposition, to make a trip on a special train to Atlanta and New-Orleans.

The disagreeable experience of Col. JOHN F. JACQUES of Illinois, who was released from an English prison a few days ago through the intervention of our legation in London, ought to enlighten and restrain certain other persons in this country who are engaged in ventures like the one which brought him before an English court.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- Senator Gorman is quoted in a Washington paper as expressing himself as follows in regard to the Maryland election:

EDENBURGH, Nov. 7. -- Thomas F. Bayard, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, delivered the inaugural address at the meeting of the Edinburgh Philosophical Society this afternoon. His subject was "Individual Freedom, the Germ of National Prosperity and Permanence." The address was of a purely academic character.

Edward Lauterbach, Chairman of the Republican County Committee, one of the Republican "big four" of the State, said yesterday that he was in favor of procuring legislation necessary for the consolidation of New-York and Brooklyn as soon as the next Legislature met at Albany.
Mr. Francis M. Jencks has bought of Henry Kruse four lots at the southeast corner of West End Avenue and Eighty-third Street.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 7. -- The responsibility for yesterday's boiler explosion is now generally placed upon the shoulders of Thomas M. Thompson, the engineer, who, it is believed, permitted the water to become low in the boilers.

Six persons were suffocated in a fire in the four-story brick tenement, at Van Brunt and King Streets, Brooklyn, at 1 o'clock yesterday morning, as was told in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of yesterday. The dead are:

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 7. -- The steamer Puritan, which should have arrived here this morning, arrived at 7:15 o'clock tonight. She will return to New-York as soon as she can discharge her freight. She was delayed by fog.

John B. McGoldrick, reading secretary of Tammany Hall and Chief Clerk of the City Court, who was stabbed in the left side Wednesday during an altercation with William Dowling, a member of the Tammany General Committee, passed a comfortable night at his home, 345 West Twenty-eighth Street, and was reported yesterday to be resting easily.

ALBANY, Nov. 7. -- The proposition to appropriate $9,000,000 for improving the canals having apparently carried, the State officers are looking into the matter of the issuance of the bonds. It is found that the law makes about $4,000,000 of the $9,000,000 almost immediately available, it only being necessary, perhaps, to await the official declaration of the vote by the State Board of Canvassers.
WASHINGTON, NOV. 7. -- Rear Admiral Shufeldt died at his residence in this city at 10:25 this morning.

ALBANY, Nov. 7. -- Commissioner Eton R. Brown of Watertown, who was appointed by Gov. Morton to take the testimony on the charges filed against Gen. Austin Lathrop, the Superintendent of State Prisons, has not yet determined upon the day for the commencement of the inquiry. He must give eight days' notice of his intention to begin the taking of testimony.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Nov. 7. -- Nothing was heard of the missing Wilson Line steamer Missoula to-day. She has been given up by the underwriters. She carried a crew of sixteen persons. The Missoula's value is fully $80,000. Her grain cargo is valued at $50,000.

The 7th of November, 1871, was a historic battle day in the City of New-York. Under the lead of Mr. TILDEN the reform Democracy united with the forces organized by the Committee of Seventy to overthrow the Tweed Ring. The Legislature was the point of attack. "My plan of campaign was in a single idea," said Mr. TILDEN; "it was to take away from the Ring the Senators and Assemblymen from this city."

Mrs. Annie Chase of 64 West Eleventh Street rented a room in her house to a refined-looking man on Oct. 21 last. The man slept one night in the house, and the next morning, when the other boarders got up, he had disappeared. So also had everything valuable that could be carried away--in all about $500 worth.
The women members of the Central Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventh Avenue and Fourteenth Street, were in a flutter last night.
" Union Missionary Training Institute" is the inscription on a sign placed on a small dwelling house in Waverley Avenue, not far from Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn.

The Chase of the buffalo was the Indian's chief amusement as well as one of his means of livelihood, and was carried on usually on horseback, formerly with bow and lance, latterly with rifle also. In this exercise they became wonderfully expert. Mounted upon his strong, fleet "Indian pony," well trained for the chase, he dashed off at full speed among the herd and discharged his deadly arrows into their hearts from his horse's back.

The reports of railroad earnings for October, complete, show an enormous increase in the traffic of the Western roads and also a surprisingly large increase in the volume of freight traffic from Chicago to the Atlantic seaboard. The aggregate shipments of east-bound freight out of Chicago last month amounted to 419,630 tons, an increase over last year of 182,650 tons.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- The Autumn of 1895 will be remembered long in ordinarily quiet Mamaroneck because of the disturbances that have followed one after the other. The discussion over the union and incorporation of the villages of Mamaroneck and Rye Neck, that is to be voted on Nov. 12, becomes sharper as the time for voting approaches.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 7. -- Halil Rifat Pasha has been transferred from the office of Minister of the Interior to that of Grand Vizier. He is reported to be an able Minister, but it is said that he does not possess the influence of either Said Pasha or Kiamil Pasha.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 7. -- The Secretary of State to-day issued a partial return of the census taken last Summer. The total number of noses counted was 1,672,942. This is an increase of 228, 009 over the Federal census of 1890. In that year the National returns showed there were 1,444,933 persons in the State.

Ex-Senator Warner Miller talked about the election at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- The Summerfield Methodist Church Fair opened in Irving Hall this afternoon. The women of the church have worked hard to make the fair attractive. The booths are handsomely decorated, and contain pretty desplays of fancy work, bric-a-brac, and flowers. A large crowd was present this evening.
The Rev. Dr. G.H. Parkhurst places some of the blame for the defeat of the fusion ticket at the door of Mayor Strong. In a statement which Dr. Parkhurst gave out yesterday, said:

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 7. -- The weather was fine yesterday, and a large attendance witnessed the regatta races. The great event of the day was the final heat, three miles with a turn, double scull, for the world's championship and a purse of $1,000, between England's champions, Bubear and Barry, and America's fliers, Teemer and Rogers.

What has happened, or, rather, what is happening, down in Cuba? It has been several weeks now since the telegraph operators at Havana won a great battle over the rebels. Apparently the Spanish officials are offended because their yarns had no effect on public opinion here or in Europe, and have resolved upon a policy of haughty silence as well as of stern inaction.

The baseball men are now preparing for the annual Fall meeting of the National League and American Association of Professional Baseball Clubs, which is to be held at the Fifth Avenue hotel, in this city, next Wednesday. Andrew Freedman, President of the New-York Baseball Club, in speaking of the matter yesterday, said that he favored the coaching rules as they were during last Summer, but that he was of the opinion that two umpire system.

It is reported that Mr. JOHN JACOB ASTOR has recently purchased a large interest in the Keely motor from a person who for some years past has been an enthusiastic advocate of Mr. KEELY. This report reminds us that Mr. KEELY has failed thus far to notice a challenge published in June last by Electricity, a well-known trade journal.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- There is a disposition in Washington to regard the sweeping Republican victories Tuesday as a rebuke to bossism rather than an indication that Democratic policy is becoming unpopular.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 7. -- William H. Davidge, and Francis Saunders, the members of the Richmond County Hunt Club who were arrested last Sunday by two policemen for playing golf on the links of the Hunt Club on the Clove Road, Stapleton, were discharged this evening by Justice Cuyler Van Vechten, in the New-Brighton Village Hall.

The body of Col. Albert W. Johnson of Fort Hamilton will arrive in Brooklyn this morning from Cleveland, where he died in the home of his son, ex-Congressman Ton L. Johnson, Wednesday afternoon. The burial will be in Greenwood at 11 o'clock this morning.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 7. -- Miss Marie Vyse, one of the best-known society women of Staten Island, was probably fatally injured to-day while driving. Miss Vyse is a daughter of Thomas A. Vyse of the New-York Life Insurance Company, whose home is in Fourth Street this village.

When the Assembly meets this Winter, the Republican majority will find it has lost its leader on the floor. Danforth E. Ainsworth, "the little man from Oswego," Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, quick at parliamentary repartee and tireless as a bee, will not be there.
The Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers helds its third general meeting in this city yesterday in the rooms of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, 12 West Thirty-first Street.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- The Daily News will to-morrow publish a Constantinople dispatch giving the details of the arrest at the Post Office of the servants of British merchants. The dispatch adds that the foreign Post Offices are surrounded by spies and there is serious danger of a conflict between them and the foreigners.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 7. -- The payment of election bets has made considerable fun in this city. William Snyder (Rep.) and Patrick McKenna (Dem.) bet a handcart ride on the result. The winner was to ride and the loser was to push the cart. Last night was selected for the event, the start to be made from the Five Corners, on the Heights.

PHILADELPHIA, NOV. 7. -- Contrary to expectations, the weekly bulletin of the Racing Board, out to-day, does not contain any reference to the "fixed" St. Louis race. F. Dwight Porter and W.M. Scheftel were admitted to membership in the Stock Exchange yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., NOV. 7. -- Testimony in the divorce proceedings in which Col. and Mrs. Colt are concerned will begin at Conway, N.H., to-morrow, and a full contingent of attorneys accompanied the respondent, Col. Colt, from Providence to-day.

A committee of three members of the Anthracite Coal Operators' Association has been appointed to solicit proxies from the stockholders of the principal coal-carrying railroads, with a view of securing representation for their association in the Directories of those roads. The names of the committeemen are E.B. Sturgis and C.D. Simpson of Scranton and H.M. Howe of Philadelphia.

PARIS, Texas, Nov. 7. -- The Choctaw Council, Instead of showing a disposition to accede to the proposition of the Lawe, Commission to allot lands, has displayed the most violent opposition to it.
Mayor Strong said yesterday that there would be a new Park Board next week.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- George Alexander, the manager of St. James's Theatre, reopened that place of amusement to-night with a revival of "Liberty Hall," writted by R.C. Carton. The audience emphasized the universal condemnation of Mr. Alexander's recent treatment by the police and a Magistrate.
