LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 7. -- Dr. Hunter, Chairman of the Republican Campaign Committee, says the Republican majority on joint ballot in the next Legislature will be four or five.

NEWBURG, N.Y., NOV. 7. -- The annual convention of woman suffragists of the State will convene here to-morrow. Jean Brooks Greenleaf of Rochester presiding. They will hold daily sessions until Monday next.

Tile grain interest Was chiefly supported by local scalpers and switchers, with prices influenced to a fair extent by better cables and firmer Western markets, and an increased business reported. Outside speculators were inclined to await the Government report. Provisions were firmer, but very quiet.
LONDON, Nov. 8. -- A dispatch from Constantinople to The Times says that the entire body of foreign diplomats accredited to the Turkish capital regard the present condition of things as unbearable.

The police of the Delancey Street Police Station believe they have captured the leader of the masked thieves who shot and killed Richard Pope in the saloon of Walters Brothers, at Brown Street and the Southern Boulevard, Thursday night.

Two handsome octavo volumes, with charming binding, pleasing illustrations, and each page with an appropriate border, are "The Tales of a Traveler," by Washington Irving, the Messrs, Putnam being the publishers. The edition will go by the name of "The Buckthorne Edition," a title taken from the second part of these stories, where Buckthorne begins telling of "the Booby Squire."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The State Department has read with much interest that the Sultan has replied to the foreign Ambassadors in Constantinople on their demand for order throughout the Ottoman Empire. The precautions for the preservation of domestic peace do not seem, from the Washington point of observation, at all adequate.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 8. -- Clara Oswaldt, eighteen years old, and Carl Graete, twenty-one, were married two months ago, by Recorder McDonough. The bride left her husband soon after the marriage, and returned to her home in Bremerhaven, Germany.

Those in this city who are in sympathy with the cause of the Cuban revolutionists -- and they are many -- braved last night's fog and drizzle in considerable numbers to attend a mass meeting in the Murray Hill Lyceum, Thirty-fourth Street and Third Avenue, for the purpose of commemorating the appointment of Tomas Estrada Palma as the Plenipotentiary Delegate Abroad of the Cuban Revolutionary Party.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 8.--Senators Morgan and Pugh, Congressmen Bankhead and Underwood, and other silver Democratic leaders held a conference in Birmingham today to decide on the course to be pursued in the coming campaign. Mr. Underwood was for subordinating the silver issue to Democratic unity, but the two Senators and their adherents contended for a hot silver campaign inside the party.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- A Consular bulletin just issued by the State Department is interesting and valuable for the tables it gives of the value of exports declared for the United States in the quarter ended June 30, 1895, as compared with those for the same quarter of the previous year, from the various countries with which we have international trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Commander Richard Rush, Superintendent of Naval War Records, recommends in his annual report that the selection of original manuscripts for the records of the Union and Confederate Navies be made by a board to be composed of one naval and two civilian members.

FRIDAN -- P. Uneasiness over the poUtical situation in Europe was re-flectdd in a sharp drop in ritish consols and marked weakness on all the foreign Bourses. There were rumors of financial difficulties in London and .Paris, but nothing definite 'as announced.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 8. -- The New-Jersey Forestry Association held its annual meeting here to-day. It elected the following officers for the ensuing year: President -- Augustus W. Cutler of Morristown; Vice Presidents -- William A. Stiles of Decker-town, Capt. A.M. Bradsh of Lakewood, and Mrs. John C. Davis of Riverton; Secretary and Treasurer -- John C. Clifford of May's Landing.

There was a pleasant little gathering last evening in the schoolroom of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church in West Forty-Sixth Street to hear Mrs. W.T. Bainbridge speak of her work among the poor in Lower New-York.

SAN JOSE, Cal., Nov. 8. -- Five thousand people attended the National Circuit races in this city. Bald won the mile open from Murphy in 2:01 2-5, but a second slower than world's record for a tandem paced race. Murphy had the tandem throughout the race, and took the pace when the tandem dropped. In the twothirds mile handicap, Cooper had twenty-five yards and Kiser thirty.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 8. -- Mail advices from Caracas received to-day, bearing date of Nov. 1, say that no ultimatum from Great Britain with reference to the Uruan incident had yet reached the Venezuelan capital.

It seems almost too good to be true, the report that a method has been found for putting fourth-class Postmasters under the civil service law, and so removing from the reach of politicians a vast number of petty offices with which politics should have no more to do than with the computation of eclipses or determining the best way to prevent hens from wasting their time on china nest eggs.

It is announced that Mr. RICHARD CROKER will personally attend to all matters of reorganization in Tammany Hall. Mr. JOHN C. SHEEHAN will continue in immediate charge at that edifice, and all the district leaders who have stood by Mr. CROKER will retain their places.

Acting Police Captain John R. Groo of the Mulberry Street Precinct appeared before Commissioner Parker yesterday to answer to charges preferred against him by the Parkhurst Society. Agent Dennett of that society appeared in its behalf and pressed the complaint.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- Miss Annie Sherman Harriman was married last evening to Carroll Moore at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Harriman, in Warburton Avenue. The house was decorated with chrysanthemums, palms, and smilax.

Announcement is made of the engagement of Miss Beatrice Thompson, the youngest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Thompson of New-Orleans, La., to George W. Murray of this city. Miss Thompson is very well known in this city. Mr. and Mrs. Thompson and Mr. Murray will sail for Europe in the latter part of this month, and will spend eight weeks in Paris.

While on his way to Denver a few days ago from Massachusetts Walter Sanger, the giant of the racing path, stopped off at Milwaukee for a brief visit to his home. He happened to be in a talkative mood, and gave out a number of racetrack secrets that cannot fail to cause talk in the cycling world. One subject on which the big racer talked with considerable freedom was "Johnnie" Johnson's alleged questionable riding methods.

BOSTON, Nov. 8. -- The steamer Herman Winter of the Metropolitan Steamship Company, which arrived here to-day from New-York, had a narrow escape from a serious collision last Wednesday while anchored in the North River, New-York, during a dense fog.

PETERSBURG, Va., Nov. 8. -- Stith Bolling and Alvah H. Martin of the Republican State Executive Committee, with Asa Rogers. Secretary, have issued a call for a meeting of the State Committee of the Republican Party in this city Wednesday, Nov. 27 to fill the vacancy in the State Executive Committee occasioned by the death of Gen. William Mahone, its late Chairman, and to transact such other business as may be necessary.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 8. -- The dividends paid by the Fall River mills in this, the last, quarter of the year, as compiled today by G.M. Haffards Co., show an increase of 100 per cent. paid out, as compared with the amounts paid in the corresponding quarter a year ago.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8. -- Lloyd Lowndes, when he shall become Governor, will have more appointments to make, more patronage to bestow and greater power than could fall to the lot of the Executive of almost any other State in the Union.

Another batch of candidates' election expenses were filed with the County Clerk yesterday. At the head of the list stands the account of James Meehan, who ran as the candidate of the State Democracy in the Eighteenth Senatorial District. Mr. Meehan received 595 votes out of a total of nearly 16,000.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

Mayor Strong's announcement that Commissioner Roosevelt will remain in the Police Board as long as he wants to has set at rest a lot of those rumors that the last election would cause the local authorities to change their policy as to the enforcement of the excise laws.

Chicago has an epidemic of diphtheria. We learn from the newspapers of the city that 65 deaths were caused by this disease in the week ending on the 19th ult., and that the number for the three weeks ending on that date was 153. It also appears that the death rate was very high; one report says that it was 49 1/2 per cent.
-- George . Grlnnell's volume, "The Stor of the Indian," the first in Ripley Hitchcock's Story' of the West Series, will be published this month by the Messrs. Appleton.

A startling array of facts respecting the spread of consumption was revealed last evening at the regular meeting of the Section of Public Health of the New-York Academy of Medicine.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- Dr. Chauncey M. Depew was entertained to-night by he Buffalo Club at a banquet given in recognition of Dr. Depew's well-known friendly regard for Buffalo and its prosperity. Eighty covers were laid, and among the number who gathered to do honor to Dr. Depew were ex-Postmaster General Wilson S. Bissell, Controller J.A. Roberts, and Mayor E.A. Jewett.

While the returns which proclaimed Tammany's victory in the city were being read out on election night at Republican County Headquarters, George Bidwell, the Secretary of the Republican County Committee, told why he felt that Tammany was likely to win before a vote was polled. He said:

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- Executive officers of the Western roads to-day ratified the new passenger agreement. A meeting of representatives of the trans-Missouri lines was also held to determine whether or not those lines should concur in the agreement. No decision was arrived at to-day, but it is practically certain they will sign the new articles.

The doubt that has been raised about the result of the election in Brooklyn seems to be based mainly on the throwing out of alleged "defective ballots." This raises the question, what is a defective ballot?
NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- The New-York State Suffrage Association is holding its annual convention here. Committee meetings have been held to-day, and this evening the first public session was held.

Nehemiah Dodge, a section foreman in the Street Cleaning Department, living at 417 West Twenty-third Street, summoned to Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday afternoon Matthew Carley of 450 West Thirty-first Street, on a charge of libeling his character by saying about the city that he had paid $50 in order that he might be reinstated as a street sweeper.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- Nearly 500 of Chicago's citizens, accompanied by delegations from Aurora, Peoria, Joliet, Milwaukee, and Racine, set out for Atlanta this afternoon, to be present at the celebration of Chicago Day at the exposition in that city next Tuesday. There were five trains of ten cars each, and all were comfortably filled.

The question of the constitutionality of the Percy-Gray racing law came up before the General Term of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday, when the case of Henry C. Judson against the Flushing Jockey Club was called for argument.

Gen. Howard Carroll entertained other members of the Governor's staff last evening at his home, 9 West Thirty-eighth Street. The banquet table was almost hidden beneath floral cannon and the insignia of the National Guard of the Empire State in flowers.
ALBANY, Nov. 8. -- Gov. Morton has issued the following Thanksgiving Day proclamation:

LIVERPOOL, Nov. 8 -- The Liverpool Autumn Cup race, run at the Liverpool Autumn meeting to-day, was won by The Rush. Portmarnock was second. Red Wing II. and Rockdove ran a dead heat for third place. Twelve horses ran. The betting was 10 to 1 against The Rush, 5 to 1 against Portmarnock, 20 to 1 against Red Wing II., and 3 to 1 against Rockdove.

CHICAGO, Nov. 8. -- A local paper publishes a long article purporting to give facts regarding a new deal, the consummation of which would mean the complete construction of the Nicaragua ship canal purely as a private enterprise, with American and British money, including Chicago capital, as represented in newly invented canal machinery in successful operation on the Chicago drainage canal.
The Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers resumed its session yesterday morning at 12 West Thirty-first Street.
The headquarters of the regular Democrats in Brooklyn last night presented a most animated scene. All the best-known men of the organization were there, among them Edward M. Grout.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 8. -- Indications point to the utter collapse of the Populist Party in Indiana. E.B. Cummings, Secretary of the Populist State Committee, resigned to-day. Edgar A. Perkins, Chairman of the committee in this county, resigned immediately after the late municipal election, announcing that he would return to the Democratic Party, and the committee has gone out of existence.
The following law students were admitted to the bar yesterday in the Supreme Court by Justices Van Brunt and Parker:

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- The Field will to-morrow publish a four-column statement from Lord Dunraven relative to the contest for the America's Cup. Lord Dunraven opens by saying that as so much has been written and said loosely concerning the races, and as he has received so many requests for fuller information, he thinks it due to the yachting and general public and himself that he make a statement.

RAHWAY, N.J., Nov. 8. -- The green goods men are here once more, and to-day two "come-ons" were taken in and swindled.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 8. -- The Standard Rope and Twine Company, with a capital of $12,000,000, filed articles of incorporation this morning with County Clerk Howard. The incorporators of the company, as shown by the papers filed, are William P. Travers of New-York, William R. Potts of New-York, John Kean of this city, Augustus C. Kellogg of this city, and William Barbour of Saddle River, Bergen County, N.J.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 8. -- A rabid dog tore through the streets of New-Rochelle this morning and bit six other dogs and a horse. Great uneasiness is felt among citizens because the dogs that were bitten are still at large.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 8. -- Next week promises to bring a crush on Atlanta. Monday will be Illinois day. Gov. Altgeld will be escorted to the exposition by the First Regiment, Illinois National Guard.

A loving cup was presented yesterday to Joseph Jefferson by members of his profession in the Garden Theatre. The theatre was handsomely decorated with palms and ferns. A pedestal bearing a laurel wreath stood at the front of the stage, and a silvered model of the cup on a revolving rest at one side, in full view of the audience.

Fog seems inclined to make New-York City a Winter resort. Having spread itself over this locality for nearly fifty hours, it went somewhere Thursday afternoon, only to make its reappearance again late at night. It shut in thick during the early morning hours yesterday and succeeded in making itself disagreeable to every one on shore and dangerous to those who fared by water.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Nov. 9. -- For the first time in eight years on the home grounds Lehigh was defeated by the eleven from Lafayette College, with a score of 22 to 12. The game was hotly contested from beginning to end. Lehigh won the toss, choosing the west goal, from which a. light wind was blowing. After playing twenty minutes Barclay scored the first touchdown for Lafayette.
The last month of this year will see in progress the most comprehensive-venture in the field of philanthropy that the Israelites of this city have undertaken in many years.

The breaking up of the past week by the election and the attendant interest in the result had an undoubted effect in preventing business in real estate. Still, quite a number of sales were made, and inquiry was fairly active. The renting of stores and lofts for business uses in the wholesale districts has kept up in such away as to indicate a good season, perhaps the best since the Fall of 1892.

Thursday was College Day in the Woman's College, and the annual exercises were held at night in the First Methodist Episcopal Church and in Goucher Hall. Among those present were many prominent citizens and noted educators. The annual college day address was delivered by President Charles W. Eliot of Harvard University, whose subject was "The Happy Life." Dr. Eliot said:

The afternoon tea of to-day bears little resemblance to the afternoon tea of some ten years ago. It has now become a distinct meal -- then it was little more than refreshment indulged in under protest. Men considered it a woman's weakness, an excuse for afternoon meetings and afternoon gossip, and few men followed this feminine fashion; the regarded it as a mere indulgence unworthy of the sterner sex.

Umpire Dashiel blew his whistle, and Freeborn sent his foot against the ball, and it spun along the ground in Princeton's territory.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 9. -- Charming Indian summer weather prevails, but only a few cottagers remain here to enjoy it, the great wedding and the Horse Show having suddenly drawn nearly everybody toward New-York.
Capt. Baldwin gave me an account of an incident that happened to him in May, 1866.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 9. -- The experiments by Prof. J. Woodbridge Davis and William A. Eddy in towing buoys by means of tailless kites were resumed to-day, Mr. Eddy's kites furnishing the motive power. Prof. Davis, the inventor of the buoys, was again unable to be present.

Brooklyn is the happy possessor of the only original American doll surgery. At least, that is what the proprietor of the establishment, which is in one of the side avenues not far from Flatbush Avenue, says, and who should know better?

BOSTON, Nov. 9. -- A letter has been sent to the Secretary of the Navy by several citizens of this country and elsewhere who were passengers on the royal mail steamship Warrimoo, from Vancouver, B.C., to Australia. The letter is signed by E.A. Sanford of Philadelphia, Arthur Lewis of Iowa, Harry Willard French of Boston, E.V. Cookey of Victoria, B.C.; Arthur F. Pate of Des Moines, Iowa, and others.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The Treasury Department has settled the question regarding the free distribution of samples of whisky and wines at the Atlanta Exposition, which has long vexed the officials. Free whisky has finally won.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 9. -- A pretty and successful fair was held in the parish house of St. Luke's Episcopal Church, this afternoon and evening, for the purpose of raising money for the prosecution of the missionary work of the society.

A New-York business man who has just returned from South Africa says that what struck him most in that country was not its immense wealth, the feverish speculation that is going on there, nor the rapidity with which enormous fortunes have been made by some of its inhabitants, but a remark which he heard over and over again, and which has become a sort of proverb at Cape Town and the other coast cities.

L.J. Seargeant's prospective retirement from the important position of General Manager of the Grand Trunk Railway was the subject of an interesting incident at the recent meeting of the Board of Trunk Line and Central Traffic Association Presidents in this city. President George B. Roberts of the Pennsylvania Road presided, and at a convenient period he granted to Mr. Seargeant the privilege of making a personal statement.

The word "dish" is used in a metaphorical sense. The barbecue gets its name from the method of cooking the meats which form its principal substance. It is a pagan feast. Its home is in the woods, by some clear running brook, and when found upon its native heath such modern conveniences as knives and forks, tables and chairs, are not known.

The municipal authorities of a large city, who recently ordered the local street railway companies to provide their electric cars with an effective fender by a specified date, may be fairly supposed to have had an imperfect understanding of the conditions governing the provisions they sought to bring about.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 9. -- An eleven representing the Fourth Division of the New-York Naval Reserves met with defeat here this afternoon in their first game of the season, the New-Jersey Athletic Club winning by a score of 11 to 4. Points were all scored during the lengthy first half. A feature was the kicking of one goal from field by Whyte.

In New-York at least three institutions have opened their doors, while in Pennsylvania both Philadelphia and Pittsburg are enjoying collections much above the commonplace.

The United Service Gazette (British) notes an interesting comparison in the results of the coal-consumption trials of the Majestic and Magnificent. The dimensions of the machinery in both ships, the paper says, are the same.
ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Prof. W.R. Scott of Princeton lectured last night in the Young Men's Christian Association Hall on "Oscillations of Level Geysers," in the University Extension course.

The many friends and members of the Alumni Association of Public School No. 26 of Brooklyn, will be glad to know that the long talked of but much delayed presentation of the bronze tablet in memory of the late Principal, James E. Ryan, is about to be made.

An American Pope, for example -- and it is of an American Cardinal that these reasoners are secretly thinking, because only an American would be exempt from the passionate jealousies which divide the States of Europe -- might even despise an earthly crown.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 9. -- The event most talked of now in society circles is the Kirmess to be held in the Columbia Cycle Academy from the 11th to the 16th inst.
PARK RIDGE, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Gustav Latterman of this place was married to Mrs. Anna D. Fox of Eastwood Oct. 1, by Edward Bradley, curate of St. Agnes's Protestant Episcopal Chapel, in New-York City.

PATERSON, Nov. 9. -- The residence of James Simpson, a silk manufacturer of this city, is under a strict quarantine. Edmund Burke, a young man, is in the house suffering from an aggravated attack of typhus. Burke arrived in New-York on the Lucania, with his mother, Nov. 1. They came from England for the special purpose of visiting Mr. Simpson.

Six interesting games were bowled yesterday afternoon at Reid's alleys, 198 Church Street, in the tournament of the Wholesale Drug Trades Bowling Association. The teams that were the most fortunate were Merck Co. and McKesson Robbins, as they each won two games. The game between Merck Co. and Whitall, Tatum Co. was the closest and most exciting of the day, and it was only won by six pins.

TIMES medals will figure in three of the biggest bowling tournaments this Winter that were ever arranged by cyclists in this country. In each instance the trophy will be won only by the highest record of individual excellence. The tournaments in question are under the auspices of the governing bodies of cyclists in New-Jersey, this city, and Long Island.

There is no truer sign of chronic and irreparable misfortune than a package of well-thumbed papers. "Just look at these for one moment," old Miss Blair would relax feverishly undoing the dingy tape and outspreading a formidable array of bemottled documents"; and then her intended victim would make haste to escape behind a cloud of spurious excuses.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Nov. 9. -- There was no change to-day in the contest over the Mayoralty in this city. Both sides continue to claim the office, and the matter will probably remain in its present unsettled condition until next week.

In accordance with a series of resolutions adopted by the Legislature of Minnesota and of Wisconsin, at their late sessions, commissions have been appointed by both States to consider the subject of creating a new State from territory bordering on Lake Superior. A proposition to join in this action was before the Legislature of Michigan, but did not receive favorable action.

The art of dining, as everybody will admit, is in its infancy in the United States, and this for a great many reasons. In the first place, in order to practice an art well, it is necessary to take a very serious view of it, and to take a serious view of eating is commonly considered in all Anglo-Saxon communities as the mark of a frivolous, if not of a depraved, mind.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Outdoor sports reign supreme these Indian Summer days. Of course golf is first, with the tournament to begin next Tuesday.

So for some three furlongs the main line wends its way up and along either bank of the nullah, what time the stops move forward to head the driven quarry. None of the smaller denizens of the woodland rise or run unassailed by him who holds the pass. Still, for many minutes is the forest silence unbroken by report of firearm or other sound, save those which the heavy-footed elephants evolve.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- A number of reports have been received at the War Department from different posts in the country complaining that the fire of the new service arm -- the Krag-Jorgensen rifle -- is very high.

CAMBRIDCE, Mass., Nov. 9. -- Harvard defeated Michigan at football this afternoon on Soldier's Field by the score of 4 to 0. The ground was wet, and it rained during the greater part of the game. In spite of the inclement weather 4,000 persons witnessed the game. The playing was not so closely contested as the score would seem to indicate.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- Before the feud between the Healyites and McCarthyites reached its present climax two efforts to effect a reconciliation were privately made, first by eminent English Liberals, who were desirous of preventing another Irish split, and secondly, by certain Irish Catholic prelates. The Healyites resented the interference of the Liberals, but placed themselves at the disposal of the prelates, who in turn, found that the McCarthyites rejected their overtures.

The United States is a broad and busy country, and it is well supplied with excellent journals. As is natural and unavoidable, these generally take their tone in treating dramatic affairs from those of the metropolis. What is said and done in New-York about plays and actors is published all over the Union as quickly as the wires and press can spread the news.

Ransom H. Thomas, Vice President of the Stock Exchange and Chairman of the Green Committee of the Morristown Golf Club, won a creditable golf victory yesterday from his persistent rival, Alexander H. Tiers. Mr. Tiers is one of the most active and energetic members of the Morristown Club, and last year held the same position on the Green Committee which Mr. Thomas now occupies.

The first banquet of the New-York Commandery of the Military Order of Foreign Wars of the United States in commemoration of the closing battles of three wars -- siege of Yorktown, in the War of the Revolution; the battle of New-Orleans, in the war of l812, and the capture of the City of Mexico, in the Mexican war -- will take place at the Brevoort House at 7 o'clock on the evening of Nov. 18.

The revolution for the independence and creation in Cuba of a democratic republic, initiated on the 24th of February last, solemnly declares the separation of Cuba from the Spanish monarchy and its constitution as a free and independent State, under the name of Republica de Cuba.

Advices from the other side of the state of the markets show they are having a fine old splitting headache after their Kaffir drunk. That wild intoxication of speculation had reached the point where it needed only some sharp nip from outside to bring collapse, and the Armenian troubles supplied it.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 9. -- Another exciting and invigorating cross-country run over the Hempstead plains and Wheatley Hills was participated in to-day by the members of the Meadowbrook Hunt Club.

Frank Cline, who attempted Friday night to rob the house of Mrs. Caroline Barry, 439 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, was held yesterday in default of $5,000 bail by Justice Haggerty, in the Myrtle Avenue Police Court.

The fabrics of which hangings and furniture coverings are fashioned take on, this Autumn, more gorgeous and brilliant colorings than for several seasons past. All the novelties shown, too, are capable of use with complementary colors, and a touch of gilt is not wanting to add to the showiness of the general effect.

On the 24th of March, 1893, just before dawn, and during a slight snow squall, the German tramp steamship Gluckauf, an oil tank boat of 2,000 tons, chartered by the Standard Oil Company, went ashore on Fire Island beach, opposite Sayville, about fifty miles from New-York, on the south side of Long Island.
The largest quantity of "green goods" literature ever seized was taken to the First Precinct Police Station House yesterday.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- The mad dog that was killed yesterday in Main Street has almost caused a hitch in the machinery of the village. The only thing relative to the matter in which there seemed to be no doubt whatever was that the Board of Health had the right to bury the dog. The dog was buried accordingly. The expense was $1.

One of Maine's interesting relics is the ancient military work at the entrance of the harbor of Wiscasset, on Folly Island, so-called, situated in the town of Edgecomb, and in the military records called Fort Edgecomb. It is a heavy, square-timbered structure of oak and pumpkin pine, cut from the surrounding forest, and double storied.

Mr. Paderewski, the famous pianist, having properly celebrated his return to America by an orchestral concert last Monday evening, gave his first recital yesterday afternoon in the Music Hall. The audience was similar in size and demeanor to those which attended the memorable recitals of two years ago.

The young ladies of the Morristown Field Club had a very interesting golf tournament yesterday afternoon. It was the first contest ever held for ladies over the club course. The membership of the club is composed chiefly of the younger element of Morristown. The tournament yesterday was limited to young ladies of eighteen years and under.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- There will be no Anarchist parade or ceremonies over the graves of Parsons, Fischer, Engel, Spies, and Lingg to-morrow. For the first time in seven years the societies which have gone once a year to the monument erected over these men will not parade in memory of them.

The special committee of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen that is investigating the war records that cost the city $11,000, in evidence of the expenditure of which there is not a single document, had another session yesterday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- Chairman Andrews of the committee appointed by the late State Senate to investigate the municipal affairs of Philadelphia, stated today that everything was in readiness for the investigation to begin Monday. He and State Senators McCarrall and Thomas of the committee, and State Senator Penrose, who introduced the bill providing for the investigation, went to New-York yesterday, and had a long talk with Recorder Goff.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Under the auspices of the New-Jersey Athletic Club last evening a concert was given in the clubhouse by the Imperial Russian Orches tra. An excellent programme was rendered for the benefit of the club's fair fund.

Because Princeton only beat Cornell 6 to 0 at football yesterday it would not be wise for any enthusiastic Yalensian to go and bet his all that Yale will have an easy time against the "Tigers" when they meet. If he makes any such bet the chances are that he will be sad and disconsolate Saturday evening, Nov. 23.

A good deal of knack and practice is necessary in hooding, especially in the case of freshly caught hawks, and any awkwardness at first may cause the hawk to take such a dislike as to very much increase the difficulty of training -- while a falconer who is quick and neat at hooding is saved much time and trouble in bringing his charges into order.

NEWPORT, Nov. 9. -- The annual chrysanthemum exhibition of the Newport Horticultural Society, which was held this week, attracted a great deal of attention from cottagers, whose plants were shown and who were therefore especially interested in the competition for premiums. As usual, the various exhibits were in the names of the gardeners at the places from which the plants came, the names of the owners only appearing incidentally.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 9. -- The British steamship Irrawaddy of the Trinidad Steamship Line, stranded at about 2:30 o'clock this afternoon, off this place. The vessel came ashore at the foot of Third Avenue. She loomed up like a mammoth skeleton in the hazy atmosphere that prevailed.

Judge Bookstaver of the Common Pleas Court yesterday denied Mrs. Fannie Brandt's application for alimony pending her suit against her husband, Meyer Brandt, for a separation. In denying the application, Judge Bookstaver said he was inclined to believe the husband's version of the family troubles.

There is one part of Brevet Brig. Gen. Guy V. Henry's report on the New-York Camp, which has not heretofore been noticed, and that is the remarks of Gen. Henry on the personnel of the officers constituting the headquarters staff. Of these the General has this to say:

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- The news that comes this evening from St. Petersburg through channels that entitle it to full belief gives a sad and startling turn to the recent pleasant gossip about the coming birth of an heir to the Imperial crown of Russia.

The origin of these senseless, brutal, and cruel conflicts is more or less shrouded in obscurity. It is abundantly clear that neither politics nor religion had anything to say in the matter. They probably originated in "hurling matches," a species of hockey, once a favorite amusement among the youth of Munster on Sundays and holidays after "last mass."

Commissioner John P. Faure of the Department of Charities and Correction conducted Corporation Counsel Scott and President Jeroloman of the Board of Aldermen through Bellevue Hospital and the city institutions on Blackwell's Island yesterday.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- The congregation of the First Methodist Episcopal Church, more familiarly known here as the "South Street Methodist," will celebrate to-morrow the one hundredth anniversary of the founding of the church. The entire celebration will be in the line of devotional services.

The following is one of Miss Dorothy Lamon's "Recollections of Abraham Lincoln." It was the custom in the days of Mr. Lincoln's Administration and of the country's sore travail for those who "knew everything and more," to call upon the President to advise him how to "save the country" -- their assumption being that he knew nothing.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 9. -- The ninth annual convention of the Christian Workers of the United States and Canada, at the Calvary Baptist Church, is at its height. The full quota of delegates has arrived, there being now about 600 present, and the programme for to-day, to-morrow, and Monday embraces the leading features of the work of the association in the past year and its hopes for the coming year.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- The Rev. Cyrus T. Brady, rector of St. Paul's Church, Manhattan, Kan., and Archdeacon of Kansas, was named by Bishop Whitaker yesterday to be Archdeacon of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Pennsylvania. The appointment was somewhat of a surprise to the clergy of this city, for it had been expected that a local clergyman would be appointed.

The annual meeting of the Isabella Heimath Society took place yesterday afternoon at the home, One Hundred and Ninetieth Street and Amsterdam Avenue. It is an institution for the care of aged indigent persons, without regard to creed or sex, and a hospital for chronic invalids and convalescents.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 9. -- "Rah! rah! rah! rah! rah! rah! V-a-s-s-a-r."

The Republican managers are preparing two contests, by which they expect to prevent two Democrats who received pluralities last Tuesday from taking their seats in the Senate at Albany. The districts are the Second, which comprises Queens County, the Sixth, which is a portion of Kings.

An interesting game, though exceedingly rough, was that played at Eastern Park yesterday by the strong teams representing the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn and the Boston Athletic Association. It was such an exposition of the popular sport of the day as completely to satisfy the most rabid football enthusiast. Neither side scored throughout the game.
Complaint has been made to the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company of the reckless manner in which a Putnam Avenue and Halsey Street trolley car was operated Friday night.

ALBANY, Nov. 9. -- The Williams College team defeated Union College this afternoon at the Ridgefield grounds in the hardest fought game of football ever played in Albany. The score was 14 to 6. It was Union's fifth consecutive defeat by Williams, and the Union students are not surprised at the result. Capt. Hinkey of Williams was unable to play.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- From Washington to Cleveland there have been but few Presidents who were fond of sports in the field and by the stream. Washington was a famous rifle shot and also a duck hunter, and carefully preserved his lands and river front from invasion by the casual shooter. Jackson was also a rifleman, but never used the shotgun, which was almost unknown at his time as a sportsman's arm.

In 1858 there lived in the City of Albany a humble and ignorant German named Emil Hartung. He kept a lager beer saloon, then a novelty, and a despised one, too, and took boarders at his table, for which his wife, Mary, and one poor serving maid, but lately arrived in this country and unable to speak a word of English, did the cooking.

A feature of the exposition that attracts a great deal of interest among Northern visitors is the old engine General in the train shed. The Northern newspapers have devoted an unusual amount of attention to the old locomotive, and many are the stories that have gone out concerning the thrilling incident in which the engine figured.

After an investigation extending over ten months and conducted, there is every reason to believe, with great care and thoroughness, the Dutch Court of Marine Jurisdiction has at last reached a decision in regard to the loss of the North German Lloyds steamer Elbe.

For the fourth time during his present engagement, Mr. Irving changed his bill last night, and once more on the stage of Abbey's Theatre appeared in the role of Louis XI. The portrayal has lost nothing either, of subtlety or force, and the malignant King, grotesque at moments, but always with the saving touch of royalty, seemed to really live and really die again.

So vague is the description of the masked robbers who descended on the saloon of Thomas Walters, and shot Richard Pope, Thursday night, and so conflicting are the rumors and stories afloat concerning them, that the police yesterday were forced, reluctantly, to admit that the chances of their ever being captured and brought to justice are slim.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Under an agreement made yesterday with Secretary Carlisle, ex-Senator Manderson appeared before the Secretary this afternoon and argued the sugar-bounty cases.

What a bustling little city New-York was in the year of our Lord 1750! There you could see the slave ships come in, their holds filled with miserable, dazed black creatures, eleven weeks from the coast of Africa. There you could see ships from London, with the white slaves aboard, who had sold seven years of their time to pay for the passage to the New World.
Two big vessels became victims yesterday of the heavy fog that has been a menace to navigation for the last four days.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 9. -- The Daughters of the Confederacy held their meeting to-day in the auditorium at the exposition. Their audience numbered 3,000. Representatives of the society were present from every Southern State and from many other States.

At that time of night, 1 o'clock, the streets in a remote quarter of far distant Brooklyn were almost deserted. Suddenly the silence was broken by a piteous wail. It was so heartbreaking that a man walking past stopped. He had a tin luncheon pail in his hand. He was a laborer, either going home after a night's shift or about resuming his job.

The military punishments of that day were terrible. The Duke of Cumberland's general orders contain on three consecutive days sentences of eight hundred, five hundred, and eight hundred lashes for thieving, "mutinous expressions," and "insolent behavior." Three days afterward a sentence of "one thousand lashes" is recorded; it is fair to say the man deserved to die; but death would have been a merciful punishment.

ALBANY, Nov. 9. -- The results which generally follow close on the heels of general elections about the Capitol have already set in. Last night ninety men employed in the construction department of the Capitol were laid off. The clerical forces of the several departments will be thinned out somewhat within the next few weeks.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- The change of opinion in official circles regarding the immediate outbreak of revolution or war in Turkey is traceable to the expectation that the Sultan designs to soothe internal agitation by promulgating a new Constitution, embodying the leading principles of Midhat Pasha's scheme.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Secretary Olney has received an intimation of the willingness of France to release John L. Waller from prison as an act of graciousness to the United States, but as an acceptance of this offer might prevent this Government from subsequently demanding an indemnity...

It is a great pleasure to see this array of goodly volumes containing "opera omnia quae extant" of a writer of whom no uniform edition at all has heretofore been accessible, and a great pleasure to find the presentation so well worthy of the contents. Mechanically, indeed, the presentation is perfect. Nobody can ask for better paper, better ink, better type, a more legible or better balanced page, or more accurate proofreading.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 9. -- The prompt action of the engineer of Engine No. 345 on the New-Jersey Central Railroad and the drawtender at the Newark Bay bridge, prevented the train from plunging into the river this morning.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 9. -- The prompt action of the engineer of Engine No. 345 on the New-Jersey Central Railroad and the drawtender at the Newark Bay bridge, prevented the train from plunging into the river this morning.
NEW-LONDON, Conn., Nov. 9. -- In the fog that shut in everything this morning the big Sound steamer Puritan of the Fall River Line went fast ashore on Great Gull Island, ten miles from this place.

Mayor Strong announced yesterday afternoon that he had selected Park Commissioners to succeed the present members of the board. The new appointees are William A. Stiles, Col. S.V.R. Cruger, ex-Mayor Smith Ely, and Samuel McMillan.

More than ten years ago a slight but significant incident occurred in Savannah, Ga. Between the acts of a theatrical performance there was occasion to drop a large National flag from the flies above the stage.

The North End Street Railway Company filed articles of incorporation yesterday with the Secretary of State at Albany, and gave a bond for $50,000 to the Controller of this city to carry out the obligations which it took upon itself.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- Pennsylvania played her last game prior to her match with Harvard on Franklin Field to-day. While they were scored against by State College, their work was very encouraging to the Varsity coaches. For the first time in three weeks the men put life into their play and appeared to be rapidly regaining their former health and spirits.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Joseph C. Kay, son of Capt. Joseph Kay of Company D, Third Regiment, N.J.S.M., has been appointed to a cadetship at West Point, and this week entered the Highland Falls (N.Y.) Government Preparatory School to prepare for entering the academy in June. He is a graduate of the High School in this city.

Since the navigation of the ocean with ships was first accomplished by man, it has been necessary or desirable at times for the occupants of vessels to communicate with each other, especially when sailing in fleets or squadrons; and, as the range of the human voice is confined to a limited area, it is not always practicable or convenient for conversation to be carried on through this medium.
While New-York is preparing for her annual Horse Show, Chicago is about to grapple with the horseless-carriage problem in a truly Western practical fashion.

That was a very surprising as well as a very gratifying account that was given in Thursday's TIMES of the success of a young professor of English literature at Yale in arousing undergraduate interest in his subject. That 300 students should attend an "elective" course of lectures is in itself a testimonial to the professor who delivers the lectures.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- The crack of the rifle is now heard on every hand, for the closing of the deer-hunting season is nigh. There are still hundreds of hardy hunters here, and they realize that the enjoyment of the noble sport which sends the blood tingling through their veins is nearly at an end.

If an average American student of literature were asked who would be his choice for editor of a comprehensive collection of the best English verse, he would probably name the editor of the work which lies before us. Mr. Stedman has not now to make himself known as an earnest, sympathetic, scholarly student of the art of poetry, in which he is also a craftsman.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9. -- The thousands of Democrats who defeated Gorman at the polls are now considering the best means of ousting him from the control of the party organization. There is a general desire to get everything in shape under new management in order to carry the State for the Democratic Presidential ticket next year.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 8. -- Whatever else there may be said about Mr. Carnegie's magnificent gift to the City of Pittsburg, and there is but little fault to find, the art galleries in the new library are splendid rooms, high as to ceiling, spacious, and well lighted. Nothing could be more simple than their arrangement.

The tides of the North and East Rivers produce power enough to generate all the electricity to light New-York and Brooklyn, to do all the mechanical work in the factories and machine shops, and to run all the railroad lines in the city and suburbs. This power is wasted, as formerly all of the power of Niagara was allowed to expend itself in a profitless way.

There was no change in the make-up of the teams in the second half but the changed goals, as usual, Cornell taking the western end of the field. Baird punted to Ritchie, who ran back ten yards before he was downed, and in the next play he punted back to the Princeton territory. Baird muffed the ball, and Suter had to fall on it to save it. This was on Princeton's fifty-yard line.

Senator William E. Chandler and William Hosea Ballou held a consultation yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Hotel with reference to humane measures to be introduced at the next session of Congress.

It is very difficult to tell precisely what is happening in Ethiopia. The Italian press is full of the most contradictory news. The Government, which had so hastily published the first successes of the campaign, remains silent, and the public reclaims information.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 9. -- Brown played the game of her life against Yale to-day, and not only scored, but tied the game, 6 to 6. It is the first time in football history that Brown has scored against Yale, Providence was not big enough for the celebrations of the virtual victory.

There were forty-three cabin passengers connected with the Metropolitan Opera Company on board the Hamburg-American steamship Columbia which arrived here yesterday morning. Among them were Mile. Calve, Mme. Nordica, and the two de Reszkes.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 9. -- At this season of the year horseback riding is the favorite pastime at Hot Springs, and young and old who are not here to relieve their twinges of rheumatism take a gallop daily. Bicycling is also a popular outdoor exercise, and there are many disciples of the wheel, the fair sex predominating.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- Eight men, all strangers in town, entered the saloon of Martin Kennedy, 106 South Main Street, Port Chester, early this morning and, after a sharp fight, threw two men who were in charge of the place into a closet and locked the door.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- In his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy, Commodore George W. Melville, Engineer in Chief of the United States Navy, and Chief of the Bureau of Steam Engineering, points out the necessity for establishing machinery repair stations for war vessels at several of the United States navy yards.

SAN JOSE, Cal., Nov. 10. -- " Eddie" Bald was beaten twice in the national circuit races in this city yesterday. Murphy outrode Bald for the five-mile National championship. The latter had the tandem position throughout the first three miles, and was forced to yield to Murphy for the last mile. As the pacemakers dropped, Bald came to the side of Murphy, and was beaten in a hard fight.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Republicans of Hunterdon County want nearly every office that Governor-elect Griggs has to fill. Ex-Senator George H. Large wants to succeed Allan L. McDermott as Clerk in Chancery, while H. Burdett Herr thinks that nothing short of Judge Reed's or Judge Dixon's place on the Supreme Court bench will satisfy him.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 10. -- The recent change in the Ministry here has not been conducive of any better feeling in political and diplomatic circles. In fact, the new Ministers, generally speaking, are looked upon askance, as their reputations give no promise of any better government than that hitherto ruling.

The White Elephant pool and wine room in the basement of 532 Sixth Avenue was raided yesterday by Capt. Pickett, and the proprietor, Philip Black, was charged with maintaining a gambling house. Nineteen persons caught in the raid were charged with being common gamblers.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Rutgers College this morning celebrated, with impressive services in Kirkpatrick Chapel, the one hundred and thirtieth anniversary of the granting of the college charter by William Franklin, the last Colonial Governor of New-Jersey. The chapel was filled with undergraduates, members of the alumni, and friends of the college.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The first ship of the new navy was put in commission over nine years ago, and, according to Chief Constructor Hichborn, the demands for ordinary repairs on the earlier vessels, for the preservation and for the maintenance of their equipage in a proper state of efficiency, are yearly becoming more serious, and Congress must hereafter make much larger appropriations for this purpose.

The Liberty and Pequod Wheelmen completed the first round of the tournament of the Long Island Association of Cycling Clubs Saturday night. The Franklin alleys, on which the games were rolled, were well lined with an enthusiastic company of wheelmen, but the play of both teams was a disappointment, the Pequods showing especially poor form, and were easily taken into camp by the Libertys.

BUENOS AYRES, Oct. 7. -- Thomas A. Eddy of Flint, Eddy Co. of New-York, who arrived here in June to establish a branch office for his firm, has made a careful study of the trade and agriculture of Argentina and Uruguay.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The Supreme Court of the United States will reconvene to-morrow, after a recess of ten days.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by the United Press.

If the malady which has caused many deaths recently in the island of Antigua turns out to be real yellow fever, it will be a matter of much interest to learn whether the infection was introduced in the ordinary way from some other part of the Antilles, or whether it was caused by the dredging that has been going on for a year past in the harbor at St. John's.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Nov. 10. -- The steamer Puritan of the Fall River Line is still held hard and fast at Great Gull Island, where she went ashore Saturday morning. The splendid boat lies just where she struck, notwithstanding the combined efforts of three powerful tugs and two steamers of the Fall River Line -- the City of Brockton and the City of Taunton -- which had hawsers out to her to-day.

QUARANTINE, S.I., Nov. 10. -- The French Line steamship La Gascogne arrived at Quarantine to-night at 8:30, having left Havre at 9 P.M. Nov. 2. It was generally supposed that La Gascogne was overdue, and Health Officer Doty prepared to clear the steamship at sight. After his inspection, Capt. Baudelon decided to remain at anchor until morning.

Laurel, Md., the town near Washington in which Senator GORMAN finds a legal residence and a Summer home, "went Republican" on Nov. 5 for the first time in so many years that its last departure from Democratic lines is not mentioned.

The valuable displays seen in the museum of the Carnegie Library this week, by exciting public interest in such scientific work, has served to bring into more general notice the collections of birds, bugs, shells, butterflies, and the like in the hands of local collectors. Mr. Thomas L.R. Loughrey, at his home, at the corner of Forbes Street and Woodlawn Avenue, has a most remarkable museum of natural specimens and curios generally.
The official canvass of the vote of Brooklyn will be begun this morning. It is likely to last two weeks, and perhaps longer. The Supervisors receive $3 a day.
LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The Post and The Telegraph will publish to-morrow a St. Petersburg dispatch, dated Friday, stating that the accouchment of the Czarina may be expected at any moment.

GLASCOW, Nov. 2. -- Clyde yachtsmen are much exercised at present over the possible meeting of the Defender and Valkyrie at New-York next Summer. Opinion favors the belief that Defender will not be launched while Valkyrie remains at New-York and on your side the Atlantic. In confirmation of this opinion, it is known that Mr. Watson regards the comparative speed of Valkyrie and Defender as an open question which Americans have no desire to close.
Prof. Felix Adler selected as the subject of his lecture before the Society for Ethical Culture, in Carnegie Music Hall, yesterday, "Savonarola as a Religious Reformer."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 10. -- The stranded steamship Irrawaddy, which took the beach off Second Avenue, this place, yesterday afternoon, is still on the sand, and every hour works her further and further ashore and deeper and deeper into the sand. When she ran into the sand yesterday in the dense fog, she was heading north for New-York.

-- The members of the Rockaway Hunt Club have been giving considerable attention to golf during the last month, and several interesting contests have been arranged for the present month. During October the principal events consisted of four handicap matches played Saturdays on the Cedarhurst links. The final match was between E. La Montagne, Jr., Dr. F.F. Brown, and E. Winthrop, Jr., each of whom had held the club cup for one week.

The Bank Clerks' Bowling Association are scarcely more than fairly started in their annual bowling tournament, as they have only had a chance to play but two games each, with the exceptions of the Mercantile National and Mechanics' National, the former having played three games and the latter one. The top score has been made by the Bank for Savings, and much is expected of this team before the Winter is over.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 10. -- The proceedings for divorce begun last month by Mrs. Elizabeth W. Colt, a social leader of Bristol, have come to a standstill. The failure of her counsel to secure the slightest evidence to substantiate her allegation against Col. Samuel Pomeroy Colt will in all probability result in the withdrawal of the petition from the Supreme Court.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 10. -- A shipwrecked crew and the Captain's wife were brought here to-day. The woman and seven men were threatened for an entire week with death, and when rescued were more nearly dead than alive, as the result of exposure and lack of nourishment.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The exclusive news dispatch of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, announcing that the Czarina was at the point of death as the result of the Caesarian operation was the one subject of discussion in diplomatic circles here to-day.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- College work was resumed Wednesday after a short recess for election. There will be no other intermission until Thanksgiving.

BUFFALO, Nov. 10. -- S. Fred Nixon of Chautauqua County has announced himself as a candidate for Speaker of the next Assembly. Mr. Nixon said last evening he would begin his canvass for the Speakership in about a week. To the question:

Our report of a train's narrow escape from very serious accident at the Newark Bay drawbridge on the New-Jersey Central Road, Saturday morning, shows either that sufficient provision for the protection of trains at that point in time of fog has not been made or that the engineer of the train in question was culpably reckless.

The police were very active yesterday in their endeavors to trace the murderer of Richard Pope in "The Rest" saloon last Thursday night, and in a certain sense were successful, as five men were arrested. Three were, however, set free.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- There has been much adverse and undeserved criticism of the University of Pennsylvania for the action of their Faculty Advisory Committee on Athletics in canceling Pennsylvania's game with the Boston Athletic Association in New-York on Tuesday. The burden of these criticisms has been, that the Faculty's action was a subterfuge to avoid playing a game in which the athletic authorities feared defeat.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The Standard to-morrow will publish a dispatch from Rome saying that the Pope's Entourage has observed during the last few days that his Holiness has broken down very perceptibly, and that he is suffering.

BOSTON, Nov. 10. -- The establishment of a "half-rater," or 15-foot class in Boston, under Seawanhaka-Corinthian rules, seems a certainty for the coming season. Seven or eight boats have already been ordered, and yachtsmen in clubs outside the one where the movement originated are taking the matter up and proposing to build.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Gen. Coppinger, who is in charge of the Military Department of the Platte, has contributed to the interesting controversy regarding cavalry mounts in the army. Quartermaster General Batchelder has charge of this matter, and he has been severely criticised by cavalry officers for the miserable specimens of horseflesh which the War Department furnishes under the prevailing system of purchasing animals.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 10. -- The first thing the Harvard coachers did when they got the football squad together Monday last was to tell the players that they thought they had disgraced Harvard by losing courage in the Princeton game. They gave the team as severe a talking to as possible and sent the men off on a long run, which exhausted them quite as much as a whole afternoon's practice would have done.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- Recent advices from Cuba indicate that the tide of the revolution has turned and is now with the Cubans struggling for liberty.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Sanjuro Ishimoto, a Japanese student at the Princeton Theological Seminary, died at the Isabella McCosh Infirmary the past week. The funeral services were held in Miller Chapel and were conducted by Dr. William Henry Green and Dr. Purves. Mr. Ishimoto was born at Omera, Japan, on Nov. 2. 1862.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman delivered a sermon yesterday in the Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street, on "Max Nordau's Degeneration: or, Is Morality Declining?"

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 10. -- The military community at Jefferson Barracks was thrown into excitement yesterday by disclosures of counter-charges involving Major Robert H. White and Capt. C.B. Ewing. Major White is the ranking Surgeon at the post, and Capt. Ewing has been engaged on special medical duty.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- The first hall play of the year was presented at Vassar College, in Philalethean Hall, last evening. "The Merchant of Venice" was the drama chosen by the committee, which consisted of Louise Van Anden, Chairman; Louise Sheppard, Belle L. Tiffany, Anne G. Ritchie. Flora E. Eddy, and Helen L. Whitman.

The excise law was, if anything, better observed yesterday in this city than usual. There were no signs of any concerted action by saloon keepers to set the law at defiance on account of the result of the election.

The annual Horse Show luncheon has been given. Superintendent Frank T. Clarke has the interior of the big Garden as completely adorned as it will be at any part of the week. The tan-bark ring has been tested and pronounced to be in perfect condition. The bugler has got a new and gorgeous uniform.
The housesmiths of this city will probably go out on strike on or about Nov. 18.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The Turkish Legation has received from the Porte the following detailed account of the recent Armenian riots at Constantinople:

Fourteen thousand miles of Southern seas has the missionary brig Pitcairn, with a large party of Oaklanders on board, traveled since she dropped down the stream on the 1st of May last and spread canvas for Pitcairn Island with supplies and good books for the survivors of the mutineers of the Bounty.

TRENTON, Nov. 10 -- The Republicans of New-Jersey are making preparations for a most hilarious inauguration of John W. Griggs, who will be the first Republican Governor in twenty-seven years. The large clubs in the Republican League intend to take possession of Trenton, and several of them have already engaged their bands and quarters.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 10. -- The unexpected victory over the crimson has given a new life to football at Princeton. When the season opened, Princeton supporters entertained little hope of winning the championship from Yale, and later, when the Harvard game was arranged, the wise ones said it was but adding another defeat to the Tigers' unhappy season.
The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott began yesterday evening to preach a series of sermons on "Christianity and Our Social Problems."

It was necessary for the hearers of the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, in the Madison Square Presbyterian Church, yesterday, to draw their own conclusions. Most of them probably concluded that Dr. Parkhurst had said some severe things about some of the elements that united successfully to overthrow Tammany Hall a year ago and failed this year.

The movement in behalf of foreign missions, which has been taken up by the Presbyterian Church in this city, was the topic of sermons in several Presbyterian churches yesterday. The sending of missionaries abroad to preach the Gospel was urged on the ground that Christ had commanded His Apostles and Disciples to preach the Gospel to all nations.

BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- The declarations of Lord Salisbury in his speech upon the occasion of the banquet of the Lord Mayor of London last night and the official statement made by M. Berthelot, the French Minister of Foreign Affairs, in Paris, sum up everything of an official character that is known here in regard to the Eastern situation.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10. -- Since Nov. 5 the football team has been practicing in secret for an hour each afternoon. The field has been regularly opened to the public at 3 o'clock, however, and a chance afforded for watching the second half of the practice against the "college," or scrub, eleven. The following men, comprising the team and two first substitutes, have gone to a special training table at the New-Haven House:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- Negotiations are said to be nearly completed for the formation of a combination by which practically all the soft coal operators of Central and Eastern Pennsylvania and the Cumberland region interested in the tidewater trade will make an allotment of tonnage much like that which is supposed to prevail in the anthracite trade.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10. -- The list of subjects for the various composition prizes in Yale University were announced this week as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Orders have been issued by Secretary Herbert relieving Rear Admiral Carpenter from command of the Asiatic station. This action was taken at Admiral Carpenter's request, as his wife was ill, and he wished to be with her. His place will be filled by Commodore F.V. McNair, at present President of the Naval Examining and Retiring Board, who will leave this city for his station Nov. 13.

Three black hearses, black-plumed and drawn by horses of darkest hue, and then three hearses of white behind steeds white as themselves, passed out of Van Brunt Street, Brooklyn, at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon and bore to graves in Holy Cross Cemetery all but one member of the family of Charles Ryan, who, with his wife, three daughters, and niece, had been suffocated Thursday morning during a fire in his home, 129 King Street.

The Tree Planting and 'Fountain Society of Brooklyn, the objects of which are to promote the planting and protection of trees, the erection of drinking fountains, and otherwise to make the City of Brooklyn attractive, has issued a circular containing interesting information regarding the work of arboriculture from the falling of leaves until the opening of Spring.

In The Kansas Farmer Prof. Georgeson of the State Agricultural College, publishes a long article urging farmers to combine, as suggested the other day by The Capital, to hold their corn for an advance. Prof. Georgeson reviews the instances where the country raised great crops, which invariably were followed by an unprofitable price for six or eight months, after which there was an invariable advance of from 100 to 200 per cent.

The life insurance companies which were defrauded by Dr. FRAKER and his accomplices, in Missouri, have recovered without litigation nearly all of the money, about $35,000, which was paid over to FRAKER'S representatives after his disappearance. It was supposed that FRAKER had lost his life by drowning, but he was discovered several months afterward in concealment and bearing an assumed name in another State.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- A noted war courier and scout has just been placed on the retired list of the army. He was a First Sergeant in the Fifth Infantry, and was stationed at Fort McPherson, Ga. His name is Albert W. James, and on the outbreak of the war he served with the Wisconsin troops as a volunteer.

In the field of practical sanitation there is to-day nothing more important or more earnestly to be desired than the application of measures approved by medical and sanitary science for the reduction of the appalling mortality caused by that scourge of the human race called tuberculosis, or, in its most common form, consumption.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- The official matriculation of the University of Pennsylvania for the current year has been announced by Provost Harrison 2,472. This shows an increase of onlly 74 students over last year, in spite of the fact that the applications for admission to the university have exceeded those of former years by nearly 10 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- An informal talk, as he called it, was given last night by ex-United States Senator George F. Edmunds to the members of the Union League Club and their friends, on "International Relations in Central and South America."

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- President Schurman lectured to the students last Sunday evening on the subject. "Huxley, the Agnostic." His audience was probably the largest that has ever assembled upon the Cornell campus to listen to a lecture. After carefully reviewing Darwin's life and works, Dr. Schurman attacked the origin of species.

There are several reasons why those immediately interested in the course of prices on the Stock Exchange look forward with more than usual intentness to the events of the next ten days. The announcement that a million of gold has been engaged for export to-morrow has turned attention to the possibility that the outward movement may be resumed on a scale that it had been hoped would not occur before the close of the Winter.

It is said by the friends of Edward Lauterbach, Chairman of the Republican County Committee, that the anti-Platt Republicans have declared war against him and his element of the party in the coming reorganization of the party machinery in this city.

Interpreted by the rules ordinarily applicable to the utterances of ministers speaking under some official reserve, but for public effect, the Guildhall speech of Lord SALISBURY means that the Sultan must put a stop to the Armenian butcheries or the powers will put an end to him and his rule.

There was some doubt as to whether the Government was entitled to an appeal from the decision of the Circuit Court of Appeals relating to the Berliner Telephone patent. The Bell Telephone Company contended that this decision was final and could not be reviewed. The Supreme Court decided yesterday, however, that it has jurisdiction. The appeal is allowed and the decision will be reviewed.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 11. -- The lawlessness of the Kurds in the eastern provinces has grown measurably since the demands for reforms were made upon the Sultan by Great Britain, France, and Russia. The Sultan's very evident inclination to refuse to grant the demands, or, at least, to defer giving a definite answer to the representatives of the powers, encouraged the Kurds to believe that the Sultan tacitly supported them in their attacks upon the Armenians.

ALBANY, Nov. 11. -- Secretary of State Palmer to-day filed his certificate of election expenses. He contributed $1,000 to the Republican State Committee, $50 to the Albany County Committee, and spent $450 for traveling expenses, printing, postage, and stationery.

GALESBURG, Ill., Nov. 11. -- A phenomenal run was made yesterday by a Chicago, Burlington and Quincy passenger train. The distance from here to Mendota, eighty miles, was covered in eighty minutes, including five stops and two slow-ups. Superintendent Rice estimates that the stops and slow-ups caused a loss of twenty minutes.

It is gratifying to observe that Lord DUNRAVEN'S manifesto has brought out on the other side some expressions of something like disgust. A yachtsman who accuses another yachtsman of a swindling trick and has no better evidence than his own guess about the comparative draught of a yacht in the morning and over night to produce in support of his accusation, is a person with whom fastidious men will thenceforth decline any relations.

David H. Roberts, wholesale dealer in window glass, at 418 and 420 West Broadway, has disappeared from his place of business, and is said to have suddenly sailed on the steamship Lucania for Europe on Saturday.
Another murder has been added to the list of crimes which are puzzling the police of this city, and with which they do not appear able to cope.

The columns of THE TIMES yesterday gave some of the results, in sermons from Presbyterian pulpits, of the concerted revival in the Presbyterian Church of an interest in foreign missions. There can be no doubt that the interest in foreign missions is languid among the laity not only of the Presbyterian Church, but of all Protestant churches.

At a well-attended meeting of Swiss-Americans yesterday at 62 East Fourth Street an application was signed for a charter for the Swiss Hall Association, and the following members were elected Directors for the first year:

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Nov. 11. -- Three days after the steamer Puritan went on Gull Island she remains as firmly fixed on the rocky bottom as she did when she first struck. To-day's effort to free her was the most determined yet made, but she resisted all the power the tugs could get upon her, and half her length nearly remains on shore.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day in an opinion read by Justice Brown sustained the Edison incandescent light patent against the claim of the Consolidated Electric Light Company, using the Sawyer-Mann system, of which it was claimed that the Edison system was an infringement.

With the increase in the number of State Senators from 32 to 50, the Republicans, who are in control by such a large majority, have begun to lay plans for increasing the number of "plums" at the coming session. They propose to increase the number of the committees in the Senate, if possible.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The controversy between the City of Detroit and the Citizens' Street Railroad Company of that city was settled in the Supreme Court of the United States to-day in favor of the company. The officials of the city sought to forfeit the company's charter, and the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit decided against them.

If the Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge and the Grand Jury of Kings County, which made a presentment against the Trustees for inefficiency in the construction of the Brooklyn terminal, ever come together there will be a war of words that will defy the speediest kind of stenography.

As the candidates for office at the recent election file their "statements" of expenses, as required by law, these appear in the usual form, with an "item" of payment to some committee which far exceeds all other items. For example, a candidate for an office in this city states that of $3,650.50 of election expenses, $3,500 was paid to a certain Chairman of a Campaign Committee, and no other account is given of the expenditure.
BERLIN, Nov. 11. -- The leading newspapers of Berlin comment upon the speech delivered by Lord Salisbury at the Lord Mayor's banquet in London Saturday evening, as follows:

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 11. -- "Hold up your hands and give us your money!" were the words which greeted the members of the Tuscan Club while they were enjoying themselves in their house at Hilton Saturday night. The command came from one of five determined-appearing masked men, who invaded the clubrooms with weapons.

Stock Exchange opinion of Lord Dunraven's statement in The London Field, in which he charged that the Defender had been lightened for measurement and ballasted overnight for racing, was expressed yesterday in a way not to be mistaken. Down-town feeling regarding Lord Dunraven had been excited by Saturday's publication, and he was then denounced wherever the statement was discussed.

Negotiations have been practically closed by which the Metropolitan Traction Company acquires control of the Eighth Avenue Surface Railroad. A majority of the $1,000,000 of stock of the last-named company has, it is believed, passed into the hands of capitalists identified with the great Metropolitan Traction system, and the future control of the Eighth Avenue line will be provided for by a lease in perpetuity.

Harry A. Ely, promoter and real estate dealer, was examined yesterday in the City. Court in supplementary proceedings, upon a judgment obtained against him by William J. Madden for $559 for money loaned.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Returns to the Department of Agriculture show the corn crop the largest in volume of record, with a rate of yield, however, somewhat less than that indicated by the returns for October, being 26.2 bushels per acre. This must be regarded as a preliminary, and not a final, estimate of the yield.
Capt. F.L. Miller of the American brig Harriet G., which was searched by the Spaniards Oct. 3, while lying at Nuevitas, Cuba, in speaking of the occurrence yesterday said:

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 11. -- The State Department is informed that the Japanese Minister has received a dispatch from his Government stating that a convention has been signed at Pekin for payment of additional indemnity for the evacuation by Japan of the Liao-Tung Peninsula. The amount of the indemnity is 30,000,000 taels and its payment is to be made Nov. 16.

Our Republican neighbor, The Tribune, appears to be annoyed by the exactions of certain Trusts or similar combinations which are still protected and assisted by tariff duties, although the duties upon which they rely are lower now than they were in the McKinley tariff, "the bravest and wisest of tariff laws yet framed." We quote as follows from the remarks published by The Tribune yesterday:

The Republican politicians, in their own little caucuses, have decided that Mayor Strong's appointment of Col. S.V.R. Cruger as a Park Commissioner, with the understanding that he is to be made President, means that the Mayor is going to try and play politics in behalf of the anti-Platt faction, or Brookfield element.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11. -- The Saratoga Racing Association began an eighteen-day running meeting at Pimlico to-day. It is in the nature of an experiment, with the view of rehabilitating the historic old course and giving regular running meetings hereafter should the preser undertaking be fairly' successful.
Foster L. Backus has been elected District Attorney of Kings County, and the question that is now agitating the Republican politicians of Brooklyn is whether he will serve two or four years.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 11. -- The position of the Irrawaddy, which went ashore here in the fog of Saturday afternoon, remains unchanged. An immense quantity of ashphalt was jettisoned to lighten the steamer, and a lighter took off a load of hides, sugar, and fruits. The steamer is still well down in the sand, and the weight taken off to-day seems not to have benefited her any.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- The Mount Vernon Camera Club opened to-day its first annual exhibition of photographs, at the Parish House of Trinity Church, in Fourth Avenue.

Josiah O. Low, an uncle of Seth Low, President of Columbia College, died at his home, in Newport, R.I., Sept. 16 last, and yesterday his will was admitted to probate in the Surrogate's Court, Brooklyn.
