JAMAICA, L.I., Nov. 11. -- The Queens County Board of Supervisors will meet in the County Clerk's office to-morrow to canvass the county vote. It is expected that there will be a deluge of protests from defeated candidates.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- In an opinion rendered by Chief Justice Fuller, the Supreme Court of the United States to-day decided that it has jurisdiction over the case of the United States versus the Bell Telephone Company to cancel the Berliner patent, which the Court of Appeals for the First Circuit decided against the Government.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 11. -- It was stated here this morning that a deal had been consummated by which the Consolidated Traction Company, which operates about all the trolley lines in Hudson, Essex, and Union Counties, had secured control of the dock at the foot of Fulton Street. For some time there have been negotiations for the purchase of this dock.

Christian W. Schaffer, an old-time gambler and doubtless the oldest living gaming-house keeper in this city or neighborhood, appeared before the Commissioners of Accounts yesterday afternoon and told a sensational story of his dealings with the police, to whom he said he had continually paid money for protection while he was running his gambling places.

Society was well represented at the Horse Show. New-York's prettiest girls, best-dressed matrons, and most perfect-groomed beaus were on hand to watch the judging of the horses, and incidentally to show off the best bib and tucker. Boston, Philadelphia, Washington, and Baltimore were represented in the thousands of fashionable people who filled the 114 boxes and crowded the arena walk.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Eugene Higgins has sold all hks horses from Glen Farm, near this city, and it Is said that he desires to sell the property. This would include the Hlggins home. stead, a half-mile training track, and the stables, which cost nearly $250,000 to build two years ago. Mr. Hlgglns has gone to Paris, and, it is said, intends to remain abro/d permanently, makinl Pts hts homxe.

The Brooklyn Bicycle Club bowlers were neatly taken into camp last night by the South Brooklyn Wheelmen in the tournament of the Long Island Association of Cycling Clubs. It was quite a surprise for the "rooters" of both clubs. The scores:

The announcement which appears in the real estate column of to-day's TIMES that Trinity Church has determined to dispose of some of its property on Hudson Street, above Canal Street, will doubtless astonish many persons who have been led to suppose that the corporation in question would never part with any of its lands. That the move is a wise one will not be questioned by any person conversant with the circumstances.

PARIS, Nov. 11. -- Mme. Moreau, wife of Georges Moreau, a prominent mining engineer, was found burned to death in her bedroom at her residence, 28 Avenue Bugeaud, yesterday. She had evidently fallen asleep while reading, and her clothing had caught fire.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Senator Hill and Secretary Lament created a mild sensation to-day by walking together from the War Department to the office of the Attorney General. Years had elapsed since the eminent New-Yorkers had been seen in public together, and the gossips who saw the unusual sight jumped to the conclusion that deep significance attached to it.

RICHMOND, S.I., Nov. 11. -- At the Court House to-day were prominent politicians, officials, witnesses, and jurors, interested in or attendant upon the trial of ex-Assemblyman Michael McGuire, former Tax Collector of Middletown. He was indicted on eleven counts, for grand larceny in the second degree, and for perjury.

The carrying of bicycles on the railroads was the subject of a conference held yesterday between the Transportation Committees of the League of American Wheelmen and the Cycle Board of Trade. Of course the cyclists want free transportation for their wheels, and they are going to try to have the Passenger Trunk Line Association issue an order securing this result.

The Dock Board held a special meeting yesterday, passed resolutions, and appointed a Board of Consulting Engineers, consisting of Gen. Thomas L. Casey of Washington, D.C., George S. Morison and Prof. William H. Burr of this city, to pass on plans for improving the water-front property so as to enable the city to retain the commerce of this port, that is so largely slipping away to Jersey City and Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The report of Major Gen. Miles, commanding the United States Army, was made public to-day. Gen. Miles believes that the peaceable condition now existing among the various Indian tribes is largely attributable to the presence of troops at suitable points and to the admirable conduct of the experienced army officers who have been placed in charge of the principal agencies.

There was considerable discussion last evening among the men at the Horse Show as to whether William K. Vanderbilt's white vest, white shirt, white collar, and white necktie, or Foxhall Keene's low shoes and fancy socks, the latter of black silk, delicately embroidered with red floss, were the features of the Horse Show.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 12. -- "A Runaway Colt," a new farce by Charles H. Hoyt, was produced at the Wieting Opera House to-night. It treats of the baseball craze, and its hero is Capt. Adrian C. Anson of still happy baseball memory. More than that, Mr. Hoyt has engaged that pugnacious and able autocrat of the diamond as the fittest person to show himself in his true colors.

The annual meeting of the National Exhibiton Company, which owns the New-York Baseball Club, was held yesterday afternoon in the Fuller Building, Jersey City. The stockholders present were John B. Day, A.H. Soden, F.A. Abell, John T. Brush, E.C. Potter, Valentine P. Snyder, Edward E. McCall, Andrew Freedman, Thomas L. Hamilton, J. Edward Bell, Jr., and Simon H. Stern.
Friends of Robert Louis Stevenson will be greatly interested in an exhibition of Stevensoniana which will open to-day at the publishing house of Charles Scribner's Sons, 153 Fifth Avenue.

The renewal yesterday of the rumor that William Brookfield is about to resign as Commissioner of Public Works was received with marked interest by the politicians because almost all of them know that Mr. Brookfield would be very glad to retire as an office holder.

ALBANY, Nov. 12. -- The Episcopal Convention of the Albany Diocese was in session here to-day. Bishop Doane delivered an address. Referring to his oft-stated position on the excise question the Bishop said:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors met this morning in their rooms in the Court House and organized as a Board of County Canvassers by electing Supervisor G.W. Davenport of New-Rochelle Chairman and Supervisors T.F. Tompkins and Charles C. Haviland, tellers.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 12. -- The great hall in the fair grounds was crowded to-day when W.M. Harper of Chicago introduced Ferdinand W. Peck, President of the Chicago-Southern States' Association. Bishop Fallows of Chicago offered prayer, and Miss Jane Gray sang "Greeting to Atlanta," composed by Miss Marie McLane.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 12. -- The sixth annual field trial of the National Beagle Club of America was begun yesterday at Hempstead, L.I., on what is known as the Terry Farm, and attracted a large crowd of sportsmen, beagles, and dog lovers from all over the country. The entry list includes twenty-nine of the best representatives of this breed in the country.

HAVANA, Nov. 12. -- A dispatch from Santiago de Cuba says: "Col. Sandoval's column captured, Nov. 9, a rebel camp at Manacas, composed of 500 men quartered in 115 huts. The rebels were commanded by the insurgent leader, Gebreco Vazquez.

It is now known positively that David H. Roberts, wholesale dealer in window glass at 418 mud 420 West Broadway, sailed for Europe on Saturday. His attorneys, Large Stallknecht, said yesterday that he had sailed, and they believe he was temporarily insane at the time.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 12. -- Congressman George L. Wellington, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, to-day announced his candidacy for the United States Senate, to succeed Senator Charles H. Gibson.

" The Merry Countess," by Charles Klein, described as a musical comedy in three acts, which was produced in a showy manner by Marie Jansen at the Garrick Theatre last evening, is only our old friend "Niniche" in a new dress. The French vaudevilles of the Judic period have never borne well the test of transplanting in this atmosphere. As "Newport" "Niniche" was a dire failure.

The General Term of the Court of Common Pleas yesterday handed down an order of reference in the suit of Henry C. Judson against the Flushing Jockey Club, which was instituted to test the constitutionality of the Percy-Gray racing law.
ALBANY, Nov. 12. -- The Attorney General was recently asked for a construction of the banking law on these questions:
ALBANY, Nov. 12. -- The following certificates of election expenses were filed to-day with the Secretary of State:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 12. -- Thirty-five head of thoroughbred yearlings were sold at auction here this morning by W. Graham Ross, Tattersalls of New-York, for $7,350. The top price was paid for a son of Tenny, by William M. Wallace, the young Lexington breeder.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 12. -- Te headquarters of the new Brice system will be in this city. The consolidation will probably be completed by Jan. 1. The following lines will be in the combination: Lake Erie and Western, Cincinnati, Jackson and Michigan, Cleveland, Akron and Columbus, Ohio Southern, Northern Ohio, and Lima Northern. The latter is not yet completed.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 12. -- The bronze statue which has been erected by the State of Connecticut on the Capitol grounds, in this city, in memory of Col. Thomas Knowlton will be unveiled with imposing ceremonies to-morrow afternoon. The speech of presentation will be made by Charles Dudley Warner, Chairman of the State Commission on Sculpture, and Gov. O. Vincent Coffin will respond.

The following were the most important purchases at the second day's sale of choice Americana by Bangs Co. yesterday: Samuel Smith's "The History of the Colony of Nova-Caesaria, or New-Jersey; containing an Account of Its First Settlement," Burlington, 1765, $22; "Acts of the Assembly of the Province of New-York, 1691-1718," London, John Baskett, 1719, $16.

HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 12. -- The steamer Portia, from St. John's, N.F., brings particulars of the suicide on the trip down to St. John's of George Buckingham, a passenger from New-York, who was returning nome to his wife and three children, who reside at St. John's.
The Brooklyn Board of Education met yesterday afternoon, passed resolutions on the death of Dr. John Lloyd Zabriskie, and adjourned until Friday afternoon.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 12. -- The Fish and Game Commissioners, who have been experimenting with a new code for the preservation of fish and game and a new system of policing the forests and streams of the State, held their annual meeting here this afternoon. United States Marshal George Pfeiffer of Camden presided, and Howard L. Frothingham, Mayor of Mount Arlington, acted as Secretary.

The hundred-odd pen-and-ink and wash drawings that Arthur Frost has made as illustrations for a new edition of "Uncle Remus" are now shown at the gallery of Frederick Keppel Co., in East Eighteenth Street, where they remain until Nov. 21.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- Police Justice Edward M. Shannon has been missing from his office in this village since Saturday and his whereabouts is unknown. Mr. Shannon conducted one of the largest real estate and insurance businesses in New-Rochelle, and has had for many years the confidence of the community.

It was expected that the Republican County Committee, at its meeting in the Johnston Building, Flatbush Avenue and Nevins Street, Brooklyn, last night, would have a jollification meeting over the recent election, but, strange to relate, they had a fight, and one that promises to become more bitter as time passes.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal news papers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

" Ghosts" was the subject of an instructive and most entertaining lecture given in the West End Synagogue last evening by the Rev. F. de Sola Mendes to an audience composed almost entirely of women and young girls.
BOSTON, Nov. 12. -- The Democratic Municipal Convention this evening nominated Josiah Quincy for Mayor by acclamation.

ASBURY PARK, Nov. 12. -- Articles of incorporation and a map of location have been filed at Trenton, showing the proposed route of a new trolley road, to be constructed from Belmar to Point Pleasant. This road is to be known as the Asbury Park, Belmar, Spring Lake and Manasquan Division of the Atlantic Highlands, Red Bank and Long Branch Electric Railway Company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The Turkish Legation here has received from the Sublime Porte the following telegram, under yesterday's date:

The Board of Police Commissioners were the guests of honor at the dinner of the Methodist Social Union last night at the St. Denis. Commissioner Grant was the only member of the board absent. The Rev. Dr. A.D. Vail, the Vice President, presided in place of the President, E.M.F. Miller.

The privilege heretofore extended to cyclists by the various railroads forming the Trunk Line Association, whereby the former were allowed to place their wheels in the baggage cars and transport them and themselves for the price of one fare, is about to be abrogated, and henceforth a tax is to be imposed for the transportation of the wheels outside of the purchase price of the railway ticket.
Steam as a motive power will be archaic within the next five years if Mr. Westinghouse and other inventors fulfill their promises.
NEW HEAVEN, Conn., Nov. 12. -- At the meeting to-day of the Yale corporation Prof. Geerge D. Watrous of the Law School was promoted to a full professorship.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Nov. 12. -- The steamer Puritan, which stranded Saturday at Great Gull Island, floated at 5 o'clock this morning, and soon after 7 o'clock came into this harbor under her own steam, going up to the wharf in front of the railway station, where she will await an opportunity to go to New-York to haul out on the dry-dock.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 12. -- The Asbury Park Board of Trade, at a meeting held to-day, passed a resolution providing for the appointment of a committee to draft a bill to be presented to the next Legislature, for the protection of Asbury Park and Ocean Grove against liquor selling.
GREEN'S LANDING, Me., Nov. 12. -- Capt. F.P. Wood, the man who picked the crew for the Defender, says:
" Why Amputate?" "When Shall We Amputate?" "Where Shall We Amputate?" "How to Amputate."

Mrs. Elizabeth Cady Stanton's attainment of the honors of octogenarian distinction was celebrated at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, and there was a gathering of those who love and venerate her which was at once both cosmopolitan and representative as to all classes and conditions.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Local and State Republican leaders were much interested in the arrival this morning of Senator Allison, who is regarded here as one of the foremost Presidential possibilities. He came with Gen. David B. Henderson of Iowa, and did not register. He tried to evade newspaper interviewers, and when cornered said he was too busy to talk politics or anything else.

It was learned that the Police Commissioners in executive session yesterday had much talk over the permanent appointment of Inspector Conlin as Chief, and the appointments of Capts. Cortright and McCullagh, who are now Acting Inspectors, as Inspectors. It is said that the promotion of Conlin as Chief and of Cortright and McCullagh as Inspectors has been decided upon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 12. -- In the regular course of searchlight practice under the lately formulated rules, the torpedo boat Cushing made two attacks on the torpedo station to-night. In the first she was defeated and in the second she was victorious. Lieut. Roy C. Smith was in command of the torpedo boat and Lieut. Hamilton Hutchins had charge of the land party with the searchlight.

The scene of this new novel signed by Ouida, which is brought out in the attractive Twentieth Century Series, is laid in Venice, and the story begins with an account of the losing of an opal necklace in one of the lagoons. The moral seems to be that opals are unlucky, for the finders of this necklace work havoc with the heart and life of Veronica Zaranegra.

A little band of women and half a dozen sailors gathered in the mission room of the Seamen's Christian Association, at the corner of Washington and West Tenth Streets, yesterday afternoon, for an afternoon tea and sale.

AaHIIGTON, NOV. 12. -- The Chief of the Bureau of Statistics reports that the total values of exports of breaxlstu/s, mineral oils, and provisions from the United. States during the month of October, 1895, 2'1d during the ten months ended Oct. 31, 1895, and of cotton during the one and two months ended the same. as compared with similar exports during the corresponding period of the pr=e, eding year, were as follows:

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 12. -- The Trustees of the Children's Home, on Glenwood Avenue, one of the aristocratic charitable organizations of this city, dropped, some time ago, the names of five women from the Board of Domestic Control. In their places the Trustees appointed nine women who had no previous concern in the institution.

Samuel Beardsley, Michael Rickard, and Alfred C. Chapin, the State Railroad Commissioners, gave a public hearing in the Chamber of Commerce rooms yesterday on the application of the Kings, Queens, and Suffolk Counties Railroad Company for permission to construct a trolley railroad through Long Island.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The naval constructors and marine engineers of the navy have finished plans for the next two battleships, bids for which will be opened on the 30th inst. In these plans the experts have been guided by the latest and best features of naval architecture and marine machinery as exemplified in construction at home and abroad.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- William B. Graham, one of the employes in the Pullman Building, was arrested to-night because it was feared the lives of George M. Pullman and J.B. Griffin, one of Mr. Pullman's Superintendents, were in danger.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., Nov. 12. -- Mrs. Mary Purcell, the proprietress of a small saloon in Second Street, this place, was found lying on the floor behind her bar in an insensible condition late last evening by John Smith, who lives in the neighborhood.
Lord Dunraven will probably be expelled from the New-York Yacht Club next Monday night.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 12. -- Populists, Republicans, and disgruntled Democrats have begun the organization of an independent "free-silver and honest elections'' party. The first positive step was taken at Athens, Ala., yesterday.

The engagement is announced of Miss Maud Snowden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip T. Snowden of this city, to George Phillips Howe of Boston. Miss Snowden is a granddaughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Stevens Edgar of New-York. The wedding will take place early in January at the home of the bride's parents, after which the young couple will go to Europe.

ALBANY, Nov. 12. -- Gov. Morton did not do much other than routine work to-day, but has promised to make a number of appointments to-morrow. One of these, it is believed, will be that of Rowland C. Kellogg as County Judge and Surrogate of Essex County, to succeed Chester B. McLaughlin, elected to the Supreme Court.

RICHMOND, S.I., Nov. 12. -- The trial of ex-Assemblyman Michael McGuire on one of eleven indictments for grand larceny in the second degree was ended to-day by a verdict of acquittal, given by direction of the Court, because of the variance of the facts from the charges alleged in the indictment.

JAMAICA, L.I., Nov. 12. -- The County Clerk's office was full of politicians and protests this morning, when the Queens County Board of Supervisors gathered to canvass the vote in the county. Nearly every candidate on the ticket was either present or represented by counsel. It was very evident that no man will take an office in the county this year without fighting for it.

Trinity Church is beginning to be comparatively empty again after its regular influx of Fall visitors. "Old" Trinity is one of the curiosities of the city, as well as a church always open for the devotions of its members and the down-town public why desire such a place.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Nov. 12. -- Masked men last night took $20,000 from the Wells-Fargo agent at the Santa F station here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The battleship Indiana, now at the Cramps' shipyard, Philadelphia, is ready for transfer to the Government by the contractors. The transfer probably will be made Nov. 20, and as the Indiana is fitted in every way for service, she will be placed in commission immediately after the transfer occurs. Capt. Robley D. Evans will be her commander.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Reports have been received here that the battleship Texas has been badly damaged at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and the timber dock in which she lies has been partly flooded to prevent further disaster. The accident, though similar to that which occurred to the Columbia at Southampton, England, is stated to be of a more serious character.
The trial of David F. Hannigan for killing Solomon H. Mann was continued yesterday before Justice Ingraham.

The commission provided for by an act of the Legislature last Spring and appointed by the Governor at the beginning of July to devise improved methods of legislation has just got to work, holding secret sessions, and it expects to report to the Governor some time next month. This commission, of which Lieut. Gov. SAXTON is the Chairman, has been extremely dilatory in taking up its important task.

Another double series in the tournament of the Long Island Association of Cycling Clubs was played last night, the Liberty Wheelmen visiting the alleys of the Columbia Wheelmen, and the New-Utrechts rolling on the alleys of the Pequods.
The work of the United Hebrew Charities for last month is thus summarized, these statistics being taken from the reports of the various committees and from the books of the society:

HEMPSTEAD, Nov. 12. -- Another exciting and enjoyable run across country after the hounds was participated in by the ladies and gentlemen of the Meadowbrook Hunt Club to-day. The hunt was held at 10 o'clock this morning. This hour was selected in order that upon the conclusion of the hunt the members could return to town and the House Show, in which several of the crack Meadowbrook hunters are entered.

The Brooklyn Aldermen began yesterday afternoon the official canvass of the vote polled for Mayor last Tuesday. Aldermen Clark, Cary, Leich, Haubert, Dunne, Guilfoyle, and Leaycraft did the counting. Jerry A. Wernberg, Almet F. Jenks, and S.S. Whitehouse looked out for the interests of Mr. Grout, and William G. Cook, Frank Sperry, and Joseph Bacon represented Mr. Wurster.
Mr. J. Delmage Trimble was the broker in the sale of the Ellsworth apartment house at One Hundred and Second Street and Manhattan Avenue, recorded among the transfers given below.

Harry C. Palmer, who is helping R. Lindsay Coleman in the matter of arrangements for the latter's big banquet to cyclists, in Atlanta, on the evening of the 30th inst., is in town for a short stay preparatory to going South again. Mr. Palmer has just returned to the metropolis from the Georgia capital, and is thoroughly conversant with cycling as a sport and trade in the South.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Arthur K. Delaney of Alaska, who was last Saturday appointed United States Circuit Court Judge of the Territory, and who was Collector of the Port of Sitka during President Cleveland's first Administration, has been in Washington for several days in consultation with Attorney General Harmon and Assistant Secretary Hamlin regarding the Alaskan boundary question.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- A telegram dated yesterday was received at the Indian Office this morning from Agent Day at Ignacio, Col., telling of the killing of two Ute Indians by whites and of the agent's fears that it may lead to another Indian uprising similar to the one that recently alarmed the Bannock country.

BOSTON, Nov. 12. -- It is thought by the police that James S. Chaffee, who was arrested yesterday charged with offering for sale stolen goods, and in whose rooms was found a great quantity of stolen property, may be a brother of William Barrett, alias Basset, now serving a life sentence for murder, and from whom Chaffee claimed to have received the goods for services rendered at the time of the murder trial.
LONDON, Nov. 12. -- The Westminster Gazette, commenting upon the charges made against the New-York Yacht Club by Lord Dunraven, says:

A wedding the preparations for which and the description of which occupy columns in the newspapers is an event upon which the readers of newspapers will inevitably form and express opinions. When the young people belong to families that are in any way conspicuous, or distinguished, they can escape this comment only by resorting to cryptogamy and being quietly married in some unfrequented place.

Chicago, Nov. 12. -- It is stated on good authority that at to-morrow's meeting of trans-Missouri lines, called for the purpose of ratifying the new passenger agreement of the Western roads to Colorado common points, Vice President Hanrahan of the Illinois Central will not refuse to enter the ranks, although one of the long-cherished rights of his road has been refused him by the other lines.

NEWARK, Nov. 12. -- In Justice Eggers's police court this morning was told the story of the theft of a horse and the restoration of the animal to its proper owner by a squad of police, who were obliged to lift the animal over a five-foot fence in order to accomplish their purpose. The feat was witnessed by over 500 people.

The continued and even increased popularity of the Horse Show proves nothing whatever about the fate of the noble animal to which it is ostensibly dedicated, because, as everybody knows, the horse is only the pretext for a social function on the part of a minority of the attendants and of a display of the most vulgar and snobbish curiosity on the part of the majority.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 12. -- John Sheffield of Watkins Glen, N.Y., came here last January to buy "green goods." He met two dealers in the article in a room in Taylor's Hotel. One of the men showed Sheffield $1,600 in good money.

Congressman William Lorimer of Illinois, who will represent one of the districts of Chicago in the next Congress, is at the Marlborough Hotel. In his visit to this city he is accompanied by State Senator Dwire of Illinois and Alderman Bidwell of Chicago.

The Lakewood Golf Club will open its three days' tournament this morning at 10:30 o'clock, when the first round will be played for the Laurel House Cup. Three silver cups will be played for during the various contests, and a large number of prominent golfers from the leading clubs have entered.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The question whether the Senate will be reorganized by the Republicans, is engaging much attention as the time for the meeting of Congress draws near. The idea prevailed here up to a month ago that the Republicans would make no effort to assume political power in the Senate.
The trial of David F. Hannigan for killing Solomon H. Mann was resumed in the court of Oyer and Terminer before Justice Ingraham yesterday morning.
The most interesting books sold by Bangs Co. yesterday, at the third day's sale of selected Americana, were the following:

The Board of Aldermen, sitting as the Board of County Canvassers, began yesterday the canvass of the vote cast at the recent election. The canvass was carried on in the Common Council Chamber. There were present to see that the interests of their candidates were protected, Assemblyman Conkling, Charles Steckler, ex-Judge Browne, and others. The First Assembly District was first taken up.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13. -- The Oriental and Occidental Company's steamer Coptic arrived from Hongkong via Yokohama and Honolulu last night. The run from Yokohama to Honolulu was made in the short time of nine days, and from the latter port to San Francisco in six days and two hours, which is a record breaker.

ALBANY, Nov. 13. -- The State Prison Commission met to-day and listened to the views of Superintendent Brockway of the State Reformatory at Elmira and the Superintendent of the New-York County and Kings County Penitentiaries, as to the best method of employing prisoners under the provisions of the new Constitution.

The piece de resistance in Tiffany's horse show, which opened in their window on Union Square yesterday at noon, is undoubtedly the bronco "Buster," by Frederic Remington. F. Wellington Ruckstuhl, Secretary of the National Sculpture Society, is also represented in a fine example of the American hackney, one of the fashionable favorites of the hour.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 13.--In reply to an inquiry from United States Minister Terrell regarding the situation of the missionaries at Harpoot, Commissioner Darnham has replied that, while they are alive and well, their position is one of extreme danger.

At the last meeting of the Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge one of that curious body explained the trouble at the eastern terminus as due to the incorrigible tendency of the patrons of the bridge to hold "conferences" on the platform. There is every morning and afternoon a series of mass meetings there, and meetings of masses much too large for comfort or safety.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 13. -- When the announcement was made some time ago that the annual meeting of the League of American Wheelmen would probably be held in this city in February, it was not anticipated that there would be any desire to hold it in any other place. Such, however, is the fact, and there promises to be the liveliest kind of a fight to secure it elsewhere.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- Ex-State Controller Edward Wemple was arrested this morning at Fultonville, on the charge of setting fire to the new dwelling of Herbert H. Fonda, Sunday evening. A basket filled with shavings and newspapers, soaked with kerosene oil, was placed against a door in the rear of the house. The flames were discovered by L.V. Peck, the cashier of the Fultonville Bank, and were extinguished in time to save the house.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13. -- The thirtieth scientific session of the American Academy of Political and Social Science was held this evening at the new Century Club. Prof. Edmund J. James of the Academy presided, and the principal paper was presented by Prof. L.M. Keasby of Bryn Mawr College, who spoke on "The Nicaragua Canal and the Monroe Doctrine," saying:

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The correspondence between Sir Julian Pauncefote, the British Ambassador at Washington, and the Government, from May 8, 1894, to Aug. 31, 1895, respecting the claims in connection with the Bering Sea seizures has just been issued.

Little progress was made yesterday in the opening sessions of the annual Fall conference of the magnates of the National League of Baseball Clubs. Men of the Diamond fairly swarmed in and about the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where the meeting is held, and all sorts of rumors were rife. At to-day's session it is expected that much business of general importance will be transacted.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13. -- The State Senatorial Committee, which is investigating the municipal affairs of Philadelphia, met this afternoon. Addison F. Bender, who, during the last ten days, has been examining the cleaning of asphalt paved streets in Philadelphia on behalf of the Citizens' Municipal Association, was the first witness.

C. Oliver Iselin went into the clubhouse of the New-York Yacht Club yesterday afternoon, and was at once surrounded by several members, who talked with him about the attack made by Lord Dunraven on his integrity as a yachtsman and as a sportsman.
The steam oyster dredge James W. Boyle sank off Rockaway Point yesterday morning, and five men were drowned.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nev. 13. -- A northeaster is making additional trouble for the wrecked steamer Irrawaddy. The wind is blowing a small gale, and the sea is very boisterous.

Hall Caine, the English novelist, delivered an address last night before the Nineteenth Century Club on "Moral Responsibility in the Novel and the Drama." If Mr. Caine should ever speak again before the club, it is probable that larger quarters will be selected for the occasion. The meeting last night was in the large assembly room at Sherry's, which ordinarily affords all the room required.
" Will he be down to-day?" asked the first patrolman of the watch of the second patrolman of the watch, at the Mayor's office yesterday morning, just before 10 o'clock.

Holders of stock in the elevated railway system in this city ascertained yesterday the extent to which the competition of the cable roads damaged their interests last year. The report submitted at the annual meeting of the Manhattan Railway Company was a record of losses, and not of gains. The only increases reported were in the operating expenses and in the deficit.

One of the most conveniently appointed establishments in the city for cycling purposes was opened yesterday at 29, 31, and 33 West Forty-second Street by the Spalding-Bidwell Company, the title of the firm having charge of the up-town depot of A.G. Spalding Bros. It is complete in every respect, and was greatly admired by many interested persons who called during the afternoon and evening.

The Excise Reform Association, of which Dorman B. Eaton is President, has the intention of being among the first in the field when bills upon the Sunday question in particular and the excise question in general are introduced in the next Legislature.

John B. Dickinson, the active partner of Sprain, Dickinson Co., bankers and brokers at 10 Wall Street, is reported to have disappeared and to have been absent from his office since Oct. 23. His absence has occasioned considerable inquiry by banks and individuals with whom he had business dealings.
The twenty-first annual banquet of the Jewelers' Association was held at Delmonico's last night. The attendance was particularly large.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

During the last few weeks many prominent Republicans have given notice that when their party shall have obtained control of National legislation -- in 1897, as they expect -- they will increase the tariff duties. Thus, they say, they will increase the revenue. This is one purpose which they have in mind.

Some of the "itemized statements" filed by candidates for office at the recent election, "showing in detail all the moneys contributed or expended," and giving the "specific nature of each item and the purpose for which it was expended," as required by law, consist mainly or wholly of one "item" of a considerable amount paid to a committee for "legitimate expenses."

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 13. -- President Schurman of Cornell University presented his third annual report to the Board of Trustees of that institution to-day. With the usual appendices the document makes a respectable book of 130 pages, and is replete with information of details regarding the university.

The book store of Henry Miller, at 122 Nassau Street, one of the best-known establishments of its kind in the city, was invaded yesterday by Anthony Comstock, the agent of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, and a collection of illustrated books which, it is asserted by Mr. Comstock, are not of such a character that their sale should be permitted, was seized.

HAVANA, Nov. 13. -- Gen. Martinez Campos reports from Santa Clara that Gen. Garcia Aldave, with fifty Government troops, has repulsed, after a hard fight, a larger force of rebels, under the command of the leader Maceo, which attempted to cross the railroad line between Jucaro and Moron, in the Province of Puerto Principe. The Government loss was three killed and ten wounded, including one officer.

Edward E. Simmons's decorations for the courtroom of Oyer and Terminer are now being put in place in the Criminal Court Building, in Centre Street. These, it will be remembered, were a commission from the Municipal Art Society, the result of a competition in which many prominent artists took part.
ALBANY, Nov. 13. -- The following certificates of election expenses were filed to-day with the Secretary of State:

During the late campaign President ROOSEVELT of the Police Commission took occasion to remark of the Goo Goo secession that it was a case of "the conscience vote gone silly." We pointed out at the time that Mr. ROOSEVELT was precisely the last person in New-York who ought to have made this criticism, because evidently his enthusiastic enforcement of the ridiculous and superannuated Sunday laws constituted the principal obstacle in the way of beating Tammany.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 13. -- There was a grand opening of the kirmess at the Columbia Cycle Academy Monday night, and the building was decorated very elaborately.

The United States Senators from Alabama have reached an explanation of the general reverses of the Democratic Party in the recent elections, and on this they base their course for the future. The trouble at the elections was due to the policy of the President on the currency question.

AMERICUS, Ala., Nov. 13. -- The rear-end collision which occurred on the Southern Road near this place yesterday afternoon between a work train and a train loaded with coal is more serious than was at first supposed. "Tony" Cunningham, "Mose" McGee, Luke Boiles, and "Sam" Franklin, negro laborers on the work train, were killed.

All the indications are that the European powers have either agreed upon some plan of division of the Turkish Empire or have at least decided for the time being to sink their differences and unite in wiping out the Sultan's Government. Just how soon or in what way this will be done is in one sense of little moment.

The most important of recent sales in the district above the Harlem River was made yesterday by Mr. J. Clarence Davies. He sold for Fordham Morris, representing Lewis G. Morris, to Ephraim B. Levy, a plot containing about 250 lots on Morris Heights, part of the Morris estate, at about $200,000. The property is on Sedgwick, Undercliff, Montgomery, and Lees Avenues, between One Hundred and Seventy-sixth and One Hundred and Seventy-seventh Streets.

SUMMIT, N.J., Nov. 13.--A fatal accident occurred on the Morris and Essex Division of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad early this morning about a mile and a half east of Short Hills. One person was killed and another badly injured.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 13. -- The non-partisan State silver and honest-election conference, attended mostly by Populists, met here to-day, with 800 delegates in attendance. It was opened with an address by Congressman Sibley of Pennsylvania. Mr. Sibley said that he was going next year with the party that favored free silver. He said he would not support a goldbug Democrat or Republican for President.

The Duke of Marlborough, who isn't much more than one-half as big as his titles, had his introduction to an American horse show and one of its crowds last evening. The Garden was packed to its utmost capacity with a crowd that simply bubbled and fizzled and fumed with curiosity.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- Central Traffic Association lines held their regular meeting here to-day. The most important action taken, which will put thousands of dollars of extra revenues into the coffers of the passenger department each year, was the raising of the clergy permit rate. The rate was raised to 2 cents a mile.

An unusual amount of attention has been devoted to the foreign missionary question during the past few weeks. The evidences of increased interest will be shown in a meeting to-morrow night in Carnegie Hall, which, it is believed, will eclpse all previous gatherings of a similar character ever held in this city.

Some of the owners of property on Broadway, below Union Square especially, have declared their opposition to the construction of the underground railroad in that thoroughfare, "as now proposed and laid out" by the Rapid Transit Commission, and have appointed a committee to take such steps as it may deem necessary to give effect to their opposition.

The charity fund of the New-York Lodge of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks was increased yesterday by the money value of the entire seating capacity of the Fifth Avenue Theatre, where all the lodges in reaching vicinity and their friends gathered at the twenty-seventh annual benefit of the order.

The franchise for the King's Bridge Road railroad extension was sold at public auction in the Controller's office yesterday afternoon to the Third Avenue Railroad Company, at 38 1/2 per cent. of the gross receipts more than the upset price, which is 3 per cent. of the gross receipts for the first five years, and 5 per cent. thereafter.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14. -- The death of State Senator Pinkney J. Bennett of Carroll County last night will result in another hot fight between the Democrats and Republicans of the State. The control of the State Senate hinges to some extent upon the result.

BOSTON, Nov. 14. -- The five-story brick building at 200 and 202 Congress Street was badly damaged by fire this afternoon. It was occupied entirely by the Empire Distilling Company. Several persons were injured. They were:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- The feature of this week's bulletin of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen is the number of records approved and accepted. The statement contains the following:

The members of the new Park Commission no doubt expected trouble when they took office, either from each other or from some section of the public. But they could not possibly have anticipated the form which their first trouble will take. The question who shall raise the flag on the Battery on Evacuation Day has never been submitted either to any court of record or to popular suffrage.
The meeting of the new Park Commissioners in the Arsenal in Central Park yesterday morning was enlivened by a dispute between Col. Asa Bird Gardiner and Charles B. Riker of 67 Park Place.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 14. -- Congress has sent to the proper committee the bill introduced, empowering Marshal Saville, the agent of the American Museum of Natural History, in New-York, to make archaeological excavations here.

On the testimony of a New-Haven clergyman's wife it appears that freshmen come to Yale College bringing letters of introduction, which entitle them to be received in Christian homes in the City of Elms, and to be regaled with hot biscuit, pickles, tea, and the other ingredients of Connecticut hospitality.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 14. -- An unusually violent northeaster raged along the coast to-day, and the wind and heavy breakers damaged the frail structures along the shore.
ALBANY, Nov. 14. -- The following certificates of election expenses were filed to-day with the Secretary of State:

The belles and beaus and matrons did not turn out in particularly large numbers yesterday afternoon at the Horse Show, and the attendance last evening was by no means as large as on Wednesday night. Had the general public known that the star attractions of Wednesday, the Duke and Duchess of Marlborough, would be present, the Garden would undoubtedly have held nearly as large a crowd of curiosity seekers as on the previous day.

The current number of the new monthly, International Trade, contains a brief but very instructive article on the relation of the silver agitation in this country to our export trade. It points out that the larger part of the trade of exporting countries is necessarily to Countries engaged chiefly in agriculture and mining rather than manufacturing.

In the trial of DAVID F. HANNIGAN for the murder of SOLOMON H. MANN the defendant's counsel have undertaken to prove that he was insane at the time when the murder was committed. Consequently there has been an interesting exhibition of what is called expert testimony, and several alienists of more or less prominence have already appeared.

It was not the Duke of Marlborough, but the place where the Duke sat on Wednesday evening, that attracted the attention of thousands at the horse show last evening. Mrs. Alva Vanderbilt and her escort, Oliver H.P. Belmont, accompanied by Col. and Mrs. Jay and a party of friends, occupied the seats last evening. Transfixed with awe, several hundred people stood with backs to the show ring.

The attention of Republican demagogues who have recently been complaining that the new tariff has "quenched the furnace fires" should be directed to the very remarkable output of "the furnaces" at the present time. The reports of The Iron Age, which have been accepted as authoritative for many years past, show that the production of pig iron on Nov. 1 was at the rate of 217,306 tons per week.

ROSLYN, L.I., Nov. 14. -- Robert H. Hegeman was burned to death last night. He lived alone. He was last seen getting his mail at the Post Office early in the evening. Fire at 1 A.M. destroyed his house, and after daybreak his charred body was found.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 14. -- The growth of the beet sugar industry in this State has attracted the attention of the Sugar Trust. Jobbers and dealers have been notified that if they sell the refined product of Nebraska factories the trust will decline to sell them a cheaper grade.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The Turkish Legation has received from the Sublime Porte the following telegram, under yesterday's date:

Members of the Presbyterian Church who have been interested in a campaign on behalf of foreign missions, and who have been holding a series of meetings in this city during the past week, express great indignation because of an editorial which appeared in The Evening Post of Wednesday. THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday printed the remarks of the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst and others on this editorial, which said among other things:

A motion was made before Recorder Goff in the General Sessions Court yesterday to relieve Walt er Requa of 22 East Ninety-ninth Street, an index clerk for the Consolidated Gas Company, from the court order to contribute $1.62 a week to the support of Mrs. Ellery Requa, who is sixty years old.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- Sir George Newnes, the millionaire owner of The Strand Magazine and of Tit-Bits, formerly the Liberal member for Newmarket, has resolved, I am told, to give an order for the most perfect thing in yachts that British science is capable of, and next year, when the present row shall have blown over, will issue a challenge for the America's Cup.

The Union League Club inaugurates its exhibition season of 1895-6 by a collection of the works of two distinguished Frenchmen of the Barbizon school. These men are Constant Troyon and Charles Francois Daubigny, and of their paintings there are twenty-seven examples hung.

Brig. Gen. Frederick C. McLewee, Inspector General of New-York, has just forwarded his report for the current year to the Adjutant General's office. The report deals minutely with every organization in the guard and naval militia, which comprises 13,000 officers and men.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 14. -- At the annual meeting of the New-Jersey Junction Railway and Union Stockyards Company the following were elected Directors: Chauncey M. Depew, William J. Sewell, Frederick H. Winston, Albert H. Veeder, Edward J. Martyn, George Peabody Gartner, Frederick H. Prince, Martin L. Sykes, W. Scott Fitts, and Nathaniel Thayer.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 14. -- The sixth annual field trials of the National Beagle Club came to an end to-day. An early start was made for the property of Mr. E.D. Lewis, where the dogs were to be put down. The weather was favorable, although cloudy, with a mild wind from the southeast. The first brace to be put down was Baronet, handled by S. Clark, against Talor, handled by D.F. Summers.
LONDON, Nov. 14. -- The Daily News will to-morrow say that the question regarding the ownership of the Island of Trinidad is near a solution favorable to Brazil.

ALBANY, Nov. 14. -- Gov. Morton will be kept busy for the next two months listening to applicants for appointment to the various State offices and commissions at present filled by Democrats whose terms expire during the next session of the Legislature.

Edward M. Grout, who was the regular Democratic nominee for Mayor in Brooklyn, and who is closely watching the canvass of the city vote by the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen, made the first move yesterday to contest the canvass as it is now proceeding.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Nov. 14. -- The schooner Aunt Ruth, in tow of the tug Connelly, arrived to-day at this port. The entire crew were so badly cut and shot during a fight with a crazy sailor that all may die.
DENVER, Col., Nov. 14. -- Francis Schlatter, the healer, has disappeared. No one knows where he has gone. The police are searching for him, but have little idea where the man is.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 14. -- The storm is playing havoc with the recently stranded steamer Irrawaddy. The huge breakers dash over her continually, and have moved her half way around. The bow of the ill-fated vessel now points to the northeast.

The property sold by the Corporation of Trinity Church, already referred to in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, consists of the four lots at the southwest corner of Hudson and Vandam Streets, 107 by 100, and four lots 100 feet front, adjoining on Vandam Street. The purchaser is Henry Heide, the confectioner, and the price paid is $185,000.

The typhoid fever epidemic which occurred in Stamford, Conn., last Spring, and continued into the early Summer, was the topic of discussion before the Section on Pediatrics at the Academy of Medicine last night.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 14. -- A fire caused by the explosion of an oil stove, and attended by many thrilling escapes from death, occurred shortly after 1 o'clock this afternoon in a four-story double flat erected a few months ago at Fourth and Henderson Streets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The Bureau of Ordnance, Navy Department, is preparing for an important, and what promises to be a very interesting, test -- that of a structure representing a turret of the battleship Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Turkish officials do not readily acquiesce with our views of what is right and just to American citizens in their country. The questions almost invariably hinge upon the nativity of the subject. Turkey claiming for herself the right to treat as she pleases American citizens who were born in Turkey, and who became naturalized in this country without the consent of the home Government.

NEWARK, Nov. 14. -- Four boys, none of them more than fourteen years old, two white and two colored, and all so small that they were placed in a standing position on the witness chair in the First Criminal Court, so that Judge Mott could see them, were arraigned this morning on the charge of highway robbery.

The newly created State Commission of Prisons has been listening to argument on the subject of providing for the employment of convicts when the restriction embodied in the Constitution last year shall take effect at the beginning of 1897. This restriction was the most foolish piece of work done by last year's convention, and as it was not submitted to a vote separately, the people had no chance to pronounce upon it.
Governor-elect Lowndes of Maryland arrived at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night. After dinner he and Gen. Felix Agnus of Baltimore went to the Horse Show.

A circular letter has been sent out by Melvil Dewey, Secretary of the Board of Regents of the State of New-York, to the Principals of professional and technical schools in this city and its vicinity asking them to give their opinion in writing as soon as possible as to the advisability of having a representative of the board in the city to answer questions on stated days before examinations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The official report of the injuries to the battleship Texas in the dry dock at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, was received at the Navy Department to-day. It is made by Naval Constructor F.F. Bowles, under whose supervision the ship was built at the Norfolk Navy Yard, and is addressed to Commodore Montgomery Sicard, commandant of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The report is as follows:

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 14. -- Official dispatches received here to-day show no diminution in the reign of anarchy in certain parts of the empire. A telegram from the authorities at Arabkir, Pashalic of Sivas, Asiatic Turkey, states that 1,500 Armenians rose against the Turks and committed many excesses Oct. 26 and 27.

SING SING, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- Warden Sage has had a big steam whistle placed on the new mess hall of Sing Sing Prison. The whistle can be heard six miles away. Following is a code arranged by the Warden for its use: ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- It is understood that a joint resolution is being prepared with much care for introduction in Congress which will provide for the annexation of the Hawaiian Islands to the United States under a Territorial form of Government.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 15. -- Massachusetts Day exercises at the Exposition began at 11 o'clock. An address of welcome on the part of the State of Georgia was delivered by Gov. W.Y. Atkinson. Gov. Frederick T. Greenhalge of Massachusetts responded at length, saying, among other things:

In the excitement that spreads over all Europe as to the crisis in Turkey, the position taken by the United States Government excites approval at home and something like envy abroad. A couple of vessels of no great strength are in the Mediterranean, ready to do whatever can be done to demonstrate the desire of our Government to protect its citizens in lawful pursuits in the Ottoman Empire.

But one day more remains in which society may disport itself at the Horse Show. The occupants of the boxes during the last five days will probably not complain when their days of inspection by a surging crowd of promenaders are passed.

Joseph Shoemaker of Grayson, Carter County, Ky., received the other day, in payment for a horse sold to an old farmer living near the Lewis County line, $46, among which were three of the famous "Sprinkle dollars" of the early thirties.
WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 15. -- Father John Bagley, a pioneer priest, stationed at Kingman, this State, arrived here last night, after having made one of the most wonderful rides on record.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The Post Office Department authorities have received positive proof of the identity of the Post Office robber, Russell, captured in Bruges, Belgium.

Some people dislike journalistic condemnation of themselves or their works, others are indifferent to it, and yet others enjoy it. We belong to this last class. Of course, if the mark is hit, if shaft after shaft goes in the clout, every one enjoys the game; dexterity is admirable even when malevolent. But mere malevolence itself, clumsy, uncouth, and pretentious malevolence, interests us; every human passion has a stimulating effect.

RAHWAY, N.J., Nov. 15. -- The bowling tournament of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey for the Winter season was inaugurated here last night, when the Union County Roadsters tried conclusions on their alleys with the Castle Point Cyclers of Hoboken. Last season the Roadsters were members of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs, and easily distanced all their opponents in the race for the silver loving cup.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The Spanish Minister, Senor Dupuy de Lome, has called the attention of the State Department to the rumor that the American steamer Laurada had violated the neutrality laws of the United States in landing an armed force on Cuban soil to aid the insurgents there.

A representative of The Free Press called upon Gov. Woodbury, who has just returned from an extended trip through the West, and asked him if he had seen Gov. Stewart's letter relative to the re-election of Governors, State Senators, and Representatives. He replied: "Yes, upon my arrival home the matter was brought to my attention.

RUTLAND, Vt., Nov. 14. -- The burial of Mrs. H. Henry Baxter of Fifth Avenue, New-York, widow of Gen. Baxter and founder of the Baxter Memorial Library of Rutland, whose death occurred Saturday at her Summer home in this city, as the result of a surgical operation, took place Tuesday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15. -All spectators were excluded from the football practice at Princeton to-day, and senttn.els patrolled the environments of the 'Varsity grounds to prevent any. spying eye from' seeing the mysterious doings behind the high board fence which hides the field from view. Cook. .'89o the. veteran tackle, and Holly,. '95, Joined the eoachers today. "Aleck" Moffat returned to New-York last night, after giving all the players a lecture on their weak points.

You should hear Mayor F.L. Noble of Lewiston tell how he shot the second deer at Madrid. He brought down the first one with a single shot at a long range, and pierced its side just above the heart with a clean rifle slug. The creature did not run two yards. It was a beauty, and its skin, with the head slightly raised, will be made into a mat to adorn his Honor's sitting room.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The Rev. Dr. Benaniah L. Whitman, the new President of Columbian University, was inaugurated to-night in the presence of an immense audience at Convention Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The annual report of Gen. Craighill, Chief of Engineers, to the Secretary of War has been made public. The board has prepared projects for the artillery defense of Philadelphia, Key West, San Diego, the mouth of the Columbia River, Galveston, and Puget Sound.

ALBANY, Nov. 15. -- A certificate of election filed to-day with the Secretary of State shows that it cost Senator Lexow $2,111 to be re-elected, $1,000 going to the Orange County Republican Committee and $500 to the Rockland County Republican Committee.
The German-American Citizens' Union begins work for a right object in the wrong way.

SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 15. -- Senator Watson C. Squire, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Coast Defenses, who will within a few days leave for the National capital, has very decided views concerning the Alaska boundary dispute. He is by no means pleased with the present outlook.

BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- The Tageblatt publishes an interview, which its correspondent has had with Halil Rifaat Pasha, the Turkish Grand Vizier, who said he was overjoyed to find that the Porte was on good terms with the powers. He added that he hope fully looked to a happy solution of the pending questions.
Mrs. Margaret Deland, the author of "John Ward, Preacher," and other novels, gave an address on "The Moral Power of the Novel" at Shawmut Congregational Church last evening.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- The sixth annual report of the Great Northern Railway Company for the year ending June 30, 1895, shows that general conditions along the line are better than most people supposed. The gross earnings of the entire Great Northern system aggregate $13,109,930, of which $10,365,031 was from freight and $1,854,821 passenger business.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 15. -- The National Grange to-day issued the following address to the American people:

The movement to get the children of this city interested in the cleaning of the streets and in assisting to keep them clean, which was started by Street Cleaning Commissioner Waring on the east side, where it met such a decided and gratifying success, has been extended to the west side.
The issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES to-day contains eminently pertinent responses from competent gentlemen to the editorial paragraphs about foreign missionaries in The Evening Post of yesterday.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Oklahoma, Nov. 15. -- During the last few weeks several important conferences have been held in this city and Guthrie between Gov. Renfrow and his advisers in this Territory and prominent citizens of the Indian Territory with several Congressmen from adjoining States, among them Congressman Charles Curtis of Kansas, who will have much to do with Indian Territory affairs during the coming session.

It was coaching day at the Garden yesterday. Had the general public known what was to have been seen at the Garden in the afternoon there would have been a crowd that would have made that of Wednesday night, to see the Duke of Marlborough and his bride, seem as a mere handfull of people in comparison.

AMESBURY, Mass., Nov. 15. -- It is proposed to merge the homestead of the poet Whittier in a memorial building open to the public, and the plan is being received in literary circles with general approval.

The strong northeast wind that has kept the sea running high from Boston to beyond Cape Hatteras since last Monday night gave up the struggle with incoming steamers last night, and quieted down to a "fair breeze."

LONDON, Ky., Nov. 11. -- On the banks of the Kentucky River, whose peaceful course lies along the most beautiful scenery of Eastern Kentucky, there was fought last Wednesday a duel as bloody as ever stained the fair soil. Two men identified with her history, hatred and bitterness in their hearts, of a courage worthy of a better cause, met, weapons in hand, and both offered their lives at the shrine of a false honor.

Twenty-five girls in the Northwestern University, members of the junior class in oratory, appeared in the class room in bloomers. Without exception they belong to wealthy families. Many of them are preparing for the stage.

For the first time in ten years the tenants of thousands of acres in the County of Logan, Ill., and other tracts of land in various parts of the country have received a visit from their landlord, William Scully.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 15. -- In regulation Western style four tramps made an ineffectual attempt to rob an express train on the Pennsylvania Railroad at Morrisville, just across the river from here, in Pennsylvania to-night.

The experts in the trial of David F. Hannigan for the killing of Solomon H. Mann engaged in a battle royal yesterday. The Justice, the jury, and those in the body of the courtroom were more or less confused spectators. Justice Ingraham prolonged the session in Oyer and Terminer to a late hour. The defense had put in its main case before 4 o'clock in the afternoon.

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- The fact that the members of the Meadowbrook Hunt Club are thorough and enthusiastic huntsmen was clearly demonstrated to-day when the ladies and gentlemen of the club participated in m thirteen-mile run across country after the hounds, regardless of a drizzling rain and a cold and penetrating northeasterly wind.
The Cooper Union Labor Bureau is a practical philanthropy begun last month. The general public has heard but little of it as yet.

There was published two or three days ago an interview with a brother-in-law of Senator BURROWS of Michigan, who says that the Government will be asked to permit him and his associates to dam the Mississippi River in Itasca County, Minn., in order that they may obtain water power there to be used in operating large paper and pulp mills, which are to be fed by the forests in the vicinity.

Three great British scientific societies are agreed that it is the duty of the British Government to fit out an expedition for thorough antarctic exploration. In November, 1893, the Royal Geographical Society appointed a notable committee to inquire into the propriety of such an expedition and report. They reported in favor of having the Government send two suitable vessels to explore the south polar regions, and keep them at it for three years.
SCNENECTADY, Nov. 15. -- John O'Neil, eighteen years of age, a pupil at the Union Classical Institute, has been arrested on a warrant sworn out by Counselor Alexander J. Thompson.
Women will have a part during the coming Winter in fostering agencies for counteracting the influence of the saloon.

The stories told by Little Mr. Thimblefinger for the entertainment of Buster John, Sweetest Susan, and Drusilla, when they visited him for the second time in his queer country, have not the perfect ease of the Uncle Remus histories. We may say that Mrs. Meadows expresses something of our feeling when she complains of a vague sense of having heard a good many of the tales before.

ALBANY, Nov. 15. -- The Supreme Court of the State of New-York to-day consists of 46 Justices, 17 of whom sit in general term. On and after Jan. 1, 1896, there will be 76 Justices of the Supreme Court, and of this number, 22 will act as Judges in the Appellate Division of the court, which takes the place of the General Term.

The annual report of Inspector General C.F. McLewee is the first on the condition of the sailor boys in the Guard under the new regime at Albany. The First Battalion is stationed in this city. On inspection Sept. 4, 1895, Gen. McLewee found the following state of affairs:

Mrs. Brightwen, knowing that through her fortunate station in life she has had opportunities to observe and study nature more fully than the majority of those who will read her book, has transcribed with minute detail much that she has perceived in connection with nature that is common to all. For years she has been a close observer of the animals, birds, and vegetation that surround her home, and has grown familiar with them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The most interesting fact to be drawn from the report of the operating of the Bureau of Supplies and Accounts for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1895, is the economy in the expenditure of money, time, and labor secured through the methods pursued by its head, Paymaster General Edwin Stewart.

BOSTON, Nov. 15. -- The annual dinner of the Boston Merchants' Association was held this evening in the Hotel Vendome. The subject for discussion was "The General Improvement of Boston Harbor." The principal speakers were Lieut. Gov. Wolcott, Woodward Emery, Alden Spear, Senator Fife of Maine, Senator Platt of Connecticut, and Senator Hoar of Massachusetts. Most of the Massachusetts Congressmen were present, and several Congressmen from other States held places of honor at the tables.

All the seats in Carnegie Hall, except those in the grand tier, were filled last night before 8 o'clock by members of the Presbyterian Church who wished to show their sympathy with their Board of Foreign Missions.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- A dispatch from the representative of The United Press in Constantinople under date of Nov. 14 says it was announced that the commission appointed to put into force the reforms adopted for the administration of affairs in Asia Minor would begin its sittings to-day, Nov. 15.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 15. -- The second day of the Methodist Missionary Conference was devoted to a continuation of the distribution of 43 per cent. of the million-dollar fund among the conferences of the United States.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 15. -- A meeting of the women composing the Board of Domestic Control of the Children's Home, Glenwood Avenue, was held this evening in the home of Mrs. Augustus Creveling, 653 Jersey Avenue, to consider the deposition of five members of the board by the Board of Trustees.

The Rapid Transit Commission, through Messrs. Edward M. Shepard and Albert B. Boardman, its counsel, applied to the General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday for the appointment of a commission to hear testimony on the question as to whether the underground plan proposed by the Commissioners shall be carried out, and to report to the court.

Suits for amounts aggregating nearly $1,000,000 are pending against the New-York and Sea Beach Railroad Company, growing out of the accident near Benson-hurst, Labor Day, Sept. 2, in which about sixty persons were injured. The amounts named in the suites range from $2,000 to $50,000.

The strike of the cabmen looks like an imprudent and irrational business, especially in the phase it has now assumed. A man who has a situation which does not require a high degree of skill to fill and who nevertheless quarrels with his bread and butter just as Winter is coming on incurs a very serious responsibility if he has anybody but himself depending upon his earnings.

A decision was handed down in the General Term of the Supreme Court yesterday in the matter of the application of the New- Work and Long Island Bridge Company, respondent, against Lenox Smith and others, appellants, relative to acquiring title to certain property, , on the easterly side of Third Avenue, north of Sixty-fourth Street, for the purposes of the proposed bridge.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Chairman John R. Tanner of the Republican State Central Committee of Illinois at a meeting of the committee this afternoon formally announced his candidacy for the Gubernatorial nomination, at the same time resigning the Chairmanship of the committee. T.N. Jamieson was elected Chairman in Mr. Tanner's place.

Gold to the amount of $2,250,000 was engaged at the Sub-Treasury yesterday for export to Europe to-day. Lazard Freres took $1,250,000 and L. von Hoffmann Co. arranged to withdraw $1,000,000 this morning. There was talk of further engagements, following Thursday's uncertain rumors.

BARBADOS, British West Indies, Oct. 30. -- Lightning and rain have again played sad havoc in the West Indies. With each succeeding year it would appear that certain isles of the Caribbean Sea are doomed for devastation by the elements, and these occurrences, together with the fact of the rapid decline in their staple products, are annually placing proprietors -- and with them the working classes -- in an almost helpless and hopeless condition.

The fifty-third report of births, marriages, and deaths in Massachusetts, returns of libels for divorce and of deaths investigated by the Medical Examiners for the year 1894, has been prepared by the Secretary of the Commonwealth, and is again edited by Dr. Francis A. Harris. The report presents in 163 pages a large amount of useful and interesting matter, with the facts so classified that their significance is seen at a glance.
DENVER, Col., Nov. 15. -- The whereabouts of Francis Schlatter, the healer, is still unknown, though he is supposed to be somewhere on the road to Gray's Peak.

The Society for Improving the Condition of the Poor closed its fiscal year Sept. 30, and is now issuing statements of work accomplished and the advance along different lines which it is planning for the year to come.

It is a matter for rejoicing that fashion is no longer to decree a slender waist as something indispensable to propriety and grace. The natural waist of the woman of average height is about twenty-eight inches, and any less size is attained only through arrested development, or compression by means of whalebone and steel.

Yachtsmen were particularly pleased yesterday by the announcement made exclusively in THE NEW-YORK TIMES that Sir George Newnes had stated that he would issue a challenge for a race for the America's Cup, and that he would have the best yacht that British money and British brains could furnish.

Marie Casacelli, a handsome, welldressed Italian, appeared at Dr. Senner's office on Ellis Island Wednesday and entered a protest against allowing Giuseppi and Vincenzo Terlazzo, who came here on the steamship Werra, to land. WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Claude M. Johnson, Chief of the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, Treasury Department, states in his report to Secretary Carlisle of the operations of his bureau during the year, that the condition of our currency encourages counterfeiting, as it necessarily increases the danger of successfully passing counterfeit notes.

Fifteen full-page photogravures, after paintings by the German artist, Ferdinand Leeke, are contained in this volume, and Mr. Finck has written an entertaining introduction -- biographical, critical, and explanatory -- that, coming from so well-informed and eminent a source, is valuable and thoroughly comprehensive. Mr. Finck says:

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- The Morning Post will to-morrow say that the indemnity agreed to be paid to Japan for her evacuation of the Liao-Tung Peninsula will be handed over to the Japanese representative by the Bank of England on Saturday. The Japanese will, therefore, evacuate the peninsula within three months.

Lafayette Post, No. 140, G.A.R., tendered a reception last night to Commander in Chief Ivan H. Walker and Department Commander Edward J. Atkinson at the rooms of the post, in the Masonic Temple, Twenty-third Street and Sixth Avenue, Many National and State officers of the Grand Army were present.

The renewal of gold exports in a moderate degree the past week has naturally aroused a good deal of interest and some uneasiness. The only element in the general situation that explains the rise in exchange to the shipping point is the reaction in the intense speculation in London and Paris, requiring the raising of money by the sale of securities, among which American securities have been found the most readily sold.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 15. -- Another attempt will be made to-morrow to pull the wrecked steamer Irrawaddy off the bar, where she has been since last Saturday. The vessel was pounded severely by the breakers during the violent storm of Thursday, but, with the exception of the loss of some of her deck fixtures, she is in good condition.

Only one close game was rolled in the bank clerks' bowling tournament on the alleys at 109 Horatio Street last evening. It was between the teams representing the Park and Mount Morris Banks and was won by the former, the score being 827 to 820. Of course this result gave the Parks a chance to yell, and they let out the loudest cheer heard this season in Horatio Street.

Superintendents of Insurance from several States were guests of Stuart Brown of the New-York Life Insurance Company yesterday afternoon at luncheon in the Hoffman House. During and after the luncheon the Superintendents discussed the question of reissuing licenses to Prussian companies doing business in this country.
BOSTON, Nov. 15. -- Eben D. Jordan, senior member of the firm of Jordan, Marsh Co., who had been ailing since last July, died at his Beacon Street residence this morning.

Generally, it is the financier, the politico-economist, who only knows Walter Bagehot, and, as Mr. Hutton writes, his books have been used in American colleges. As editor of The Economist he made himself a lasting reputation. What is not so well known is the literary side of the man. It is in the three volumes entitled "Literary Studies" that the many-sidedness of Bagehot may be seen.

Richard J. Navarro yesterday told to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES a story of Spanish oppression in Cuba that must seem incomprehensible to people living in the nineteenth century. Mr. Navarro, who arrived in this city a few days ago, was himself the victim of the outrage, and the authenticity of his recital is vouched for by J.F. Pierra, a prominent shipping merchant, at 81 New Street, in whose office Mr. Navarro was seen.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 15. -- But little damage was done along the Jersey coast by the storm to-day, although during the early morning the damage threatened to be considerable. The heavy rain which fell during the night calmed the sea to a considerable extent, although the wind held until about midnight, when it began to subside, and by midday, except for the sea's roughness, there was hardly an indication of the storm of Thursday.
An attempt was made early yesterday morning to burn the Winona apartment house, 334 Central Park West.
