Mr. Navarro, who arrived in this city a few days ago, was himself the victim of the outrage, and the authenticity of his recital is vouched for by J.F. Pierra, a prominent shipping merchant, at 81 New Street, in whose office Mr. Navarro was seen.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Nov. 15. -- The Directors of the defunct Union Bank, Sir Robert Thorburn, ex-Premier of the colony; Augustus Harvey, until recently a member of the Whiteway Executive and leader in the Government upper house; Walter Baine Grieve, a leading merchant, and William Donnelly, ex-Receiver General, were committed to-day for trial before the Supreme Court on the charge of presenting false statements of the bank's affairs.

Messrs. Hoffman Brothers have sold for Warren E. Dennis 373 Broadway, and for the Fay estate 375 Broadway, 50 feet south of White Street, to a Brooklyn resident, for investment. The two plots are 49.10 by 150 feet, extending to Franklin Alley, and have five-story buildings on them. The price paid was about $375,000.
A consignment of books from England was sold yesterday by Bangs Co., some of the prices obtained being as follows:

NEWARK, Nov. 15. -- General Manager Young of the Consolidated Traction Company to-day expressed himself as being very much surprised at the decision of City Counsel Riker, which was made public yesterday, and which was to the effect that the trolley company had no right to run express or freight cars through the streets of the city.

Capt. Lawson and other miners who have returned to Tacoma from Cook's Inlet, Alaska, are telling stories of Alaska's richness in gold which have aroused the deepest interest of all miners and bids fair to induce hundreds to go north next Spring.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- At the call of Assemblyman James M.E. O'Grady of this city, there was held this evening here a concference of the Republican Assemblymen of several Western New-York counties to discuss the Speakership of the next Assembly, and to unite on a candidate whom they would support.

As a result of an accident yesterday morning in the Brush Electric Light Company's building many of the streets below Fifty- ninth Street were in gloom last night. The fact that the mishap to the machinery was a serious one was learned through a message which was received at Police Headquarters late yesterday afternoon from the Department of Public Works.

The Third Avenue Railroad Company filed its bond with the Controller yesterday, in the total amount of $500,000, to guarantee the construction of the King's Bridge Road extension, under the franchise which it bought at public auction Thursday.

C. Augustus Haviland of the depositors' organization of the defunct Commercial Bank of Brooklyn has filed with Gov. Morton charges against State Superintendent of Banks Charles M. Preston, whose term expires May 9, 1896. Mr. Preston is charged with being absolutely derelict, negligent, and false to his trust in dealing with the affairs of the Commercial Bank.
R.H. Macy Co. started a horseless carriage yesterday at noon on its way to Chicago, where it will take part in The Times-Herald contest, to be held Nov. 28.

JAMAICA, L.I., Nov. 15. -- The expected legal battle over the ballots cast in Queens County at the recent election was opened to-day. While the Supervisors were tabulating the results of their official canvass of the vote, they were served with an order issued by Justice Gaynor, directing them to show cause why they should not be enjoined free counting for Supreme Court Justice the battle-axe ballots of the Gleason party.
ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 16. -- The imperial proclamation, which was issued this morning, announcing the birth of a daughter to the Czar and Czarina, adds:

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 16. -- One of the social features this season will be the dances to be given by the Cotillion Club for the younger set. A series of dances has been arranged by the following committee: Miss Nella Whiton, Miss Maude Van Boskerck, Irving C. West, and Howard Huntington.

Visions of untold wealth and a life of ease and pleasure floated through the brain of John Shannon of Falls of Schuylkill a few days ago, when he discovered $15,000 in bank notes snugly wrapped up in tinfoil and a stout piece of paper, which had been secreted thirty-four years ago in a beam in the old Mifflin mansion, fronting on Ridge Avenue, below Spencer Street.

SALE LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 16. -- The Utah Woman has passed her preliminary examination in politics triumphantly. In the campaign just ended she proved a factor whose potency for good is now admitted, even by those who were wont to declare that her advent into politics would destroy her delicate sensibilities and degrade her toward the level of the ordinary city politician.

WEST POINT, Nov. 16. -- It was away back in 1813 that class meetings were first instituted at the United States Military Academy. Capt. Alden Partridge was then Superintendent. In addition to this he held a professorship in the department of civil and military engineering. The cadets were at that time appointed from the engineers, artillery, cavalry, infantry, and riflemen, and had their quarters in the old "Long Barracks" that stood near "Gallows Hollow."
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16.--The heirs of the William Sharon estate came into possession of their shares to-day, through the expiration of the trust by limitation.

Although for dynastic reasons an heir might have been more joyously welcomed, the birth of an heiress to the Russian throne is an event upon which the Czar, and more especially the Czarina, may be congratulated. No one congratulates the imperial mother more heartily than THE TIMES, which a few days ago printed a cable dispatch reporting that all was not going well--in fact, that all was going the worst possible.

The Ward Line steamer Santiago arrived last evening at Quarantine from Nassau and ports on the south side of Cuba with thirty-eight passengers, twenty-six of whom were seamen, some returning home after completing cruises, others shipwrecked mariners.

" The Lakes of Central New-York and the Erie Canal" was the subject of Prof. Albert S. Bickmore's fourth lecture of the series to the teachers of the City and State of New-York, under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction, at the American Museum of Natural History yesterday. The usual large audience was present, every seat being filled.
One tranquilizing and important result of the recent rains has been the restoration of the Croton River to its normal volume.

One of the popular sports this Winter is going to be hockey. As soon as there is ice several teams will be organized, and match games and tournaments arranged. To make it a popular out-door game, of course there will have to be plenty of cold weather and good ice, but the game is also to be played on the artificial ice on the St. Nicholas and other rinks.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 16. -- Bayonne Hook and Ladder Company, No. 1, passed the quarter-century mark of its existence last evening. It observed the event by giving an entertainment, dinner, and reception to the Mayor, Council, Department and Volunteer Company officers. Councilman Edward E. Stinson was Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements.

The successive steps of equine local evolution have been, of course, the result of the peculiar requirements of the time. Nothing more positively demonstrates a doctrine of utilitarianism than the evolution of the horse.

ORANGE. N.J., Nov. 16. -- Ground has just been broken for the new and handsome building of the South Orange Free Library, which is to be erected at Scotland Road and Taylor Place, facing on the former thoroughfare. It is to stand on land given for the purpose by Eugene V. Connett, the President of the South Orange Board of Village Trustees.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 16. -- Prof. Dawson lectured on "Music as a Factor in Education" before the Town Improvement Society yesterday afternoon, in the High School hall.

G.M. Hitchcock, a well-known Western newspaper man and publisher of The World-Herald of Omaha, Neb., has been in this city several days. He talked to a United Press reporter yesterday concerning the business and political outlook in the West. He said:

On Saturday, Nov. 30, a small party of missionaries will leave this city for Central America, where they intend to establish a colony at Costa Rica. This party hopes to build up an industrial community of Christian workers, preachers, and teachers in a region that knows nothing of Christianity.

Several of our contemporaries have been moved by the recent marriage of Mr. WILLIAM K. VANDERBILT'S daughter to compare the father's settlement of $5,000,000 upon the new Duchess of MARLBOROUGH with the gifts of Mr. JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER to the Chicago University, and to indulge in comments which are not conspicuously just.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 16. -- The Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey announced at their meeting that the representation of entered organizations in the billiard, pool, and whist tournaments, which number about five each, would meet at the Atalanta's rooms to arrange the schedule. By many of your readers who feel an interest in the scenes and events of Colonial days in the City of New-York and other sections of our country the articles published in relation thereto are perused with great pleasure as well as with profit by young and old.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 16. -- The whereabouts of Francis Schlatter, "The Messiah," is still a mystery. If Schlatter is in all the places where he has been reported, he is certainly to be credited with supernatural powers of ubiquity. Thus far he is alleged to have taken up his abode at Elizabeth, Kiowa, Golden, Fort Collins, and Rooney's Ranch, Several counties remain to be heard from.

The forty-ninth annual convention of the Delta Kappa Epsilon fraternity is to be held here on Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday of this week. Undergraduate delegates are expected from almost all the leading colleges in the country, from Maine to California. Delta Kappa Epsilon is one of the oldest of the college fraternities and the largest in point of total membership.

As an agriculturist I enjoy visiting New-York. It contains somewhere between two and three millions of stomachs that make a constant demand for farm products. The New-York appetite for good things to eat and drink could not be enlarged even by legislation seeking to improve the home market.

Statements of expenses incurred by candidates have been pouring into the County Clerk's office for the past two weeks, and the limit of time expired Friday night. There are eight delinquents, liable to punishment for misdemeanor. County Clerk Purroy had the list made out for transmission to the District Attorney yesterday.

SUMMIT, N.J., Nov. 16. -- There was a pleasant entertainment at the Hotel Beechwood Music Hall last night, when the Misses Leech sang and played their banjos. Harry M. Peckham whistled and sang, and Walter Leon did some character impersonating.

Ex-Senator Edmunds, who sat for years in the Senate with Allen G. Thurman, the aged Democratic leader, now lying at death's door at his home, in Columbus, Ohio, indulged Sunday in some personal reminiscences of the "Old Roman," who, despite political differences, he counted a warm personal friend.

Osias is one of nature's beneficiaries. Art is his foster-mother, and both combined to make him gorgeous for the filial journey.

The four Northern Commonwealths which have figured in the role of "doubtful States" ever since the rehabilitation of the Democracy in the Congressional elections of 1874 are no longer in that category.

The jury in the Supreme Court, before Justice Andrews, that has for several days been trying the case of Julia Leddy, administratrix of the estate of her father, Thomas Leddy, against the Bank for Savings, handed in a sealed verdict yesterday morning, finding for the defendant.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 16. -- Mrs. Voorhees and Stewart Coriel of Middlebush were married on election day.

The golden horseshoe of the Metropolitan Opera House will be graced by fair Women to-morrow night, when the opera season will be opened with "Romeo and Juliet." This has always been a popular opera with society people, and this is the second season the managers of the Opera House have chosen it for the opening night. Many debutantes will be present to-morrow night, among them Miss Duer, Miss Post, Miss Neilson, and Miss Bronson.

The after enjoyment of sailing small boats can be appreciated only by one who has held a tiller or tended a sheet in a race for a prize and glory -- principally glory. It seems to be unlimited, and, perhaps, it is more satisfying, when one has the leisure to recall everything that made or marred a particular occasion, place the blame for blunders, and size up one's share of the glory.

WEST CHAZY, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- The agents of the State Fisheries, Game and Forest Commission claim that they have got a good case against the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company, under Section 76 of the game laws, which reads:

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Committee named to make arrangements for Manhattan Day, Nov. 25, at the Atlanta Exposition, met yesterday in Room 183 Stewart Building, and arranged the programme. John C. Eames presided, and Gen. McAlpin. Chairman of the Plan and Scope Committee, aided in arranging the programme.
The following extract is from a letter recently received by the Rev. H.A. Schauffler from his daughter, who is a missionary in Persia:

I can see no positive proof that Roman Catholicism, as such, is gaining to any very appreciable extent, although it is perfectly true, and very grievously true, that doctrines once regarded as distinctly Romish are now taught on every side in the Church of England. In an article by the late Dr. Littledale, in The Quarterly Review of January, 1888, various facts are quoted which support this view.

Does the style of riding in a show ring differ from the style of riding in the hunting field? This question is answered affirmatively to the observer of a cross-country run the minute he witnesses a jumping competition at the Horse Show. Every experienced huntsman knows that the horses behave differently. Therefore, why should not the rider be accordingly affected?

ELMSFORD, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- The new trolley railroad, which has recently commenced operations between this little hamlet and White Plains has given Elmsford, formerly known as Hall's Corners, new life and importance in the eyes of the world, and on pleasant days brings many visitors to see the delightful Sawmill River Valley, and the attractive spots within it.

A covey of partridges will, for some unexplained reason, upon occasion, fly right out to sea and alight on the waves with as little apparent concern as they would in a turnip field, though every single bird among them is certain to perish by drowning.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 16. -- Golf is fast becoming a favorite pastime for the members of the Essex County Country Club of Hutton Park, West Orange, and the links recently laid out on their extensive grounds under the mountain is now frequented almost daily by those who seek to become proficient in the popular sport. In fact, Instructor Bendeiow is delighted with the rapid progress being made by his pupils.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will he disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16.--The contest for the Clerkship and minor places in the gift of the House has begun in earnest. Major A. McDowell, the Pennsylvania candidate for Clerk, opened his headquarters at Willard's Hotel to-day. Mr. Glenn of Cuba, N.Y., the candidate for Doorkeeper, probably will open his headquarters at the same hotel Monday.

In the Spring of 1894 a Hungarian named Jordan started on a bicycle from Bucharest, with the intention of making a tour through the Balkan peninsula to Constantinople. Not far from Philipoppel, in Roumelia, he was overtaken by night and obliged to stop at a hovel, which served as a public house, and after confiding his "wheel" to the care of the innkeeper, who took charge of it with considerable distrust, went to bed.

The feature of New-York which most impresses me is the magnitude of her commercial interests. Other cities are great in numbers and enterprise, in wealth and its varied employments, in opportunities which stimulate the ambitious, and in attractions which satisfy the self-indulgent; New-York adds to all these a unique and unrivaled relation to the commerce of the world.

PARIS, Oct. 26. -- Sun -- yes, and plenty of it. Who in the world could dream of anything but white muslins, soft silks, shade hats, and hammocks. It seems that these would shadow out into Fall tints, without gaining one pound in texture or weight; phenomenal, fairy fabrics, strange, like the season.

Why the songs with which the melodious Italians brighten their home life have been confined heretofore mainly to their native habitat is less easly understood now than before the company of troubadours performing at Koster Bial's began their visit here.

News of the horrible massacre by Turkish soldiers of 800 Armenians at Kharpout, coming, as it does, at a time when the people of New-York City have been specially stirred up to a more lively interest in the work of foreign missions, has served to intensify the feelings of horror and loathing which the previous massacres had awakened.

One of the most dejected-looking men I ever saw was at the Ebbit House last night. For five days he had been without means to buy a cigar or even get shaved. I had a slight acquaintance with him, and he told me the story of his troubles. He said:

There are in Odessa, at the present time three young Russian ladies of great wealth, who are engaged in the useful calling of selling coals, washing linen, and serving in a farm, and the charbonniare, the washerwoman, and the farm-servant have received and divided among them during the last few weeks 863 offers of marriage.

Of course, Harvard College rose up and roared at the strictures passed upon it as a "rich man's college" by The Illustrated American, but there is a lurking suspicion in the minds of many that Harvard knew it to be a home thrust. Harvard has great credit in Worcester, and Worcester has sent many of her best sons to the famous old college.

Millions of pages of black spots laid upon Staves of five lines are in the world. Some of them were written by men of marvelous genius, and, though they represent nothing but sequences of sounds in orderly array, the judgment of the world has accorded them fellowship with the works of Michael Angelo and Dante, that speak at once through the eye to the heart of every man who can see and read.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 16. -- The Duke and Duchess of Marlborough sailed for Genoa at 11:10 o'clock this morning on the North German Lloyd steamship Fulda, and many friends wished them a pleasant voyage.

In many English papers, especially those which claim to circulate among the aristocracy, may be seen advertisements of the "Matrimonial Herald and Fashionable Marriage Gazette." This is the organ of "The World's Great Marriage Association, Limited," which has been duly registered as a limited liability company under act of Parliament, and has been established for more than twelve years.
I like to go to New-York because it is a great city made up of elements illustrating many of the best and the worst phases of modern life. It has things to admire, things to study, things to fear.

The committee appointed at the meeting of the creditors of J.B. Brewster Co. of 319 West Forty-third Street, carriage manufacturers, on Nov. 9, reported yesterday that the company has liabilities of $199,452.10, and assets of the nominal value of $150,000 and the actual value of $100,000.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 16. -- The rear guard of cottagers departed this week for New-York and elsewhere where they have their Winter homes. Therefore, save in less than a half dozen instances, the Summer villa section of Newport is deserted.

Individual as well as team scores ruled small in yesterday's games in the Wholesale Drug Trades' Bowling Association, rolled on Reid's alleys, in Church Street. The teams engaged were those representing Dodge Olcott, Tarrant Co., Seabury Johnson, Park, Davis Co., Colgate Co., and Lanman Kemp. The Seabury Johnson, and Park, Davis Co. boys scored two wins apiece.

The Czaritza has displayed great sense as well as taste in the choice of a layette for her first baby. Correctly speaking, there are two layettes, which have been ready for some time past -- one set tied with purple and the other with pale-blue ribbons -- waiting until time should decide which would be required.

The subject of modified Sunday laws will be very much in evidence in the next session of the Legislature. The Democrats of the delegation of the City of New-York will not only introduce bills aiming in that direction, but will push these bills so that the sentiment of the Legislature on this question will be easily recognizable shortly after the opening of the session.

Five more of the whaling fleet arrived from the north yesterday, they having succeeded in getting out of the ice, and are coming in from the Ohkotsk Sea. From the latter place came the bark Charles W. Morgan. The vessels to reach port from the Arctic were the steamers Narwhal and Orca, the brig Hidalgo, and the barks Alice Knowles and Lydia.

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 16.--Every returning steamer from Alaska brings down miners who tell enchanting stories of Alaska's wonderful richness in gold. Most of them, too, bring with them little sacks filled with gold dust and nuggets secured during one to three seasons' work in the placer fields on the Yukon and its tributary streams.

In THE TIMES of the 10th you published a philological note concerning "fantigue," its origin and meaning; and "Old Chap" wrote that while "fantigue" was novel to him, "fantod" was in use in the United States, with the meaning "fidgety," as in the phrase, "She was in such a fantod."

To me New-York differs from other great cities in its great harbors filled with shipping from all parts of the world. It is this that to me gives the impression of the great city not only of the United States, but of all the world. New-York has all the elements of greatness. It will, I believe, eventually make one of the greatest cities in the world.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- A deal was made this afternoon by which The Chicago Evening Journal and The Chicago Evening Press were consolidated.

Not so very long ago I heard a civil surgeon gayly tell at a mess dinner how the other day he had felt constrained to teach a native somewhat forcibly his respectful duty to the "ruling race." The "nigger," as he put it, had his whiskers and beard tied up -- as all natives like to have them when traveling -- when he met him on a country road.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Lord Dunraven's charges against the Defender syndicate and the New-York Yacht Club have caused him to be generally censured. The Speaker to-day says that Lord Dunraven's statement was ill judged and was neither dignified nor sportsmanlike. It shows temper and want of self-respect. Abuse of the umpires under whose auspices he agreed to race is in lamentably bad taste, and his statement will revive a waning controversy.

In 1840 a negro lad of sixteen years was sent to Auburn Prison for five years for stealing a horse. At the time of trial there was much doubt of his guilt, and shortly afterward his innocence was generally conceded; yet no one ever suggested that he should be pardoned. After all, what difference did it make?

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 16. -- The Kentuckians celebrated to-day at the exposition. Two celebrations were announced, and some friction was expected, but Mrs. Cantrell, who was running one of them, did not carry out her programme, although she had secured the Auditorium. Mrs. Stevenson directed the woman's feature at the Woman's Building in the afternoon.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- There is a little weather-beaten sailboat called the Dollar that lies when not in use at the dock near the foot of Franklin Avenue. Its skipper is Capt. George W. Loyd. The Captain's boat can be distinguished from other craft in Echo Bay by a white flag that is always kept at the masthead.

Gertrude Sumner was visiting her cousin Marian, and late on the evening of her arrival the two, in dressing robes and slippers, were chatting before the grate in the latter's sitting room as a homeopathic preparation for sleep. Their surroundings were dark, heavy, and elegant; even as those of the adjacent bedroom were white, airy, and simple.

A Buffalo newspaper man who owns a bicycle had a peculiar experience last week. The man, who for the purpose of identification might as well be called Jones, had occasion to go to Rochester. The roads were in good condition, and the air was just right for riding, so he concluded to save his railroad fare and make the trip on his wheel.

I always enjoy a visit to New-York, because it is, in point of population, commercially, and in nearly every respect, the greatest city on the American continent. I like New-York; I like its bustle, its life, and the spirit of its people. I like to stand on Broadway and watch the cosmopolitan crowd go by.

As to the artisan class in Marseilles, the best of them are most intelligent and pleasant companions when you get to know them, slow at executing commissions, but most commendably careful to execute them thoroughly well. One such, of whom I was fortunate enough to see a good deal, was very well informed, a good talker, and never n bore, with a very fine type of Southern physique.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- Bank Superintendent Charles M. Preston to-day discussed the charges made against him by the depositors' organization of the Commercial Bank of Brooklyn to Gov. Morton.

I always enjoy my visits to New-York, partly from the great interest attached to the city itself, and partly for reasons entirely personal. A great modern city is a great modern wonder; and New-York, as the commercial emporium of this country, is naturally one of the most interesting cities of the world to an American citizen.

It is significant that there is a vast amount of talk in the Tammany rank and file just now about the necessity of a reorganization that will attract Democrats now opposed to the Wigwam into the organization.

M. Rodin, the celebrated French sculptor, is before everything a conscientious artist. Last year this conscientiousness of his proved a little too much for that equally artistic body, the Societe des Gens de Lettres. The society was annoyed because their statue of Balzac, ordered of M. Rodin some years previously, was not delivered at the stipulated date.

Four noteworthy exhibitions of an artistic nature have occupied a fair share of attention during the past week, and in addition the Union League Club began its regular Winter season of monthly collections, always interesting and invariably suggesting a regret that the number of visitors is necessarily limited to a favored few.

The silver discovered at Bosco Reale, near Pompeii, having been perfectly restored, is now on view at the Louvre. From time to time the conditions under which this silver were found have been presented in these columns. All the vases had been originally wrapped up in a woolen cloth, and some fragments of the material were adhering to the silver.

To the efforts of Mr. W.G. Steel, Capt. Dutton, and the Oregon Alpine Club, Oregon is indebted for the National park known as Crater Lake. This park is situated directly on the summit of the Cascade Mountains, and the crater is about twenty-five miles north of Fort Kalamath. By soundings made during the survey the water was found to be over 2,000 feet deep.

It is a good maxim to have patience with a weeded fish; indeed, this virtue often stands the angler in good stead. I once knew a friend of mine put to serious inconvenience for want of it. He had hooked a heavy salmon, and this fish lay down and sulked, as salmon will do once in half a dozen seasons, though not nearly so often, if properly handled, as some people suppose.

It is extremely significant that Secretary HOKE SMITH has been invited by the Legislature of Georgia to address it on the financial question. That body is already fully informed of the views of Mr. CRISP, who aspires to represent the State in the United States Senate. It knows also, of course, the views of Secretary SMITH, and that they are totally opposed to those of the ex-Speaker.

The report of Inspector General Fred C. McLewee, a synopsis of which appeared in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of Friday last, is just now absorbing the attention of the National Guard. The recommendations of the General, which have been made after a careful study of the needs of the service, will be indorsed through the service.

The proudest man in Lakewood, and the man most talked about and complimented yesterday was Jasper Lynch. This popularity was occasioned by the exhibition of golf which he made on the Lakewood Golf Club links, and his defeat of the ex-amateur champion of the United States, L.B. Stoddart, the star player of the St. Andrew's Club.

The news of the massacre at Harput and the sacking of the mission premises there is in some respects the most serious that has come from Turkey. Harput is a city of about 30,000 inhabitants in the centre of one of the largest plains of Eastern Turkey. It is the seat of Euphrates College and a centre of somewhat extensive missionary operations throughout the whole section.

Mrs. Galatian P. Harmon, whose husband is an importer of rice at 121 Pearl Street, and who lives at 17 West One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street, was run down by a brewer's wagon while riding a bicycle in Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon. She was so seriously injured that it was said last night that she could not live.

Blenheim, restored by the American heiress, has a certain sentimental significance founded upon an anecdote which links the history of Blenheim and the Marlboroughs directly and romantically with America.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 16.--An accident by which twelve people lost their lives occurred in the heart of the city this evening. Owing to the unexplainable carelessness of a street car conductor, a car, well filled with people, took an awful plunge of 120 feet from the Central Street draw of the Central Viaduct into the dark waters of the Cuyahoga River.

MADRID, Nov. 16. -- A dispatch from Havana to the Correspondencia says that an insurgent band from Remedios is co-operating with the insurgent leader Maximo Gomez in putting a stop to outrages by the negroes and mulattoes under the rebel leader Guerra.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 16. -- A charming silver tea was given yesterday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Allerton W. Kilborne, in High Street, for the benefit of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Young Men's Christian Association. William H. Barber played selections from Chopin, Liszt, and other masters.

PARIS, Oct. 22. -- At first no one believed it. The Boulevard reasoners passed on, conjecturing rather why coincidence brought together the lately married Duke d'Aosta and the young, fresh, baby-faced King of Portugal in Paris, both to visit, as a family party, the President and the Elysee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Resolutions passed by a local temperance organization in Maryland were recently forwarded to the Commissioner General of Immigration, Herman Stump. They alleged that the efforts of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union for helping immigrants at Ellis Island had been frustrated by six saloons on the Island, which greet the immigrants on their arrival.

A book is soon to be published entitled "International Reminiscences of a Society Woman." It is written by Mrs. James Mackin, widow of State Senator James Mackin, and formerly Miss Sallie Britton, a noted St. Louis belle. Mrs. Mackin has had a varied and wide experience, has traveled extensively, and enjoys the acquaintance of many prominent people, both in America and Europe.

One of the most audacious moves ever made in local politics was the appointment by the Committee on Organization of the Republican County Committee of a sub-committee in each Assembly district to revise the enrollment. The general enrollment will take place Nov. 23.

Among the passengers on the American Line steamship St. Louis, which arrived last night, were the thirty foreign vaudeville performers who are to appear to Hammerstein's Olympia Music Hall, Monday, Nov. 25.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 16. -- There is an old landmark in the town of Clinton that has attracted much attention and interest during the past year, in spite of the fact that it is in a state of comparative ruin. The ordinary observer might not mind it, and it is only as its ancient story is told that it becomes an object of public interest.

We recall in the history of American inventive industry no example of patience, steady persistence, and ever-reviving hope after repeated disappointment so impressive as that which is exhibited in the case of KEELY and his motor. Once more he is confident that success is near at hand.

The apparent obstacle which stands in the way of a bull market now is the export of gold. London has quieted down, and is no longer sending us hourly cable alarms. It has even stopped selling our securities. Railroad earnings generally are good, both present and prospective. Money is easy, prices have had a severe reaction from their September level.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 16. -- Lehigh defeated Annapolis to-day by a score of 6 to 4. All the scoring was done in the second half, and Lehigh won by the narrow margin of a goal kicked to one missed. Lehigh has pretty generally won on former occasions, but last year Annapolis took the game. Annapolis was confident of winning this year, and Lehigh was anxious to redeem herself.
QUINCY, Cal., Nov. 16. -- An Indian vendetta, which has already resulted in five deaths, is being waged between factions of redmen in the Genesee Valley.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 16. -- An Adams Express car on the Pennsylvania Railroad train that left here at 8:30 o'clock last night was entered by robbers near Morrisvllie, Penn.

The translator is reported to be badly paid by the publisher, and this, to the general reader, naturally suggests inferiority in the nature of his wares. He is generally ranked among the unskilled workmen who hang about the market place of literature and are glad of odd jobs.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 5. -- Don Guillermo E. Billinghurst, First Vice President of Peru, is a man of energetic character and sound common sense. Thrown on his own resources at an early age, owing to the death of his father, he made of himself the man of the family, liquidating his father's affairs, and, by dint of intelligence and hard work, has succeeded in building up the position and fortune which he at present enjoys.

In that wonderful story to be found in Rudyard Kipling's "Jungle Book" it may be read how the white cobra "had outlived his poison." The question arises how far is this true? Can a venomous snake, through old age, be deprived of its power of secreting venom? Experimentally this never has been proved, but there is a fair probability of this being the case.

The Heine Monument Fair was thrown open to the public last night, and the Lenox Lyceum, where the bazaar will be continued until Nov. 24, was filled with a large and distinguished gathering of people.

" And John Hutchinson, oh my! He is a pioneer. He sang abolition into the hearts of the people when the orators couldn't beat it into their brains," said Susan B. Anthony at the celebration of Mrs. Elizabeth Cady Stanton's birthday in the Metropolitan Opera House Tuesday.

The attention of the new Park Commissioners may profitably be directed to the condition of the so called plaza at the southwestern corner of the Central Park. Formerly the other plaza, at the southeastern corner, was in as bad a condition and equally the terror of whoever had occasion to cross it.

At the monthly meeting of the Montreal Folk Lore Society, on Monday last, Dr. W. George Beers read a paper entitled "The Last of the Hurons." The central figure in the paper was Zacharie Vincent, alias Telariolin, a Huron of Ancienne Lorette, born in 1808, a pure-blooded example of the great Huron-Iroquois stock.

LENOX, Mass., Nov. 16. -- The country houses are now nearly all closed. Many hastened to get away from Lenox early this week, so as to go to town to attend the Horse Show. There are, however, a few places which still remain open, including those of Richard Goodman, Mrs. William B. Bacon, Capt. John S. Barnes, and David W. Bishop.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- Judge Gibbons this morning declared the State law closing barbers' shops on Sunday unconstitutional as being class legislation. An appeal was at once taken by the Barbers' Sunday Closing Association, which accused, as prosecutor in the case, W.S. Eden, manager of a hotel, and the barbers who are under him are the defendants in the case.

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- There is a sort of chronic unrest in the office of the Fisheries, Game, and Forest Commission. The large force of men which this commission has to deal with is a constant source of disturbance, from the fact that the politicians are pulling and hauling to get favorites employed and are polling and hauling to save favorites from punishment who have been detected violating the law.
Ex-President Harrison spent most of yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. He was in the best of humor, but he declined to talk politics.

Howard Gould, who went abroad seven months ago to race his twenty-rater yacht Niagara against the cracks of her class there, arrived here late last night on the American Liner St. Louis. Mr. Gould looked extremely swell, and talked readily of his victories on the other side, but evidently did not care to express an opinion on the Dunraven incident.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The report that there was a serious uprising in Venezuela under the leadership of ex-President Rojas Paul was regarded here as exaggerated. It had long been known that considerable apprehension was felt in Venezuelan official circles concerning the purposes of Rojas Paul, and that, indeed, he had always been regarded by the Government as a dangerous man, ready to strike a blow at President Crespo whenever opportunity should offer.

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- The Edwin Booth Dramatic and Pleasure Society has been incorporated for sociability, and "charitable and literary debates and discussions." The office of the society is in New-York, and the Directors for the first year are: William Green, "Ike" Pastematk, Josef Friedman, Louis Wernersbach, Henry Wernersbach, and William S. Katzenstein.

Employes of the Union Pacific and the members of their immediate families to the number of 150 went out to Denver yesterday to see Father Schlatter, the "Messiah." Every one of them had an ailment of some description.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- A paragraph in the last Sundry Civil Appropriation bill reads as follows:

Town and country succeed one another. The train passes at full speed over low bridges, spanning broad rivers which flow between forests -- remains of forests, rather -- violated, massacred forests, whose vigorous vegetation still bears witness to the primitive splendor of this country before "the pale-faced destroyer of forests" had set foot upon it.

BOSTON, Nov. 16. -- The Rev. Dr. Samuel Francis Smith, author of the hymn. "America," is dead. Death came suddenly to Dr. Smith, without premonition or warning. Accompanied by Mr. Williams of the Baptist Publication Society, he to-day entered a car at the New-England Railroad Station. The train was to leave at 4:40 for Readville, where Dr. Smith was to preach to-morrow, in the interim being the guest of Mr. Williams.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 16. -- A beautiful day, a good-sized crowd, and one of the prettiest football games ever seen on Weston Field describe in a few words to-day's championship contest with Dartmouth.

The noted land suits of H.C. King of Boston, Mass., in which hundreds of people, hamlets, towns, timber companies, farmers, and miners in Logan, Mingo, McDowell, and in fact, nearly all of the southwestern part of West Virginia, are concerned, have come up for trial in the United States court, before Judge J.J. Jackson.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The Turkish Legation has received from the Sublime Porte the following telegram, under yesterday's date: "The Armenian rioters of Zeitoun and Marash attacked the villages of Fersakh and Bitchi. Those of Azirlon and of Tchokmerzemenk plundered Plas and other Mussulman villages, killed a great number of the inhabitants, and set fire to many houses.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- From information gathered this evening it is understood that Austria's proposal for the settlement of the Turkish question is the deposition of the Sultan and the appointment of a successor pledged to reform, the granting of some measure of local autonomy to Armenia, and the formation of an international commission to supervise the changes.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- Although we are apparently new within days, or even hours, of important events in the Orient, England is very much easier in mind about the whole business than it was a week ago. The action of Austria in assuming the initiative and formulating a proposition for concerted action of the European powers has given to the entire situation an altered tone, which people here observe with a deep sigh of relief.

James J. Barry, a private in Company B, Sixty-ninth Regiment, which is commanded by Capt. Edward T. McChrsytal, has mysteriously disappeared from his home, 450 Hicks Street, Brooklyn. It is feared that he has been the victim of foul play, or perhaps committed suicide by drowning himself while under temporary aberration of the mind, due to an injury received about the time of his disappearance.

Marriage customs in Finistere have remained among the peasants very much what they were centuries ago, and their old-fashioned ceremoniousness is not their least interesting peculiarity. The Breton peasant of to-day has an almost religious respect for those notions of polite manners which have come down to him from his forefathers of the Middle Ages, who, as far as they dared, imitated the etiquette of their Princes or nearer feudal Lords.

Few mining men in Montana are better known than is William Hall of Butte, who was for a long time the Superintendent of the Alice Mine, but is now operating in British Columbia. Mr. Hall is an Englishman and a practical miner. He began in the mines of the old country when he was a small boy, and that was something less than half a century ago.

VIENNA, Nov. 16. -- In the lower house of the Reichsrath to-day the Anti-Semites and Clericals violently attacked the Government for dissolving the Vienna Municipal Council because of the re-election of Dr. Lueger, the noted Anti-Semite leader in the Reichsrath, as Burgomaster, and contended that the Government's action was illegal.
A most remarkable railway accident recently occurred in Paris, and is described in The Engineer of London.

The Fifty-third Congress authorized the construction of two first-class battleships, and the plans for those vessels for the navy have been prepared, the designs completed for the inspection of shipbuilders, bids will soon be solicited for their construction at a cost of about $4,000,000 each, exclusive of armament, and the Fifty-fourth Congress will be asked to provide the money with which the work on the battleships may be prosecuted.

It is interesting to note that men well informed in the affairs of the cycling world are placing the output of wheels next year at high figures. H.E. Maslin of Syracuse puts it at 900,000, and A.G. Spalding thinks it will be 1,000,000. Should this estimate come true, there must necessarily be a decided boom in cycling as a pastime.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- Cornell defeated Brown University here to-day, 6 to 4, in the best game of football ever played on Percy Field. There was hardly a vacant foot of ground on the field, so dense was the crowd. The yelling and cheering was so deafening that the quarter backs had to wait for signals to be heard.

The commotion which has been caused in Denver, Col., and the surrounding lands by the so-called healer, SCHLATTER, and by his reported "mysterious disappearance" is, to use the favorite phraseology of the late Mr. CARLYLE, "significant of much," as to the superstition and credulity that may still be displayed in communities reputed to be intelligent.

Capt. S.B. Thorne of the Yale football team thought his men needed one good hard game to fit them for the contest with the Princeton Tigers, which is to take place next Saturday. A game with the Orange Athletic Club was arranged, and the Yale team yesterday afternoon won by a score of 26 to 0.

The skeleton of a woman was received at Police Headquarters yesterday. It arrived by Westcott's Express, and was addressed to Police Headquarters, 310 Mulberry Street. On the reverse of the card bearing the address was the following printed matter:

Prince Charles, to whom our Princess Maud has been betrothed, is not (writes one who knows him) so popular in Denmark as his eldest brother, Prince Christian. He is more quiet and unassuming, and cares less about the display and ceremonial of royalty than his brother, but in pluck and energy he has shown himself to be behind none.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- Robert Louis Stevenson, the great novelist, has a warm place in the hearts of Adirondackers, and his enthusiastic friends propose the erection of a granite column in his memory. The site of the proposed memorial is the very summit of Baker Mountain, the one especially favorite resort of the writer during his eight months' sojourn here.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 16. -- Among the improvements adopted by Vassar College from time to time, according to the best and most scientific usages of the day, has been one put into practical use this last year in regard to the disposal of the college sewage.

BERLIN, Nov. 3. -- The Royal Opera has been renovated within and without, rearranged, repainted, and especially regilded, just in time to entertain the King of Portugal. To-night we had a "theatre pare" in honor of his Majesty. The entire first balcony was reserved by the Emperor for the Court and special guests.

The admirers of the greatest of German lyric poets gathered in large numbers at the Lenox Lyceum last night, where the fair for the Heine Memorial Fund is now being held. The local German residents are united here in the determination to accomplish what many of the foremost municipalities of the fatherland have failed to bring about.

BERLIN, Nov. 17. -- Father Cerebotani, an Italian priest, who claims priority for the new pantelegraph, which presumably was invented by Elisha Gray, is announced to deliver a course of lectures here. His programme includes a series of practical illustrations of the workings of the invention.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- A largely attended mass meeting was held here to-day to protest against the massacres of Christians in Armenia. The proceedings of the Turks were strongly condemned, and the following message was cabled to the Marquis of Salisbury, the British Prime Minister:

" If a man in any of the civil departments of the public service had been guilty of the conduct of Commander William M. Folger of the United States Navy, he would find himself under indictment for bribery. Yes, and for perjury. This ma should be arraigned at once before a court-martial and dismissed in disgrace from the navy.
At the Church of the Holy Trinity, Brooklyn, the Rev. George T. Dowling, D.D., of Boston preached yesterday on John, x., 41: "John did no miracle."

Thomas Byrnes, ex-Chief of Police, has sent a telegraph from Vienna to his lawyers in this city, authorizing them to deny in the strongest manner the charges made by Christian Schaffer against his character before the Commissioner of Accounts on Nov. 11.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- John Fox, Jr., author of "A Cumberland Vendetta," addressed Vassar College Friday evening on the subject of "The Southern Mountaineers." After the lecture a reception was given to Mr. Fox by the Southern Club, of which he is an honorary member.

The feelings of horror and indignation stirred up in the breasts of New-York citizens by the atrocious massacres of Armenians by Turkish soldiers during recent months are growing stronger, deeper, and more intense, if the utterances yesterday of men qualified to speak on the subject may be taken as any criterion.

Following close upon the wreck of the Baranoff comes the loss of another equally famous pioneer of North Pacific waters -- the steamer Cariboo and Fly, which, according to a report received at Victoria, is now only a mass of drifting debris floating down the Skeena River to the sea.

The New-England Association of School Superintendents held its fifty-seventh meeting at the English High School yesterday. The first paper was on "Slant or Vertical Writing," by Miss Anna E. Hill, supervisor of penmanship in Springfield. She said at the outset that vertical writing has been delayed in adoption by unreasonable claims made for it.

Our conveyances were brought around, and we looked at them with some astonishment. There were two horses for my husband, and for myself and my little daughter were two of the State jampans, such as the court ladies would travel in. They were about the size and shape of a small boat, but most dreadfully heavy and cumbrous.

All the bowlers in the tournament of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs will be interested in the rules adopted last week by the Bowling Committee. The rules have not yet been printed in pamphlet form for distribution, but will be later on. They will read as follows:

The tennis season just ended has been a most successful one for local players. A number of the New-York and Brooklyn experts played prominently in the big open events last Summer, and their success has inspired others to try for laurels, so that already the prospects for next year are very bright.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17. -- The 'Varsity eleven will take but two more days' practice on the home grounds before their departure East for the Harvard game. They leave Tuesday night for an unknown destination in the State of Massachusetts, which even they themselves are unaware of. An advance messenger was sent to Massachusetts to select a suitable site for the short sojourn, which the men will make until the game at Cambridge.

The housesmiths and bridgemen held a mass meeting in Clarendon Hall yesterday afternoon in response to a "red-letter" call to make arrangements for a general strike on buildings to-day. The men came early and crowded the sidewalks and lobbies, and when the doors were opened they made a rush and soon packed the ballroom.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The annual report of the General Superintendent of the life-saving stations shows that during the last fiscal year the number of disasters within the scope of the service exceeds that of any previous year by seventy-nine. This large excess is in a measure found to be due to the extension of the service, but principally to the conditions of weather which prevailed during the year.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 17. -- The bodies of fifteen victims of last night's catastrophe were to-day recovered. This accounts for all but four of the passengers known to have been on the car at the time it made its plunge from the open Central Viaduct draw into the Cuyahoga River.

A "theatre mecanique" was among the most carefully guarded freight on the American Line steamship St. Louis, that arrived Saturday night. It is the property of M. Hewelt, a sculptor of Paris, who is its inventor, and it is said to be one of the greatest stage novelties ever shown in Europe.

The Police Commissioners have decided to go back to the old system of ward detectives which was abolished by ex-Chief of Police Byrnes, who held that the ward detective was, to a certain extent, responsible for the great bribery and corruption that existed in the Police Department.

William H. Stayton of 45 Cedar Street, who resigned from the United States Navy in 1891 to take up the practice of law in this city, gave an interesting interview yesterday to a reporter of THE NEW-YORK TIMES relating to the history of the battleships Texas and Maine.

BERLIN, Nov. 17. -- Prince von Hohenlohe, since his conference with the Emperor Thursday, has intimated to Count Goluchowski, Austrian Minister of Foreign Affairs, that Germany will consent to discuss the question of united action on the part of the European powers toward Turkey, so far as providing protection to Christians and maintaining order are concerned.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 17. -- Representatives of thirty Greek letter societies arrived here to-day from different sections of the country to attend the Pan-Hellenic Congress which will meet to-morrow at the Exposition Auditorium. About eighty fraternities will be represented, and a Pan-Hellenic League will be organized.

The latest news from Turkey is that the persecution of the Christians throughout the disturbed parts of the empire is more extensive and more calamitous even than had before been believed or reported. It shows also that the Turks have inflicted upon this country the same grievance that it has lately suffered at the hands of China, the buildings of the American mission having been sacked and destroyed in the massacre of Harput.

BERLIN, Nov. 17. -- The Emperor's pet dog, a Russian greyhound, was shot maliciously and wounded badly a few days ago by unknown persons at Potsdam. The Vorwaerts, the Socialist organ, prints a humorous article about it under the caption, "Attentat auf den Hund des Kaisers," (Attempt upon the Life of the Emperor's Dog.) and will probably get into trouble for doing so, as the Emperor is greatly incensed at the article.

Mr. AUSTIN CORBIN returns, in a paper entitled "Quick Transit Between New-York and London," in the current number of The North American Review, to his old topic of the desirableness and possibility of shortening the voyage between New-York and London by making the first hundred miles of it over the Long Island Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- In transmitting to the Secretary of the Navy the annual report of Lieut. A.P. Niblack, United States Navy, on the operations of the naval militia, Assistant Secretary McAdoo says that the organizations in the various States are growing rapidly, and that the public interest in them is steadily increasing.

TOTTENVILLE, S.I., Nov. 17. -- Henry Winant and Gottfried Carsten, two old and respected residents of Pleasant Plains, who have for years been warm friends, met as bitter enemies in Justice Smith's courtroom, at this place, last evening. Mr. Winant is the plaintiff and Mr. Carsten is the defendant in a suit for trespass and damages, resulting from a practical joke played on the plaintiff some time during election night.

The marriage of Miss Irene Stuyvesant Black and Mr. George Barry Mallon will take place Tuesday evening of this week. The residence of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William T. Black, 149 West Ninety-third Street, will be profusely adorned with flowers for the occasion.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- A local paper says this morning:

VINELAND, N.J., Nov. 17. -- The four-year-old daughter of John Harvey of Quince Street attempted to eat a handful of hot coals last night, and is believed to be dying from the effects. The child was alone in the parlor of the house at the time. The mother was busy in another portion of the house.

A two weeks' celebration of the ninetieth anniversary of the Bedford Street Methodist Episcopal Church was begun yesterday with eleven services, which began at 6 o'clock in the morning and ended at 7:30 in the evening.

Policeman Quirk of the West Twentieth Street Police Station arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday Gabriel Marchanol, thirty-five, a real estate and fire insurance agent, at 70 Seventh Avenue, on a charge of having attempted to burn the five-story tenement house at 104 Seventh Avenue early yesterday morning.

Jacob Beresheim, the fourteen-year-old self-confessed murderer of William Krauel, whose body was found in the rear of his restaurant, 1,252 Second Avenue, last Monday morning, was, for the first time, arraigned before Magistrate Kudlich, in the Centre Street Police Court, yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The Turkish Legation here received, under to-day's date, the following telegram from the Sublime Porte:

It has passed into a proverb that the equine part of the National Horse Show is merely an lncJdenu to the display made by sociely. I-laving had their innings, the fashionable folks retire after a week of triumphant and continued receptioxP. The horses are now the real actors, and remain at the (}arden for another six days. Not all of them, to.be sure, but a large proportion, including several prizewinners.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Secretary Morton's third annual report is a briefer document than the two which preceded it. It discusses the work of the several bureaus of the department, asserting that expenditures have been reduced in some of them for the sake of economy, and increased in others for the sake of efficiency.

Achille Rivarde, a young Spanish violinist, who has just entered his twenty-eighth year, made his American debut last night at Carnegie Hall. The concert was not one of the regular series of Sunday concerts, but a special entertainment arranged by the managers of the violinist. Mr. Seidl was engaged to conduct and Mme. De Vere-Sapio to sing.
LONDON, Nov. 17. -- The Daily News will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Constantinople, dated Nov. 16, saying that the most serious anxiety prevails, and the situation is becoming worse.
" This promises to be a Winter of discontent to the police and a Summer of harvest to thieves in Washington," announced Detective Weedon at headquarters last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- "BOSS" Quay of Pennsylvania, who just now is catching tarpon in Florida, is credited with the composition of a ticket which his henchmen declare will be adopted by the House caucus on Nov. 30. This is it:
WEST HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 17. -- John Smith, thirty-six years old, of 274 Spring Street, was shot by a burglar at 2 o'clock this morning. He is in Christ Hospital, and will probably die.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 17. -- The Harvard football season will be brought to a close on Saturday next by the game with Pennsylvania on Soldiers' Field. This is about a week earlier than usual. The Harvard Faculty insisted on this shortening of the period of training.

Much misinformation has recently been published about the domestic woolen industry. Leading Republican journals in the East have asserted that the industry was in a very deplorable condition, their aim being to gain popular support for a bill restoring the tariff duties on wool and incidentally, we presume, to depress the industry, if possible, by their own pessimistic utterances.

Benjamin F. Stover is a well-to-do carpenter, living in Aaronsburg, a little country village that nestles between the Brush and Seven Mountains, not far from Bellefonte. He works wherever his services are demanded in that vicinity. His son, Clarence, having reached his seventeenth year, is an apprentice to the trade of his father.

The Cunard steamship Campania arrived here yesterday morning about thirty hours overdue. For the first three days out from Queenstown the vessel encountered tremendous seas and heavy winds that retarded her progress so that she covered not more than half the distance she would have covered in ordinary circumstances.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The Naval Engineer Corps is threatened with complete extinction, much to the concern of the officers of that branch. Engineer in Chief Melville has called the attention of Secretary Herbert to the matter, and the circumstance forms one portion of the annual report of Commodore Melville which escaped the eagle eye of the departmental editor.

The reports just now made of the doings of the Society for the Improvement of the Condition of the Poor contain suggestions for those who would do good by stealth or otherwise and not run the risk of wasting their substance or of encouraging the willfully idle or worthless.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Arrangements have been made for an interesting test to be held at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The experiments will be on a large scale to determine the value of liquid fuel on board torpedo boats and the smaller types of vessels. Some such experiments have been attempted abroad, and enough is already known of the fuel to warrant further inquiry.

The filing of the certificates of election expenses of the candidates for State offices shows how cheaply office seeking may be conducted by a prominent person under the new ballot law. It is rather hard that the defeated candidates should be required to file statements which so often show that they have paid more money to be defeated than it has cost their competitors to be elected.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 17. -- The first of the series of three dances given every year by the Stevens Social Society was held Tuesday evening in the Stevens Hall. It was well attended and was altogether a most successful affair. The patronesses were Mrs. Morton, Mrs. Mayer, Mrs. Leeds, Mrs. Stillman, Mrs. Richard Stevens, and Mrs. Smith.

FREDERICK, Md., Nov. 17. -- James Goings, a young negro, begged food at the residence of Hamilton Geisbert, near this city, yesterday afternoon. After eating voraciously he attacked Miss Lizzie Jones, who was alone in the house. The negro broke her nose and cut her with a razor. He was arrested, and held for a hearing Monday.

The first Orthodox Greek Church in this country for the exclusive use of Syrian worshippers in that faith was dedicated and consecrated at 77 Washington Street yesterday afternoon by Nicolas, Orthodox Greek Bishop of Alaska and the Aleutian Islands.

When a man as prominently identified yith the cycling industry as A.G. Spalding gives an opinion anent the volume of business for next year, devotees of the popular pastime everywhere will lend an ear. Mr. Spalding, as President of the National Board of Trade of Cycle Manufacturers, and one of the foremost makers of wheels himself, has an opportunity accorded to few to study carefully the fuller details of the cycling industry.

A man who might have been either a victim of mountain ague or liquor took his place before Schlatter to receive a treatment. The "gifted" cobbler started perceptibly at sight of him. Then with evident reluctance Schlatter took the man's right hand in his, while a convulsive shudder racked the "healer's" unsymmetrical frame.

A special detail of six policemen were sent to the Metropolitan Opera House last night in the expectation that there would be a big crush outside. The policemen had little to do. There were no crowds, and the carriages were so few that there was not the slightest sign of disorder.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18. -- The argument for a new trial for the convicted murderer, H.H. Holmes, was heard to-day, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, and this remarkable case furnished another sensation.

Arrangements for the mass meeting called by the Armenian Relief Association for Thursday evening, in Chickering Hall, are being satisfactorily completed. The meeting will be one of representative men, without reference to creed, nationality, or politics, and there will be expression of opinion from clergymen and laymen as to Turkish atrocities.

Lord DUNRAVEN is a most astonishing person. In the midst of the great storm provoked by his charge of cheating against the Defender he comes to the fore with a cablegram to Mr. H. MAITLAND KERSEY offering to sail for America on the 4th of December in order to appear before the committee of the New-York Yacht Club and substantiate his charges.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

The Chickering Hall meeting of protest against the Turkish butchery of Armenians will serve the very useful purpose of introducing a moral element into a question that the great powers of Europe have discussed almost wholly from the point of view of politics. The English press has been very little stirred up by the mere bloodshed in Armenia.

The Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge met yesterday afternoon to decide what system of electricity should be adopted for switching trains at both ends of the bridge, and also to settle the vexed question of whether street railroad tracks should be allowed on the Plaza or not, and if allowed, under what conditions.

To dispose of 400 head of horses at auction in two days is the formidable task which W.D. Grand began at Madison Square Garden yesterday. This business sequel to the Horse Show brought an unusually large crowd for the daytime, and the attendance last night was a record breaker for this city.
LONDON, Nov. 18. -- The Anglo-Armenian Assoiation has reeived the following telegram from Constantinople:
The Commissioners of Accounts began a public investigation of the Building Department yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The revelations in THE NEW-YORK TIMES to-day regarding Commander William M. Folger of the navy, created quite a stir in the Navy Department. Folger is at present on leave of absence in Japan. He was relieved of the command of the Yorktown Nov. 1 and ordered to return to this country, but asked and was granted an extension of time until Dec. 7, when he will sail.

The investigations of the present Commissioners of Accounts have thus far been judiciously chosen and judiciously conducted. There has not, however, been a more interesting or fruitful field of investigation than that upon which they have now entered. For it is really a question whether for the past few years that department has been of any public service at all, and whether the city would not have been better off without it.

Word of the death of Samuel Barton, in his apartments at the Dakota, Saturday evening, caused many expressions of regret in the financial district yesterday. Mr. Barton appeared in Wall Street only seldom since he retired from the brokerage firm of Work, Davis Barton, in 1883. When he re-entered business, in 1885, with the firm of J.W. Davis Co., he located himself in the firm's up-town office, near the Grand Central Station.
It is much to be hoped that the fair now in progress, which has for its object the raising of funds for the Heine Monument, may succeed in its purpose.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 18. -- The news that the United States Supreme Court had decided adversely to Theodore Lambert in his appeal from a conviction of murder in the first degree reached here this afternoon. Lambert is now under sentence of death in the county jail here.

William C. Whitney, J. Pierpont Morgan, and George L. Rives were appointed last night by the New-York Yacht Club a committee to investigate the charges made by Lord Dunraven regarding the changing of the ballast of the Defender. They were given full power to represent the club and to take any action they may see proper.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 18. -- James Thompson, George Caulfield, and John Berry, Commissioners of Appraisal for the new reservoir for the New-York Waterworks, at Purdy's Station, being constructed by the Aqueduct Commission, have filed their second separate report. It treats of 561 1/2 acres.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Commodore Sicard, commandant of the New-York Navy Yard and ex-Chief of Naval Ordnance, has attacked the plans for the new battleships authorized by the last Congress, and for which the Navy Department two months ago called for bids, which will be opened the 30th inst.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day reversed the order of Judge Hughes of the Federal court for the Eastern District of Virginia, releasing James Van Vranken from the custody of John F. McGlensil, an officer of the United States Navy.

The Aldermen, sitting as a Board of County Canvassers, counted the vote of the Seventeenth Senate District yesterday, in which the Page-O'Sullivan-McManus Senatorial contest has been attracting so much attention. The Senatorial district is made up of the Fifteenth, Seventeenth, and Nineteenth Assembly Districts.

" I don't know what is the trouble," said the young woman of many interests, whose aureole of deep auburn hair encircled a delicate face, "but since I have been around in the streets, cars, and elevated trains so much, something has happended to my temper.

A Richmond County correspondent inquires whether "the Greater New-York" would not lose from 15 to 20 per cent. of its representation in the Legislature under the provision of the Constitution "limiting the proportion of representation to be held by any one city."

There was a well-attended meeting of the Atchison Reorganization Committee in this city yesterday, and matters relating to the selection of Directors and a President for the new company were discussed. No definate action was taken, however, and another meeting will be held to-day.
Ex-President Harrison was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel almost all day yesterday. The politicians said there was no longer any doubt about his being a candidate for a renomination for the Presidency.

Wheelmen bowlers in Greater New-York are showing a lively interest in the big tournament beginning this evening under the auspices of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs. The games will be rolled on Reid's alleys, in Church Street, near Suane, throughout the entire tourney, beginning each evening at 8 P.M. Eleven teams will take part.

There seems to be a general skepticism on the subject of obtaining more "liberal excise laws," or "local option" on the question of Sunday liquor selling, from the next Legislature, more than two-thirds of whose members in each house will be Republicans. Practical politicians and practical reformers would do well to consider carefully the alternatives in this matter, for one of three things is sure to happen in the next two years.

MADRID, Nov. 18. -- A dispatch from Havana to The Heraldo says that Gen. Martinez Campos denies the truth of the reports that an armistice has been agreed upon in Cuba, or that it has even been contemplated.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Nov. 18. -- Engineer James D. Ackerman of the New-Jersey and New-York Railroad had for his dinner yesterday an eel which he caught under peculiar circumstances.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 18. -- Attorney General Hancock this evening gave out his decision in the case of C.A. Whelan Co. of Syracuse against the American Tobacco Company, a proceeding preliminary to the commencement of an action to prohibit the American Company from doing business in this State.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Nov. 9. -- Matters in this section have not materially changed in the last few weeks. The insurgents are not only holding their own, but are steadily gaining the upper hand and advancing westward. It is generally understood that the Spanish troops have been badly defeated recently in this neighborhood, with the loss of several guns.

Counsel for Edward M. Grout yesterday submitted briefs to Justice Cullen of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, in the mandamus proceedings to compel the city and county canvassers to correct errors; that is, to count ballots which have been returned as defective. Argument in this matter was heard Saturday.

Senator-elect Ellsworth of Lockport, Niagara County, who has been slated by Mr. Platt for President pro tem. of the Senate, came to this city yesterday. He hurried to 49 Broadway, and had a long talk with the "boss."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18. -- The battleship Indiana, which has been lying off Cramps' shipyard, left her anchorage about 1:30 o'clock this afternoon, and, in tow of four tugs of the Red Star Line, was taken down to League Island, where on Wednesday the formal transfer of the Indiana to the Government will take place, and she will be put in commission.

A building trades strike which, it is feared, may involve many thousands of men began yesterday by 1,000 men leaving work on twenty buildings in course of erection by J.B. J.M. Cornell and by Milliken Brothers, in New-York and Brooklyn. These men are all housesmiths and structural and architectural ironworkers.

The paintings that adorn the walls of the Court of Oyer and Terminer in the new Criminal Court Building, in Centre Street, were presented to the city yesterday afternoon by the Municipal Art Society with appropriate ceremonies, and an important art event was commemorated.

The rejection of the Heine Memorial which the Germans of New-York intended to be a gift to the city, to be erected in some prominent place, was strongly recommended to the Park Board yesterday by the National Sculpture Society.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Senator Vest, who is in Washington, declares in an interview that hard times and scarcity of money caused the sweeping defeat of the Democrats in the recent election. Mr. Vest's remarks on the subject smack more of Populism than Democracy. In the face of the evident prosperity which the country is enjoying, he indulges in the following claptrap:

BALTIMORE, NOV. 18. -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company to-day made a departure from the policy of limiting the Directory to the controlling interests of the company within Maryland by giving recognition to large outside interests. Four Directors, representing the London and New-York holders of the stock, were elected by the stockholders at their sixty-ninth annual meeting, held in the Baltimore and Ohio Central Building.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Nov. 18. -- The Norton Line steamship Manitoba, inward bound to New-York from Rio Janeiro, shoved her bow into the sand off Beach Haven early this morning and could not get it out again. She is held fast, but is in no danger, and will doubtless be floated at high tide to-morrow morning.

The interior of the Metropolitan Opera House last night presented a brilliant sight. Society was on dress parade. The horse-shoe of boxes, sometimes called "the diamond horse-shoe," had a setting of the prettiest and best-gowned women in New-York.

Jane May, highly esteemed in Paris as an actress, and especially as a representative of nimble, saucy, conscienceless Pierrot, in pantomime, appeared at Daly's Theatre last night, in "Miss Pygmalion," a new play without words, by Michel Carre and Jane May, with a musical accompaniment for piano, strings, and wood wind by Francois Thome.

There was a large attendance yesterday at the first day's sale by Bangs Co. of the library of David Adee, and high prices prevailed. The total sales for the day reached $3,043. Among the well-known buyers present were Beverly Chew, the President of the Grolier Club; J.H. Purdy, E.H. Bierstadt, J.O. Wright McDonough of Albany, Mr. Rigby of Philadelphia, and representatives of Dodd, Mead Co. and the Scribners.

The Inter-State Commerce Commission, consisting of Col. William R. Morrison of Illinois, Judson C. Clements of Georgia, Martin A. Knapp of New-York, and James D. Yeomans of Iowa, convened in Room 73 of the Federal Building, in this city, yesterday, to investigate the complaints of the Milk Producers' Protective Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- At the adjourned meeting of the Bar of the Supreme Court of the United States this morning Secretary Olney presided and James H. McKenny, Clerk of the Court, acted as Secretary. Assistant Attorney General Dickinson, Chairman of the Committee on Resolutions, appointed at the meeting Oct. 14, reported resolutions expressing the high esteem of the Bar of the Supreme Court for the late Associate Justice Howell Edmonds Jackson of Tennessee.
Several important features made memorable the one hundred and twenty-seventh annual dinner of the Chamber of Commerce at Delmonico's last evening.

It was very high ground that Secretary CARLISLE took before the Chamber of Commerce last evening, and he maintained it with dignity, force, and brilliancy. The exposition of the perils to which the country is exposed from the "practically unlimited" demand made upon the gold reserve by the notes that must be "continually redeemed" and can "never be paid" was very lucid.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The probability that the Hawaiian Congress will pass a measure pensioning Princess Kaiulani is foreshadowed in unofficial advices which reach here to-day from Honolulu.

Mr. Ford has the true humorist's habit of girding at the traditions. In reading carefully his new book, which is, in point of sustained effort, his most important work thus far, one is impressed chiefly by his almost abject submission to this habit. It has grown upon him so strongly that it has become second nature.

The big meeting of the New-York Yacht Club on Monday night, C. Oliver Iselin's answer to Lord Dunraven's charges, the committee appointed to investigate these charges, and Lord Dunraven's offer to come back, were all discussed freely in yachting circles yesterday. The appointment of J. Pierpont Morgan, William C. Whitney, and George L. Rives as a committee to investigate, with full power to act, was commended by all.
Mr. Julius Friend has sold for Joseph Schultz the property at 87 Crosby Street and 52 Marion Street, 26 by 173.6, with two old buildings, and has resold the same to a client.

The six-story building at 98 Clinton Street was destroyed by fire yesterday in less than an hour. The blaze started about 11 o'clock in the basement, where Adolph Bauch had a candle factory, and is thought to have been caused by the boiling over of a vat of wax.
Little progress was made yesterday toward a settlement of the differences between employers and employes involved in the architectural ironworkers' strike.

Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn, speaking of the desire of the railroad companies to get possession of the bridge plaza, yesterday said that, if the vote of the Trustees Monday was any indication, he judged the railroad companies could succeed in their purpose. A number of citizens, he said, had told him they were willing to bring an action in the courts against the Trustees should they vote in favor of the companies.
" If they throw this case out of court, we will have one that they won't next time. We are learning something now."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Capt. Healy telegraphs from San Francisco that he is preparing a reply to the charges of inefficiency and neglect of duty preferred against him. He will forward his defense here in about ten days. No reply was received from him until to-day.

It is naturally assumed that one of the things that the next Legislature is sure to do is to make preparation for carrying out the "popular mandate" of 1894 in regard to the consolidation of certain territory across the river and across the bay with the "municipal corporation known as the Mayor, Aldermen, and Commonalty of the City of New-York."

Over $50,000 were realized yesterday from the first day's sale of the personal property of Mrs. Sarah A. Smith, widow of Richard Smith of MacKellar, Smith Jordan, type founders of Philadelphia.
