Mrs. Smith ordered by will the sale of the property to procure funds for constructing a playground and house for children in Fairmount Park, Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The President today appointed John L. Peake of Kansas City, Mo., as Minister to Switzerland, vice Broadhead, resigned, and Otto Munchmeyer of West Virginia as Consul at San Salvador, Salvador.

In the formation of a new joint traffic association, which was practically completed yesterday by the Presidents of the trunk lines and their Western connections, the railroad companies interested have taken a step of much more than ordinary significance. Never before have so many great railroad systems bound themselves by an agreement, so carefully considered and so elaborately contrived, to regulate and maintain rates on both freight and passenger traffic.
ROME, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- A mail train on the New-York Central went into the ditch early this morning as the result of the operations of train wreckers.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--Daniel H. Brenizer, Secretary and Treasurer of the Citizens' Trust and Surety Company, is, according to a story which The Philadelphia Times will print to-morrow, a defaulter to the extent of about $25,000.
The trial of David F. Hannigan for the murder of Solomon H. Mann nears its end. The evidence will probably be submitted to the jury to-night.
LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Rustem Pasha, the Turkish Ambassador to Great Britain, died at 3 o'clock this morning.

It is very evident that ice skating is to develop into a fashionable amusement this Winter, and will divide interest with indoor cycling and bowling. The success of the St. Nicholas Club social organization last Winter and the erection of their new and palatial skating rink this Fall has turned attention of amusement caterers to the sport.
When the Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday in the Mayor's office, Controller Fitch had some things to say that made the meeting unusually interesting.

After giving a few finishing touches to the much-discussed new joint traffic agreement, the representatives of all the railroads in the Trunk Line Association and the Central Traffic Association gave it their unqualified approval yesterday afternoon. The vote on the adoption of the agreement was unanimous, and the Joint Traffic Association thus formed will become operative Jan. 1, 1896.

Arrangements for the visit of representative New-York merchants and business men to the Atlanta Exposition have been completed, and there is ample promise that the trip will be both enjoyable and memorable.
The New-York and New-Jersey Bridge Company met at 214 Broadway yesterday and elected the following Board of Directors:

The crowd was not quite so large yesterday at the sale of the library of David Adee by Bangs Co. as it was on the first day, but the bidding was more spirited. Among the new buyers present were Harry B. Smith, the librettist, and Francis Tomes. Among the books sold were the following:

FORT PLAIN, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Superintendent of the Poor Perry Kline applied to County Judge Wendell, in this village, to-day for commitment papers consigning Edward Wemple, ex-State Controller, ex-Senator, and ex-Congressman, to the State Asylum for the Insane. Judge Wendell declined to grant the petition on finding that the examining physicians making out their report had endeavored to evade the responsibility of pronouncing Wemple Insane.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- An incident that is unparalleled in the annals of English diplomacy occurred this evening at the conference of the Colonial agents in London. This was the reading of a letter from the Sultan of Turkey to Lord Salisbury, begging him to make a speech that would offset the one he delivered on the occasion of the banquet given by the new Lord Mayor of London.

TUESDAY -- P.M. Prices to-day were influenced by news generally of an unfavorable character. London was decidedly weak, being well below parity at the opening of our market. Louisville and Nashville was the principal sufferer, being more than a point down. All the European Bourses closed weak, with notable liquidation at Paris and London.

Several State Superintendents of Insurance met in this city a few days ago to consider the question of refusing to issue new licenses or to renew existing ones to German insurance companies for doing business in this country. This movement is frankly one of retaliation on account of requirements imposed upon American insurance companies in Germany, which were intended to exclude them from prosecuting their business in that country.

ALBANY, Nov. 19. -- The State Railroad Commissioners believe that the inquiry of the Inter-State Commerce Commission into the question of milk rates will result in destroying the uniform system of getting an ample supply of milk into New-York City daily.

IRONTON, Ohio, Nov. 19. -- Miss Clara Campbell, who figured in the famous Arbuckle breach-of-promise case as "Bunny," died at 1 o'clock this morning at the Hanging Rock Sanitarium. An operation was performed upon her for tumor last week, and she had been gradually sinking since Sunday evening. Miss Campbell was forty-five years old.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 19. -- By the time Commander William M. Folger of the navy, who is now on leave of absence in Japan, reaches this country, steps will probably have been taken by the Secretary of the Navy to bring him before a court-martial, to answer the serious charges involved in the revelations in THE NEW-YORK TIMES concerning his connection with the Harvey Steel Company.

The dense fog that enveloped New-York, Brooklyn, Jersey City, and Staten Island yesterday morning was the most impenetrable of all the fogs that have been this year. It came down from Long Island Sound about 6:30 o'clock and lasted a little more than three hours.

The promoters of the Heine Memorial Fair are agreeably surprised to find that the resolution of the National Sculpture Society has given the enterprise a very profitable impetus, the Lenox Lyceum having been crowded to the doors last night, and the day's receipts having been the largest up to date.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Several prominent New-Yorkers are here to attend the marriage to-morrow of Miss Joy Lindsley to Dr. Edward Augustus Ayers of New-York City. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Van Sinderen Lindsley, formerly of Nashville, Tenn., who built herself a fine mansion on Massachusetts Avenue a few years ago.

We took occasion yesterday, not for the first time, to commend the work of the fair held to provide means for the erection of a monument to HEINE. But, of course, any commendation of such a project involves not only the memorableness of the subject, but the worthiness of the memorial.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- The property occupied by the City Club will be sold at auction Saturday. The sale, it is said, is the result of a friendly suit to clear up the affairs of the club.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Secretary Herbert has promulgated a general order reprimanding Col. James Forney, United State Marine Corps, in accordance with the findings of the court-martial which tried him on charges of irregularities alleged to have been committed while he was serving as commandant of the marines at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- The cross-country run and the hunt ball of the Meadowbrook Club, which was held at the New Garden City Hotel, at Garden City, to-night, eclipsed everything that has ever before been held by the hunting set on Long Island. The festivities commenced in the afternoon, when the largest number of huntsmen present in the saddle this year assembled at the Queens County Fair Grounds, where the hunt party met.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Nov. 19. -- Express Train No. 3 on the Great Northern Railroad was stopped by armed robbers eight miles from St. Cloud, at 10 o'clock last night, but no booty was secured.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The Turkish Legation here received from the Sublime Porte the following telegram, under to-day's date:
An accident on the Brooklyn end of the big bridge during the dense fog yesterday morning at 7:20 o'clock cost the lives of two men.

Joseph Barth of Stapleton, S.I., the assistant manager of the Bechtel Brewing Company, was to have been married to-day to Miss Clara Madeline Walter of 130 West Fifty-seventh Street, this city, but it is now announced that the wedding will not take place. Lawyers representing the engaged couple met Friday and all letters and presents were exchanged.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Statement of the condition of the United States Treasury and the receipts and expenditures of the Government on the 20th day of November, 1895:

BOSTON, Nov. 20. -- The market for local stocks was very dull, and the tone on the whole weak, though the better class of investment securities held up well, and advances in some cases were made. The telephone stocks were quiet, with Bell down 1, to 199, and New-England Telephone off 1 1/4, to 85. Mexican Central 4s were down 3/4, to 67, and the first incomes off 1/2 to 20 1/2.

The American Liner St. Louis sailed yesterday with thirty diamond workers bound for Holland. About fifty others preceded them last week, and the 175 workers who are participating in the strike in this city will probably follow soon. This will leave New-York diamond merchants practically helpless.

What is believed to be the finest copy in existence of the Earl of Surrey's "Songs, and Sonnets" was purchased yesterday at the third day's sale of the David Adee Library, by J.O. Wright, who paid $1,680, the next highest bidder being G.H. Richmond. This is one of the rarest volumes of poetry in the English language.

The eighth triennial Synod of the clergy of the Archdiocese of New-York began at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, with the celebration of low mass, in St. Patrick's Cathedral, by the Rev. Michael J. Lavelle, Archbishop Corrigan being on the throne. Appointments were made as follows:

Your excellent paper has put lovers of Heine so greatly into its debt by its hearty encouragement of the Loreley fountain project, and by devoting so much valuable space regarding the fair, that I trust you will not consider it unduly captious if I ask you to correct the serious error contained in the editorial printed in to-day's issue.

We remark with wonder the published opinions of several yachtsmen that in case Lord DUNRAVEN fails to make good the foul charges he has brought against Mr. ISELIN it will not necessarily follow that he must be expelled from the New-York Yacht Club. In the name of all that is either logical or honorable, what else can follow?
A meeting of women was held yesterday afternoon at the residence of Bishop Potter, 10 Washington Square, to organize a "Women's Auxiliary to the New-York Civil Service Reform Association."

It was decided yesterday afternoon by the Sinking Fund Commission to locate the New-York terminus of the New-York and New-Jersey Bridge between the southerly side of West Fifty-ninth Street and the northerly side of West Sixtieth Street, 100 feet west of Eleventh Avenue. This location has a frontage of 320 feet.

The first day of the convention of the State Federation of Women's Clubs opened with such a gathering of women, in spite of the inclement weather yesterday morning, that the lecture room in the Young Women's Christian Association Building, Brooklyn, was more than comfortably filled.

PORT HURON, Mich., Nov. 20. -- The steamer J.B. Ketcham, lumber laden, arrived here at noon to-day in a dismantled condition. The Montgomery broke away from the Ketcham during the night, and was driven ashore near Cull Drain, Ontario. She will prove a total wreck.

WEDNESDAY -- P.M. Professional traders regarded to-day's news as somewhat more reassuring. Home conditions, barring the gold shipments, are by no means discouraging, but the uncertainty prevailing abroad holds in check any disposition there may be on the part of outsiders to buy stocks, even at the low level now existing.

The grain trading was confined to local scalpers, as outside news was very scarce and without importance, while the general run of prices was to steadiness. Provisions were influenced by the heavy receipts of swine and closed weak. Cotton was unsettled, but closed at an advance. Coffee was freely offered and closed lower.

There is a naivete about the Sultan's letter to Lord SALISBURY asking him to make another speech, and this time in defense of him, that is at the same time pathetic, amusing, and exasperating. No one who has come into personal relations with the Sultan doubts the general sincerity and good purposes of the man.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- It is evident from the tone of the comment heard here from Republicans on Mr. Carlisle's New-York speech that they regard themselves as much better prepared to take up and dispose of the revenue question by a return to McKinley lines than they are to supply a solution to the proposition renewed by Secretary Carlisle to get rid of the ever-redeemable but never-redeemed greenbacks.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 20. -- The Grand Lodge of New-Jersey, I.O.O.F., convened in Masonic Temple this forenoon. Grand Master John H. Griffiths called the body to order. There was a large number of Past Grand Masters present, who, with the representatives from the subordinate lodges, made up an attendance altogether of nearly 500.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

PURCELL, Indian Territory, Nov. 20. -- The Star Store was on fire early yesterday morning. A high wind blew, and the flames spread rapidly and soon ravaged the entire north side of the street, made up of frame buildings. The Chickasaw National Bank Building and Kanoff's hardware store are the only buildings left standing on that side of the street.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 20. -- Vice Chancellor Emery continued the five phonograph suits, in one of which Thomas A. Edison sues to recover from John R. Hardin, as receiver of the North American Phonograph Company, over $78,000 on a promissory note.

What was declared to be a reopening of the Potter-Luscomb feud, a matter with which the cyclists of the Empire State are well acquainted, caused a ripple of excitement Tuesday evening at the annual meeting of the Good Roads Association, held at 1,217 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn. The fuss came about through the nomination of two prominent wheelmen for the office of First Vice President.

ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- There has just been issued from the office of the Regents of the University an "Extension Bulletin" on "Extension of University Teaching in England and America," which Secretary Dewey styles "a study in practical pedagogies," and which he says is a very valuable manual for those who wish to understand clearly this modern movement.
The young Ladies and Gentlemen's League of the Monteflore Home for Chronic Invalids gave an entertainment, followed by dancing, last night in the Recital Hall of the Carnegie Music Hall.
BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- A dispatch received here from Sofia, Bulgaria, says that the Sultan of Turkey, Abdul Hamid, has been poisoned. No details are given.

The cold wave which was announced by the Weather Bureau Tuesday night reached this city yesterday. At 8 o'clock Tuesday night the temperature was 52, and there was no great change until after noon yesterday, when the fall began in earnest.

Miss Elsie Stillman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Stillman, and William G. Rockefeller, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Rockefeller of 689 Fifth Avenue, will be married at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon in St. Bartholomew's Church in Madison Avenue. The ceremony will be performed by Bishop Henry C. Potter, assisted by the Rev. Dr. David H. Greer, rector of the church.
Sir Henry Irving talked yesterday afternoon to 1,000 Columbia and Barnard College students and their friends in the reading room of the college library.

ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- One of the earliest measures which will be introduced in the Legislature, probably by Senator John Raines, will be an act to authorize the Secretary of State to issue transportation over railroads in this State to State officers, Legislators, Judicial officers, and such subordinates in State officers as the heads of those departments may indicate.

William B. Van Houten, who was detained in the Oak Street Police Station over Tuesday night for being one of a throng gathered before a Nassau Street restaurant where a waitress clad in bloomers was the attraction, is much incensed over his arrest.

Although Senator John Sherman declared yesterday to the reporters that he did not see any popular sentiment running in the direction of the renomination of ex-President Harrison, the Senator and the ex-President met in the parlor of the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night, shook hands, and chatted for some time together.
ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- Information has been received here of a contract for the equipment of the Erie Canal with electrical power.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 20. -- The annual fair for the benefit of the Memorial Hospital was opened this afternoon in Berkeley Hall, East Orange, and the attendance, particularly to-night, was large, and augurs well for the success of this great charitable event of the year in the Oranges. The fair is to remain open to-morrow afternoon and evening.

Mr. Daniel B. Freedman has bought of E. H. Landon about twenty-one lots, forming the block front on the west side of Sherman Avenue between Emerson and Isham Streets. The property lies advantageously between the new speedway and the Harlem Ship Canal. Mr. Freedman has sold to A. Wessel a plot, 150 by 160, on the east side of Sherman Avenue, 100 feet south of Hawthorne Street.

The second night of the opera season at the Metropolitan, which was last night, brought forward once more Bizet's "Carmen," with Mme. Emma Calve in the title role. The manner in which the public treated this incident was suggestive of a good many things. The house was packed, just as it used to be two seasons ago, when this one opera was the earner of the profit of the managers.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- The United States battleship Indiana was placed in commission at the League Island Navy Yard at 1:20 o'clock this afternoon. The ceremonies were brief, comprising the reading of the orders from the Navy Department and the hoisting of the ensign at the flagstaff aft.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- The local market opened weak and irregular, with the specialties commonly called "Philadelphia Kafirs" the centre of attraction. Electric Storage Battery common opened at 35 1/2, a decline of 5 1/2 per cent., and the preferred at 36, a decline of 5 per cent. This naturally unsettled the other market.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Beyond the routine movement of troops in the Department of the East during the last fiscal year, Gen. Miles, who was in command at the date of the report, has little to discuss.

President Seth Low of Columbia College is announced to preside at the mass meeting to be held in Chickering Hall this evening, under the auspices of the Armenian Relief Association, to protest against the massacre of Armenian Christians by the Turks, and to appeal to the powers of Europe and the United States Government to put a stop to the slaughter.

Rouee Youma, a stockily built son of Barbados, who is now in this city, tells of a remarkable experience he had with a shark. It is because of this experience that he is here in a sailors' boarding house, suffering from a bad wound in his leg, awaiting opportunity to return home.

CONSTATINOPLE, Nov. 20. -- Advices from Aleppo are that all Americans at Aintab, Marash, Orfah, and Mardin are safe. The missionaries at Kharput are leaving and returning temporarily to Constantinople. The Armenian provincial refugees here have petitioned the Patriarch to avert a famine in their country, and ask him to appeal to Europe.

ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- The State Board of Claims will hold a session in the County Court room, New-York City, commencing Dec. 17. It has a calendar for that session of about fifty claims which arose in and about New-York, the aggregate of which is $250,000.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 20. -- Dr. David Flourney, who engaged in the famous bowie-knife duel with Edgar Garth at the University of Virginia in 1854, died here this evening.
ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- Gov. Morton appointed as the new Board of State Assessors to-day Martin Heermance of Poughkeepsie, Edwin L. Adams of Elmira, and Rollin L. Jenkins of Moriah, Essex County.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 20. -- The Republican conference called here to-day attracted about 500 party men from every part of the State. Col. Richard W. Thompson of Terre Haute presided. In his speech, Col. Thompson predicted the nomination and election of Gen. Harrison to the Presidency.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Representative D.B. Henderson of Iowa reached Washington this morning for the coming session of Congress.

There was another public hearing before the Board of State Railroad Commissioners in the Chamber of Commerce rooms yesterday. Commissioners Samuel Beardsley, Michael Rickard, and Alfred C. Chapin were present. The case of Richard S. Williams of City Island against the Pelham Park Railroad Company and the City Island Railroad Company was continued.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- Trading to-day was confined chiefly to Lake Street and West Chicago. In spite of the good showing made by the former yesterday in earnings, the stock declined on heavy selling by the bears. The short interest has undoubtedly been largely increased in the last day or two.

His Royal Highness the Nawab of Basora, an Indian Prince, is experiencing considerable difficulty in introducing a new sign language. A few days ago he arrived at a leading hotel in this city. He was accompanied by a secretary and two servants. The Nawab's rich Oriental costume created much respectful admiration.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 20. -- Capt. Lea decided to-day to give the students one more chance to see the Princeton football eleven play before the big game with Yale on Saturday. During the first ball the gates were thrown open, and for an hour before the game began a constant stream of enthusiasts poured into the 'Varsity grounds.
Calvert Vaux, the well-known landscape architect, has mysteriously disappeared from the residence of his son, C. Bowyer Vaux, in Twentieth Avenue, between Bath and Benson Avenues, in Bensonhurst.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 20. -- The first annual reception and banquet of the Union League Republican Club of this city was held at Turner Hall to-night. Between 500 and 600 guests were in attendance. Among the principal speakers were Lieut. Gov. Lyon, Congressman W.A. Stone, Mayor Kennedy, and several well-known local orators.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Representative Babcock of Wisconsin is likely to be taken in hand by Lodge, Chandler, Hitt, and other jingo Republicans if he repeats the opinions published as from him in to-day's Star. He believes the Monroe doctrine, as originally intended by its author, has come to be an unwritten law.

In a little less than a fortnight Congress will meet. The House of Representatives will have a strong majority of Republicans. In both branches we believe that the supporters of sound money, of that money for which the standard is gold, will be a decided majority. In principle and in law this standard is now and has for years been absolutely established in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The Turkish Legation this morning received the following telegram from the Sublime Porte, under to-day's date:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- The Turkish Legation this morning received the following telegram from the Sublime Porte, under to-day's date:

The closing scenes in the trial of David Hannigan on the charge of killing Soloman H. Mann began yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer. Charles W. Brooke, the leading attorney for the prisoner, took the entire day, no time being allowed for the usual noon recess, in summing up.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Nov. 21. -- The following excerpt from a private letter received in this city from Juneau, Alaska, is given as illustrating the feeling among the citizens of that Territory over the boundary question:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The field notes of the corps of surveyors who ran the line of the one hundred and forty-first meridian of longitude from Mount St. Elias to the Arctic Ocean, which for that distance forms the boundary between Alaska and British Columbia, have not yet been reduced by the computing division of the Coast and Geodetic Survey, where the work has been prosecuted during the last month or six weeks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day heard argument in two cases wherein ex-Cabinet officers were defendants in actions for damages resulting from their official acts. Harvey Spalding, an attorney of the District, had secured contracts with several thousand Postmasters throughout the country for prosecuting their claims for a readjustment of salaries under the act of June 12, 1866.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The Turkish Legation received from the Sublime Porte the following telegram under to-day's date:
LONDON, Nov. 21. -- The Rev. Joseph Rawson Lumby, D.D., Professor of Divinity at St. Catharine's College, Cambridge University, died to-night at his residence at Grand Chester.

Everybody connected in any way with trotting affairs who attended the sale of Fasig Company at Madison Square Garden yesterday felt elated over the steady demand for serviceable light harness stock. The few undeveloped youngsters kept the average down, or the business would have compared favorably with the days of the boom that prevailed from 1886 to 1892.

The hearing before the Aldermanic Committee on Lands, Places, and Park Department yesterday on the all-important question as to who had the right to raise the flags in Battery Park on July 4 and on Evacuation Day was one of unique interest.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- A fire which caused a property loss of $500,000 and imperiled the lives of half a thousand persons, mostly young women, originated at 3 o'clock this afternoon on the third floor of Charles Emmerich Co.'s feather and down goods factory, 175-181 South Canal Street.
BIDDEFORD, Me., Nov. 21. -- A reception was tendered to Senator William P. Frye at the York Club to-night. He gave an informal talk of an hour and a half, dealing chiefly with tariff questions.
The State Board of Arbitration and Mediation received yesterday this letter from the Iron League:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- In the absence of the decision in the much talked about Titus-Cabanne-Murphy case, the most interesting item in this week's bulletin of the Racing Board, out to-day, is the official publication of the transfer to Class B of Jack, Douglass, and Hammer. It will be recalled that these men received notice of their suspension from Class A, pending investigation, while at the Springfield tournament in September.
LONDON, Nov. 21. -- The Morning Post, commenting on Lord Dunraven's speech at Cardiff, will to-morrow say:

The name of JOHN W. JACCBUS, who is newly appointed Tax Assessor, has turned up pretty frequently in the Republican annals of the last fifteen years. The bad Republican boys used to sell him out when he ran for office, but now and then some kind soul like BENJAMIN HARRISON would give him shelter and a salary.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- Special Policemen John W. Brown and H. Whalen found tramps in the Pennsylvania Railroad cut at Engleside this morning. The policemen ordered the tramps away the tramps resisted, there was a fight, and a negro tramp known as "Skinny" was shot dead. Brown and Whalen are under bail to appear at the Coroner's inquest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Senhor Augusto de Sequeira Thedim, Minister from Portugal to the United States, died this morning from the effects of a severe hemorrhage that came upon him suddenly last Sunday evening. The announcement of the death of the Minister was a shock to the Diplomatic Corps and others who knew the family, inasmuch as the serious nature of the illness was not generally appreciated.

There was a large gathering of homeopathic physicians and of laymen interested in the advancement of homeopathy in Delmonico's last evening, at the second annual banquet of the Hahnemann Association. Many prominent physicians of the homeopathic school from Philadelphia, Boston, and Washington were present, together with a large delegation of practitioners of this city and Brooklyn.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 21. -- At a meeting of the Board of Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern Railway to-day the annual report was presented, and shows the road to be in a prosperous condition, despite the troubles of last year. For the year ended June 30, President Bacon reports: Gross earnings, $6,323,635; operating expenses, $4,017,106; net earnings, $2,305,931; net earnings applicable to interest, $1,973,542; interest on bonds and equipment certificates, $1,761,485.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- Gen. Sir Henry F. Ponsonby, for many years Keeper of the Privy Purse and private secretary to her Majesty the Queen, died at Osborne Cottage, Cowes, at 7:45 o'clock this morning. He was seventy years of age. He had been ill and incapacitated for duty for several months past.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- The cause of Cuba was advocated at the Academy of Music to-night at a meeting held under the auspices of the Philadelphia brigade, Pennsylvania Reserves. The principal address of the evening was made by Gov. Claude Matthews of Indiana, who delivered a speech upon "Free Cuba" that he had prepared to deliver at the Atlanta Exposition. The audience was not large.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Nov. 21. -- There are a number of men at work quarrying stone on the Carpenter farm, a short distance from here. Yesterday one of the men struck his crowbar into what he thought was a piece of stone, and, to his surprise the crowbar went into the earth and disappeared. This led to an investigation, and a mammoth cave was discovered.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The report of Joseph S. Miller of West Virginia, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, made public today, states that the receipts for the fiscal year had fallen below his estimates $27,753,000. This he attributes to the decision of the Supreme Court, declaring the income tax unconstitutional after only $77,000 had been collected.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 21. -- The invention of the phonograph and the results of such invention, including the organization of several companies, and subsequent litigation, were told of in the evidence presented to-day in the five phonograph suits in chancery, wherein John P. Hardin, receiver of the North American Phonograph Company, and Thomas A. Edison are at odds.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 21.--It is said that friends of ex-President Harrison held an informal meeting yesterday, and determined on the delegates at large to the National Convention. The gentlemen said to have been selected are Col. R.W. Thompson of Terre Haute, Charles W. Fairbanks of this city, W.H.H. Miller, ex-Attorney General, and the Chairman of the State Committee, yet to be chosen.

By the purchase of a majority of the 25,000 shares of stock of the Forty-second Street, Manhattanville and St. Nicholas Avenue Railroad Company, the Third Avenue Railroad Company has acquired control of the Forty-second Street and Boulevard horse-car line, which comprises about twelve miles of road now in operation.
The sale of the library of David Adee was concluded yesterday by Bangs Co. The books sold brought over $4,000, making the total for four days about $17,000.
About 200 New-York excursionists started for Atlanta, Ga., yesterday, at 2:22 P.M., to attend the Manhattan Day celebration at the Cotton States Exposition, and two hours later Troop A also started.

When Gov. FLOWER appointed the three State Assessors three years ago he gave New-York City a representative on the board for the first time in twenty-eight years. Although Gov. MORTON is a New-York City man and is familiar with the large share it bears in State taxation, he has left it out again in appointing the new Assessors.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 21. -- Edward Vanderwater and William Cornelius, sons of village officers, have been seen but a few times in Hempstead streets since last Monday, when they were the victims of a highway robbery of which they do not care to talk.

Charles De Forrest Burns, Secretary of the Park Board, political protege of "Larry" Delmour, and Tammany politician of the most pronounced "revenue" stripe, seems to enjoy a "pull" that defies all reform or reformers.

All that Secretary CARLISLE said on Tuesday evening to the Chamber of Commerce as to the absurdity and peril of the Government banking business was perfectly true, but he did not include the whole truth. Mr. CARLISLE did not take specific note of the way in which the condition of the revenue may affect the ability of the Treasury to meet the perpetual demand made possible by the legal-tender notes.

The body of Calvert Vaux, the landscape architect, who disappeared Tuesday from his home in Bensonhurst, was found yesterday morning in Gravesend Bay, at the foot of Bay Seventeenth Street. It will be buried privately to-morrow in Kingston, N.Y. The Coroner will hold the inquest to-day.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 21. -- The following awards of medals and diplomas of merit for exhibits at the exposition have been made.

The discovery that two students at Union College have been systematically stealing is more startling perhaps than it ought to be or than it is to anybody who reflects upon the nature of the undergraduate. Certainly the discovery does not indicate any failure upon the part of the institution with which these adventurers were connected or upon their previous training in their respective domestic circles.
CARDIFF, Nov. 21.--A banquet was given here to-night in honor of Lord Dunraven. Lord Tredegar presided, and there was a large attendance.

David Hannigan was acquitted at 11:25 o'clock last night by the jury before which he had been on trial for seventeen days for the shooting of Solomon H. Mann. The jury found that he was insane when he shot Mann, and so not responsible for his act.

The engagement is announced of Miss Voorhees Barney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Voorhees Barney of Boston, and a granddaughter of the late Mrs. James L. Voorhees of New-York, to Henry H. Fitzgerald of this city. Mr. and Mrs. Barney and Miss Barney arrived in Boston from Europe last week after having been abroad for nearly six months.

A mass meeting was held in Chickering Hall last evening, under the auspices of the Armenian Relief Association, to protest against the Turkish slaughter of the Christians, and to appeal to the powers of Europe and the United States Government to demand the protection of American life and property in Armenia.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 21. -- The annual meeting of The Southern Associated Press, which convened here yesterday and adjourned to-day, was harmonious in its proceedings and determined to maintain its independence, as is evidenced by the unanimous adoption of the following report of a special committee:
Messrs. Hoffman Brothers have sold a plot between one and two lots in size on Broadway, near Houston Street, for something under $200,000. The details are withheld for the present.

HAVANA, Nov. 21. -- A special train, upon which Gen. Suarez Valdez was returning from Santa Clara, was wrecked yesterday by the explosion of two dynamite cartridges which had been placed on the track by rebels near Jicotes. Gen. Suarez Valdez was not hurt, but of the twenty-five men composing his guard two were seriously wounded and twelve bruised.

Word was sent not long ago to the friends of William McKinley, in Ohio, that something must be done if they expected to maintain strength enough in this city to secure a single delegate in the next Republican National Convention. The "Ohio crowd," so called, in the Republican Party here is not meeting with much success in getting hold of the machinery.

The announcement in THE NEW-YORK TIMES on Monday that Dr. Ahlwardt, the anti-Semitic leader of Berlin, Germany, is making arrangements to sail for the United State next month to deliver lectures, is not giving the Hebrews of this city much concern.

The political friends of Senator-elect Ford, who carried the Nineteenth Senatorial District by a big majority at the last election, gave a banquet in his honor last night in the Hotel Minot, One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street and Eighth Avenue.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 21. -- Warner Miller seems likely to acquire a reputation as a sensationalist. His performance at the Saratoga convention last Summer in forcing from his party a declaration in favor of the antiquated blue laws as applied to excise matters, was only a little more surprising and unexpected than his deliverance to-night before the Boston Home Market Club.

" Do I deserve that you stand between me and the outrageous slander heaped upon me by The Tribune and The Mail and Express? Won't you rather stand with the executive officers of your committee than with these slanderers?" thundered Edward Lauterbach, Chairman of the Republican County Committee, at the meeting of that committee at the headquarters, in West Thirty-eighth Street, last night.

The unprecedented output of pig iron has caused a natural decline of prices. Bessemer pig has been sold this week for $13 in Pittsburg, and steel billets for $18 at the works. "More than one-half of the great Summer advance," says The Iron Age, "has been lost." This was the natural and inevitable effect of the enormous production of crude iron, exceeding by about 20,000-tons per week the highest recorded in past years.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

Wagner's most honeyed measures filled the Metropolitan Opera House last night. "Lohengrin" was the opera of the evening, and, as all good Wagnerites know, this is the least Wagnerian of all the "meister's" works. The audience was one of good size, but it did not pack the house with its numbers, nor did it shake the circumambient air with its enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- A liberal supply of candidates for the post of Chaplain of the House is presented for the suffrages of members. The candidates are making themselves and their objects known by personal visits to other headquarters; they have not obtained yet places of business for themselves.

SARATOGA, Nov. 22. -- Gen. Harrison is expected here to-morrow afternoon to see his grandson, Benjamin McKee, better known as "Baby" McKee, who has just passed through a six-weeks' siege of scarlet fever. The quarantine was raised this morning. Gen. Harrison will be the guest of Mr. and Mrs. McKee two or three days, and, if he shall not be called away by business, may remain in Saratoga till after Thanksgiving.

" It is not true," said President Roosevelt of the Police Department yesterday, "that since the change in the department crime has increased and the police have been less active and vigilant in making arrests. The fact is that there has been a remarkable falling off in the number of felonies committed, and the arrests have increased.

Now that the charges of Lord DUNRAVEN against Mr. ISELIN are under consideration by a committee which commands universal confidence for its intelligence and its impartiality, it seems highly proper to await the decision of that tribunal and to refrain in the meanwhile from any comments upon the subject.
WESTWOOD, N.J., Nov. 22. -- A bold attempt at holding up was promptly frustrated about midnight between River Edge and Cherry Hill, a few miles north of Hackensack.

The Grand Duke Alexis was at Kiel. He is a full Russian Admiral now, and the head of the Russian Navy. He was a frequent visitor to the Americans, and, like all the other notables, talked with the utmost frankness to our officers.

The question who shall have the honor of raising the flag in Battery Park on Evacuation Day has somehow been suddenly transferred from the Park Commissioners to the Committee on Lands and Places of the Board of Aldermen. The contestants are the same, the polemical Col. ASA BIRD GARDINER and the hereditary CHRISTOPHER R. FORBES, represented this time not only by the irascible RIKER, but by the suave but formidable APPLETON MORGAN.

The properly sold by Hoffman Brothers, referred to yesterday, was the three-story iron-front building 634 Broadway, east side, just below the south corner of Bleecker Street. It measures 22.1 by 196.3 to Crosby Street by 25 by 196.5. The seller was Jacob Rothschild and the buyer Louis Sachs. The property was bought in March, 1888, for $103,250, and has now been sold for something under $180,000.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 22. -- Mrs. Clara Valois, who fled from Scituate when she heard that a warrant was out for her arrest on the charge of murdering her father, has not been apprehended. It is alleged she has a lover in New-York, whom she intended to wed as soon as she had secured a divorce from Adolph Valois, her Boston husband.

Keir Hardie, the English Socialist and labor leader, said farewell to his Socialistic friends in America last night at a meeting in Webster Hall, and to-day he will sail for home. The meeting was held under the auspices of the Central Labor Federation and the Socialistic Labor Party.

On account of gales and high seas several of the ocean liners have been delayed, but no fears are felt for their safety. The Ethiopia of the Anchor Line is four days late, the Weimar of the North German Lloyd Line two days late, and the St. Paul of the American Line is one day late.

ALBANY, Nov. 22. -- Senator John Raines, the author of the ballot law, which was first put into operation in this State at the last election, was at the Executive Chamber to-day. When asked if he anticipated making any changes in the law during the coming session of the Legislature, he said:

The jurymen who acquitted HANNIGAN appear to have reached their conclusion after some deliberation, for they had the case in their hands more than six hours. If they had been moved by sympathy alone they would have given their decision to the court with very little delay, for it was known that the defendant's father, who had testified before them, was dying.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The long-expected and much-desired revision of Army Regulations has been issued. It first was put into shape by a board of officers of the Adjutant General's department; that copy was revised by Gen. E.S. Otis, commanding the Department of the Columbia; a final revision was made by Assistant Secretary of War Doe, Major George W. Davis of the Eleventh Infantry, and Capt. J.T. French, Jr., Assistant Quartermaster.

With the unexpectedly large shipments of gold this week the reserve of the Treasury drops to $82,000,000. A like draft next week would bring it to $75,000,000, at which point it has been reported that the Administration would deem it wise to strengthen the reserve by such means as are at its disposal.

To-day's gold shipments to Europe will amount to $4,600,000, including $500,000 withdrawn from the Sub-Treasury by Baring, Magoun Co. on Thursday. The same firm withdrew yesterday a second $500,000, and the other firms and amounts were: W.H. Crossman Brother, $1,000,000; Lazard Freres, $800,000; Heidelbach, Ickelheimer Co., $750,000; Muller, Schall Co., $500,000, and L. Von Hoffmann Co., $500,000.

Ex-Register John Reilly, one of the foremost of Tammany's district leaders, is in favor of the organization adopting a broad, policy that will attract Democrats to its support. Mr. Reilly has been in local politics for the last twenty-five years.

What woes do not befall Chicago! That city has a debt of $6,000,000, which is increasing at the rate of a cool million each year. One Chicago newspaper gives a double-leaded opinion that the city has a "prognathous City Council," whose members accept bribes so quickly that Boss Tweed turns over in his grave.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Secretary Herbert's annual report to the President is nearly completed. He has done much of the work at his home, where he has summoned bureau chiefs for consultation. He has gathered many tabular statements showing various expenditures and the needs of the service.
Mrs. George Livingston Baker of Staten Island will introduce her second daughter to society this afternoon.
NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 22. -- The battleship Maine was placed hors du combat twice in succession by the torpedo boat Cushing to-night.

Justice Ingraham of the Supreme Court yesterday directed that Mrs. Birdie S. Sternberger's young son, Robert, be restored to her, the father, Louis Sternberger, having the privilege of seeing him an hour for six days in each week, and longer on Saturdays.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- In the case of Commander Nicoll Ludlow, now before the President, it was said to-day in the Navy Department that the President would probably adhere to his former decision and disapprove the findings of the board.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 22. -- Eleven trainloads of New-Yorkers arrived here, one after another, this afternoon. They came to celebrate New-York Day next Monday, arriving early in order to take part in the exercises of Brooklyn Day at the exposition to-morrow.

Justice Cullen of the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, yesterday denied the application of Edward M. Grout, regular Democratic nominee for Mayor of Brooklyn, for a mandamus compelling the Board of Aldermen to correct defective votes. He granted the application to compel the board, as a body, to canvass the votes, and thereby invalidates the canvass which was made by a committee of the board.

Peter De Lacy got his first serious set-back in his long career as a race track litigant yesterday afternoon. It was when Joel Marx withdrew as counsel for John C. Dudley and Henry C. Judson in the trumped-up cases brought by them against the Flushing Jockey Club.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22. -- The Hasty Pudding Club of Harvard began the celebration of its one hundredth anniversary to-day. From 2 o'clock on, the clubhouse was open to members past and present. During the afternoon there was a band concert, and free beer was on tap. Many old "grads" were out to renew old times and drink from their dusty, half-forgotten beer mugs.
[ LODOI, 'ov. 22_. -- $ohn Redfern, the celebrated London tailor, died at his residence, in Cowes, Isle of Wight, to-day.

The Rev. Dr. James Chambers of this city has just received a letter from a friend who has lived in Turkey fifteen years. Dr. Chambers's correspondent gives a graphic description of the condition of the Armenians in Turkey. The Sultan, he says, bitterly resented the pressure of the great powers, and their forbearance gave him time to make preparations.
BELVEDERE, N.J., Nov. 22. -- Grant Keller of Kenton on Nov. 12 pleaded guilty in the Warren County Court to horse stealing, and Judge Morrow sentenced him to two years in State prison at hard labor.
HONOLULU, Nov. 14. -- The United States gunboat Bennington returned from Hilo yesterday with Minister Willis and family, after sixteen days' absence.
The Executive Committee of the Reform Club's Committee on Sound Currency has submitted the following report to the full body:
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 22. -- Whitelaw Reid was here to-day. He arrived from the East, accompanied by his wife, in a special car, and left over the Santa Fe for Arizona.

The New-York Mercantile Exchange held a special meeting yesterday to consider the question of the use of oleomargarine in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. It is alleged by the members that a quantity of oleomargarine was found at a freight depot marked "For the U.S. Steamship Texas, Brooklyn, N. Y." It is a matter of general knowledge, they say, that considerable quantities of these goods have been used at the navy yard.

At the tenth meeting in the Bank Clerks' bowling tourney, hold on Truman's alleys last night, the American Exchange carried off the honors, winning two games and establishing the second highest team score in the tourney, 805. The Bank of Savings men still top the list with 856. The Mechanics' Bank team lost both its games, while the Southern National won and lost. The scores:

There is to be an enrollment of Republican voters in this city to-night preparatory to the primaries to be held Dec. 10. The result of the primaries will determine the control of the County Committee and the working of the party machine next year. It will also determine whether the Republicans of the city really object to the bossism of PLATT or whether on the whole they rather like it.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- Eugene V. Debs was to-day released from the county jail at Woodstock, where for six months he had been imprisoned for contempt of court. His offense consisted in advising disobedience to an injunction of the United States court restraining him, as President of the American Railway Union, and his followers, from interfering with the operation of trains during the great railway strike of 1894.

I attended an annual meeting held at the house of Mrs. Russell Sage, and I was fired with such zeal that I come with a few facts which I hope to make public and helpful through the columns of your paper.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Nov. 22. -- Special watchmen, well armed, are guarding the oyster beds in this vicinity to-night, and should any attempts be made by pirate craft to dredge for oysters, there will be trouble.

Familiar as are these drawings to readers of the magazine in which they first appeared, their arrangement in book form cannot fail to cause no small wonder; first, at the surprising number that Mr. Abbey has executed, and, second, at the artist's astonishing fertility of invention as regards composition, combined with inexhaustible resources of type and pose.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- A fire, disastrous to life and property, swept through the Dry-Goods and Woolen Exchange Building this morning.

-- In writing his "Story of the Indian," the first volume in Ripley Hitchcock's series devoted to the Great West, George Bird Grinnell has used personal observation and experience. He is an adopted Chief of the Pawnees and Blackfeet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Capt. N.M. Brooks, Superintendent of the Foreign Mail Service, has submitted a report showing the valuable services rendered by his bureau in conducting the transportation of the foreign mails during the past fiscal year. The aggregate weight of mails dispatched by sea during the year was 5,758,608 pounds. The cost of the transatlantic service was $607,698; for the transpacific service, $88,494, and for miscellaneous service, $366,699.

A reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES called on David F. Hannigan, acquitted of the murder of Solomon H. Mann, in the Tombs yesterday. He found the prisoner changed. There was a light in his eye that was not there before, and his whole hearing expressed hope and greater cheerfulness.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The Treasurer of the United States, D.N. Morgan, in his annual report on the operations and condition of the Treasury, after giving figures as to receipts and expenditures, which differ very slightly from those already published, says:

Eleven young men from Yale will face eleven young men from Princeton in the annual football match for the college championship on Manhattan Field to-day. The game will begin promptly at 2 o'clock. Manhattan Field can be reached by the Sixth and Ninth Avenue elevated railroads, by the cable road up Third Avenue, transferring at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street for a Tenth Avenue car, or by the Eighth Avenue horse-car line.

Cedar Rapids has a citizen, P.A. Peterson, who claims to possess a curiosity -- an unpaid bill against Barney Barnato, now the most-talked of man in the English-speaking world. In 1872, Mr. Peterson and Carl Lutter, now of San Francisco, kept a boarding house at Du Toy Pan, three miles from Kimberley.

News has been received in this city of the sudden death in Beyrout, Syria, of the Rev. Dr. Cornelius Van Allen Van Dyke, who was known throughout the civilized world as the translator of the Bible into Arabic. His death was due to old age and an organic trouble with which he had suffered for many years.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 23. -- C.F. Richings gave illustrated lectures on "The Condition of the Colored Man" in the Union Baptist Church Wednesday evening and last evening.
GEORGETOWN, Demerara, B.G., Nov. 8. -- That the crisis in the dispute between Great Britain and Venezuela as to the boundaries of the republic is approaching cannot longer be doubted.

This is the best week in all the year for the theatres. Business generally reaches high-water mark Turkey day. It seems that many New-Yorkers make a custom of going to the theatre Thanksgiving Day if they never go any other time. It is a poor play, indeed, that does not draw crowds both afternoon and evening on the Yankee holiday.
The Sultan who has come before the public in such an unenviable manner of late, need not be lonely while hiding in his palace.

The lightning-rod agent struck Granite County some time ago, and as a result the school buildings of that prosperous county are well protected, but in few of them are there pupils to enjoy the benefits of instruction. This condition of things was revealed by a letter sent to the office of the State Superintendent of Public Instruction a day or two ago.

There are many people who regard a Thanksgiving Day as a meaningless day and its celebration once a year a waste of time and a mockery. It might have been, they go on to say, a day of reality to those who in early Colonial times had hostile tribes, inclement weather, and threatened starvation to fight, and whose natures were wrought upon to all their depths of fear and gratitude.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Dr. Henry Race has written a very interesting history of the Presbyterian Church of Kingwood, Hunterdon County, N.J., which has been promulgated by The Jerseyman, a magazine of local history of quarterly circulation and devoted in a great measure to the historical interests of Hunterdon County. The publisher frankly announces that the magazine is "published irregularly, when time permits and material can be found."

The history of the lives of such men as BARRETT and HOLMES brings to mind the trite saying that truth is stranger than fiction. An English novel which attracted much attention a few years ago had for its chief personage, if not its hero, a quiet man who apparently led a correct and highly respectable life, but really was an expert and daring burglar, steadily engaged in the practice of his criminal profession.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- The question of providing a new City Hall has divided this city into factions with as many ideas on the subject as there are factions. Scarcely any one denies that the present accommodations in the old Manor Hall, now over 200 hundred years old, are totally inadequate for the business that is daily transacted in the various departments of this rapidly growing city.

For private reasons Mr. WILLIAM BROOKFIELD, the Commissioner of Public Works in this city, and Mr. ALFRED T. WHITE, Commissioner of City Works in Brooklyn, are about to retire from office. The announcements are nearly simultaneous. There is a notable difference in the manner in which they have been received in the two cities.

Mr. Aldrich needs no words of praise at this late day for his lovely lyrics. He has long been acknowledged to be a master in the making of this kind of verse. His tenderness, delicacy, refinement, and warmth, coupled with the mellifluous fluency of his lines, have given him a high position among the craftsmen of the lyre.

In the country, whether in the East or West, North or South, the compensation to school teachers is so small that it seems wonderful that those who receive these salaries can live on them. These salaries range from $100 a year to $900 a year. The average for a school year of about seven months Is $318.36 for men and $:262.92 for women.

E.M. Reynolds, Assistant Auditor of the Lehigh and Hudson River Railroad Company, was the first witness yesterday morning at the continuation of the milk traffic inquiry before the Inter-State Commerce Commission.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 23. -- A concert was given by the choir of the Crescent Avenue Church Thursday evening for the benefit of the Children's Home. Those who took part in the programme were Miss Emily M. Banta, soprano; Miss Annie P. Hardenberg, contralto; Mrs. Minnie Marshall Smith, reciter; Elmer E. Runyon, tenor; Miss Nellie Udelle, violinist; Charles Lewis, basso, and Philip Edner, cellist.

ARKANSAS CITY, Kan., Nov. 23. -- An incident occurred at the Chilocco Indian School, near this city, which, while not uncommon, is at least new to the general public. The school contains children from every tribe in the Territory, and among the thousand boys may be found those of every degree of untamed disposition, many being very difficult to manage.
ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 23. -- The people of this city and vicinity feel, and have always felt, that they could claim the Oranges as the cycling centre of the State of New-Jersey.

-- One may not know exactly whether Mr. George Saintsbury laughs or does not laugh at Marmontel and his "Moral Tales." In editing the stories he has revised the stock translation, and the volume is published by Macmillan Co. in very pretty style. These are the "Contes Moraux," so dear to our great-grandmothers.

In studying games, and the invention of them, we must be above race prejudice. It would be, therefore, manifestly unjust to insist that because Chinese, Japanese, or Coreans do not play poker theirs is a case of arrested civilization.

Winter has come upon Paris, our correspondent says, in its most unpleasant form -- that of icy drizzle. It interfered on Sunday with pilgrimages to the cemeteries. Tens of thousands wended their way there in the morning before the rain began to fall. The graves were less richly decorated with flowers than usual.
Prison management in the Empire State has been attacked by a coterie of politicians.

If you ever made an attempt to color a meerschaum pipe you may have noticed that in your eagerness to paint it a beautiful brown you have filled it again and again immediately after smoking, and while it was still hot from the former charge of tobacco. You have noticed, also, that in a short time the pipe is burned, and you have destroyed every vestige of hope that it may ever be colored.

ALBANy, Nov. 23. -- In overhauling some old vouchers of Revolutionary times in the Controller's office recently, one of the attaches of the office came across three well-preserved discharges of Federal soldiers, which had been filed with applications and prooofs for pensions. They were signed by Gen. George Washington.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 23. -- The Administration to-day decided upon a plan to replenish the gold reserve, which, it is confidently expected, will have the effect of deferring, for some time at least, the issue of bonds for the purpose of strengthening the gold reserve. The following circular was sent to Sub-Treasury officers:

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Not until the final score had been received did the few Princeton students who remained behind give up hope. They began to assemble around the bulletin early in the afternoon, and remained, cheering everything that contained a grain of hope, until the bulletin told that the game was over and hope was gone.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- Before going to Letzlingen on his hunting trip, the Emperor gave an audience to M. de Szogenyl-Marich, the Austrian Ambassador to Germany, with whom he had a prolonged conference, and upon his return from Letzlingen on Tuesday, his Majesty invited himself, upon very short notice, to dine with the Austrian Ambassador.

Postmaster Charles W. Dayton, ex-Controller Theodore W. Myers, ex-Corporation Counsel William H. Clark, and ex-Sheriff John B. Sexton, with a number of friends and acquaintances, started yesterday for the Atlanta Exposition in a unique private car that suggested very strongly the story of Christopher Columbus and his famous egg.

Three days of lively trade in light-harness stock exhausted about all of the good things that W.B. Fasig Co. had collected for their first big sale in this city. The offering yesterday were mainly of mediocre quality, so that the market was rather dull. Still, when anything with a record and likely to train on came into the ring there was no lack of competition.

The Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, Lafayette Avenue and Oxford Street, Brooklyn, will be the scene of an interesting "grand rally" this evening to celebrate the seventy-eighth anniversary of the New-York Port Society.

Driven from the little house she had called home, because she was unable by her daily toll to pay the paltry sum of money required as rent, Mrs. Mary Roberts, with her little three-year-old baby in her arms, was compelled to spend the night on a common, with no protection except the small amount of rubbish called her furniture.
By the special pleasure of Thomas C. Platt the Republicans of this city were permitted to enroll themselves last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The public report that declares it to be the intention of the President to send to the Congress a "one topic" message, similar to one sent to a prior Congress, is regarded with incredulity here.

Yesterday, while in Chicago a, dozen private property owners and a corporation were fighting tooth and nail over the possession of a public street, New-York was offering a spectacle which in the comparison was deeply humiliating to this city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The plans for the two new battleships authorized by the last Congress were made public yesterday. Bids for their construction will be opened next week Saturday.

Under English rule "local self-government" has been bestowed upon the people of India, so the board has to look around for means to pay for water and drainage schemes and town conservancy; the barrier dues are one of them, and the carters, who have just come in, are as discontented as the people of the town, who pay, one way and another, two shillings per head annually for local rates.

The violinists are all here but one, and the opera season has begun. The Symphony Society and the Philharmonic have made their bows, the Oratorio Society has wrestled with the counterpoint of Handel, and the Musical Art and New-York Musical Societies will soon come forward with their initial concerts.

Though by no means unexpected, the action of the committee from the National Sculpture Society in recommending the rejection of the Heine memorial by the Park Board caused a mild tempest last week, and has brought out many protests. These protests do not come, it may be added, from those whose judgment and experience in such matters are of great artistic value.

Something must be done about the poetry of this town. It appears to be getting worse every day. If this is not true, most certainly it is true that the writers of poor poetry are becoming frightfully numerous in the community, and are giving it a shocking character abroad. We have a few poets of merit, but they sing rarely.

An extraordinary character has just found his way to Carmaux, apparently with the charitable intention of relieving the monotony of the strike. This personage, who come forward as a candidate at all the elections in the district, scours the country with proclamations, in which, among other dreadful things, he predicts "the beginning of a terrible week and the last battle between all the men on the earth."
Brentano's counting room was visited Friday night by professional burglars, who drilled and blew open an old-fashioned safe and secured $1,700 in money.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 23. -- William A. Paxton has received a letter from Mac Stuart, who for a number of years was foreman for Mr. Paxton on the Keystone Ranch, near Ogallalla. Stuart is under sentence, in Chihuahua, Mexico, to be shot, and implores his old employer to interest the United States authorities in his behalf, as his trial had been "railroaded" through the Mexican courts, and justice has not been done him.

The recent death of Mr. Eugene Field lends to the verses in this volume a pathetic interest, which is increased by their genial, humorous tone. The voice of the poet floats back to us across the Styx in mingled laughter and song, and there seems to have been in these products of his pen a prophecy of speedy union with the classic shade, whose thought they have translated into modern echoes.

The way to get great crowds to the exposition is not by pandering to a visionary sentiment, but by looking conditions squarely in the face. Entirely too much time has been taken up in burying sectionalism. It is all right to do this in time, but three months is too short a period in which to dig the hole and fill in the dirt for this great corpse.
A man in a long black coat and baggy-kneed trousers stepped up to the weighing clerk's window at the Post Office the other morning and handed in a parcel done up in paper.

It is not surprising that in the first use of the new form of ballot and method of voting in this State mistakes should have been made by voters, by public officers charged with the duty of providing ballots, and by Election Inspectors, or that defects in the law should be revealed.
ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 23. -- An exhibition drill in full-dress uniform was given in the armory to-night by the members of the Gatling Gun Company A.
Your editorial entitled "Comstock" in your issue of Nov. 21 has just been brought to my attention.

Something after the plan of THE NEW-YORK TIMES relay race between this city and Philadelphia will be attempted on Sunday next by the Military Cyclists of Washington. They will start a relay ride on that date, ending in this city, the distance being 250 miles. Like THE TIMES race, the relays in this run will average twenty-five miles each.

This book is filled with verse of a kind that is altogether too common. Given an ordinary, common-school acquaintance with the English language, a good ear for rhythm, a genuine love for nature, and a large desire to write, and any one can produce this kind of verse. Indeed, there have been few prose writers of eminence who have not produced better.
All the late transatlantic steamships arrived yesterday. None of them met with an accident, although they all reported that they had had heavy weather early in the week.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Two beautiful statues of white marble that have recently been put in place on either side of the altar of St. Gabriel's Catholic Church are the latest additions made by the Iselin family to their former gifts of land, church edifice, and rectory. St. Gabriel's, indeed, owes its existence to the Iselin family.

The missionary schooner Robert W. Logan sailed for the South Sea Islands yesterday afternoon with a party of missionaries on board. The destination of the little vessels is Ruk, in the Caroline group, but on the way thither she will put into a number of ports, the first being Honolulu.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The temporary lull in the Turkish crisis gives the Conservative press occasion to publish radiant eulogies on Lord Salisbury as the savior of the peace of Europe. He alone, it is claimed, has preserved the continuity of concerted action by the powers; he is the greatest living figure in diplomacy, and he extorts the admiration of foreign statesmen,

Alligatah climbin' up a hickery tree Had a altahcation wif a bumble bee; Dat bumble, bee done bit him in de nose, And make dat gatah jump outen he clothes Den come along John, come along Sally. Come along Susan Jane.

KIOTO, Oct. 19. -- When we sat down to our first tiffin in Yokohama four months ago we could not realize we were in the Orient. English was spoken on all sides, and one could imagine himself in New-York or London. However, there was an almost imperceptible charm of the East, with the swinging punkahs overhead and the Japanese coolies to wait on us.
The old Volks Garten, at 231 and 233 Bowery, which for a number of years was a well-known music hall, was destroyed by fire last evening.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- The Brown football team met the cadets on the gridiron for the final tussle of the season this afternoon. The field was in perfect condition, and the weather, though gloomy and threatening, was just the right kind for a hard game. The cadets showed up in better work than at any other time during the season.

People who read in the metropolitan newspapers day after day of crimes undetected, of men waylaid, of servants shot down, and of poison becoming the speediest and safest path to inheritance, are apt to sneer at the old adage, "Murder will out." The case of Charles Jefferds is worthy of note as an instance where a guilty man, acquitted, was afterward convicted through his own insensate, almost involuntary, admissions.

On a fine May day in the year 1741 there trooped out from New-York fort and town a throng of men and women, all apparently intent on witnessing some great sight. There were men on horseback and women in litters as anxious as any to get a front place. They came to a halt on the semicircle of hills which then stood where Five Points is now.
Judge Allison Fixes Dec. 2 as the Date -- Gov. Morton's Request to the District Attorney.

HAVANA, Nov. 23. -- The rebel bands, under the leaders Masferrer, Tapanes, and Vidal, were defeated yesterday by a Spanish column on a sugar plantation at Unidad, in the Province of Santa Clara. The leader Masferrer was killed, and the Spanish captured thirteen horses.

The withdrawal on Friday of the counsel for the two men who pretended to be suing a pretended jockey club for money the recovery of which might or could be held to be evidence of a violation of the Constitution was, in view of the evidence, not only a proper but a necessary proceeding.

My friend Daphius Patchouli, a late, very late, descendant of the well-remembered Tityrus T. of that name, to whom I have heretofore referred, has frequently expressed to me his surprise that the abandoned farms of which we have so many, and other little used territory in these New-England States, should not be employed in sheep husbandry.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 23. -- Brooklyn Day at the exposition was a great success. The weather, which was as mild, clear, and balmy as that of a September day, was a powerful factor in the result. The appearance of Squadron A as an escort for Mayor Schieren and his associates aroused the most unbounded enthusiasm among the inhabitants of Atlanta.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Murmurs that may precede a tumultuous outbreak are heard among Republican members of the House, as they gradually reach the Capital, against the reported Quay combination of forces to elect the Clerk from Pennsylvania, the Doorkeeper from New-York, and the Sergeant at Arms from Missouri.

LENOX, Mass., Nov. 23. -- The Rev. William M. Grosvenor gave his friends a farewell reception at Trinity Rectory Tuesday evening. All his church people were there, and many of the townspeople were also present. Mr. Grosvenor will preach his farewell sermon to-morrow evening. He has taken great interest in the Episcopal Church in Lee, and his friends there will give him a reception at St. George's Rectory in that town Monday evening.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

For the first time within the memory of man the streets of New-York have been cleaned. Col. Waring has given us an object lesson, and now it rests with ourselves to decide whether or not the streets shall remain clean. For, in spite of Col. Waring and his determined corps of assistants, the streets of New-York will never remain clean unless we good citizens of Manhattan do our part in aiding him.

ATLANTA, NOV. 23. -- Mayor Strong reached here at 6 o'clock this evening, the train being two hours late. Long before his arrival, the neighborhood of the Southern Railway Station was crowded with residents of Atlanta. A Dart of the attraction for the crowd was undoubtedly the display made by Squadron A, which was drawn up in front of the station.

The members of the Knollwood Country Club at Elmsford, Westchester County, had a very interesting golf tournament yesterday afternoon. It was the fifth match in the series of handicap competitions for the silver cup given by P. Gibert Thebaud. This cup is to be played for at intervals of two weeks for one year, and the player who wins it the greatest number of times will become its owner.

There's a heap of similarity between Princeton and Yale football games and Harvard and Yale boat races. Yale is always going to be beaten at each of the sports in which the Yalensians excel, but somehow she will persist in coming out at the top of the heap year after year, with not enough intervals of defeat to make the contests interesting.

Mlle. Beglarion, the young Armenian lady doctor of whose history our Vienna correspondent lately gave an account, delivered a lecture in that city last night before an audience composed chiefly of persons interested in the question of women's higher education. Her subject was "The Women of Armenia and Their Mohammedan Sisters."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 23. -- A well-dressed woman about thirty-five years old jumped from a Brooklyn Annex ferryboat as it was entering the slip on this side at 8:30 to-night. James McAnerney, a ferry watchman, jumped after her and held her up until other employes went to his aid and lifted them to the pier.

-- Mr. H.G. Trevor has offered for competition two handsome sliver cups for foursome thatches on St. Andrew's links Thanksgiving Day, to all clubs in the United States Golf Association. Each club can enter as many foursome teams as it wishes, but both of the foursome players must in each case be of the same club. The tournament for these cups will be a long one, thirty-six holes, medal play.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 23. -- The friends of Miss Maggie Hardy gave her a surprise party one night this week, which was enjoyed by about twenty couples.
The St. Andrew's Golf Club practically completed all the preliminary arrangements last week for the purchase of its new golf farm, near Mount Hope, Westchester County.

PARIS, Nov. 6. -- " Ah! la bonne soiree!" and how delighted Bernhardt has Peason to be, even in the glory of her own Madrid season, where the Queen Regent receives and greets the great artist with singular kindness and pleasure. Who would not?

One million pounds per annum, or nearly so, has been realized during the past few years from the gambling tables at Monte Carlo. * * * The glamour and the mystery which once surrounded Monte Carlo have departed, and this matter-of-fact examination of the management, taken together with a statement of the ways and means of the enterprise, will doubtless go to efface any halo of romance which may still encircle the notorious Casino.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 23. -- Cardinal Gibbons to-day stated that the consistory at which the elevation of Mgr. Satolli to the Cardinalate will be officially promulgated will assemble in Rome next Monday. In an interview, the Cardinal said:

FLUSHING, L.I., Nov. 23. -- This village is in the midst of an exciting local political campaign. A new Board of Trustees is to be chosen Dec. 2, and those residents who have not already been nominated for a Trusteeship are vainly endeavoring to bring about a condition that will place them in the race for public office.

Twenty years ago James Blount, the prison guard, was a hearty, well-preserved man, who only felt his fifty years when something less agreeable than sitting down was proposed to him. He drew a pension for wounds received in the civil war. His father had left him a cottage on the corner just opposite to the side entrance of the penitentiary grounds, with a small but profitable grocery business in the rear.

That a launch is a matter of mathematics, as well as of great skill and labor, is shown by the fact that the man of science who has the matter in charge always makes a set of calculations showing the strain on the ship and its precise condition at practically every foot of the journey down the ways.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., Nov. 23. -- A special Commission in Lunacy, appointed by Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court descended upon Amityville early this morning like a storm out of a clear sky, and succeeded in rousing the peaceful town to a state of excitement never known before in its history.

Moll Cutpurse's entrance into a gang of thieves was beset by no difficulty. The Bear Garden, always her favorite resort, had made her acquainted with all the divers and rumpads of the town. The time, moreover, was favorable to enterprise, and once again was genius born into a golden age.
