Raymond Elroy and James E. Morse, who were arrested Friday, on suspicion of having been concerned in robberies in Baltimore, Md., and Hoboken, N.J., were remanded again yesterday, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, to await the arrival of police officers from Baltimore, who hope to be able to identify them.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 23. -- A systematic effort is being made by the veterans of the war in this locality toward the preservation of authentic relics of the war. There are many curiosities and memorials in individual hands that can be secured and placed lm a war museum, to be built here in the future, preserving them thereby for posterity.

In the Fall we have a flower show, but the flowers that bloom in the Spring have something to do with the case; so have insects, and it is a wise flower that knows its own insects. But, like most gentle things, the flower takes pains that its insect wooer shall be in no doubt as to what it is in search of.

TRENTON, Nov. 23. -- The Republican Governor-elect. John W. Griggs, has become very weary of office seekers. They do not give him a moment's rest. They sit on his front steps at nights, and follow him about days. He cannot escape from them.

WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 23. -- The offer of $10,000 from the chief of the Osage Tribe of Indians to rebuild St. Ann's Academy, at St. Paul, Kan., marks the beginning of a new era in the educational progress of the American Indians. As soon as the destruction of the academy became known to Crief Lawrence, he immediately telegraphed to Father Sebastian instructing his to draw on him for $10,000 to rebuild the academy.

Oscar Hammerstein's Olympia, on which an army of men has been working since its owner bought the block front in Broadway, Forty-fourth to Forty-fifth Street, last January, will be opened to-morrow evening with Rice's "Excelsior. Jr.," in the theatre, and a variety show, in which all the performers will be foreigners, in the music hall.

SUMMIT, N.J., Nov. 23. -- Miss Lulu Rubsaman gave a fair at her home, in Hillside Avenue, yesterday afternoon, for the benefit of the Fresh Air and Convalescent Home, and it was well attended and very successful.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 23. -- The handful of cottagers that remain here will stay until Thanksgiving, as the weather continues far from wintry and cottage life has not yet been found at all uncomfortable.

There has been almost a surfeit of Oriental art in the United States during the last decade or two. Our houses and our persons have been overladen with Chinese and Japanese stuffs until it has come about that almost every country cottage even runs riot with impossible dragons and storks on plaques and fans innumerable.

The Eastern press and people newer allow an opportunity to pass to cast a slur upon the sturdy men of Arizona. Our people are held up as the quintessence of ignorance, vulgarism, Arizona is not alone in this connection, the entire West and Southwest are included in their category of simplicity. Every joke published by the Eastern press, having for its body an exhibition of ignorance or uncouthness, is shouldered upon Western men.

BRISTOL, R.I., Nov. 23. -- The Winter promises to be a busy one at the Herreshoff shop. Nearly everything is in readiness for committing of the torpedo boats. The south construction shop has been extended harborward about twenty-five feet, for the purpose of giving length enough to the shop, so that the boats can be built in it.

One of the unconsidered trifles that the Mikado has picked up as the result of the Chinese war is the monopoly of camphor. That drug is produced only in Japan and Formosa, and, though a variety known as Borneo camphor is obtained from Borneo and Sumatra, it cannot compete with the product of the evergreen laurel of the Eastern Asiatic Islands.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Some interesting figures are produced by the report of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue to show what proportion of the income tax would have been paid by different sections if the act had not been declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court. The South, it must be remembered, was particularly favorable to this plan of securing revenue.

BERLIN, Nov. 23. -- Dr. Stoecker's paper, Das Volk, publishes without comment today the announcement that the ecclesiastical courts are about to inquire into Stoecker's relations with Baron von Hammerstein, formerly chief editor of the Kreuz-Zeitung, who absconded some time ago while under charges of forgery and embezzlement.

During the past season Western Europe has been practically free from cholera. The presence of the disease last year in Germany, France, Belgium, and Austria and the survival of it in epidemic form through the Winter in Russia indicated that there might be a dangerous outbreak in the western parts of the Continent during the warm season of 1895, but the fears thus excited were not realized.

JAMAICA, L.I., Nov. 23. -- Postmaster George C. Damon has at last succeeded in securing for this village a free-delivery mail service. He has been trying to have the free-delivery system introduced ever since he succeeded George W. Callow as Postmaster, a year ago.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The cool contempt with which Prime Minister Salisbury, when speaking last Tuesday at the meeting of the National Union of Conservatives, treated the proposals of the protectionists relative to the imposition of a tariff on wheat, oats, barley, and hops has keenly disappointed the agriculturists, who trusted that the accession of the Tories to office would imply some modicum of protection.

JAMAICA, L.I., Nov. 23. -- The fact has just become public that by a bill that was allowed to pass unnoticed through the Legislature of 1895, the local Board of Directors of the Jamaica Normal School has been deprived of the power to choose its own plans for the proposed school, and that the plans drawn by the State Architect must be used.

The annual meeting of the State Charities Aid Association was held yesterday afternoon in the United Charities Building. Dr. George G. Wheelock presided, in the absence of the President of the association, Joseph H. Choate.

The new submarine boat Goubet is, our Paris correspondent tells us, propelled by a screw, which also serves the purpose of a rudder, the shaft being joined to enable its being moved right or left. The horse power is extremely small, (one or two.) this, it is said, being sufficient under water, where there is no wavemaking to give 7 or 8 knots.
The Horse Show still is, although its visible form is no longer with us. Nothing big enough to crush out the remembrances of it has yet appeared upon the horizon of the metropolis.

ALBANY, Nov. 23. -- The work of getting the State Capitol into shape for the incoming Legislature is progressing slowly, and will be finished not many days before the session of 1896 begins. Superintendent of Public Buildings Frederick Easton has been busy all Summer on the Executive mansion and the Capitol.

New-York and St. Louis have been society rivals for years, and their rivalry is not at an end. They are both old enough to remember when coronets were the most precious baubles on this old earth, and now that these trinkets are sold to the highest bidder, both the old society belles of long ago are wild with excitement over the opportunity to possess them.

This is the second edition of this volume of verses, and that fact should be in itself an assurance that its contents must have attractions for an uncommon number of readers. On turning the pages of the little book, one easily finds reasons why these verses, though of no striking quality, appeal to many persons.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 23. -- For several years the students of Stevens Institute have published an annual called "Link." The editors of the edition for '96 recently requested President Henry Morton to allow them to use his portrait for the frontispiece. This he refused to do. He said he did not like the way in which the publication had been conducted.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 23. -- The last week has been one of importance to the Lakewood season. The opening of the Lakewood, the largest hotel at this resort, on Thursday, three weeks in advance of last year, and the announcement that the Laurel-in-the-Pines will open on Dec. 14 must be taken as unmistakable signs of the advancing season.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 23. -- According to most authorities, the Ohio River is a steady-going, reputable stream, free from many of the perversities which distinguish the Mississippi or the Missouri. Its one great weakness, these authorities remark, is the inability to maintain the happy mean between low water and flood.

The rapid spread throughout this country of the love and practice of the health-inspiring game of curling led to a desire among a number of its votaries some thirty years ago to have a federation of clubs similar in character to "Oor Auld Respectit Mither," as the curlers fondly term the Royal Caledonian Curling Club.

Frequently it is a sort of professional fondness for writing that is the final cause of the new book. Teaching history is Mr. Oman's business, his field of labor being the University of Oxford. A desire to be known as a historian as well as a teacher of history undoubtedly explains why we have this new work on England.

Passengers by the Brooklyn Bridge cable cars at "rush" hours who may find themselves on a platform because they have been urged or pushed through the gates by employes of the road, and are unable to enter any car because its standing and seating capacity will not permit of the admission of a single additional person, may abandon hope of redress, through the average jury, in case of injury or death.

New-York had an interesting visitor last week. She was a little lady, who appeared and disappeared in a quick, bright, and eminently characteristic way, like a small meteor -- if meteors ever arrive by steamer --somewhere in the Back Bay regions of Boston.

The German Legal Aid Society is compelled to make an appeal to the public for a more liberal support. It finds its work circumscribed by a lack of funds, as the demands made upon it have greatly increased year by year.

DANNEMORA, N.Y., NOV. 23. -- The Clinton Prison at Dannemora is the one which has been most severely attacked by the little nest of politicians who desire control of the prison machinery of the State, because it is at this one that the prison methods, so far as the treatment of convicts is concerned, have been made the basis of charges which are now in the hands of Gov. Morton.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Funeral services for Senhor Augusto de Sequeira Thedim, the late Minister from Portugal to the United States, were held this morning at 10 o'clock in St. Matthew's Church.

Alfred W. Martin, thirty years old, a publisher who lives at 253 West Fifty-fourth Street, was held in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday in $2,000 bail for trial on a charge of felonious assault.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Within a year after the famous frigate Kearsarge was wrecked on Roneador Reef, Congress determined to perpetuate the name by giving it to the most powerful defender of American rights that could be designed by American naval constructors, and, by its act of March 2, 1895, authorized two great armored battleships, to ultimately cost, complete, about $5,000,000 each, and to be invulnerable against the heaviest seagoing fighters of any foreign navy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The navy line officers are arrayed for the Winter's campaign. A large number of the officers on duty in Washington, representing, it is claimed, a majority of the officers of the navy at home and abroad, met to-night at the Arlington Hotel, in this city, and discussed the chances of obtaining relief from Congress.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The desertion of the richest Liberals from the party is causing a depletion of the purse of the party. The executive of the National Liberal Federation designs to levy an assessment of a shilling a head upon the members of the party, and it is calculated that this will produce 100,000 yearly, but it can be said that unless the executive is reformed the rank and file will not subscribe.

Prominent members of Good Government Clubs have issued a letter urging Republican members of the clubs to enroll themselves and attend the primaries of their party. A similar appeal, it is proposed, shall be sent to Democratic members of the clubs. But under present conditions of "regularity" where are Good Government Democrats to enroll?
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- Peekskill is very proud of its new hospital -- the Helping Hand Hospital -- which was dedicated and opened with a simple religious service Thursday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The famous Myra Clark Gaines case, it is believed, was finally ended in the Supreme Court of the United States yesterday, when Chief Justice Fuller announced that the appeal of the City of New-Orleans from the judgment of the Circuit Court of the United States for the Eastern District of Louisiana, in favor of the United States, ex. rel. W.W. Whitney, had been dismissed for failure to print the record.

The returns from the Police Courts yesterday indicate that an unusual number of thieves are being arrested. They may also indicate a prevailing epidemic of crime, but the thefts and attempted thefts reported were, as a rule, of minor importance.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Amid the excitement of the busy preparation for the contest with Yale on Manhattan Field, Princeton has been quietly preparing for another contest with Yale of quite another sort. Last Wednesday evening the representatives of Whig and Clio Halls met in the interhall contest in Old Chapel to decide who should represent Princeton in the Yale-Princeton debate, to occur on Dec. 6.

A well-attended meeting of the New-York Protestant Episcopal Mission Society was held at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon in St. Agnes's Chapel, in West Ninety-second Street. Bishop Henry C. Potter, President of the society, presided.

BERLIN, Nov. 24. -- The pending reforms in the old-age insurance measures have led to a squabble between Dr. von Boetticher, Imperial Secretary of State for the Interior, and Dr. von Boediker, President of the Imperial Insurance Office, in which Dr. Grieseman, editor of the North German Gazette, also is involved.
The following are from The Naval and Military Record (British) of Nov. 14:

The attempt to discredit the prison management of this State had its origin soon after Gov. Morton was elected, in 1894. It began when some Republican politicians in Clinton and Franklin Counties cast covetous eyes on every possibly available bit of official patronage, on the one hand, and at their own waning influence on the other.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission has issued a preliminary report of the income and expenditures of railways in the United States for the last fiscal year.

CAMBRIDGE, Nov. 24. -- The chess tournament at Harvard, to determine Harvard's representatives in the intercollegiate chess tournament, which will take place in New-York in the Christmas holidays, is pretty well along. The leader is E.E. Southard, '93, who has a record of eight and a half games won in nine played. Of the other twenty-seven men in the tournament, three are tied for second place.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Nov. 24. -- Fire at 6:45 o'clock this evening destroyed the elevator and a storage building of the Staten Island Milling and Elevator Company on the water front opposite the railroad station. The damage is about $40,000.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Under the title, "Extinguish the Turk," the Rev. John L. Scudder, pastor of the Congregational Tabernacle, gave this evening a prelude on the Armenian massacres.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 24. -- The dinner given last night at the Capital City Club to Mayor Strong and a few associates by Capt. F.L. Lowry of the Lowry Banking Company was a most enjoyable affair. No reporters were present at this dinner, and the speeches were entirely informal.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

I heard a good story about a burglar, or, rather, a sneak thief, in Philadelphia, a while ago. A gentleman was standing with a few other people in front of a store window on Chestnut Street, and as he took out his watch to compare his time with that of the chronometer in the window, he discovered that his timepiece was gone.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott preached in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last evening on "Christianity and Communism." The sermon, which was heard by a large congregation, was the third of a series on "Christianity and Our Social Problems." Dr. Abbott will speak next Sunday on "Christianity and Socialism."

The delegates to the Central Labor Union were somewhat surprised yesterday afternoon when they saw a policeman stationed at the door of Clarendon Hall. There has not been trouble at a meeting of the Central Labor Union since the Socialist element tried to capture the organization some years ago and was repulsed.

The centennial of the Duane Methodist Episcopal Church was celebrated with impressive services yesterday, in the brick church, on Hudson Street, near Spring. The celebration will continue throughout the week.

It is reported from North Carolina that a "drummer evangelist" has met with great success in converting liquor dealers, which appears to be his specialty, or, as he might say, his "line." The methods of the modern revivalist are indeed so nearly those of the commercial traveler that it is no wonder that an evangelist who has had actual experience in drumming should be highly successful.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 24. -- Enthusiasm is running high here to the end of making Wheelman's Day, on the 30th inst., the biggest thing in a cycling way that the South has ever seen. The festivities leading up to the great event will begin on Friday evening, when an illuminated parade of wheelmen through the principal streets will engage several thousand riders of both sexes.

The ready sale of this new edition of Browning is by no means an indication that his popularity will continue to increase. Most of this edition has probably been absorbed by members, or those who were members, of the absurd Browning societies, and they perhaps have purchased the books under the hallucination that new type may make clear to them the meaning of the poet whom they never understood.

William Hannigan, the father of David F. Hannigan, who was acquitted last Friday, on the ground of insanity, of the killing of Solomon H. Mann, was buried yesterday afternoon. It had been announced that the body would be taken from the house, 403 West Fifty-fifth Street, at 1 o'clock, but the funeral party did not start until after 2 o'clock.

LEWES, Del., Nov. 24. -- Complications are likely to result from the seizure and detention of the schooner Joseph W. Foster by the Government on suspicion of violating neutrality laws by carrying munitions of war and men to the insurgent forces in Cuba. Capt. Wheaton has abandoned his vessel to the Government, and proposes to sue for damages on account of the seizure and delay.

ROME, Nov. 24. -- The Pope attended mass to-day in his private chapel, but afterward, acting on the advice of Dr. Lapponi, he went to bed. The representative in this city of The United Press learns that the Pope is suffering from an attack of rheum. Dr. Lapponi, his body physician, is in attendance upon him. His secretaries were engaged at the Vatican this morning, as usual.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- The chief officer and five of the crew of the American ship Belle O'Brien, Capt. Colley, from San Francisco June 19 for Queenstown, have landed in a small boat at Kerry Head, south of the entrance to the River Shannon, Ireland.

A ratification meeting of the Irish National Alliance was held last night in the Grand Opera House, Eighth Avenue and Twenty-third Street. The meeting was called to ratify the proceedings of the Irish National Alliance Convention held in Chicago in September last and of indorsing the programme enunciated there.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Some of the members of the First Methodist Episcopal Church are astonished because of the denunciation of a young woman by the Rev. Dr. J.B. Graw, pastor of the church. The young woman's offense consisted of teaching her younger sister and several of her girl friends the art of dancing.
John Pettingill, the noted wild man of the Wise River country, died suddenly last Friday, near Silver Star, Mon.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- Early in the Summer the Board of Trustees decided to transfer the psychological laboratory from its old quarters in White Hall to the more spacious fourth floor of Morrill Hall. Now, with additional space and new apparatus, the department is considered to be the best equipped of any college in this country.

The Heine Memorial Fair came to a successful close last night at the Lenox Lyceum. Thus the first chapter of the American history of the unfortunate memorial of Heinrich Heine has ended in a triumph for its projectors. The remaining chapter is now in the hands of the Park Commissioners.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 24. -- Mayor Strong was in exceedingly good spirits when a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES called on him this morning at the Aragon House. With him were Gen. C.H.T. Collis, Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Public Works; Samuel Spencer, President of the Southern Railway Company, and J. Seaver Page.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- A boatman known to the members of the New-Rochelle Yacht Club as "John" was shot in the neck yesterday afternoon through the accidental discharge of a rifle which Lawyer Charles W. Voltz of Brooklyn was showing to a friend in the main room of the clubhouse.

Hayward was at that time (1856) in the full swing of his society success, and quite a power in the London world. These were the days of dowagers. Viscount Palmerston was Premier, and old Lady Palmerston was a queen of society.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 24. -- The steamer Mary Patten of the New-York and Long Branch Line grounded at 6 o'clock last night in the Shrewsbury River.

If a circle be described, with the Charleston City Hall as a centre and a radius of fifteen or twenty miles, there may be found within its limits at least twenty-five different species of wild animals, several of them in sufficient numbers to make their capture for the sake of their skins a profitable employment.

BERLIN, Nov. 24. -- Reports received from Constantinople by diplomats here show that the situation in the Turkish capital is quieter. It is hoped that further measures on the part of the powers will not be needed.

" A Word on the Armenian Atrocities and America's Duty" was the subject of the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton's morning sermon, in the Church of the Divine Paternity, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, yesterday. He said that in Armenia there was a tragedy in progress which entitled its people to the active sympathy of the nations, but especially of the Christian people of the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The Director of the Mint has submitted his report to the Secretary of the Treasury, covering the operations of the mints and assay offices of the United States during the last fiscal year, together with the statistics of foreign countries relative to the production and coinage of gold and silver and the monetary condition of each country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The revenue cutter Bear, the last Government vessel to leave Bering Sea this Fall, brought some startling evidence of the effect of pelagic sealing on the Pribilof, or Seal, Islands.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 24. -- Mayor Strong and other well-known citizens of New-York, including the members of Squadron A, attended church here to-day. The soldiers marched to St. Philip's Protestant Episcopal Church this afternoon, preceded by a full band and followed by the Gate City Guards as an escort.

The Republicans in Congress are not to be allowed to bring forward tariff-tinkering bills without being held to account by the cooler-headed men of their own party. We have already noted the admonition of the press and some of the representatives of the Northwest. A still more striking, though indirect, warning was given by ex-Senator MILLER of this State last week at the annual dinner of the Home Market Club of Boston.

These are the days that try the cycler's mettle. During this genuinely wintry weather the boreal blasts are rifting through the ranks of the wheeling army and sharply sorting out those in whom the sporting blood runs warm. Wide swaths have been cut through the bicycle pageants of the boulevards, yet enough of them is left to show that the spirit of Sparta still has some echoes in the wheeling fraternity.

The first of the Sunday night concerts was given at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. An audience of fairly large size was present, and what was lacking in numbers was made up in applause. The solo performers were Franz Ondricek, the violinist; Mme. Francis Saville, soprano, and M. Plancon, basso.

SAN JOSE, Cal., Nov. 24. -- A comet was discovered by Mr. Brooks of New-York on Friday morning. It was observed at Lick Observatory Saturday morning, and its place determined and telegraphed to the central station for distribution to other observatories.

There is too much rule of thumb, too great a want of precision, too close an adherence to old-fashioned ways in his farming to please an expert. He has no pretension to the infinite care with which the French or Swiss peasant will utilize every scrap of ground.

Judge Buck of Spokane has found out how embarrassing it is for a man in his position to have a wife engaged in social reform movements. The defendant was John Considine, the statesman, and the prosecuting witness was I.P. McCoombs, who lately completed his term for robbing the fire relief fund.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 24. -- In an interview to-day, M.E. Ingalls, President of the Big Four and Chesapeake and Ohio Railroads, said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- Postmaster General Wilson, in his annual report of the operations of the Post Office Department, remarks that the financial and industrial depression, which has seriously affected the revenues of the Postal Service for the past two years and disappointed the estimates of his predecessors, extended far enough into the fiscal year 1895 to make an unusually wide gap between revenues and expenditures.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The text of the characteristically impudent letter which Senator William E. Chandler of New-Hampshire a few days ago addressed to President Cleveland on the subject of the recent agreement of railroad Presidents was made public to-night, as follows:

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 24. -- Michael Anzio, an Italian barber at 97 Ferry Street, cut his throat to-day under peculiar circumstances, and, as a result, he is lying on a cot in St. Michael's Hospital, while Hugh Madden, a shoemaker, of 116 Madison Street, who was indirectly responsible for Anzio's condition, is held at the Third Precinct Station on a charge of atrocious assault and battery.

That the masked robbers who entered Walters's saloon in Mott Haven, one of whom shot and killed Richard Pope, belonged to a gang that has been committing daring robberies in different parts of the country was a theory reached by the police in this city after a few hours' work on the mystery.
The last vestige of the old Striker and Mott manses, which are on the North River, between Fifty-second and Fifty-fifth Streets, will soon have disappeared.

People who recall the adventure of Senor Fombona Palacio, an attach of the Venezuelan Legation who accosted a lady on the streets of New-York without the formality of an introduction, and who was fined in the police court for that breach of the proprieties of social life, may perhaps be surprised to learn that Senor Palacio is again in Washington in his former position.

BERLIN, Nov. 24. -- The time for hunting which is allowed to the Kaiser before his attention will be engaged in the direction of political and Court affairs by the resumption of the session of the Reichstag and the opening of the Winter season will be passed upon the royal estates in Prussian Saxony, where the Emperor will go Monday.

Our Republican friends are beginning to hear complaints in the West about the proposed revision of the wool and woolens schedules of the tariff. For example, The Chicago Tribune (Rep.) says, with reference to the expressed opinion of Congressman CONNELLY that the duties on wool should be restored:

On the French Line steamship La Bourgogne, which arrived yesterday, was Admiral Kirkland, who was relieved by Secretary Herbert from the command of the European squadron, at that time lying off Marseilles.

Interest among the members of the Brooklyn bowling clubs is on the increase. Thursday nights have been set aside at the Union League Club for the members' wives and daughters. The Montauks also announce a series of receptions on their allays.
The Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman of the Temple Emanu-El yesterday lectured on "Max Nordau and a True Remedy for Moral Degeneracy." He said, in part:

The press dispatches of yesterday reported two lynchings, one in Georgia and the other in Texas. In the latter State a mob hanged a negro who was accused of having driven over a little white girl in the road. But it was discovered afterward that this negro was innocent. The lynchers had killed the wrong man; the negro who had driven over the child made his escape.

The Abyssinia Baptist Church, 166 Waverley Place, was crowded last evening, and it was necessary to send for policemen to keep back the throng that came to see and hear Claretta Nora Avery, the little colored girl preacher. Finally the lecture room in the basement was opened for an overflow meeting. This hall was soon crowded, and hundreds were turned away.

There is a corner of Paris where the theatrical outbursts of politics are not heard, where there is much agitation, nevertheless -- a special, curious corner, noisy, very vivid in its hours of feverish intensity. It is the Conservatoire, where candidates for places as pupils are now passing their examinations.
In two of yesterday morning's newspapers the following advertisements appeared:

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 24. -- The social part of Rutgers College life will begin on Dec. 6, when the Delta Chapter of the Zeta Psi Fraternity will give its annual dance at its chapter house, on College Avenue. This is always an event much appreciated by the society people of this city, and many guests from out of town look forward to it.

A fire at 513 East Eighty-fifth Street yesterday forenoon destroyed nearly $1,000 worth of property and frightened the tenants of adjoining flathouses so that they rushed into the street. The fire started in the cellar and was not discovered until smoke suddenly filled the hallways.

The question arose as to the date at which a comet should be seen again. We muse observe that the question was complicated by the fact that the body, in the course of its voyage around the sun, was exposed to the incessant disturbing action produced by the attraction or the several planets.

The experience of the last eight years with the inter-State commerce law has led to a very decided change of opinion on the subject of pooling agreements between competing railroad lines, which are prohibited by that law. The demand of the railroad companies for a change in the law which shall legalize such agreements is now very generally supported by commercial bodies which represent the shipping interests and the general public.

The deer season in Minnesota closes to-day, and from this date the real work of the Minnesota Game Commission should be done in the prevention of poaching. On the very day that the season closes, the conditions for which every hunter in the woods has been longing occur. The snow falling in Minneapolis to-day is pretty general up north, and much heavier, especially in the territory most frequented by big game.

Capt John Codman, well known throughout Utah, has a short article in a recent issue of your paper anent the first State election in Utah, held on the 5th of the present month. It is regrettable that a man of Mr. Codman's intelligence and familiarity with the people should have been unable to distinguish between the Republican talk of protection and the attitude of the early Mormon leaders, as to local industries.

Within about an hour's ride of the city, at Port Kennedy, there has recently been discovered, or rather rediscovered, a cave of unusual interest to the scientific world; in fact, no equally valuable find his been made on the Eastern coast of the United States for many years.

Cyclists who have had occasion to transfer their wheels on the trains of the New-York Central Railroad will be surprised to learn that the rate on bicycles will be raised on Dec. 1 to 20 per cent. of first-class fare. The Central is one of the pioneer roads in the matter of charging for the carrying of wheels, the rate in the past having been about 12 per cent. of the regular passenger tariff.

Much has been said and written about Thomas Hardy's work, but very little, indeed, is generally known of the man himself. An obvious reason is the novelist's dislike of personalities, his shrinking from public curiosity, and the simple, serene -- almost mediaeval -- tone of nature that dominates him.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24. -- The navy plays football this year as it never played before. The play of the cadets is sport. It never lets up. From the moment the contest is on to its close the navy fires its broadsides against the opposing line or sends one of its rifle gun backs around the wings of the enemy with the same unflagging, tireless spirit. Few of its men get hurt.

Wilhelmina Arnett, the young cloak model who attempted to commit suicide in the vestibule of the home of Candy Manufacturer C.F. Winkemeier, 79 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, Saturday night, was in a critical condition in the Seney Hospital last night, and it is feared she cannot recover.

We called attention some weeks since to the statement by The London Economist of the enormous inflation of prices in the South African mining ventures and in stocks connected with and growing out of these. In its latest number The Economist tabulates the prices for the early part of September and those for the 11th of November -- had the prices for the preceding Saturday been taken, the change would have been even more marked.

Col. Albert H. Rogers, who was Deputy Commissioner under former Street-Cleaning Commissioner Coleman, was committed yesterday in the Yorkville Police Court, by Magistrate Crane, for examination as to his sanity.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 24. -- Miss K.L. Strong, '91, of Rochester addressed the Hellenic Society of Vassar College Saturday evening. Miss Strong spoke of "Modern Athens," a subject on which she was qualified to speak through her residence and study in Athens a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The Turkish Legation in this city has received from the Porte the following telegram:

The steamship Mississippi, Capt. Gates, of the Atlantic Transport Line, arrived yesterday after a most tempestuous voyage. She came from London by the way of Halifax, although she had no intention of touching at Halifax when she started for this port. She put in there to replenish her supply of coal.

The averages of the New-York Cricket Association have been issued by Secretary Hake. The club records were published some time ago, showing the Paterson Cricket Club first, with an unbeaten record. The loss of two score books prevented the compilation of the individual figures, for they could not be made up until duplicate reports had been received from several clubs.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24. -- Under the caption "A Japanese Invasion," a local paper last evening publishes a story that will amuse American manufacturers.

Officers are still gentlemen nowadays, but they are also soldiers; to be called soldiers is their best title of honor, to behave like good and true soldiers their highest aim. The change is, indeed, remarkable. Time was when they were almost ashamed of their honorable calling. It was kept in the background, everything connected with it was tabooed.
The enforcement of the Sunday excise law in the city yesterday was much the same as on preceding Sundays under reform rule. In all, fifty-five arrests were made.

A protracted session of the Atchison Reorganization Committee was held yesterday afternoon in the committee's offices down town, and a subsequent session was held in a hotel up town last evening. The matter under discussion was the selection of a Board of Directors, a Chairman, a President, and a Vice President.

Old Admiral Farragut said that the best defense against an enemy's guns is not armor plate but a fierce and well-directed return fire that will silence the foe. He believed in protecting his ships, but he relied for success upon good guns and brave men. Battles are won with them, not with armor.

AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 25. -- The trial in the United States court here, of Samuel Gillett, formerly teller of the wrecked Rome bank, was interesting to-day, owing to the confessions, under oath, of ex-Cashier John E. Bielby, chief witness for the prosecution.

There was a large assemblage of people interested in the work of All Souls' Church Friendly Aid House at the house 248 East Thirty-fourth Street last evening. The house has been closed since February last and has been undergoing many improvements and repairs, which are now very nearly completed.

Louis Herbert Moore, the London manager of The United Press, who is now in Turkey in the interest of his association, sends the following account of a visit to Mgr. Iszmirlian, the Armenian Patriarch:

Messrs. Hoffman Brothers have bought of the Jeremiah W. Dimick estate the five-story brick building, 17 Hubert Streei, south side, 52.11 feet east of Greenwieh; Street, 25 by 25. The piece 'adjoins th'e' L-shaped property recently bought by the: same firm, giving them a plot 75 by 100 on Greenwich Street and 47.11 feet front on Hubert Street.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25. -- The entire Princeton football team, with the exception of Dudley Riggs, returned to the college to-day to attend recitations. None of them was seriously hurt, their mental injuries being far greater than the physical ones. Riggs went to his home in Baltimore for a few days' rest. He is not badly injured. The players will say nothing concerning their defeat.

The finest stock farm in the country is in the Madison Square Garden this week. The first annual show of the Live Stock Society of America is being held and the managers of the show have induced the owners of fine stock to place their animals on exhibition. The result is that the Garden is stocked with cattle, sheep, swine, poultry, farm produce, fruit, and vegetables.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Senator Hale called at the Navy Department to-day and had an interview with Secretary Herbert. The estimates to be submitted to Congress from the department were discussed fully, and Senator Hale assured the Secretary that the Senate would do something substantial for the service.

The City Magistrates held their regular monthly meeting last night in Jefferson Market Court. In executive session the Wilde cumulative sentence law was discussed. All the Magistrates think the law is faulty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The Nicaragua Canal Commission, in the report which it has filed with the President, calls attention to many obstacles to the construction of the channel, which have heretofore received little consideration. It also estimates the cost of construction at a much greater sum than has been fixed by promoters of the enterprise.

W.P. Severance, as attorney for J.B. Brewster Co., the carriage corporation, moved in the Supreme Court yesterday to set aside an attachment granted to Henry H. Armstead, one of the creditors of the company.

Our esteemed contemporary, The Hartford (Conn.) Times, publishes the following, under the headlines "Billions Unclaimed; Fortunes for Americans in the English Chancery Court," at the beginning of a long article relating to property in England to which, it is alleged, American heirs are entitled:
The investigation of the Dock Department by the Commissioners of Accounts was resumed yesterday afternoon.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- It is again announced that the Illinois Central Railroad Company will, inside of eighteen months, change the motive power on the suburban service from steam to electricity. Mr. J.F. Wallace, chief engineer of the company, said yesterday:

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 25. -- J. Sterling Morton, Secretary of Agriculture, has written H. J. Smalley, Secretary of the Minnesota Democratic Association, a letter which has been read here with a good deal of interest. It is in answer to Mr. Smalley's request that he address the association on Jackson's Day.

Once more the insufficiency of the arrangements at the Bridge terminals was demonstrated yesterday after the fog that closed over the city about 2 o'clock P.M. made persons unwilling to trust to the ferries for early conveyance to Brooklyn.

The Aldermen, acting as a Board of County Canvassers, met in the Aldermanic Council Chamber yesterday, and officially declared the vote cast at the last election. The results thus declared become the official returns, and the County Clerk will issue the certificates of election to the Judges-elect of the Court of General Sessions to the Justices-elect of the City Court, and to the Assemblymen-elect.

We notice that at a Spiritualist seance in this city Sunday evening several persons who had been admitted to "the circle" refused to observe those "conditions" which are essential to the success of an exhibition of materialized shades. It is well known, we think, that whenever these "conditions" are not accepted implicitly by the members of the circle, the exhibition is bound to be a failure.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The statement is made here to-night that it has been decided to remove the body of Gen. W.S. Hancock from Norristown, Penn., to the Arlington National Cemetery.

Oscar Hammerstein had to call on the police last night to help him keep people out of his Olympia, one of the most colossal places of amusement in the world. He had seating room for 6,000; he sold 10,000 tickets. Some persons saw the theatrical performance and heard and observed the concert and music-hall entertainments, while 5,000, Mr. Hammerstein says, slid through the mud and slush of Longacre back into the ranks of Cosmopolis.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 25. -- The conference on the Canadian copyright question commenced this afternoon, there being present Sir Charles Tupper and J.A. Quimet, representing the Government; representatives of the Canadian publishers, the Canadian Copyright Association, and the Canadian Press Association; Hall Caine, representing the British authors, and F.R. Daldy, representing the British Copyright Association.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The marriage of Lieut. Commander W.S. Cowles, Naval Attache to the United States Embassy here, and Miss Anna Roosevelt, sister of Theodore Roosevelt, President of the Board of Police Commissioners of New-York City, was celebrated in St. Andrew's Church, Westminster, to-day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- In his dealings with those of opposite political faith, Senator Chandler is generally splenetic and sometimes funny. His recent address to the President on the subject of the proposed agreement of the Railroad Traffic Association, while characteristically impertinent, is robbed of all point by reason of the Senator's inaccuracies.

Miss Edith Rockefeller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller, and Mr. Harold H. McCormick of Chicago, will be married at the bedside of the bridegroom in the Hotel Buckingham at 12 o'clock to-day, instead of having the grand wedding which had been planned to take place in the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church at the same hour.
The Union Leaguers scored their third successive victory last night in the senior tournament of the Inter-Club League of Brooklyn by defeating the Irvings on their own alleys. The scores:

An investigation of the city railways was begun yesterday by the Assembly Committee on Railways in the old Special Sessions rooms in the Tombs. Of the members of the committee, there were present S. Fred Nixon, Chairman; William B. Stephenson, Edward W. Thompson, and Edwin P. Stewart.

The afternoon sale of the household effects of Mrs. Paran Stevens took place yesterday, despite the wretched weather. Two statues were sold among other things. One of these was a figure by W.W. Story, whose recent death in Rome lent additional interest to the work. It was of "Cleopatra," and brought $1,600.

The engagement is announced of Walter Launt Palmer of Albany, N.Y., to Miss Zoe Marguerite de Vauthrin Wyndham, daughter of the late Horace Wyndham of the Castle, Cokermouth, England, and ward of Sir Lambert Playfair.

An important illicit distillery plant was captured yesterday morning by Deputy Internal Revenue Officers Driscoll, Hahn, Fortman, Kinzler, Gambichler, and Stroh. Two prisoners, one an old offender, were captured, after a struggle in which several women took active part.

At the Metropolitan Opera House last night one of the familiar double bills of two years ago was brought forward again. Gounod's "Philemon et Baucis" was given, followed by Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rusticana." One would suppose that a pretty contrast like this might appeal with considerable force to artistic taste, but the size of the audience demonstrated, just as it used to, that this sort of programme has no potency in New-York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Mr. Reed, soon to be Speaker of the House in the Fifty-fourth Congress, has had his time fully occupied to-day in receiving political callers in his room at the Shoreham. Mr. Reed is in robust health and talks most entertainingly of his Summer outing on the coast of Maine.

ATLANTA, Nov. 25. -- The Manhattan Day exercises in the Auditorium were opened by the band of the Fifth United States Infatry, which played "The Star-Spangled Banner." At the first notes of the music every one stood up. J. Seaver Page, who had been selected as the Chairman of the meeting, then said that the opening was an auspicious one.
PARIS, Nov. 25. -- Jules Barthelemy Saint-Hilaire died in his chair in his study, where he was found by members of his family, last evening.

" Dr." Henry R. Rogers, the promoter of spirits; Mrs. Matilda Chadwick, the "spook" of the show, and Elias S. Whitmore, an old friend of the "doctor," were arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Crane, in the Yorkville Police Court.

To the always tastefully adorned stage of the little Lyceum Theatre last evening Mr. Daniel Frohman's stock company, now beginning the ninth year of its existence, returned. A full house gave the players a kindly welcome. If the enthusiasm was less marked than at the beginning of the previous seasons, that was not the fault of the weather or the play, or of the acting.

David F. Hannigan, who was acquitted last Friday of the murder of Solomon H. Mann, on the ground of insanity, will be taken to-day to the Hudson River Insane Asylum, at Poughkeepsie. If the doctors declare him sane, he will be set free. Justice Ingraham drew up the commitment yesterday afternoon in the Court of Oyer and Terminer.
The Park Board has accepted the resignation of Secretary Charles De F. Burns whose management of the patronage of the Park Department was exposed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES last Friday.

Adolph Hirschkopf and Meyer Dietscheck were arraigned before Recorder Golf in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, on the charge of murder, in causing the death of Lizzie Yaeger by a fire which, it is alleged, they started at 129 Suffolk Street, May 23, 1894.

The laying on the table by the Dock Commissioners of Nathan Straus's application for the use of part of the West Fifty-second Street and East Third Street piers as coal-distributing stations for the poor brought from Mr. Straus a letter, read at last Thursday's meeting, in which he detailed at length the character and purpose of his humanitarian enterprise.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 25. -- Manhattan Day at the Cotton States and International Exposition has come and gone, leaving a lasting impression on the minds of all those who took part in it. The pageant was fine, the speeches were short, and the interchange of courtesies which followed the formal exercises was delightful.

Evacuation Day was celebrated by a social reunion and dinner by the Sons of the American Revolution in the Hotel Normandie last night. Robert B. Roosevelt presided in the absence of President Chauncey M. Depew. Gen. Horatio C. King of Brooklyn was elected to the vacancy in the Board of Managers caused by the death of Ebenezer K. Wright.

One of the principal subjects under discussion at the meeting of the Board of Directors of the National Board of Trade of Cycle Manufacturers, held yesterday in the Vanderbilt Building, was the sanction of cycle exhibitions. Numerous applications for leave to hold shows had been received, and the subject received much attention.

The way in which the Platt crowd carried on the Republican enrollment last Saturday night has set the whole party in this city by the ears. Charges and counter-charges are being made in all the districts.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 25. -- Mrs. Samuel P. Colt, who made charges against her husband, is to have an absolute divorce. This has been agreed to by those who represented the different interests at the conference brought after the collapse of the charges made against Col. Colt's conduct at Jackson, N.H.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The full correspondence between Sir Julian Pauncefote, British Ambassador to the United States, and the London Foreign Office, covering the period from May 8, 1894, to Aug. 31, 1895, respecting the claims in connection with the Bering Sea seizures, was received by the State Department to-day. An abstract of it was cabled by The United Press from London a week ago, but many interesting points remained to be covered.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 25. -- William Leonard and Castellar Ansart were convicted in the General Sessions Court to-day on a charge of atrociously assaulting William E. Lewis, station agent of the Central Railroad, at Danforth Avenue.

The mandamus proceedings brought yesterday by Senator T.C. O'Sullivan in the Supreme Court, before Justice Ingraham, sought to compel the Board of County Canvassers to count forty-nine ballots for him which were marked as defective.

Fate seems to have been against the Live Stock Society of America, that is holding its annual show this week at the Madison Square Garden. To begin with, it could not get the Garden in time to have it ready for the opening on Monday. Carpenters found it impossible to get the pens and stalls and coops all ready for the opening hour.

DANNEMORA, Nov. 26. -- To the charges made by the Republican politicians who are after the prison patronage, Warden Walter N. Thayer of the Clinton Prison has made answer so far as the institution at this place is concerned.
BOSTON, NOV. 26. -- A meeting was held this afternoon for the purpose of publicly introducing a project looking toward the improvement of the theatre.

It is more than ninety years since The Edinburgh and Quarterly were started, and the chance of either of them reaching the century of life is generally declared to be remote. Their more unfriendly observers assert, indeed, as they have asserted this week, that they are already dead, and that nothing but the reluctance of their proprietors to part with objects which during their lives have been so conspicuous prevents their being decently buried.

This volume is one of ten into which the papers on our civil war read before the Military Historical Society of Massachusetts have been gathered. A prominent point to strike the reader is the diversity of views entertained by the contributors as to Gen. McClellan's conduct and military capacity.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26. -- Arlington Heights, on the east bank of the Passaic River, in the Township of Kearny, was the scene of a double shooting affray this afternoon, which will result in the death of Thomas Colt, who did the shooting, and the possible maiming of Miss Carrie Plate, whose life Colt made a desperate but futile effort to end, before he fired a bullet into his own brain.

CAMDEN, Nov. 26. -- While seated in the parlor of his home this afternoon explaining to a friend the wonders of the Keeley motor Charles Peterson, a young man, suddenly became insane and made a violent attack on his friend.

A recent experience of one driver, who was driving his own team, by the way, illustrates this. He had been carrying a passenger around town in his cab all the afternoon, with frequent stops, at each of which the "fare" made an ineffectual attempt to quench his abnormal thirst, and he was not too sober when he engaged the cab.

Satisfactory progress of the fortnightly settlement in London, a smaller amount of gold engagements for export than had been looked for, and continued increases in the earnings of all the great railway systems, except those in the Southwest, combined to give a better tone to the railway list. Covering of short contracts by traders indisposed to have obligations outstanding over the coming holiday also tended to give the market an appearance of strength.
VINCENNES, Ind., Nov. 26. -- The boiler of the tugboat W.W. O'Neil exploded to-day at Ludlow, Ky.

Tonquin and the Annamites are new subjects in fiction. Mr. O'Neill thinks the time has come for them, now that China and Japan are so well known. There is no doubt that Mr. O'Neill knows Tonquin well by experience. He must have lived there long enough to absorb some of its spirit, for there is a strange, new charm in these tales, which one feels must be a true thing.

In accordance with the annual custom, the Berkeley Athletic Association last night began the Winter season with a reception and entertainment in the Berkeley Lyceum, which brought each of the several branches of the institution into requisition. The affair was of a complimentary character, only the stockholders and patrons being invited, and the talent appearing was wholly of the amateur world.

The Police Commissioners requested the Board of Aldermen yesterday to allow two iron posts to be erected temporarily at Sixth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, and on Madison Avenue, between Twenty-sixth and Twenty-seventh Streets, for the trial of a new signal system.

Joseph Murray left for Washington last night to hand in his report concerning the Alaska seal fisheries to the Government, and also to furnish evidence upon the disputed boundary line. Mr. Murray went to Alaska as Commissioner of Fisheries and spent the entire Summer sailing through the Alaskan waters and collecting data as to the destruction of the seals.

What Mr. REED has to say as to the policy of the Republican Party in the next Congress must necessarily be interesting. He will be the Speaker of the House and, within certain conventional lines, have the shaping of the course of the majority through his make-up of the committees. Not only that, but he is far and away the strongest man in his party in that body, easily, naturally, and completely its leader.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26. -- It was learned positively to-day that the September term Grand Jury, which adjourned sine die yesterday, returned true bills of indictments against the Consolidated Traction Company and the Newark and South Orange Street Railway Company as corporations, but no individual indictment of officials was returned.

She was seeking a position as stenographer. She had answered an advertisement, "Care X Y Z, The News," and received a letter by the next post from a prominent firm, asking her to call at once. She mounted her "bike" and wheeled forth in the bracing air, with the glad sunshine falling lovingly around her, and the hopes of a twelve-dollar-and-a-half-a-week position.
ALBANY, Nov. 26. -- Gov. Morton and all the State officers except Treasurer Colvin, who is in the South, were at the Capitol to-day for the first time since last Winter. Speaker Fish was also here.
One or two things about the outburst of fury against the Armenians which is now sweeping over the Turkish Empire ought to be clearly understood.
The sale of John T.M. Pierce's library was continued yesterday by Bangs Co. Among the books sold were the following:

CINCINNATI, Nov. 26. -- A terrific windstorm swept over this section last night, doing considerable damage to property. Trees were uprooted buildings unroofed or wrecked, telegraph poles and wires blown down, and several boats in the river were torn from their moorings, and set adrift. The watchmen and crews of packets and towboats were all aboard, and consternation reigned among them.

The time is coming when New-York City and all the other American cities will be well governed, but nobody can say how far away that good time is. If we take the case of New-York for an example, we may discern the beginning of the new era -- there is not a doubt of that. The encouraging signs are sentimental rather than of a material sort.

Law-abiding sportsmen in Maine are unanimous in the opinion that more effective means ought to be provided for the prevention of illegal methods of taking game and shipping it out of the State. Officers of the law in general give the matter little or no attention, and the Game Wardens are neither in number nor in quality what they should be, in view of the importance of the work intrusted to them.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- William Mathers, who keeps a hotel in Broadway, North Scarborough, several miles from this village, was shot and slightly wounded last night by his daughter Annie. The shooting was intentional and probably saved the mother of the girl from being badly hurt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Commander Jewell, the officer in charge of the naval gun factory in Washington, has complained to the Navy Department that there are many defects in the gun forgings which are furnished the service under contract. He states that these defects take the form of splits, some being so fine and short as to be observed with difficulty, while others are from one-fourth to one-half inch in length.

DENVER, Nov. 26. -- The fever in mining speculation shows no signs of abatement; indeed, it seems to be growing each day more virulent. The Colorado newspapers are devoting a vast amount of space to reports from the mining districts and to gossip of the exchanges. Everybody "talks mine." Little else is heard on the streets, in the hotel lobbies, or wherever people are gathered in numbers.

Messrs. Frederick Southack Co. have sold for Mr. Davren to Samuel Henry Corn, at $175,000, the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Seventeenth Street, 22 by 116. This property adjoins 91 and 93 Fifth Avenue, owned by the Messrs. Corn, who are completing a business building on the site.

BOSTON, Nov. 26. -- The official election returns, to be published to-morrow, show that the Senate of 1896 will be composed of 33 Republicans and 7 Democrats, as against 36 Republicans and 4 Democrats in 1895. The House will have but 239 members, there being one vacancy. This will necessitate the issuing of a precept for a new election to fill the vacancy.

In to-day's edition of your valuable paper, I, as a native of Germany, felt particularly interested in an interview your reporter had with Mr. William Steinway. I can only indorse all he said, especially when he pointed out the quiet enjoyment a mechanic or laboring man with his family has in Germany, even on a Sunday at a concert or in a garden, with beer as an incident, but not as a main object.

Mr. Pitt liked practical fun, and used to riot in it with Lady Hester, Charles and James Stanhope, and myself. Once we were resolved to blacken his face with burned cork, which he most strenuously resisted; at the beginning of the fray a servant announced that Lords Castlereagh and Liverpool desired to see him on business.
TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 26. -- Dispatches from different parts of the country report great damage to property by yesterday's gale.

The Assembly committee, S. Fred Nixon Chairman, appointed to inquire into the condition of the surface and elevated railways in this city resumed its investigation yesterday morning, at the Hotel Metropole.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 26. -- The Rev. Julius Feicke, who was until Sept. 30 pastor of the First German Evangelical Reformed Church, Monmouth Street, near Mercer, is the proprietor and bartender of a saloon at the northeast corner of Fifth and Garden Streets, Hoboken.

And if you enter the door what do see? Everything that is new and old, strange and beautiful, Dutch or Roman, Japanese or Italian, English or French, dominated and harmonized by one man's triumphant taste. Everywhere you look you are met by some sign of the owner's genius for decorative design and arrangement.
ALBANY, Nov. 26. -- By the decision in the case of Daniel Schmeer against the Gaslight Company of Syracuse, the liability of gas companies is extended.

It is satisfactory to observe that Great Britain has offered to submit to arbitration the question of the ownership of Trinidad. If the report be true, the British confidence in the British title must be much greater than any facts accessible to the public about the history of the island would lead anybody to believe.
Two men lost their lives by an explosion at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning in Hammerstein's Olympia, at Forty-fourth Street and Broadway, and ten others were badly scalded.

There was some lively bowling at Reid's alleys in Church Street last evening, when three teams in the tournament of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs met in regularly scheduled games. The "fives" represented the Jersey City Club Wheelmen, the Catholic Club Cyclers of Jersey City, and the Harlem Wheelmen of this city.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The quintet of bowlers from the Montclair Wheelmen came down in the rain to-night to try conclusions with the Atalanta Wheelmen's five, who, since the tournament of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey started, have lost only one game. There came near being no game, but for the fact that Ernest Miller arrived from Hartford, Conn., at the eleventh hour and joined the waiting Atalantas.
Ex-President Harrison returned to the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night from Saratoga, where he had been to see his nephew "Baby" McKee, who has been ill, but who is now recuperating.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Senator Morgan returned from Alabama this morning and first saw the abstract of the correspondence between Sir Julian Pauncefote and the British Foreign Office when it was shown him by a reporter of The United Press. After reading it carefully, Senator Morgan characterized the statements of the British Ambassador as a "piece of presumptive arrogance."

Thirty old Californians met last night at Zangheri's, in East Twenty-second Street, at the twenty-second annual dinner of the Associated Pioneers of the Territorial Days of California. On the walls of the dining room were hung old signs of the early days of California.

LONDON. NOV. 26. -- The Daily News will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Constantinople saying it is generally believed that if the diplomats' demand for a second guardship shall be refused by the Sultan, a serious decision will be taken.

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 26. -- A blizzard descended upon Chicago yesterday afternoon. It rained, it snowed, and between times sleet pelted down pitilessly. When night came the downpour of the mixture of snow, rain, and sleet came heavier, and the wind, which was gusty in the afternoon, rose to a gale; the streets, the pavements, and sidewalks were flooded with slush, the storm making the pavements almost impassable.

It seems strange that not until the middle of last century did it occur to any of the successors of Peter to rescue from the desecration of indifference a spot saturated, one may say without hyperbole, with the blood of the martyrs. Everybody knows that earthquake, fire, and inundation competed with each other for its destruction.

TRENTON, Nov. 26. -- The formality of canvassing the vote cast for the five candidates for Governor in New-Jersey occupied but a few minutes this afternoon in the Executive Room. The figures show that there was a notable falling off of the Prohibition vote from the past three years.

ALBANY, Nov. 26. -- In reply to a request by Superintendent of Public Instruction Skinner, W.D. Manro, Superintendent of Schools at Rome, has written a long letter setting forth the school life of the four boys who wrecked the Chicago express some days since near Rome.

The heavy rainstorm last evening did not prevent the Cubans in New-York from flocking in hundreds to the mass meeting in the Cooper Union at 8 o'clock. They filled all the seats and thronged eagerly up and down the aisles, while several hundred who could not find chairs massed themselves against the walls round the big hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Senator Morgan is not surprised that the Nicaraguan Canal Commission should find it necessary to enlarge the estimated cost of digging the canal. But that does not change his support of the canal project in the least.

The foreign-born population in the United States is very numerous, and in some of the cities forms a numerical majority, but the legal rights and the remedies are almost entirely American in principle and form of expression. The Constitution of the United States contains the principles of Magna Charta and of every subsequent declaration of political and religious liberty in the mother country.

The Board of Police Commissioners, at its meeting yesterday, took action upon the case of Capt. Joseph B. Eakins of the Mercer Street Station, and, as was expected, dismissed him. The vote stood 3 to 1, Commissioner Grant standing out for the accused Captain.

DETROIT, Nov. 26. -- A hurricane struck this city this morning, but beyond carrying down telephone and telegraph wires, and a couple of electric light towers, and destroying numberless shade trees, little damage was inflicted. The windstorm started in about 2:30 o'clock, blowing forty-eight miles an hour from the northwest, which increased steadily in violence until at 7:30 o'clock a velocity of seventy-six miles an hour was reached.
Chicago, Nov. 26. -- Considerable anxiety was manifested in marine circles to-day for the safety of four passenger steamers -- the Jay Gould, the Peerless, the Traverse City, and the City of Duluth.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 26. -- Despite the bad weather, the heavy fog over the harbor and the city, and the muddy streets, the reception given to-day by the State of Maine, represented by Gov. Cleaves, and the City of Portland, represented by Mayor Baxter, to Capt. Crowninshield and his officers of the battleship Maine, was brilliant.

Ex-Senator Warner Miller was the honored guest of the Republican Club last night, at a pre-Thanksgiving dinner. He sat to the right of Elihu Root, and near by sat Cornelius N. Bliss, John Sabine Smith, and James A. Blanchard.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- Tarrytown is taking steps to increase its water supply, and John D. Rockefeller, who owns much property in the vicinity, particularly at Pocantico Hills, has interested himself in the project. He has declared that he will give to the village property through which pipes are to be laid and, also build a high service water tower.

BUFFALO, Nov. 26. -- One of the most furious windstorms of recent years raged to-day over the eastern portion of Lake Erie. As far as the eye could reach, the lake was lashed into an unbroken succession of white caps, and the tumbling waves are dashing high over the piers here. The warning which were sent out yesterday, however, kept many vessels in port, and doubtless saved a number of wrecks.

J.B. Skehan, senior member of the firm of Skehan Co., 16 Broad Street, killed himself early yesterday morning by shooting himself in the back of the head with a revolver, in his private residence in Belleville Avenue, Montclair, N.J.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- A public meeting, called by Mayor Peene, will be held to-morrow evening at 8 o'clock in Music Hall to consider the project of building a new City Hall, either on the present Manor Hall grounds or on some other site.
The old discredited Police Justices, who were legislated out of office last Summer, are using other methods in an endeavor to get at the fat salaries they formerly drew.

This handsome volume is one of the Fur and Feather Series, which publications give in monographic form what is known of the various English birds and beasts included under the head of game. The books serve a double purpose, because they present not only the natural history of the animal or bird, but contain information valuable to the sportsman.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26. -- The statement of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company for the month of October, 1895, shows gross receipts of $2,274,260.59, and expenses of $1,060,776.62, leaving the profit in operating, $1,213,483.97. Net receipts from other sources of $28,172.32 bring the profit for the month up to $1,241,656.29.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The Bergen County Wheelmen came here to-night and rolled two games with the Bloomfield Cycling and Athletic Association on the letter's alleys, in the series of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey's Bowling League. The visitors were bested in both, although they held the lead in the second game up to the sixth frame, when they were nineteen pins ahead.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- A new feature in battleship construction was authorized today by Secretary Herbert in his approval of a report submitted by the special board of officers, of which Rear Admiral John G. Walker is President, convened to consider plans for the Kearsarge and the other battleship for which provision was made by the last Congress.

ALBANY, Nov. 26. -- The State Commissioners of the Land Office and the members of the State Forest Commission met in the office of the Secretary of State to-day to consider the proposition that the State purchase 80,000 acres of land in the Adirondack region, within the State Park boundaries, in Hamilton and Herkimer Counties.

-- It is impossible to escape the early Englishmen in these days, turn where one will. The galleries of Arthur Tooth Sons are no exception to the rule. Here at their Fifth Avenue shop are not a few interesting examples of the school now enjoying so much popularity and differing somewhat from the usual portrait pictures, seen with so much frequency.

An appeal for Thanksgiving has been issued on behalf of the Five Points House of Industry, at 155 Worth Street. It is proposed to give a dinner to the children who are inmates of the home, and also to the street poor, of whom 1,200 were fed last Thanksgiving.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- Mr. Reed found it advisable this afternoon to leave his comfortable rooms at the Shoreham and go out into the storm. It is the opinion of those who kept track of the number of cards sent to him that Mr. Reed braved the rain in order to escape the horde of politicians who gathered at the Shoreham.

The work of getting a jury to try Louis Gordon, who is charged with arson, was continued yesterday, before Judge Fitzgerald, in Part III, of the General Sessions Court. Gordon was a shirt manufacturer at 21 Walker Street, where an alleged incendiary fire occurred on June 24, 1894. The place was heavily insured.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The action of the Presbytery of Newark in dropping the Rev. Howard J. Widdemer from its membership was received here with considerable surprise, as it was expected that the minister would be vindicated against the moral and ecclesiastical charges preferred by the Presbytery of Monmouth.

The sermon that Mr. Henry James deduced from the study of Theophile Gautier some dozen years ago was this: "That a man's supreme use in the world is to master his intellectual instrument and play it in perfection." Perhaps Mr. James would not put it just in that way now that he has come so close to using his own instrument perfectly.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- Samuel William Johnson, one of the most prominent men in Rye, died last evening at his home in Rye Neck.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., Nov. 26. -- The coming election of village trustees is causing considerable excitement in this place. Nine tickets have been placed in the field and a lively canvass is anticipated. The last ticket nominated was that of the Citizens' Party, and the nominations were filed just two minutes before the time for receiving them expired.

NEW-ROCHELLE, Nov. 26. -- The annual Thanksgiving festival of Trinity School was held yesterday at Trinity House, the home of the school. The assembly room, where the exercises were held, was handsomely decorated with chrysanthemums, vines and flags. The Stage was banked with flowers, among which were Autumn fruits and vegetables.

The annual meeting, and election of the Children's Aid Society was held at the American Exchange National Bank yesterday. It was really a re-election, the following officers retaining their places for another year:

ALBANY, Nov. 26. -- There is a discrepancy between the accounts of Controller Roberts and those of Edward P. Doyle of Staten Island, the late Secretary of the Fish and Game Commission. Experts are at work on the books, and at Controller Roberts's office an investigation is being made.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- None of Mr. Reed's visitors has been able to-day to extort from him anything like an intimation of a financial policy for the Republicans in Congress. He has not added to nor explained his words of Sunday, when he plainly indicated his intention to wait upon the leadership of the President.
Commissioners Orr, Steinway, Claflin, and Inman were the only members of the Board of Rapid Transit at the meeting yesterday afternoon.

The romping Lady Teazle, the true type of the rustic girl who has not long been the wife of a wealthy old man, first introduced to the stage by Dora Jordan, and revived brilliantly for this generation by Ada Rehan, again delighted a large and distinguished audience at Daly's Theatre last night.

During the week and more that the ironworkers on a number of buildings in this city have been "on strike" nothing has been presented showing any justification of their attitude toward their employers. No substantial grievance has been stated and no tangible demand has been made showing the least ground for such a "remedy" as a strike, always to be considered by reasonable workingmen as a last resort.
The following paragraphs are summarized from a recent issue of The Frankfurter Zeitung:

What during the eighteenth century was called a "bubble" or a "folly" and is now commonly known as a boom is in London called a "circus." "The Kafir Circus" is the designation of the London stock market for the excitement produced by the recent developments of the gold fields of South Africa.

Capt. James Gurney, Jr., and seven of the shipwrecked crew of the barkentine Bruce Hawkins reached this city yesterday from Hoffman Island, where they were sent Monday when they arrived at Quarantine on the steamship Vigilancia from Havana.

During the week and more that the ironworkers on a number of buildings in this city have been "on strike" nothing has been presented showing any justification of their attitude toward their employers. No substantial grievance has been stated and no tangible demand has been made showing the least ground for such a "remedy" as a strike, always to be considered by reasonable workingmen as a last resort.

He has in his veins a strong dash of fine Norse blood, which has saved him from the dour taciturnity, the brutal coarseness, the banality, which marks the pure-blooded Angle. He is a good listener, a fair talker, and marvelously quick at grasping any point which touches his personal interests.

ROGERS, the "materializing medium" who was arrested Sunday night, offers a somewhat inadequate explanation of the appearance of a woman named CHADWICK in the place of one of his "materialized spirits" in front of his cabinet at the time when a policeman sought to take this "spirit" into custody.

In a note upon the Utah election I ventured the opinion that a strong belief in protection derived from the teaching of Brigham Young greatly influenced the votes of the people. Your Salt Lake correspondent, in his letter, published in THE TIMES this morning, takes exception to this, and goes into a labored argument to prove that the motives of the prophet were not political.

Seldom has a more pathetic incident occurred in a New-York hospital than the untimely death of Thomas Halloren, a young Irishman of magnificent physique. He had been a patient at the Hudson Street Hospital a month. He died early yesterday morning from pyaemia. So affectionate was his nature and so cheerful his disposition, that the surgeons and nurses of the hospital witnessed the ebbing away of his young life with feelings of genuine grief.

" White's Selborne" belongs in the same category with Walton's "Complete Angler." If it is not so well known, it is only because it appeals to a smaller class than that which finds delight in Walton's quaint writings. Neither White nor Walton undertook to do more than to write out of the fullness of his mind and heart on a subject that really was a part of his life.

The farcical Republican enrollment of last Saturday night had a sequel last night when the Committee on Organization of the County Committee met at the headquarters in West Thirty-eighth Street, to hear protests. There was a shower of them. The committee sat until early this morning and did not get half way through its work.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 26. -- One of the worst windstorms that Cleveland has ever known began in the early hours this morning and increased in severity until about 5 o'clock, when the greatest velocity of wind in the history of the Cleveland Weather Bureau was attained. At 5 o'clock the wind blew at the rate of seventy-four miles an hour.

Ex-Assemblyman Alfred R. Conkling appeared before Magistrate Kudlich, in the Centre Street Police Court, yesterday as complainant against the Board of Election Inspectors in the Sixth Election District of the First Assembly District, charging them with neglecting to paste the defective and sample ballots on their returns to the Board of Aldermen.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

The passion for dueling which had cost France, it was said, between seven and eight thousand lives during the twenty years of Henry the Fourth's reign, was at its height when his son came to the throne. The Council of Trent in 1545 had solemnly condemned the practice of single combat impartially including principals, seconds, and spectators in its penalty of excommunication.

It is a little strange that our earliest National holiday, the one at least which had its origin in the very early days of our country, should always be associated with the dinner table. Thanksgiving Day and Thanksgiving Day dinner are synonymous terms with a great many people.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street.
