Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- An interesting series of experiments have been conducted at Newport at the Naval Station with the little torpedo boat Stiletto. It was desired to determine the distance at which the noise of approach of the boat with a Howell torpedo in readiness for launching could be heard from a stationary vessel.

PHILLIPSBURG, Penn., Nov. 27. -- As the Altoona and Phillipsburg passenger train due here at 6:30 this evening emerged from Steiner's Cut, one mile from this place, it struck and wrecked a handcar containing T.J. McDermott and his wife, and John Richmond, his wife, and his daughter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- President Cleveland received his prize Thanksgiving turkey this morning. It came by express from Henry Vose of Westerly, R.I., the customary giver of Presidential turkeys, and weighed thirty-four pounds.
The sale by Bangs Co. of the John S. M. Pierce library was concluded yesterday. Among the books sold were the following:

Now that the Republican leaders in Spain are beginning to advocate the granting of autonomy to Cuba, it is evident that the patriot cause is gaining ground as rapidly in the mother country as it is in the field. The royalist rumor factory has been hard at work lately spreading obviously false reports about the purchase of rebel chiefs and the disintegration of the rebel army.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 27. -- This village was in darkness for a time this evening. A mass of eels had clogged the water wheel which runs the Hallett electric light plant.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 27. -- The Hoboken Common Council, at its meeting to-day, heard protests against granting to the Jersey City, Hoboken and Rutherford Railway Company permission to run its tracks through First Street. Ex-Judge Abel I. Smith represented the company. He urged the passage of the ordinance.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 27. -- The Hudson Boulevard, as Hudson County's new driveway has been named, will be formally opened to-morrow by a parade of the wheelmen of Hudson County, accompanied by delegations from various cities.

Controller Fitch has refused to pay certain bills for work authorized by heads of some of the city departments on the ground that if they are not direct violations of Section 705, Chapter 368, Laws of 1894, they violate the section in spirit. This law provides that all work amounting to $1,000 or over must be let by bids.
It now looks very much as if there would be open Tammany primaries this year.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 27. -- Peter McGeoch, who lived opposite the National Soldiers' Home, ordered his carriage this morning to go to the city, and then went upstairs. He was not seen alive after that. As he did not appear, the servants became alarmed, and instituted a search for him. Annie Beese looked through the keyhole of the bathroom door, which was locked, and saw McGeoch lying on the floor with a revolver in his hand.

The production of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" in German at the Metropolitan Opera House last night marked the beginning of the new and liberal policy which Messrs. Abbey Grau promised for this season. On March 24 THE NEW-YORK TIMES said: "The Wagner and anti-Wagner war is over.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 27. -- O.B. Groff, a hotel keeper, has brought suit against the estate of Abraham G. Brenner for damages. Brenner committed suicide in Groff's hotel, and the latter brings his claim on the ground that Brenner's act injured his business.

The ardent zeal of ALFRED R. CONKLING as a reformer, somewhat erratic as it is apt to be, has its uses. He is doing a public service by bringing to book some of the election officers who failed to do their duty according to law in making up returns at the close of the last election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Some of the coal dealers in the East are complaining of the action of the Navy Department in calling for bids for 1,200 tons of coal to be delivered at Honolulu, where the navy has a coaling station. Neither the call for bids nor the specifications make any mention of the fact that but forty-five days will be allowed for the delivery of the coal on the Hawaiian Islands.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 27. -- John Austin Stevens, Jr., son of the well-known writer, was to-day sent to the Butler Asylum for Insane, in Providence, R.I. The young man had lived at the Calumet Club, in New-York, but last Summer he came here and lived at his mother's cottage.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 27. -- Judgment was to-day entered in the Supreme Court, on an opinion given by Chief Justice Beasley, against the Borough of Cape May Point. The order is of ouster, and declares the borough government illegal and without warrant, in that the law under which it was organized was not constitutional.

The athletic and cycle meet of the Twenty-second Regiment Association last night was a big success. The armory at the Boulevard and Sixty-sixth Street was crowded and the winner of each event enthusiastically cheered.

The mistaken arrest of Christian Reis, Jr., at Colon Oct. 20, in place of a thief named Joseph Reis, who was wanted for the larceny of $2,000 worth of watches and diamonds, is still a matter under the consideration of President Roosevelt of the Police Board.

Overruling the courts of last resort is often one of the pleasures, and may become one of the sternest duties, of conscientious journalism. We have seldom had an occasion to overrule the Court of Appeals about the urgency or propriety of which there could be less question than that which is presented by the decision of that body in the case of SCHUYLER against CURTIS and others, which decision was given out yesterday.

Announcement is made of the engagement of Miss Helen Steele of Washington, D.C., to Edward Gwynne of New-York. Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt is a sister of Mr. Gwynne's father. Miss Steele is very prominent socially in Washington, and is well known in New-York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- "This country can be made ready for a successful defense in case of war by the year 1900," said J.H. Outhwaite, a member of the Board of Ordnance and Fortifications, after a tour of inspection of the several plants in the East where the work of constructing ordnance is conducted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Navy Department experts have had much difficulty in securing an entirely satisfactory material for barrels for small arms. After many experiments, it has been decided that nothing superior to 4 1/2 per cent. nickel steel can be secured. The life of a barrel with the type of rifling hitherto used will not exceed 3,000 rounds, as the rifling becomes worn and the accuracy of the gun is consequently seriously affected.

She was a sweet-faced little old lady, and she sat by the window yesterday thinking and looking out on one of the up-town side streets, where the children were playing, her head resting lightly on one hand.

Theodore Allen, better known as "The" Allen, who is now under indictment on the charge of maintaining a poolroom above a saloon at 546 West Broadway owing to a raid the police made on the place early in June of this year, was again arrested yesterday afternoon by Acting Inspector Brooks and a squad of police, and arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court on a similar charge.

No progress was made by the Atchison Reorganization Committee yesterday in the selection of a Chairman of the Board of Directors of the new company. Another session of the committee will be held tomorrow.
PARIS, Nov. 27. -- Henri Rochefort is confined to his bed with an attack of influenza.
ALBANY, Nov. 27. -- Chancellor Upson of the Regents of the University of the State of New-York to-day announced the list of standing committees for 1895.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- Commissioner Lyman of the State Fish, Game, and Forest Commission to-day gave out the following statement, after consultation with the State Controller, concerning Secretary Doyle of the old Fish Commission and the commission itself:

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

Friends of J.B. Skehan, senior member of the firm of J.B. Skehan Co., brokers, 16 Broad Street, who committed suicide at Montclair, N.J., Tuesday, gave as an explanation of the act that Mr. Skehan had worried over the "business irregularities" of the late A.C. Bernheim, who was at the time of his death a partner in the firm of Skehan Bernheim.

A statement was published in a local morning newspaper yesterday that President Cleveland would not accept a nomination for a third term. E.C. Benedict was quoted as authority for the statement. He said that in part it was correct, but that it had been made too strong.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 27. -- Andrew Carnegie, who came to Cleveland with several members of his iron company to attend the St. Andrew's Society benefit last night, was received by the members of the Cleveland Chamber of Commerce this afternoon. The rooms of the Chamber were crowded with representative business men when President Day introduced Mr. Carnegie, who delivered an address of half an hour's duration, in the course of which he said:

It is high time that preparations were making by the Americans who propose to become exhibitors at the Paris Exposition of 1900. It will be high time when Congress assembles for that body to take action which shall give such facilities as the exhibitors at world's fairs have a right to demand of their own Government.

While many of the anti-Platt Republicans believe that the only way they can ever secure their party rights is to establish a new Republican County Committee in this city, there are other anti-Platt men who have different views, despite the curious enrollment of last Saturday night.
The Assembly Committee on Railways resumed at the Hotel Metropole yesterday its inquiry into the fiscal and physical condition of the elevated and surface railroads in this city.

JERSEY CITY, NOV. 28. -- The Hudson Boulevard, Hudson County's new $2,000,000 driveway, was formally opened, to-day by a parade of wheelmen. The affair was in charge of the Clio Wheelmen, the arrangements being under direction of the following committee: William Buckbee, Thomas B. Longfield. Frank E. Allison, A.L. Schermerhorn, Edward Wissert, Charles Parkins, and William Ferris.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 15. -- Discussion of the reasons for the present frenzy of slaughter in Turkey seems a waste of time. There are the natural Turkish ferocity, the oppression of the Armenians, the Sassoun massacres, and the revolutionary movement inextricably mingled with it all; there are the wrath at English interference, and the vague spectre of purely religious fanaticism urging the Turk to proclaim war on all Christians.

Miss Mary B. Lee, who, for twenty years, has been a teacher in the public schools of Brooklyn, is in danger of losing her position after long and faithful service. Her only fault seems to be that her pupils have been taken away from her.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- A serious row has broken out among the Eastern roads regarding low-rate special excursions to Eastern points. Last Summer the Nickle Plate ran such excursions to Niagara Falls, and as a result similar excursions were run by the Wabash and Grand Trunk roads. To get even, the Erie was authorized to run a special low-rate excursion to the seaboard.

This is the story of a hen. If it was an ordinary country hen, the story would not be worth telling, particularly at this season of the year, when the thoughts of the Nation are engrossed with thoughts of a larger fowl which is admired from a practical standpoint.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The Rev. S. Edward Young, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Newark, gave a Thanksgiving dinner here to-day to the members of the life-saving crews of the New-Jersey coast. Those participating included Capt. T.H. Patterson of Sandy Hook, Capt. Abner H. West of Galilee, Capt. Mulligan of Monmouth Beach, Capt. Benjamin Van Brunt of Deal Beach, Capt. Pierce of Shark River, and a number of surf men.

It is an interesting announcement that the British and American steamship lines have already agreed and that the Continental lines are preparing to agree to an arrangement raising and classifying the east-bound steerage rates. It is true that steerage passengers going east may be regarded as "ballast," that is to say, they take room that is not required and could not be made available for any other purpose.
John Hammond's patent infringement suit in the Federal courts against the Stockton Agricultural Works, involving his double-ender street car patent, is now to go up to the highest judicial tribunal.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- Four oxen were slaughtered before a large crowd in an inclosed lot in Adee Street, near Main, this afternoon. Even children saw the animals killed.

A change seems to be coming over the celebration of Thanksgiving Day, especially in this city. Of course, the withdrawal of the annual football match makes a considerable difference. An event which assembled thirty or forty thousand people, and which interests ten times that number, cannot be discontinued, even in so big a town as this, without leaving a perceptible void, and even inducing the impression that there is nothing going on.

One of the interesting social incidents to-night will be the first dance of a series, to be given at the Essex County Country Club at Orange, N.J. This affair will take down to the pretty little clubhouse a number of fashionable folk from New-York. The patronesses will be Mrs. Oliver S. Carter, Mrs. T.H. Powers Furr, Mrs. John P. Tarday, Mrs. Cyrus F. Loutrel, Mrs. William Barr, and Mrs. John Pettit.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The Republican "steering" committee of the Senate, has issued a call for a caucus of the Republican Senators to be held immediately after the adjournment of the Senate, next Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- Secretary Olney has directed that the copper plate made early in the century of the original Declaration of Independence shall be locked up in a fire-proof safe in the Department of State. The process to which this valuable document was subjected in order that a fac simile might be secured for a copper plate caused the ink on the Declaration to fade and the parchment to deteriorate.
Ex-Mayor Gilroy returned to this city from Atlanta Wednesday night, with United States Marshal McCarty, and Isaac A. Hopper.

HAVANA, Nov. 28. -- The trial of Julio Sanguily, the American citizen who was arrested here in February last on the charge of being an active agitator in the Cuban revolution, began to-day. It was stated that evidence would be produced proving that Sanguily made appointments of delegates to the Revolutionary Committee in New-York, and that among his appointments was that of Jose Ynocencio Arcuy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- It being reasonably certain that the "Quay combine" slate is to be put through the House caucus, public attention has turned from the question of the House offices to the more important one of the House committees. Mr. Reed gives no information bearing on this matter. He still preserves a most provoking silence.
Comparatively few of the business men who went to Atlanta for the celebration of Manhattan Day at the exposition had ever before been south of Washington, or Richmond at the furthest.

TOPEKA, Nov. 28. -- The Kansas Republican machine next year will have other fights than with the Democracy. It will have a hard fight to renominate its present State officers and a harder fight to elect them if renominated. The rural Prohibitionists and the urban Resubmissionists threaten to make considerable trouble for the Republican leaders.

EDINBURGH, Nov. 28. -- The Marquis of Bute has been re-elected Lord Rector of the University of St. Andrews. His opponent was the former Sir Arthur Wellesley Peel, now Viscount Peel, late Speaker of the House of Commons.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 28. -- Admirers of the New-Jersey Athletic Club football team of Bayonne turned out in force here this afternoon and had the satisfaction of witnessing a handsome victory earned by the home team against Pennington Seminary. While the New-Jersey Athletic Club made 20 points just about as it pleased, the Pennington team was prevented from scoring.

The synagogue at 115 East Eighty-sixth Street was crowded at the Thanksgiving service yesterday morning by a congregation to hear Register Ferdinand Levy speak on "The Jew as a Citizen and Patriot." Mr. Levy said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- The report of Hoke Smith, Secretary of the Interior, elaborately reviews the varied work of the Interior Department. It begins with the Indian service and calls attention to the strict enforcement which has been given to civil service reform, both as to those places covered by the classified service and those to which the rules of this service do not apply.

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- Of the many gay social events that have taken place on Thanksgiving Day at the Meadowbrook Hunt Club to-day's hunt across country after the hounds and steeplechase was one of the best ever held by the club. The fun began at 11:30 A.M., when the steeplechase, which was over a six-mile course, was run.

TORONTO, Nov. 28. -- The Stars and Stripes caused a mimic war here to-day, and those who flaunted the starry emblem came out winners. The early days of the present century were renewed at the Ontario Veterinary College, when a number of American students, headed by a New-Yorker named Shaw, produced an American flag and hoisted it in the main assembly hall just after Dr. Smith had finished his lecture.

The movement on foot to form an intercollegiate bicycle association is meeting with great favor. This popular sport has attracted many college athletes, and for a long time the various institutions have been discussing the feasibility of such a plan.

Mr. MAX SILVERSTEIN, the expressman who has just been sentenced to nine months in prison for driving furiously along Third Avenue and incidentally disfiguring for life a woman whom the wheels of his wagon passed over in their rapid course, will have time in which to realize that pedestrians have a few rights which even persons so important as he are expected -- vainly in most cases -- to recognize.

The "vigorous" policy which The Tribune and some other of the more extreme Republican papers have been urging in regard to revenue legislation clearly does not find unqualified favor at Washington as the Congressmen gather for the opening of the session. Probably the rather savage campaign on which these papers have entered was somewhat thoughtlessly undertaken.
There is at least one neighborhood in this city where there is room for reform, or improvement, in police methods, and that is in the vicinity of City Hall Park.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 28. -- The society and sporting public here are now busy with preparations for and discussion of the coming horse show which is to be held in the Academy of the Orange Riding and Driving Club, in Halsted Street, Fast Orange, Wednesday, Thursday. Friday, and Saturday. Dec. 4, 5, 6. and 7. It promises to exceed in magnitude anything that the management had contemplated at the start.

Sir Alfred Moloney, the Governor General of British Honduras, is in the city, accompanied by Lieut. Carbally, his aide de camp. It may possibly be remembered that this Central American dignitary visited New-Orleans last Spring on his way to Europe, to which section of the globe he had been ordered by his physician in order to permit his constitution to recuperate from the enervating effects of his four years' residence in the tropics.
NEW-ROCHELLE, Nov. 28. -- The union service held in the First Presbyterian Church this morning brought together an unusually large congregation.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The correspondent of The United Press in Constantinople telegraphs under date of Nov. 27 that a second terrible massacre has occurred at Marash, and that the houses there have been pillaged without regard to who their occupants might be. It is reported that thousands of persons were killed and many hundreds wounded.

One of the important matters considered in the twenty-sixth annual report of the State Board of Health, just printed, is the outbreak of smallpox in the seven months ended in June, 1894. During that time 201 cases, or nearly nine-tenths of all that occurred in two years, were reported.

In all the churches of this city yesterday special services were held celebrating the feast of Thanksgiving. These services were well attended, and in many places of worship special programmes of music were given by the regular choirs, assisted by soloists.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- Philadelphia is football crazy to-night. The streets of the city are thronged with a crowd of enthusiasts cheering for their respective favorites in a wild, hilarious mood. The red and blue of Pennsylvania waves triumphant, for the eleven of that university not only defeated the strong Cornell team to-day, but snowed them under, scoring forty-six points by clean, hard football against two for Cornell.
RIO JANEIRO, Nov. 28. -- The Brazilian cruiser Uranus has been wrecked and her commander and five others were drowned. No details of the wreck have been received.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Nov. 28. -- Joseph Campbell, an employe of H.W. Biffars, a coal dealer of Steinway, went down into an old well on Biffar's place this morning to loosen a pipe that ran down into the well. While he was climbing out, some of the stones that lined the well caved in before the man had climbed up many feet, and he was buried under the stones and earth.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- Dr. T. Warren Rice and daughter, Miss Helen W. Rice, who left New-Brunswick, N.J., Tuesday, and were supposed to have taken passage on an outgoing ocean steamer, arrived here on the night boat from New-York Wednesday morning and remained at the Delavan House for three hours, leaving on the electric motor cars for Troy, where they intended to take a train for Montreal.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Nov. 28. -- Spring-like weather and an unusually attractive programme were the two agents chiefly responsible for the large attendance of the members of the Rockaway Hunt Club at their club at Cedarhurst to-day. The programme consisted of a hunt, a luncheon, and two golf contests.

No result was reached at the recent meetings in this city of the Proprietary Committee of the National Wholesale Druggists' Association and the Association of Manufacturers and Wholesale Dealers of Proprietary Articles in regard to a new plan for the distribution of proprietary medicines.

_LBA.N'y, i'OV. 2S. -- The raid for prison atronage which the little coterie of Republican politicians living in the northeastern part of the State has made, even if successful, will net the raiders far less in the %way of "spoils" than it would have (lone one year ago.

The members of the Knollwood Country Club had a very interesting golf tournament yesterday over their eighteen-bole course near Elmsford. The weather was perfect for golfing, but the early morning thaw made the grounds a bit heavy. The prize played for was a handsome silver cup, given by Mrs. N.F. Reynal, and there was also a second prize of two golf clubs for the best scratch score.

During the past four years a large number of horses have died in the northern part of this State from the ravages of a disease which has baffled the skill of veterinarians, and I have been called upon to make investigations as to the cause and nature of the malady.

The cause of municipal reform has no more dangerous enemies than those who oppose such a modification of the excise law as will grant local option on the subject of Sunday selling. The talk among Republican politicians is of making the excise law more stringent when the Legislature meets, and especially of increasing license fees and reducing the number of saloons.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 28. -- A fully equipped training school for domestics is now about ready to be opened here under the auspices of the Woman's Orange Improvement Society. The management, teachers, and conduct of the school have been decided upon and a sufficient sum subscribed to start upon the desired scale. Options on several houses have been secured.

Compared with the first half of the week, the holiday programme arranged by the Live Stock Society received a much more liberal patronage. The show has gone along amid varying fortunes, hindered by the weather until the sunshine came on Wednesday, and it is still rather too much of a novelty to catch the pleasure seekers of the metropolitan district.
Thanksgiving was quietly celebrated in Brooklyn yesterday, and many families enjoyed reunions at heavily laden dinner tables, where turkeys and mince pies made up the feast.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The American Society in London gave a Thanksgiving banquet at the Holborn Restaurant this evening. The dining hall was elaborately decorated with the arms of the various States of the Union, flags, and palms. Over the President's chair there was a canopy composed of pumpkins and fruits, surmounted by a model of the Statue of Liberty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- When a candidate for the most responsible House office leaves his headquarters almost on the eve of the decisive caucus to witness a football match he furnishes the best of presumptive evidence that he is certain of election. Major McDowell of Pennsylvania, the "combine" candidate for Clerk, did this to-day.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 28. -- Stories of strikes in the mines continue to come in. One of the most remarkable was at Cripple Creek. A blast was made in the Height and Snape shaft on the Anchors, and when the rock was hoisted to the surface, it was said to be literally covered with sylvanite and drops of rusty gold.

Dr. Victor C. Bell, Professor in the Dental College of New-York, lectured in Primary School No. 14, at 73 Oliver Street last night on "The Care of the Teeth and the Mouth." The lecture was illustrated with stereopticon views. It was given under the auspices of the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- A caucus of Republican members of the House of Representatives from the Southern States was held to-night to determine upon a course of action in connection with the organization of the House. Eleven members were present all through the caucus. It was said that in the course of the evening fifteen members were in the room, but when adjournment was reached but eleven members came out.

WESTBURY, L.I., Nov. 28. -- While riding a superb hunter on the Wheatley Hills this morning, Mrs. E.D. Morgan, wife of the ex-Commodore of the New-York Yacht Club, was thrown to the ground and her leg was broken at the ankle.

Early Italian and Gothic art, represented by twoscore examples, forms the basis of the opening exhibition of the present art season with the Lotos Club. These pictures have been brought together and arranged by Henry T. Chapman, Jr., who is deserving of much credit for his trouble and the judgment displayed.
Thanksgiving Day was celebrated in New-York and Brooklyn yesterday in a comfortable and easygoing way.

WOODSBURO, L.I., NOV. 28. -- Several thousand spectators gathered along Central Avenue, from Lawrence's to Woodsburg, this afternoon to witness sprinting matches between local amateurs. The first event was a one-and-one-half- mile race between John Phillips and Edward Warren. The latter won with ease.

William R. Smith, a member of the Parking Commission of this city and the Superintendent of the Botanic Gardens, read a paper recently before the Florists' Club of Philadelphia on shade trees. In the course of his address he said:

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 28. -- This was Atlanta Day, Savannah Day, Inman Day, and South Carolina Day, and the exposition grounds were packed with people. The crowd was nearly three times as large as the largest up to this date. Every building was crowded and the thoroughfares were thick with people.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- President and Mrs. Cleveland followed their usual custom to-day of attending the Thanksgiving service of the First Presbyterian Church, of which their favorite minister, the Rev. Byron Sunderland, who married them, is one of the pastors. The Rev. Dr. Talmage, who was recently appointed a co-pastor of the church, preached the Thanksgiving sermon.

The Gashouse Rangers thoroughly enjoyed themselves yesterday. In fact they have not had a more delightful outing since the time when they all fell off the pier at the Morgue on the occasion of the united picnic of the Lushundbumverein Association and the Nocturnal Prowlers.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- C.E. Rycroft of 247 Fifth Avenue, New-York, reported at Police Headquarters late this afternoon that a gold hunting-case watch, a twisted gold chain, and a diamond ring, valued at $250, were stolen this afternoon from his locker in the St. Andrew's Golf Clubhouse during the golf game.

Mrs. Adeline S. Lincoln of Worcester can have judgment on the twenty-dollar verdict which she was awarded in her action for damages against Dressmaker Anna L. Gay of that place for injury to her dress pattern in making the same up on the wrong side of the cloth, as the full bench of the Supreme Court has overruled the defendant's exceptions.

FLUSHING, L.I., Nov. 29. -- Edward Pfeffer, a prominent lawyer, living at Parsons and Madison Avenues, this village, who is associated with Magistrate C.A. Flammer, A. C. Palmer, and J.W. Shepard at 280 Broadway, New-York City, went to the Yale-Princeton football game in the city last Saturday afternoon with Howard Slocum, Thomas Cooper, and Lester Lane, his friends, all of Long Branch, N.J. All were enthusiastic for Princeton.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- There is just enough Presidential talk in connection with the scramble for the House offices to give interest to what generally is regarded as a cut-and-dried programme. The Southern Republicans, particularly those from Tennessee, and the members of the Ohio delegation have supplied the gossips with this kind of material.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Officials of the Department of Agriculture learned to-day upon reading The United Press cablegrams that the British Government had finally announce an order, to take effect Jan. 1 next, forbidding the importation of sheep form the United States and Canada unless the animals are slaughtered at their port of landing.

A handsome young Jewess, who was married in Bremen about two months ago, and who arrived in this city with her husband Thursday on the steamship Munchen, was robbed some time Thursday night of $1,200, all the money she possessed, and then deserted.
SARATOGA, Nov. 29. -- The will of Miss Sarah D. Wheeler of Greenfield, who died several months ago, is in litigation in the Surrogate's Court of this county.

When through the agitation begun in this paper a game protective association was formed in the State, The American pointed out that a mere change of laws would not prevent the disappearance of game. It was then predicted that we were on the verge of a hard Winter, which would probably destroy more game than all other causes combined.

Commissioner of Accounts Terry yesterday said that an opportunity would in all probability be given to ex-Dock Commissioner James J. Phelan some time next week to tell what he knows about the building of the crib at Riker's Island.

When a man asks, in a drug store, for a patent medicine, and is put off with the reply that the druggist has another article, made by himself, which is not only better, but cheaper, than the original medicine wanted, the customer is being made the victim of substitution, and often of deception.
BREWSTER, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- Twelve lives were lost, it is believed, by the falling of the walls of the Tilly Foster Mine, one of the Lackawanna Iron and Coal Company's group, this afternoon.

ALBANY, Nov. 29. -- Notice was received at the Attorney General's department to-day from James F. Lowrey of New-York City, as attorney for Pitt Barrows, asking that Attorney General Hancock agree to set a hearing for Dec. 11, at his office here, on an application that he bring an action to restrain...

The schooners Edward E. Webster and Herman, which were sealing last year, are now fitting out for an otter-hunting cruise. The best hunters on the coast have been engaged, it is said, for the work. Down at San Pedro the sealing schooner Penelope is also fitting out, and it is expected that some rich hauls will be made next year.

LONG ISLAND CITY, L.I., Nov. 29. -- Charles Wilson, a privileged prisoner in the Queens County Jail, this city, reported to Jailer John McDougal at 4 o'clock this afternoon that an escaping prisoner was hiding under a stairway off the hallway leading to the jailer's office. McDougal hurried to the place and saw a strange man lying on his side under the stairs.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29. -- The latest bulletin of the League of American Wheelmen Racing Board, George D. Gideon, President, reads:
When Mayor-elect Frederick W. Wurster of Brooklyn returned Wednesday from the Atlanta exposition he said to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES:

The bowlers of the Manhattan Bicycle Club struck two soft spots last night, and improved their position in the bowling tournament of the Metropolitan Association of Cycling Clubs by two victories. First of all they defeated the Prospect Wheelmen, and then, after a little rest, the Hudson County bowlers proved easy victims.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 29. -- To-morrow will be the biggest day for cyclists that the South has ever known. The exposition managers have advertised it broadcast as wheelmen's day, and delegates of cycling enthusiasts from all parts below Mason and Dixon's line as well as from New-York and Chicago will be here. Two large parties arrived this evening from the North, about sixty in all.

Mrs. George Augustus Sala desires to thank the many friends who have telegraphed and written to her from all parts of England sympathizing with her on the sad condition of her husband's health, and to say that at present she is totally unable to reply to their communications individually, as she would wish to do.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 29. -- The Turkish Legation received from the Sublime Porte the following telegram under to-day's date:

The daily bulletins distributed to a grateful press by the Turkish Legation at Washington deserve careful preservation in the scrapbooks of all people who are interested in the curiosities of literature. Nothing like them in cool disregard of facts, logic, and experience was ever gravely put forward for public judgment.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Nov. 29. -- Capt. Sylvester Smith of this place and Werner Banzhaf, a relative of William Steinway, the piano manufacturer, started out from here yesterday after wild ducks. They sailed up Cold Spring Harbor toward the lighthouse off Lloyd's Neck. There they found a large flock of ducks.
A choice collection of books was sold yesterday by Bangs Co. Among the books sold were the following:

Controller Palmer of Brooklyn has made room for two more political henchmen and trouble for two of the largest departments of Brooklyn by deciding that policemen and firemen shall be paid by individual checks. He put the new system into effect Wednesday, and city employes have been trying ever since to straighten out their financial affairs.

The Rev. Arthur E. Michel made an application yesterday to Surrogate Arnold for an order directing the trustees under the will of his first wife, Sophia, to pay to him the income derived from a truest fund created by his wife for the benefit of their three children.

PHELPS, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- Senator Raines predicts that a radical change in the excise laws will be made by the Legislature this Winter. The present law, he says, permits a system of blackmail in the cities and large towns.

TRENTON, . J., NOV. 29. -- Justice Van Siekel ot the Supreme Court filed an opinion to-day which upholds the Common Council of New-Brun6wIek in its recent action authorizing the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to cIose up a portion of Somerset Street in that city. The railroad company agreed in return for this right to open up a new street and pay the cost thereof.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- It is said to-night that the Republican Senatorial caucus will not take up the question of reorganization. The most important question which will confront the Republicans in connection with the proposed reorganization will relate to the construction of the Finance Committee.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 29. -- Mary Delph, the eight-year-old daughter of William Delph, a blind man, while on her way from her home to her father's store last evening was accosted by a young man, who asked her to go with him while he wrote a note for her to take to her father. The girl accompanied the man to a house in John Street, Harrison.

Mr. Chamberlain appears to be developing the histrionic faculty. Most admirable of debaters and of business speakers these ten years past, he seems now in a fair way to become an orator; he is not afraid to touch emotional chords, and it cannot be denied that he touches them like a master. The occasion was a fitting one.

The meeting of the Boston Scientific Society Tuesday evening was particularly interesting since C.J. Maynard, the naturalist, presented his own ideas on the "Migration of Birds." Why birds should migrate with such exceeding regularity has been a puzzle to scientists, and no hypothesis which has yet been suggested has been adequate.

ALBANY, Nov. 9. -- The investigation which has been made by the State Fish, Game and Forestry Commission has shown not only very loose methods of business on the part of former Secretary Edward P. Doyle, but has developed that Mr. Doyle had a practical control over all the Long Island oyster beds.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 29. -- The twenty-first annual meeting of the State Sanitary Association will be held in the Brighton Casino here Friday and Saturday, Dec. 6 and 7. The programme gives promise of an interesting and instructive meeting.

The very interesting and informing dispatches from Constantinople published in THE TIMES yesterday morning make intelligible the news of to-day in a striking fashion. The conduct of the Sultan with reference to the firmans permitting the added guardships to pass the Dardanelles is precisely in the line of the conduct of the Captain of the Turkish ship in trouble described in our dispatches.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 29. -- Samuel S. Brown, the millionaire coal merchant, proprietor of the Monongahela House in this city, and prominent as a turfman, has secured a divorce from his wife. The suit was brought in September. His wife was a Miss Lizzie P. Pollock of this city, whom Capt. Brown married in 1864.

Thomas Brackett Reed was never appreciated outside of Washington until within the last half dozen years, because of a combination of physical lethargy and intellectual indifference which kept him from putting forth his strength. If he had been of Blaine's nervous, excitable, and showy temperament he would have had throughout his twenty years of Congress the same prominence that Blaine had throughout his Congressional career.

The historic Welaka River, the modern St. John's, is to the stranger one of the most interesting rivers on the American Continent. It is unique in many particulars which go to make up a river. Finding its source in the far south, it flows northward for nearly all its length, until, reaching the metropolis of Florida, it turns eastward, and pours its great volume of waters into the ocean.

-- The Atlantic announces that during the coming year it will print an unpublished notebook of Nathaniel Hawthorne which was written while he was weigher and gauger in Salem, in 1839. It will be followed by some memoirs of the great romance writer, by his daughter, Rose Hawthorne Lathrop.
The following letter on the subject of carrying concealed weapons has been received:

The account which Secretary LAMONT gives of the condition of the army is certainly gratifying. This body is better fed, clothed, and housed than ever before; its health record is the best ever known during any twelvemonth; its drill and discipline are satisfactory; its court-martial record shows a great falling off in trials both by general and inferior courts.

The Assembly Committee appointed to investigate the physical and fiscal conditions of the elevated and surface railroads in this city resumed its sessions yesterday in the Hotel Metropole. Chairman S.F. Nixon called the meeting to order at 10:30 o'clock A.M.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- The Times will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Julfa, dated Nov. 28, saying that the Armenian villages between Persia and Van, probably to the number of forty-six, have been destroyed by the Hamidieh cavalry. All the reports say that the number of persons killed was very large.

The Police Commissioners held their regular meeting yesterday and then began, in Commissioner Andrews's room, a secret session which lasted far into the evening. When they adjourned they refused to tell what they had done or of what they had talked.

The public sale of the McLean estate brings to our mind the most singular coincidence we recall in our reading of history. The first meeting of the Army of the Potomac and the Army of Northern Virginia took place at Blackburn's Ford, July 18, 1861, and brought on the first pitched battle of the war.

The children of the tenment house district lying south of Washington Square who are in the habit of attending Sunday school services in Bethlehem Chapel, in Bleacker Street, flocked to the chapel with their parents yesterday afternoon to learn how to help Col. Waring keep the streets of New-York clean.

Donizetti's "La Favorita" was performed last night for the first time in the Metropolitan Opera House. The opera has not been heard in this city since 1885, when Mme. Scalchi sang the leading role at the Academy of Music under Col. Mapleson's management. It was a highly popular work in those elder days, which we are so frequently told were better than the present.

There is prospect that a new club will be organized at Harvard, that will be large enough and comprehensive enough to include all the many varying interests of the university. A number of prominent alumni are interested in the scheme, and it is likely that if their plans are carried out they will result not only in great benefit to graduates, but also to the university itself.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 29. -- Another important newspaper change will take place in this city the 1st of next January. Joseph O'Connor, who for the past ten years has been the editor-in-chief of The Post-Express, will retire from that position, and the paper will again become Republican.
The weekly police trials were held at Police Headquarters yesterday, Commissioner Roosevelt presiding. Complaint Clerk Peterson had seventy cases on the calendar.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The most definite information afforded about the President's message to Congress is that conveyed to the Public Printer and to the news associations that handle it for the press, and that information is only as to the area the document will occupy in a paper. It is to be about 15,000 words in length, so that it will fill over a page of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

An onyx deposit that now promises to prove the largest and mast valuable in the United States has just been discovered by ex-State Geologist Gorby. The deposit is in Greene County, Ky., in one of the most out-of-the-way sections of the Blue Grass State, about eighty miles directly south of Louisville.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- The Times will tomorrow publish a dispatch from Constantinople, dated Nov. 28, saying that the Ministers sent a new report to the palace relative to the guardship matter after Wednesday's council. The first dragoman of the British Embassy was at the palace all night.

Robert Dale of 412 West Seventeenth Street last night threw his one-year-old infant through a fourth-story window and then jumped himself. The baby is not much the worse for the fall. Dale is seriously hurt.
St. Francis Xavier's Church, in West Sixteenth Street, was filled with the friends of Gen. Thomas Jordan yesterday morning, when funeral services were held in his honor.

Among the thousand Princesses who have fallen in love there may have been one who married the man of her affections. But all their hearts beat with precisely the same rhythm as the metronome would have recorded them had the heaving sighs of the ragpicker's daughters been thus scientifically noted.

There are many who hold to the opinion, and this is the time of year in which they voice it most enthusiastically, that this country would do a wise and patriotic thing if it would remove the bald headed eagle from his present perch as the National bird, and install in his place the canvas-back duck, the noblest and best not only of the fowls of the air, but of the water as well.
E.E. McCall and Leopold Wallach, attorneys for J.B. Skehan Co., issued a statement yesterday afternoon concerning the affairs of Skehan Bernheim and J.B. Skehan Co., in which they say:

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 29. -- One of the fashionable society events of the season in the Oranges was the large dance given at the Essex Country Club in Hutton Park, West Orange, to-night under the patronage of Mrs. Oliver S. Carter, Mrs. William Barr, Mrs. T.H. Powers Farr, Miss Lillie Page Ely, Mrs. Charles A. Sterling, Mrs. John Pettit, Mrs. Cyrus F. Loutrel, and Mrs. Charles B. Yardley.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 29. -- Joseph Robertson and Ozias McGaha; negroes, who were this morning sentenced to twenty years each for criminal assault, in the Circuit Court, at Lewisburg, were taken from the jail at Fayetteville to-night by 300 men and hanged in the Court House yard.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 29. -- Augusta has originated a plan, to include the whole South, for a Southern Cotton Exposition in Chicago. The purposes of the exposition are to be:

In view of the heavy inroads that have been made recently on Colorado's game supply, an organization has just been formed for the purpose of taking steps for the prevention of these depredations in the future. State Game Warden Land is one of the Directors, and many citizens of the State, who realize the necessity of such an organization at this time, have associated themselves with it.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- John D. Weeks of Pennsylvania, who was Treasurer of the Republican National Committee during the campaign of 1884, declared in an interview to-day that the nomination of Benjamin Harrison for the Presidency would be exceedingly unwise, because "he has for his bitter enemies all the party leaders in Pennsylvania."

Additional interest was added last night to the movement for open Tammany primaries this year by ex-Mayor William R. Grace, who was asked by a reporter for his views on the subject. The ex-Mayor, who has been a leader in so many fights against Tammany, said in reply:

According to Edouard Herve, who is in a position to speak with authority on Turkish affairs, Abdul Harold has made up his mind to strain every nerve to restore order in Armenia and Asia Minor, with his own unaided resources, and has resolved to discard the schemes put forth by England for the pacification of Armenia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- The report of Daniel S. Lamont, Secretary of War, opens with a suggestive tabular statement of insufficient Congressional appropriations. The actual expenditures for the last fiscal year were $52,987,000, and the appropriations were but $43,466,571. The estimates of the department for the next fiscal year amount to $51,945,000, and indicate a probability of a large deficiency next year.

That is an interesting rumor which attributes to the Judges of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court the purpose of induing themselves in gowns upon their first appearance as a tribunal. It appears that a petition has been addressed to the court asking its members to adopt some "distinctive garb," and, of course, the only distinctive garb that an American Judge would think of assuming is a black gown.

The labor of Mr. Scott is that of thrashing out old straw, so far as concerns any practical influence on existing American politics; for reconstruction is happily an accomplished fact, with the sisterhood of States once more complete, and all on an equal footing. But there is an undoubted interest in the question which it is the purpose of his volume to answer.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 29. -- The New-Jersey Women's Suffrage Association held its annual meeting this afternoon and evening in Trinity Church. Mrs. Florence Howe Hall of Plainfield presided, and thirty delegates were in attendance.

ROME, Nov. 29. -- A secret Consistory was held at the Vatican to-day, over which the Pope presided. The session ended at noon, when it was announced that his Holiness was in fair health and had made a speech of some length, eulogizing the new Cardinals whom the Consistory had elevated to the Sacred College.
MUNICH, Nov. 29. -- The correspondent of the Nueste Nachrichten at Constantinople telegraphs a report of an interview had by him with Halil Rifat Pasha, the Turkish Grand Vizier.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- John R. Tanner, who recently resigned the Chairmanship of the Illinois Republican Committee in order to enter the field for the Gubernatorial nomination, left for Washington yesterday.

WELLSBOROUOH, Penn., Nov. 29. -- The County Court here has been occupied all this week with the cast of Mrs. Charlotte Howell, who is charged with the murder of Miss Elizabeth Knapp, at Tioga, last May. Miss Knapp died in mysterious circumstances, and it was suspected she had been poisoned.

LONDON, Nov, 29. -- The Standard will tomorrow publish a dispatch from Rome saying that the Pope was somewhat exhausted toward the end of the Consistory. Dr. Lapponi, his physician, ordered him to take some cordial. The pontiff's spirits were not impaired, and he asked smilingly of Cardinal Rampolla, the Papal Secretary of State: "Who knows who will preside over the next Consistory?"

Our neighbor, The New-York Tribune, remarks, in substance, that if Congress should re-enact the McKinley tariff and if President CLEVELAND should refuse to permit the bill to become a law, "the issue would be one which every voter would readily understand." And our neighbor advises Congress to take such action.

The Kings County Grand Jury, which has been investigating the recent accident on the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge, in which two lives were lost, yesterday made this presentment to Judge Moore in the County Court of Sessions:

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 29. -- One lone hiss from an apparently intoxicated auditor in the Temple Theatre here last night so vexed ex-Gov. "Bob" Taylor of Tennessee that he left the stage in anger, and abruptly closed the odd entertainment which he and his brother, ex-Congressman "Alf" were billed to give.

These sketches are drawn from the history of that famous old Connecticut town, Fairfield. They are bits of a series of lectures delivered before the Daughters of the Revolution living in Fairfield, Southport, and Bridgeport. The author disclaims the title of historian; his purpose has been "simply to etch a series of pictures so that the life of former days may come before the reader with a fair degree of accuracy and suggestiveness."

The opinion expressed by Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst in his Thanksgiving sermon that he hoped the four boys who wrecked the New-York Central mail train a few days ago would be speedily convicted and executed, has aroused some discussion among those who are interested in the case.
The police of Washington read with sorrow the announcement of the death of their good-hearted member, Thomas Holsey. He was taken to the hospital on Oct. 23, suffering from typhoid pneumonia.

ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- The committee of the State Board of Health investigating tuberculosis has submitted a report covering the work of the committee from July 15 to date. In that time it examined 853 head of cattle, finding 298 suffering from tuberculosis. These were killed, and for their killing awards amounting in the aggregate to $6,952 have been made.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 29. -- The Denver Mining Exchange to-day was wild, and all stocks made advances, some rushing up at great advances over Wednesday's quotations. The brokers complained that the upward tendency of cheap stocks was not warranted, and already they predict an early smash.
The Metropolitan Telephone and Telegraph Company have bought, at $116,000, the property at 17 Dey Street. The lot adjoins the company's other property in Cortlandt Street.

In this learned and interesting volume the legends and history of Wales are set forth from the prehistoric advent of the Hu Gadarn to the comparatively modern period of Richard III. A list of nearly seventy works used in its compilation is prefixed, and one of the least of these is Sir Thomas Malory's famous "Morte d'Arthur," yet the careful and readable rearrangement of the original Arthurian legends gives the book its chief charm.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- That politics will cut some figure in connection with the organization of the House was made clear to the loungers in the Arlington lobby to-night when Field Marshal "Lou" Payn of Chatham marched in and placed his name upon the register. The Field Marshal never comes to Washington on pleasure.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- The correspondent of The United Press at Constantinople telegraphs under date of Nov. 28 that the Turkish troops en route to Zeitun have arrived at Marash, where they have halted pending the result of negotiations with the Armenians, who are in possession of Zeitun. The conditions offered to the Armenians include the surrender of their arms, as well as the leaders of the recent revolt at Zeitun, to the Turkish troops.

United States Senator KNUTE NELSON of Minnesota says, in an interview in Chicago, that his State proposes to take an active part in the competition for the Republican nomination for the Presidency. Its candidate will be Mr. CUSHMAN K. DAVIS, and we are bound to say that he has some qualifications for both nomination and election that the other competitors would find it difficult to match.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 29. -- It was learned to-day that Edgar N. Wilson, attorney for C.A. Whelan Co., in their suit against the American Tobacco Company, has been retained in the interest of a number of grocers to bring proceedings against the American Sugar Refining Company for the annulment of the certificate under which that concern does business in this State.

The old complaint about the accumulation of untried excise cases continues and is regarded as so serious that a Grand Jury has made a presentment on the subject. It is treated as an abuse in the administration of justice calling for a remedy by legislation, but the legislation recommended does not strike us as of the kind that should be sought.

Leopold Levy, a bookkeeper, who lived at 1,670 Lexington Avenue, and was Secretary of King David's Lodge, No. 26, United Order Friendly Sons of Israel, committed suicide yesterday in Crook's Hotel, 114 Park Row, by hanging himself. He had written to a friend announcing his intention, and this letter was the means of Levy's death being discovered.

The code of rules prepared by the Justices of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court for the regulation of Trial and Special Terms of the Supreme Court were filed yesterday with the County Clerk. The order and rules follow:
The Metropolitan Telephone and Telegraph Company have bought, at $116,000, the property at 17 Dey Street. The lot adjoins the company's other property in Cortlandt Street.

ROSLYN, L.I., Nov. 30. -- Just as it was when the poet knew it, the home of William Cullen Bryant still stands on the Roslyn hillside. It was here that the inspiration for many of his sweetest poems was derived, and where the poet himself passed the latter days of his life. The spot and surroundings well exemplify Bryant's love of nature, for

HAVANA, Nov. 30. -- The Spanish columns commanded by Gens: Luque and Oliver recently met the force under Maximo Gomez and drove the rebels into Camaguey. Gomez intended to invade The Villa again, but was defeated and pursued to Ciego de Avila.

As a piece of book manufacture, paper, type, and binding being considered, the new Riverside Edition of the works of John Burroughs (Houghton, Mifflin Co.)must be said to be in its way absolutely perfect. The greatest pains were taken to arrive at such excellence. Mr. Burroughs has, in most cases, selected his illustrations, and the etchings are careful studies.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- As the Emperor is scheduled to go to Breslau Monday to take part in the fete of the First Regiment of Silesian Cuirassiers and Tuesday to preside at the banquet of the Hussars at Oblau on the occasion of the anniversary of the batle of Orleans, his absence from Berlin at the time of the opening of the new session of the Reichstag is variously commented upon.
It was asked long ago: "What becomes of all the pins?"

Charles F. Browne, whose, drollery wafted his pseudonym as far as the English speech could carry laughter, was a Westernized Yankee. He added an Ohio habit of talking tc the Iaine habit of thinking, and he so became a literary product of a rarer aud stranger sort than our literature has othervis known.

NYACK-ON-HUDSON, Nov. 30. -- The 135-foot steam yacht which Messrs. C.L. Seabury . Co. are building, will be called Hiawatha. The yacht is in frame. Her triple-expansion engine and Seabury boiler are progressing nicely, and the joiner work is also being gotten out. The yacht shows up well, and there is not the slightest doubt but what she will be a beauty.

There have been stories upon stories written about the new woman, but this one from Pierce County, down on the Okefinokee Swamp, introduces a new phase of woman's achievement. Miss Lydia E. Smith, the heroine of this story, resides at Fort Mudge, on the Waycross Short Line to Jacksonville.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 30. -- Principal among the social festivities in Bayonne during the week was the annual masquerade ball Thanksgiving Eve, given by the Association of Exempt Volunteer Firemen, numbering 200 members. Several hundred guests of the honorably discharged firemen were hospitably entertained in the new Bayonne Rowing Association Hall, on New-York Bay shore.

At the Franklin Institute Friday evening Mr. James Christie delivered a lecture on "Structural Steel." He defined steel as an alloy of iron, with a small percentage of sundry constituents and products by fusion. Wrought iron is produced by agglutination, and has a less proportion or entire absence of the principal constituents of steel.

It is practically settled that there will be open Tammany primaries this year. The leaders are crowding each other in their desire to come out for them, in view of what Mr. Croker and others have said on the subject. When the Tammany Executive Committee meets to call the primaries, which will be held the last week in December, it will decide on the number of hours the primary polls shall be open.

The American Line steamship New-York arrived yesterday from Southampton. She made the voyage of 3,050 knots in 6 days 20 hours and 46 minutes, which is remarkably good time for this season of the year.

The alert mind of the modern drug manufacturer has not failed to take note of the extraordinary interest and widespread indulgence in athletics and sports of every kind. The bicycle, field and track athletics, football, golf -- all these things have increased enormously the number of contests in which the person who has the greatest physical vigor and endurance wins.

The coming season promises to be one of much activity with the German and Hebrew clubs of the city, and even at this early date there is unusual life displayed at the quarters of these organizations. While many of them have commenced their regular Winter entertainments, the season cannot yet be declared in full swing.

Not only is Japan now manufacturing many things which it used to buy from Europe, but, having satisfied its own requirements, is beginning to export. Five years ago there was a great trade in matches to the East. Not only does Japan now supply herself and supply China, but she supplies the Straits Settlements and India, and sends large quantities even to Australia.

Senator RAINES threatens to introduce a bill at the coming session of the Legislature abolishing local Boards of Excise and concentrating all functions connected with a regulation of the liquor traffic in three or more State officers, to be appointed by the Governor. He proposes to impose a tax upon liquor selling and allow anybody paying the tax to engage in the business, except in towns voting against permitting any sales.

What is spoken of as "one of the cleverest political poems ever composed," has recently come under the notice of a contributor to a northern contemporary. The Dundee Advertiser. It was written by Arthur Connor, (or O'Connor,) the friend of Lord Edward Fitzgerald, and, like him, a prominent figure in the Irish rebellion of 1798.

When Purcell was born the great Oliver was still alive, but he was breaking fast, and only survived a few months, and by the time Purcell was old enough to feel artistic influences Charles II, was in gay possession of the country, and was very busy encouraging music to adapt itself to his peculiar tastes.

New editions of Mr. Hamerton's well-known books, handsomely gotten up in convenient library form, will doubtless be welcome to many, and they will continue on in their inexplicable popularity. Mr. Hamerton writes readable English, and runs along with no little charm of manner. As to the critical value of his efforts, that, as Mr. Kipling would say, is another story.

In his study of the recent recrudescence of superstition, Prof. E.P. Evans, in Appletons' Popular Scienec Monthly, cites the "Spring procession," or procession of jumpers, which takes place at Echternach, in Luxembourg, some time after Whitsunday, and is regarded by its votaries as a sure cure for epilepsy, St. Vitus's dance, syntexis, (wasting away from consumption,) murrain, and other maladies of men and cattle.

The English stage has certain customs which greatly hurt a Frenchman who is not used to them. The last scene of every act is constantly interrupted, and sometimes in the most interesting part, by the tinkling of a little bell, which apprises the music to be ready to play in the interval between the acts.

Mr. Smith follows the traditional custom of fruit dealers in putting his largest, ripest, and juciest plums on the top of his basket. And whatever the reader may think of the somewhat insipid flavor of "The Knight of the Legion of Honor" on the suggestion of over-ripeness conveyed by "The Lady of Lucerne," there is no denying that the Gentleman Vagabond is a most delicious morsel.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- That the Sultan would be allowed to stand out for twelve days against a demand by the united European powers for something clearly within their treaty rights, if those powers were honestly united, could not be credited by even the fabled horse marine.

TRENTON, Nov. 30. -- The preparations for the inauguration of Governor-elect John W. Griggs are far from completed. Those who have taken the responsibility to arrange the preliminaries find themselves somewhat embarrassed by the fact that they can get no definite expression from the Governor-elect as to what will be acceptable to him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Society has come to life again. You can feel the bustle and stir in every phase of fashionable endeavor, and especially when you begin to count the invitations that are flying about. Naturally the pacemakers are a little cautious yet, and an easy gait, suitable for beginners, or for those who have grown a bit stiff from too much leisure, is the proper thing.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Nov. 30. -- Full of poetry and philosophy is James Budd, an old gravedigger residing here. And no wonder, for his life has been spent amid death. His trusty spade has turned the sod and shaped the last earthly temple of nearly 4,000 fellow-beings. The dead have been his constant associates, and he has spent most of his life in God's Acre.

In the South most of the servants were negroes. Among ours was a little mulatto girl, ("nut-brown maid," she called herself,) whose chief attraction to me was her enthusiasm for the theatre. One night in desperation I went to her while she was washing dishes in the kitchen, and there unfolded all my hopes. It was to her I first acted, and it was she who gave me my first applause.

The houses are mainly broad and low, three-story buildings being rare, and one-story structures quite common. You notice that everything is made to serve comfort and coolness. Instead of having panes of glass, the windows are open and guarded by light iron railings, and the heavy wooden doors are left ajar.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- Herman W. Mudgett, alias H.H. Holmes, who was convicted of murder in the first degree for having caused the death in this city of Benjamin F. Pietzel, this morning, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, was sentenced to be hanged.
Speaker--THOMAS B. BREED of Maine.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 30. -- The indictment of Col. A.B. Coit of the Fourteenth Regiment, Ohio National Guard, for the alleged murder of several persons who were engaged in an attempt to take a prisoner from the custody of the Sheriff of Fayette County on the afternoon and night of Oct. 18, l894, is without a parallel in the history of National Guard organizations.

It is time that this country was insured and adequately policed. Land fortifications are the insurance of a nation; fleets and armies are its police. It is time, I say, that the proper policing of this country should begin.

An ingenious writer, of active but rather commonplace fancy, has been allowed by one of our American monthlies to contribute to its pages a mass of what, for want of a better name, may be called Trilbyana. Its appearance in a periodical that has done much for the sensible American reader is a matter for unpleased surprise.

Second Lieut. M.F. Smith of the Fourth Cavalry, who accompanied First Lieut. C.L. Potter of the engineers in his late expedition down the Colorado River, is busily engaged on his official report of the undertaking. Although the report is primarily prepared for official eyes, it will be no ordinary compilation of technical information and forbidding statistics.

The recent National Good Roads Parliament at Atlanta should result, sooner or later, in many benefits to cycling. Good roads in a State make wheeling popular and profitable, besides increasing the value of land and acting as a tonic to business generally. The reports at the parliament showed to what extent the different States had progressed in the improvement of highways.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30. -- The California Railroad Commission last September adopted a resolution ordering a reduction in freight rates of about 25 per cent. on all railways operating within the State. The Southern Pacific Railway Company appealed to the United States Court and obtained a temporary injunction restraining the commission from enforcing the proposed reducton, and the case is now pending.

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 30. -- Springlike weather and an unusually attractive programme brought together a large number of the ladies and gentlemen of the Meadowbrook Hunt Club at the cross-country hunt on the Wheatley Hills to-day. The run was the longest that the club has participated in this Fall, and was also one of the most enjoyable and successful of the season.

The Rev. S.P. Hargrave, an Episcopal clergyman of New-Haven, Penn., two weeks ago began to remove to Woodbury, Conn., to which place he had received a call. He started with his wife and eight children from Philadelphia for his new home yesterday.
The first week this month will be a busy one with society people, as the following list of social functions will show:
Minnie Arnett, a cloak model, attempted to commit suicide by shooting herself, in the vestibule of the handsome home of C.F. Winkemeier, at 79 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, a week ago yesterday.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of the city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 30. -- A woman who came to the Kingsley House last night in company with a man who registered her name for her and then left, was found dead in her room at the hotel at 2 o'clock this afternoon with a bullet hole in her head. Her name, as it appears on the hotel register, was Grace M. Hubbard of Albany.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 30. -- The jury in the case of the Hyams brothers this afternoon rendered a verdict of not guilty. The brothers were not allowed to leave the courtroom, but were rearrested on the charge of conspiracy to murder Mrs. Harry Hyams for insurance which had been taken out on her life.
In the last days of imperial Rome all of the highways leading to her were lined with tombs. So, too, on the approach to any old city there may be found the dwelling places of tragedy and of death!
The Reinhard Assembly committee, appointed to investigate the condition of girls and boys working in stores and factories, held another session yesterday in the Aldermanic Chamber, City Hall.

Martha Gordon often read over the letter of secret instruction which had been found addressed to her, and inclosed in her father's will. While never for one instant did she dispute its binding force, she was prone to muse on its philosophy, wondering whether, like her fortune, it might not prove more prolific of evil than good.

Dr. ALBERT SHAW, who has made much study of municipal problems, including that of providing means of transit in the streets of large cities, has been enlightening an Assembly committee on the latter subject in relation to the needs of this city.

It was announced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst that henceforth the City Vigilance League will largely suspend its detective work. The reason given for the change is the increased efficiency of the police. The only branch of the work which it is planned to keep up is on excise cases, and even in this branch, efforts will gradually be stopped.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 30. -- The warfare between the banks and express companies, arising originally out of the demand of the latter for higher rates for the carriage of money packages, on account of the greater risk due to frequent train robberies, has assumed a new and curious phase.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Thirty minutes sufficed to complete the work of the Democratic caucus which was held to-day at 3 o'clock to nominate officers for the offices of Clerk, Doorkeeper, Sergeant at Arms, Postmaster, and Chaplain of the Fifty-fourth Congress. The roll call disclosed the presence of seventy-five members, an unusually large number when the perfunctory character of the proceedings is remembered.

There is no denying the fact that a rival to the National Horse Show has come to town. It has come to stay moreover, for the men who compose the Live Stock Society of America did not merely plan an experimental enterprise when they began their show last week. This exhibit, a "city fair," so to speak, is to be an annual fixture hereafter, and to all appearances its future success is assured.
President Roosevelt of the Police Board talked yesterday to the twenty-two members of the department who have been made Acting Roundsmen. He said to them:
Birmingham has become noted because of its great municipal improvements and the success of all its efforts in this direction.
ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 30. -- The very pretty Japanese tea and bazaar which has been held in the Church of the Sacred Heart, East Orange, this week, were brought to a successful close to-night.

The students of the Metropolitan School of Fine Arts welcomed their friends at the classrooms of the school. In the Carnegie Building, Saturday afternoon, from 4 until 6 o'clock, the fine weather bringing out a large attendance. The studios of the various classes were thrown open, forming one large suite, with ample room for all the guests.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Mr. Kurino, the Japanese Minister, is indignant at the constant reiteration of rumors originating in Hawaii calculated to convey the impression that Japan entertains some hostile purpose against the so-called "Key of the Pacific."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- E.P. Baldwin, Auditor of the Treasury, in his annual report, states that at the end of the fiscal year there was not pending in his office an account that could have been settled, and there was not an item of business that could have been transacted.

Miss Jessie Seymour, twenty-two years old, who lives in Elizabeth, N.J., lies at the home of her aunt, Mrs. Wily, of 1,741 Sedgwick Avenue, High Bridge, in a cataleptic fit, which is puzzling the doctors of Fordham Hospital and the physicians her friends have called in. Miss Seymour came to New-York four days ago to spend Thanksgiving with her aunt. Thanksgiving was celebrated with a dinner and a party, during the afternoon and evening.

" Jack" McAuliffe, the pugilist, visited Police Headquarters, Brooklyn, Thursday night, and asked to see Superintendent McKelvey, but Capt. Henry French was in charge. An introduction followed, and then McAuliffe said:

At Berkeley Oval yesterday afternoon about 3,000 youthful football enthusiasts witnessed the defeat of Trinity School's football eleven by the Berkeley giants in the final game for the championship of the New-York Interscholastic Athletic Association. The score was 38 to 0.

It is remarkable how little the tendency to humor has been developed in the men who have been Presidents of the United States. We do not so much refer to exhibitions of humor in office; that, of course, is not to be expected. He must be bubbling over with a sense of humor as was our single humorist, President Abraham Lincoln, who could give it vent under such conditions.

A distinguished lady who has the entree to the harem assures me that its present inmates dress more or less in European fashion, but almost invariably in the costliest conceivable tea gowns from Paris and Vienna. They wear magnificent diamonds and other jewels, and appear to lead a very happy life.

The grand procession of the leaves has about whirled itself away, and, clear cut against the sky, we now see the naked branches stripped for their long Winter's fight with old Boreas. What a fairylike picture they present, when, after a rain followed by frost, they show tracings as though made of the most delicate lace, and how they sparkle and crackle under the sun's rays!

Companies I and K of the Seventh Regiment have football teams, and ever since the football season opened there has been bitter rivalry between the two companies. Finally a game was talked about, and yesterday the two teams met on Manhattan Field. Company K proved to be the best team, and won the match by a score of 4 to 0.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30. -- Theodore Durrant is said to be a plagiarist. Soon after he had been sentenced, he said he had written a poem.

BUFFALO, Nov. 30. -- As a result of a renewal of negotiations with the Lehigh Valley Railroad, an arrangement has_ been agreed upon under which the company will take possession of the Iiddlesex Valley Railroad, running from Geneva, where it connects with the Lehigh Valley, westward to Naples.

Does any one of my readers know where a tinderbox can be seen, or has one of them any idea what it is like? Fortunately, I came upon a description of it in the recently published account of the lifetime of John Hollingshead. "The tinderbox was the toy of my childhood." It was certainly not a "toy" in my time; it was very much the reverse -- an absolute necessity.

POMONA, Cal., Nov. 30. -- An expedition of scientific students has been made up, in Los Angeles and Pomona Valley, to explore thoroughly the Channel Islands, off the coast of that part of California, during the next six months, in the interests of archaeology. The party is to be sustained by Leland Stanford Junior University and Harvard University.

Two representative druggists yesterday replied to the strictures passed on their methods of doing business by patent medicine manufacturers. Both say it is not in the interests of trade or of the public good that the sale of patent medicines should be restricted to drug stores, or that any price limit should be fixed by arrangement between the producer and the retailer.

Great men have their peculiarities -- usually accepted as the eccentricities and weaknesses inseparable from genius. One of these peculiarities is the fondness which many of the great men have for kissing. Recently a dispatch in the daily press announced the fact that Prince Bismarck was enjoying himself at Kissingen, adding that he had kissed a young lady.

Alexandre Dumas had bought recently at Marly the Chateau de Champflour, which is as pretty as its name. Even his neighbor, Sardou; even his intimate friends, the wealthiest bankers of the Rothschild, Lippmann, and Ephrussi circles in the Tout-Paris, had not the time to become well acquainted with Champflour.

GLASGOW, Nov. 23. -- Lord Dunraven is once more to the front with a proposal to return to New-York to discuss the difficulties which were the outcome of the cup matches. That he will do so is doubtful. The reckless charges he has made against the Defender syndicate forbids further altercations, unless he is prepared to withdraw every word he has written, and this he cannot be expected to do.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30. -- Ex-Gov. Campbell of Ohio, who arrived here this morning, said, for publication:

The early naturalists could not afford to disregard stories derived from native sources, but they gave them with too little qualification. Herodotus gave currency to animal "myths," some of which have been shown to be based on fact, while others seem a priori impossible. The story of the pygmy race in Africa, and of the pygmies fighting the cranes, (Bushmen and ostriches,) is always quoted to his credit.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 30. -- The situation here shows very little change. The Cabinets of the powers have not yet reached a decision as to what action they shall take in regard to the refusal of the Porte to issue firmans permitting the doubling of the foreign guardships in the Bosphorus.

PORT RICHMOND, S.I., Nov. 30. -- Mrs. Annie Heffren, wife of Michael Heffren, a farmer on the Crocheron place at New-Springville, died this morning after drinking carbolic acid given to her in a milk-punch by mistake.

The one hundred and thirty-ninth annual banquet of the St. Andrew's Society was held at Delmonico's last night, and was attended by nearly 300 members of the society and their guests. The banquet hall was handsomely decorated with bunting. The American flag and the union jack of England were conspicuous.
